HEADLINE: Chase's Share Price Is Lowest in 12 Years

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The share price of the Chase Manhattan Corportion closed at a 12-year low yesterday, and interest rates on its long-term debt rose - a result of the banking company's weak earnings and unconfirmed rumors of its difficulties in borrowing money, analysts said.
''There are a lot of negative stories converging about Chase,'' said Ann Robinson, an analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. She said Chase's fundamental problem of a rising level of delinquent loans had been made ''more scary'' by the rumors about its borrowing difficulties. 
''It's clear there are worries in the marketplace about liquidity and funding the company,'' said Arthur Sotor, a banking analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company.
The share price of the nation's second-largest banking company ended the day at $13.875, down $1.1254 for the day and $3.25 for the last week. Like most other banking companies, Chase has had weak stock for nearly a year. In early October 1989, after its stock traded as high as $44.875, it issued more than 16 million new shares at a price of $40.125 a share.
At yesterday's closing price, Chase stock yielded about 17.9 percent, assuming that it continues to pay a 62-cent quarterly dividend. Many investors and analysts doubt that Chase can maintain the high yield of the dividend despite promises by its executives. Chase officials note the dividend can be paid from earnings of its highly profitable credit card banking operation in Delaware, even if Chase Manhattan Bank in New York is hard pressed to make large dividend payments to the holding corporation, which then makes payments to shareholders.
In the bond market there were several signs that investors were reluctant buyers of Chase issues. An issue of 10 percent Chase notes due in 1999, for example, was traded yesterday with a yield of 13.35, or 4.45 percentage points more than Treasury notes, up from 12.90 percent a day earlier. Among other New York banking companies with similar notes, a Chemical Banking Corporation issue was quoted at about 14 percent, while a Citicorp issue was at about 11 percent.
In the private placement market, no agreement has yet been reached with Japanese investors on a $100 million issue of long-term debt that officials at First Boston proposed to Chase several weeks ago. One banker close to the deal said, however, ''It is still very much alive.''
Elsewhere in the bond market, a Chase issue that sold last week with a two-year yield of 13.01 percent has increased in price to about 100 1/2, to yield 12.71 percent. An official at Salomon Brothers, which bought most of the note issue, said that, contrary to market rumors, the Federal Reserve did not put any pressure on the firm to buy the issue.
In the short-term markets, where Chase is a heavy borrower despite cutbacks over the last few years, Steve Rautenberg, a spokesman for Chase, said yesterday that ''our entire funding operation is operating normally, including the interest rates we are paying.'' A similar statement was issued by Chase officials on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Fund Yields Stay Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, underlining the lack of clear direction that has enveloped the market for nearly two months.
''The money markets remain listless as they await the Federal Reserve Bank to take some action, which is not likely to happen anytime before a budget compromise is achieved in Washington.'' Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, said, Therefore, he added, the money market yields are expected to continue in a very narrow range. 
Managers of tax-exempt money market funds increased the average number of days that securities are held in portfolios by one day, to 59. Many analysts said the level was still high, and the reason might be that managers were still taking advantage of the high rates available, maximizing their investments while awaiting an expected decline.
 
Tax-Exempt Assets Fall
Assets fell by $308 million, to total $80.9 billion, as the average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield increased by 2 basis points, to 5.56 percent for the week, and the 30-day average yield rose by 7 basis points -or hundredths of a percentage point - to 5.46 percent. Analysts said the rise in yields might have been caused by a large supply of new issues and fewer buyers.
For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket, the equivalent taxable seven-day compounded yield is 7.72 percent, and for investors in the 33 percent bracket, it is 8.29 percent.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of better than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the USAA Tax Exempt Money Market fund produced the best return. The compunded average yield is 6.30 percent, or about 74 basis points better than the average. The fund is distributed by the USAA Investment Management Company of San Antonio.
Assets of taxable funds, meanwhile, increased by $2.1 billion, to a record $402 billion, with assets of institutional funds up $600 million, to $84.8 billion, and consumer funds assets up $1.5 billion, to $317.2 billion.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios decreased by one, to 46.
Donoghue's said the seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund was off by a basis point, to 7.74 percent, the same as the 30-day average yield, which slipped to 7.75 percent.
Of the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million, Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market fund had the best return for the fourth straight week. The yield was 8.58 percent, down slightly from 8.59 percent the previous week.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 13.86 in Another Lackluster Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Wall Street suffered through another day of the blahs yesterday, with stocks down only slightly despite several fairly strong declines.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 13.86, to 2,557.43, bringing the relentless slide in the Dow to 442 points - or nearly 15 percent - since mid-July.
Stock market activity picked up a bit more, climbing to 147.5 million shares from 141.1 million the day before.
But 883 stocks fell and 130 hit new lows - including Sears, Roebuck and Dayton Hudson - while 599 rose and 18 hit new highs. 
Traders attributed yesterday's somewhat stronger volume to activity in advance of the ''triple witching hour'' tomorrow, when Standard & Poor's futures, stock options and index options expire.
The event coincides with the Jewish New Year today and tomorrow, when many traders take off either or both days, often raising volume in advance of the holiday and increasing market volatility during the holiday sessions.
While I.B.M. rose an encouraging 1 1/8, to 108 3/8, Merck, one of the Big Board's most popular drug stocks, slumped 3 1/8, to 76 7/8, after Patricia Lee of Vector Securities questioned its prostate drug, Proscar. It was the third-most-active Big Board stock, with nearly 3 million shares changing hands.
American General, the Texas insurance giant, plunged 6 3/8 in heavy trading to 33 5/8, after saying it was less likely to sell the company.
General Electric topped the Big Board active list, falling 2 1/2, to 56 1/8 -a new low - on three million shares.
Traders said Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a newsletter, said G.E. and General Electric Credit might be vulnerable because of their heavy loans for real estate and leveraged buyouts.
''In a nervous market, people are looking for any excuse to sell,'' one trader remarked.
Even so, Hugh Johnson, chief strategist for the First Albany Corporation, a brokerage house based in Albany, described the market as ''friendless, trendless, directionless, featureless and stuck.''
He argued that investors were ''still gun-shy - very comfortable with substantial cash positions - sitting this one out.''
''There isn't any event, or expectation of any,'' he said, ''that'll stir a sense of urgency to move investors off the fence.''
Testifying before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress yesterday, Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Board chairman, gave investors no reason to believe interest rates might be heading down. He remarked, ''The oil shock has clearly increased both the probability of inflation and recession.'' While nothing new, the chairman's remarks helped raise investor frustrations, one trader said.
Moreover, Mr. Johnson argued, at this point even an interest-rate reduction might not be enough to lift the stock market.
''Even if we get an agreement on the 1991 budget deficit - which we should get,'' he said, ''and that's followed by a reduction in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve, very few investors believe it will stir any sustainable move up in stock prices.''
''As long as the Middle East crisis hangs over the market,'' he said, ''the focus remains on the Middle East. It's raised the risk of investing a decibel or two by injecting uncertainty into any forecast of inflation and interest rates or the economy and earnings.''
Among the strong moves, Ralston Purina rose 2 7/8, to 100, after John M. McMillan, food analyst for Prudential-Bache, said it would ''keep outperforming the market.'' Quaker Oats rose 2 3/8, to 45 5/8.
American Stores fell 1 3/8, to 64, after saying it would explore the sale of Acme Markets and use the money to cut debt. UAL fell 5, to 100, amid interminable doubt that its unions will find financing for a buyout.
Occidental Petroleum slid 1 3/8, to 21 3/8, in heavy trading after The Wall Street Journal raised doubts about its dividend. The oil producer said it remained ''committed'' to the $2.50-a-year dividend.
Disney fell 3 3/4, to 90 3/8, after a new low of 90 1/4. David Londoner of Wertheim & Company cut his earnings estimate in the wake of concern over theme-park attendance but continues to recommend the stock.
 
Nikkei Index Off Again
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -Tokyo stocks fell again today after closing Wednesday at a low for 1990. The benchmark Nikkei 225-share index closed today down 123.19 points, to 23,602.98, after slumping 158.65 on Wednesday in thin volume. Banking issues and high-technology blue chips led declines. ''Where's the bottom?'' Masahiko Tsuyuzaki, chief trader at Tachibana Securities, asked rhetorically. ''Right now the market consensus is that the Nikkei will fall to 21,000. But some people are saying it may fall as low as 18,000 or 15,000.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in fairly active trading yesterday, as market participants reacted to comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, by selling short-term notes and buying long-term bonds.
In testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that the continuing crisis in the Persian Gulf could further weaken the economy, but added that he saw no signs suggesting a recession was imminent.
More significant to credit market participants were comments from the Fed chairman that strongly suggested that inflation was a more important byproduct of the Middle East situation than recession. And Mr. Greenspan's comments suggested once again that the Fed would not be prone to ease credit until Congress passed a credible budget package. 
''The fact that Greenspan was talking about inflation rather than recession was good news for bonds,'' one trader said, ''because it reinforces the notion that the Fed is being vigilant as an inflation fighter.''
Robert Dederick, executive vice president and chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said: ''Mr. Greenspan now seems to be more willing to run the risk of recession than before. The message that comes through here is that if there is a recession, so be it.''
 
Survey of Economic Conditions
To traders, Mr. Greenspan's comments outweighed in importance the release of the Fed's ''beige book,'' a survey of economic conditions prepared by regional Federal Reserve banks, as well as weak figures for August housing starts, which provided further evidence the housing industry is in recession.
The Fed survey, which covered a six-week period ending in early September, characterized the economy as either ''expanding slowly or declining in most areas.'' In the Northeastern and Mid-Atlantic regions, weakness was most apparent, the report said.
''If it weren't for the Middle East, the beige book and the housing starts numbers would be met with all kinds of calls for a further easing in Fed policy,'' said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. ''But the Fed is sitting there bound and gagged.''
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020, which have sagged in price recently, were offered at 97 11/32, up 18/32, to yield 9.00 percent, compared with 9.05 percent late Tuesday.
The Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes also benefited from Mr. Greenspan's remarks about inflation, and by late yesterday were offered at a price of 99 1/4, up 5/32, to yield 8.86 percent.
The Treasury announced late in the afternoon that it will auction $11.5 billion worth of two-year notes on Sept. 25, and $8.25 billion of four-year notes on Sept. 26.
In when-issued trading after the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.04 percent. The four-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.39 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to up slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.36 percent, unchanged from late Tuesday. Six-month bill rates rose by two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to a late offered rate of 7.29 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, two foreign governments priced issues.
 
Province of Manitoba Debentures
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for an offering of $350 million worth of 10-year debentures for the Province of Manitoba.
The 9 1/2 percent securities, which mature Oct. 1, 2000, were priced at $99.733, to yield 9.542 percent, 65 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities are noncallable for life.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
That issue was followed by the Government of Malaysia, which priced a $200 million 10-year note offering through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 7/8 percent notes, which are noncallable for life, mature Sept. 27, 2000. They were priced at $99.00 to yield 10.036 percent, 1.15 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 8 3/4 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mostly Higher in U.S. After Sharp Jump in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly higher in United States trading yesterday after surging in Europe as currency markets drew encouragement from comments by the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, who seemed to suggest that interest rates were not likely to be cut soon.
Gold prices declined worldwide. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $386 an ounce, down $1.60 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank later quoted gold at $385.60, off $2.50. 
Speaking before a Congressional committee, Mr. Greenspan said the nation was not in a recession, although events in the Persian Gulf were putting new and substantial pressures on the economy.
The dollar has been losing ground in recent weeks amid speculation that the Fed would ease interest rates to stimulate the sluggish economy. When rates move down, the nation's securities become less attractive to foreigners, thereby diminishing investors' appetite for dollars.
 
A Favorable Reaction
The initial reaction among currency market participants to Mr. Greenspan's comments ''was favorable because it seemed to downplay the likelihood of a near-term easing,'' said Marc Chandler, senior strategist at the consulting firm IDEA.
 
Pound Declines
The dollar gained sharply yesterday at the expense of the British pound, which fell after the president of the West German Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, hinted that Britain might not join the Exchange Rate Mechanism, or E.R.M., as expected. The E.R.M. is built into the European Monetary System and limits the fluctuations of 9 of the European Community's 12 currencies. It is expected that the pound will strengthen if Britain joins the mechanism.
In London, the pound fell to $1.8855, from $1.9190 late Tuesday. In New York it dropped to $1.8833, from $1.9140 on Tuesday.
The dollar also jumped against the German currency, ending the day at 1.5730 marks, up from 1.5525 the day before.
Against the yen, however, the dollar fell slightly in New York trading, closing at 137.68 yen, down from 137.75 on Tuesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar had closed at 138.05 yen, up 0.37 yen from Tuesday. Later in London, it was quoted at 137.55 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, were: 1.3105 Swiss francs, up from 1.2900; 5.2670 French francs, up from 5.1995; 1,175.00 Italian lire, up from 1,162.50, and 1.1563 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1590.
Gold fell in London to $386.75 an ounce, from $388.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to $385.50, from $387.80 late Tuesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold dropped $4.50, to $385.35.
Silver prices were little changed. On the Comex in New York, silver closed at $4.769 an ounce, down from Tuesday's $4.790. In London, silver bullion was trading at a late bid price of $4.82, unchanged from Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Jordanians Meet Frustration In Search for 'Arab Solution'

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Sept. 20

 BODY:
As Iraqi troops were storming toward Kuwait City on Aug. 2, King Hussein of Jordan was awakened at 6 A.M. by a phone call from King Fahd of Saudi Arabia.
''Have you heard?'' King Fahd asked the sleepy Jordanian King. ''The Iraqis are within a few kilometers of Kuwait City. Can you ask them to withdraw to the disputed area'' on the Iraq-Kuwait border?
Crown Prince Hassan, brother of the Jordanian King, gave this account of the events during a long breakfast interview at his palace this morning, adding that King Hussein had quickly called Baghdad and reached the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz. Later that day, Prince Hassan said, the King spoke to Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi President, and pressed King Fahd's case. 
And so, the Prince said, with those calls in the early hours, the elusive and so far futile search for an ''Arab solution'' to the gulf conflict began.
For the last six weeks, King Hussein has been shuttling among Baghdad, Rabat, Cairo and other capitals in the Arab world, the United States and Europe - trying, Jordanians say, to be an honest mediator. But now Prince Hassan and other Jordanians candidly acknowledge that King Hussein has nothing to show for his efforts - no progress to report, not even a clear plan to offer. [In Washington, Administration officials said the United States opposed King Hussein's current peacemaking attempt. As they spoke, Arab oil industry executives said Saudi Arabia had stopped its oil deliveries to Jordan, which have long constituted about half of Jordan's daily consumption of oil. Pages A8 and A9.] If there has been movement toward a solution to the crisis, ''I don't have knowledge of it,'' Prince Hassan said.
A senior Jordanian official acknowledged: ''I don't think we have a coherent ready-made recipe. I don't even think that is possible in this situation.''
The King's efforts might have succeeded in the first days, the Prince and many others here assert, had not the United States and others quickly decided to send in military forces.
But Jordan can point to no tangible progress, and some foreign diplomats say they have concluded that the King's travels are really just to show the audience at home that he is active, concerned and involved, despite denials from the Royal Palace that this is his motivation.
Prince Hassan acknowledged that officials in Washington, suspicious of Jordan's activities with Iraq, were saying that ''we are just playing for time, or trying to play out the Iraqi tactic of just gaining time.'' The Prince shook his head.
''But if you say the Arab solution is dead,'' he added, ''I say in the first weekend an Arab solution was offered and undercut'' by the United States.
 
Economy on Verge of Collapse
While King Hussein has continued his quest for the Arab solution, his country has fallen deeper and deeper into trouble. Jordanian officials say that is one reason the King has tried to mediate in the crisis.
By all accounts, the nation's economy is on the verge of collapse as a result of Jordan's decision to comply with the United Nations sanctions against Iraq. ''We are teetering on the edge of that,'' the Prince said.
And because of the widespread perception that Jordan supports Iraq, the country has few places to turn for help. Iraq and Kuwait, long Jordan's patrons and largest trading partners, are in no position to help now. Several other Arab countries that had been friendly are expelling Jordanian residents.
The Prince also said Saudi Arabia, Jordan's third-largest trading partner, was no longer willing to buy most Jordanian products.
Other countries are so suspicious of Jordan's motives, he added, that they have even been reluctant to offer aid for the thousands of refugees pouring over the border from Iraq.
Looking west for help, the Prince acknowledges, is not such a bright prospect just now either. The United States Congress is openly angry at the King, and the Prince and other Government officials accuse the Bush Administration of harboring secret designs to take control of the Arab world's oil.
''I think the Americans are thinking, 'Let's deal with the present brush fire, but while here, let's stick it out for keeps,' '' the Prince said. ''That doesn't mean American troops won't be seen withdrawing. It can be done more subtly.''
Prime Minister Mudar Badran went further and suggested that American companies had helped engineer the gulf conflict to create a new market for American-manufactured arms.
''When the military industry of the West realized that the end of the cold war would stave off wars, there was a need to think of ways and areas for marketing the weapons,'' he said in a newspaper interview on Wednesday.
 
Messages to Washington
Despite all that, Prince Hassan said he and his brother were trying to show Washington that Jordan was still an ally. King Hussein has written a letter to be delivered to every member of the Senate and the House on Friday, presenting Jordan's case. Prince Hassan, an articulate, Oxford-educated 43-year-old, is planning a trip next week to Washington, where he wants to testify before a Congressional committee.
''You can envy me that task,'' he said with a wry smile. ''The assumption is they will fry me alive.''
As all this goes on, King Hussein returned this evening from another diplomatic mission, this time in Rabat, Morocco, where he discussed the gulf crisis with the leaders of Morocco and Algeria - trying again, his brother said, to find a formula. The Algerian radio reported this evening that the King would leave shortly for Baghdad for another set of talks with President Hussein. A palace official said there was a chance that King Fahd would join them there, but Saudi officials dismissed that idea.
King Hussein was last in Baghdad two weeks ago. After the visit ended, neither the King nor the Iraqi leader said a word about their meetings. But today Prince Hassan acknowledged that the talks had been a failure.
''I'm afraid that is the case,'' he said. ''That is why he is making this last attempt with other Arab countries.''
''Maybe it is'' grasping at straws, the Prince added. ''But at least it is an attempt to see if anything is possible.'' And if it is not, he said, ''I think we are closer to war than ever before, because nothing is being offered but sign language.''
If war comes, he said, it will be largely because every Arab attempt to resolve the crisis has been thwarted by American intransigence and ignorance of the Arab world.
''The basic problem is outsiders looking into the area without any understanding of the perceptions in the area,'' he said. ''They should know that the problem with the Iraqis is that every time something happens to pressure them, they become more adamant on the question of withdrawal.''
 
'The Americans Knock It Down'
Still, he said, ''every time a group of leaders say they have a package, the first thing that happens is that the Americans knock it down by beginning with the assumption that nothing short of complete Iraqi withdrawal is acceptable.''
He added, ''To be symmetrical, the Iraqis have not been too forthcoming either.''
But the Americans concern the Prince the most. ''It has a lot to do with the cold war ending,'' he said, ''and this development of what the American are calling this 'new world order.'
''On an entire world scale, it seems you are now gaining brownie points for being anti- or pro-American.''
In that environment, he added, ''there is a sense that we are being punished as wogs who don't know our place and have stepped beyond our bounds.''
The Prince says he suspects he knows how he and his brother can redeem themselves in the eyes of Washington. But he cannot do it, and does not want to.
''Jordan is abiding by all the items of the U.N.,'' he said. ''We are not playing the American role, but we are not playing the Iraqi role either. I don't know what more we are meant to say. What are the magic words? Are we meant to be pejorative about Saddam Hussein? It would be tantamount to making a U-turn, which we are not prepared to do, and I don't think anyone should be expected to do so.''

HEADLINE: The Job Is Picking Up Garbage; 100,000 Want It

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
Frank Moos, who was laid off a year ago by a Wall Street brokerage house, postponed his honeymoon for a week just so he can take a written exam tomorrow for a city job. The job is picking up garbage.
Mr. Moos is one of more than 101,000 people scheduled to take the test for 2,000 jobs that are expected to be open in the New York City Department of Sanitation over the next four years -the largest number of applications on record for any Civil Service test.
When only about half that number are taking the Civil Service exam to become firefighters and a fifth to become police officers, such a turnout is striking. City officials say it is a testament to the times, when a job that pays well, offers security and does not require a high school diploma has mass appeal. 
''I want job stability,'' said Mr. Moos, 30 years old, of Ridgewood, Queens, who was laid off from his $26,000-a-year job as a clerk in the reorganization department of Drexel Burnham Lambert in September 1989 after six years. He found work only last month as a delivery man for a florist.
His motive was echoed by many others who signed up to take the test, including several college students, one of whom is studying to be a psychiatrist; a food preparer in an airport restaurant; an insurance claims adjuster, and a special-education teacher in the Bronx, who explained, ''I would get more money as a sanitation worker than as a teacher.''
Mr. Moos (pronounced mose) said he had become disillusioned with the uncertainty of Wall Street.
''I decided not to go back on the Street again because, first, there were few jobs, and two, I was disgusted,'' he said. ''Nothing was safe in that type of industry. You could be there one day and gone the next. So I decided to take all the city tests.''
So far, he has passed tests for police officer and correction officer. He said he is waiting to see if he is offered a job and will take the court officer's exam in November.
Another applicant, Robert Bimonte, 19, who lives in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, is studying psychology at John Jay College and is interested in becoming a psychiatrist.
But he said if he was offered a job, he would probably become a sanitation worker because of the ''good security.''
For Mr. Bimonte, the Sanitation Department is like family: his father is an assistant chief and his mother works as a clerk there. ''I've seen how the department has taken care of me and my family,'' he said.
 
Work as Aide
Michael Calabria, 20, of Richmond Hill, Queens, a police science major at John Jay, said hauling garbage is not so glamorous as being a police officer, but it pays well and is much safer.
And as a college aide for the Sanitation Department over the summer, he said, he learned that sanitation ''is much more than just picking up garbage.'' The department's starting pay is $23,000 a year, and the salary rises to $35,000 after five years, said a spokesman for the Department of Sanitation, Vito Turso.
By comparison, police officers and firefighters are paid $25,977 to start, moving to $31,575 after five years, said a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Personnel, Denise Collins. At six years and above, the police and fire salary is $38,914.
The applicants for the Sanitation Department paid $15 to take the test. They will gather at 26 schools throughout the city at three separate sessions. #2d Test Since 70's Of those who pass, only 15,000 will be chosen at random by a computer to take the more rigorous physical test. The last hurdle is a medical exam. Mrs. Collins said that when the test was last given, in 1983 as the city emerged from its financial crisis, there were 88,000 applications. The test before that had been in 1974, before the city's fiscal crisis.
By comparison, the last exam for police officer in June attracted 26,258 applicants. The police exam is given each year and averages about 20,000 applicants. The largest number of applicants recently was 40,000 in 1982. The Fire Department exam, given every four years, drew 45,405 applicants in 1987.
Last Saturday, Mr. Moos and his wife, the former Laura Ann Donohue, were married in Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Jackson Heights, Queens, but changed their plans when they learned that the sanitation test fell this Saturday, ''We postponed the honeymoon,'' he said. ''She didn't mind at all. She knew I had to take this test.'' 'A Better Deal'
Clifford Josey, 24, of Long Island City, Queens, has been working as a claims adjuster for an insurance company since graduation from Forest Hills High School in 1985 but would become a sanitation worker partly for ''better benefits'' and better pay.
Another applicant taking the test was a 28-year-old man working at a restaurant at La Guardia Airport who asked that his name be withheld so that his employer does not find out he is looking for another job. ''Prices going up the way they are, it's almost impossible to make a decent living from paycheck to paycheck,'' the man said. ''The city is a better deal.''
A large turnout for the sanitation test is not a new phenomenon, but the current outpouring reflects a troubled economy, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. ''It's now a zero-growth economy,'' Mr. Ehrenhalt said. ''That adds to the desirability of jobs that are relatively well paying and have a good deal of security.''
The Department of Sanitation, which has 1,200 supervisors and 7,000 other uniformed workers, says its average worker lifts five tons of garbage a day. There is no age limit for applicants. The city's personnel director, Douglas White, said that of the 67,000 applicants who actually took the sanitation exam in 1983 about half were minorities.
The director of equal employment for the Sanitation Department, Fernando Camacho, said there was a comprehensive campaign last spring to recruit minority applicants.
''We made a conscious effort to let people know this was a damn good job and how to get it,'' Mr. Camacho said.

HEADLINE: Japan Shielding Gasoline Buyers From Gulf Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Six weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait, motorists in this completely oil-dependent nation are only now beginning to pay a bit more for gasoline, thanks to a Government that exerts quiet but enormous influence to insulate consumers from the Persian Gulf crisis.
So far, the strict control of gasoline prices is the most visible evidence that Tokyo is determined not to allow a repeat of the oil-crisis psychology of 1973 and 1979, which sent the economy into a tailspin and angered voters who are usually docile about high prices.
Japanese consumers already pay more for gasoline than almost anyone else in the industrialized world - a gallon costs as much as $3.75, including taxes of roughly $1.50. Contrast to the U.S. The unwritten rules that have steadied prices in recent weeks provide a vivid counterpoint to the sharp increases in the United States. 
To contain price rises, Japan is using the same mechanism that American trade negotiators regularly rail against: the tight-knit network of Japanese politicians, bureaucrats and industry officials who work together in what some call a Government-sanctioned cartel.
Except for rice, the staple of the Japanese diet and a fiercely protected commodity, oil has always been Japan's most politically charged commodity. That is not surprising in a country that warms most houses with kerosene, is madly in love with automobiles and increasingly disdains nuclear power.
Wholesale gasoline prices finally began to rise this week, and consumers are beginning to face somewhat higher prices at the pump.
Some officials here say that Japan's slowness in gathering political support for a bigger contribution to the forces in the Persian Gulf was partly a result of the fact that many Japanese still see the crisis as a distant problem with little effect on their daily lives.
''Up to now, many Japanese have not seen the gulf problem as affecting them because it hasn't cost them anything personally,'' an influential Japanese executive with close ties to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party said the other day.
There are fears that a big increase in gas prices could spawn a consumer and political backlash, much like the sales tax imposed on all goods a year and a half ago that contributed to the ruling party's loss of control of the upper house of parliament. Moreover, it could slow capital spending and consumer buying, both of which are crucial to Tokyo's drive to narrow its huge trade surplus with the United States.
Japan's high gasoline tax is a remnant of the previous two oil-price shocks, which helped to foster huge energy efficiencies. As a result, oil imports have actually fallen considerably since the 1970's, though the economy has leaped in size.
 
'What the Japanese Want'
''What the Japanese want most in their energy markets is stability,'' said Richard J. Samuels, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of the Technology and an expert on Japanese energy policy. ''And they will go to great lengths to insure it.''
Officially, the Government says market forces are the biggest influence on the price of petroleum products. But after weeks of behind-the-scenes wrangling over who would bear the brunt of increased oil costs - Japanese consumers, the country's refiners or the oil-dependent manufacturers - the Government approved a modest increase in the wholesale price of refined petroleum products.
No one has said explictly how much of that increase will be passed along to consumers, though it could be as much as 21 cents a gallon, On a percentage basis, that is roughly 7 percent of the cost of a gallon of gasoline, compared with a 21 percent rise in retail gas prices in America since the gulf crisis began.
But last week, Kabun Muto, the Minister of International Trade and Industry, warned that the Government would ''closely watch to prevent opportunistic price increases'' and threatened legal action - a step to which the Government here rarely resorts - if retail prices jumped too quickly.
 
Low Price of Kerosene
Under one of the many informal rules that govern this society, the price of home heating oil and kerosene is kept artificially low.
Oil companies typically recover their profits, however, through the sale of gasoline. Also benefiting are Japan's huge number of gas stations - about 55,000, far more than the number in the United States. Though very small, they are usually quite profitable.
In fact, gasoline prices are so high Japan - about twice the level in America, excluding taxes - largely because the industry is so well protected by the trade ministry. Besides policies that shield inefficient gas stations and distributors, the Government requires that most refining be done in Japan, where expenses are high.
 
Rough Justice
Some experts theorize that having allowed the industry to reap its harvest in good times, the Government is now exacting some rough justice, insisting that consumers be protected from huge increases. Companies are being encouraged to dip into private stockpiles of gasoline if such a move will help them stabilize prices. Gas stations are being pressed to keep increases to a minimum.
Both the Government and the companies know they are walking a fine line between an illegal cartel and administrative guidance, the formal mechanism that the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, known as MITI, uses to control supply. A sudden jump in prices in 1973 led to an antitrust suit that embarrassed the Government and is still widely discussed.
And there are few Japanese who have not read or heard about the exploits of Taiji Sato, an amateur boxer and gasoline station owner who tried to buck the system a few years ago by bringing inexpensive gas into the country from Singapore. But because he was bypassing the Japanese oil companies, which dominate the refining of petroleum products at giant operations, and selling his imported oil at a below-market price, Mr. Sato angered many people.
In his book, ''How I was Butchered by MITI,'' Mr. Sato contended that the fuel pipelines at his station had been cut by competitors, that his employees had been constantly harassed, and finally, that his banks had refused to extend credit because of pressure from the Government. Mr. Sato was violating a system that had been carefully engineered to assure that everyone made a profit and that excess competition did not ''confuse the market,'' a favorite Government term. Eventually, he gave up and sold his stations to his competitors, at a handsome price.
''It is a ludicrous system to Americans, but I am not sure I am entirely against it,'' said Frank Upham, an expert on Japanese law at Boston College. ''At times, like now, it can pay off.''

HEADLINE: FINANCING BY U.S. URGED IN BAILOUT

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The head of the Federal agency overseeing the bailout of the savings and loan industry proposed today that the Government provide financing to purchasers of commercial and residential properties to speed the sale of $50 billion in real estate and other assets.
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, said that providing mortgages and other forms of financing to small and large buyers would help the Government sell the property by the end of the year at a higher price than the property is now fetching.
''The basic approach we ought to take is the same kind that a private seller would take and offer financing at the competitive level,'' Mr. Seidman said at a meeting of the oversight board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, in response to a question posed by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, a member of the oversight board.
''If we don't,'' Mr. Seidman added, ''then we will sell less property or at a lesser amount.'' 
 
Real Estate Markets Weak
The Government has generally resisted offering financing in the sales of the bulk of its real estate holdings, largely on the theory that it would require still more outlays of Federal funds. But declining economic conditions and soft real estate markets in many regions, particularly in the Southwest and Northeast, have led to new thinking by regulators on the least expensive way to resolve the savings and loan debacle.
The members of the oversight board did not take action on the proposals to provide financing, but it was clear from their questions that they might act soon to revise Resolution Trust's current policies. The board formulates policy for Resolution Trust. . Its members, in addition to Mr. Kemp, are Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve;Nicholas F. Brady, Treasury Secretary, and two representatives from the private sector: Robert C. Larson, a real estate specialist, and Philip C. Jackson, a former Federal Reserve official.
''There are a lot of people out there who are profoundly concerned about the ability to get loans,'' Mr. Kemp said.
As of July 31, the latest figures available, Resolution Trust's portfolio of assets from failed institutions had swelled to almost $165 billion, 10.8 percent of which was in real estate. Mr. Seidman said the agency had already sold more than $80 billion in assetsbut added that properties had been ''coming in faster than we're selling them.''
Last month, Mr. Seidman announced an aggressive campaign to sell $50 billion in assets by the end of the year.
An advisory committee to the oversight board, also recommended today that the Government re-evaluate its policy restricting financing of asset sales. That committee's acting chairman, Philip Searle, said a nationwide consensus had emerged that the tightening of credit by banks and other lending institutions had become an obstacle to the orderly sale of assets by the Government.
Mr. Searle told the board that there were problems in selling all types of real estate. He said that with the collapse of savings institutions in certain parts of the country it had become virtually impossible to sell raw land.
 
'Going to Require Help'
''Some of the ill-conceived projects are going to require help in financing if they are going to be moved,'' he said.
Mr. Seidman had also raised the idea of seller-financed sales at a hearing of the Senate banking committee earlier in the day.
At that hearing, widespread support began to appear to finance an effort that would ultimately reduce the Government bill from nearly 100 transactions, most of which were completed in 1988, in which savings institutions were transferred to private entrepreneurs. Those transactions are now expected to cost taxpayers more than $69 billion, more than previously estimated.
Resolution Trust said earlier this week that more than $2 billion could be saved by exercising options and repurchasing certain high-interest notes held by the institutions, but that the savings could require an initial expenditure of $22 billion.
Democrats and Republicans on the banking committee said that amount should be appropriated in addition to the amount needed to continue the bailout. Regulators have sought $100 billion to $110 billion to finance the rescue effort for the next fiscal year, which begins in October, but roughly half of that is in working capital that the regulators say would be returned to the Government.
''We ought to save every amount we can,'' said Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the committee. ''Whatever steps need to be taken, I think ought to be taken.'' The ranking Republican member of the committee, Jake Garn of Utah, and other lawmakers concurred.
 
Earlier Effort Recalled
Several committee members recalled the situation two years ago, when Congress and the Reagan Administration failed to appropriate enough money to contain the savings and loan problem, a failure that by many accounts contributed to the current crisis.
Many of the same lawmakers were on the banking committee at the time, some of whom acknowledged that the rush to support cost-cutting measures was a clear attempt both to avoid future criticism and blunt critics who have attributed the present situation to Congress.
Mr. Seidman said the full $22 billion might not have to be spent because the mere ability to exercise the options could be sufficient to encourage the savings institutions to renegotiate the terms of their contracts in a way that would save the Government money.
The options for cutting the costs of the 1988 deals were outlined in a report prepared by accountants, lawyers, investment bankers and consultants from private firms. The report was criticized at the banking committee hearing today by Senator Timothy E. Worth, Democrat of Colorado, who said that one of the major participants in the study, the accounting firm of McGladrey & Pullen, had been accused five years earlier of fraudulent accounting practices in a lawsuit filed by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.
The lawsuit blamed the accounting firm for contributing to the collapse of the San Marino Savings and Loan Association, of San Marino, Calif.
The case was ultimately settled three years ago for an undisclosed sum.
Mark A. Jones, a partner at McGladrey, said it had never been found guilty of any wrongdoing in connection with San Marino and that the firm had disclosed two other instances of disputes with Resolution Trust before it was retained.
''Like other national firms, from time to time we get involved in lawsuits,'' Mr. Jones said. ''McGladrey has a clean track record when it comes to such suits.''

HEADLINE: Bulgaria Crawls From Crisis to Crisis

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria

 BODY:
It has been three months since Bulgaria, following the lead of its Eastern European neighbors, held its first free elections in more than four decades. Today, the country is still waiting for a new strategy to deal with an economic crisis that is fast spinning out of control.
Some blame the opposition for delays in dealing with the nation's problems, saying its intransigence helped create Bulgaria's stalemate. Others see the Socialists - who a year ago ruled the country as the Communists - as the culprits for trying to share responsibility for the country's disastrous condition. [The Associated Press reported that early Friday, three months after the elections, Parliament approved the Socialist-dominated Cabinet chosen by Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov, whose Socialist Party won the elections by almost 53 percent of the vote. The main opposition refused to vote on Mr. Lukanov's choices, which apparently represented his decision to abandon efforts to patch together a coalition government with the liberal opposition, The A.P. said.] As the political accusations fly, Bulgaria's economy continues to go from bad to worse. Electricity, gasoline, detergent and some food are rationed. Bread shortages have been reported in areas along the Black Sea coast. 
Cuts in deliveries from the Soviet Union and Iraq have reduced Bulgaria's oil supplies by 50 percent. Industrial production has fallen sharply, the grain harvest has been hit by drought, the rice crop has been contaminated by pollutants, hard currency reserves are dangerously low at $250 million, according to estimates, inflation is rising and, as the cold weather sets in, people are getting anxious.
Standing in line for meat in downtown Sofia recently, Emila Asenova, an accountant with three children, described the hardships, including the stunning news that now even cheese -a staple of the Bulgarian diet - was being rationed.
''There is a crisis in everything,'' she said. ''Already, there are cuts in electricity, which will mean not enough heat, and vegetables are too expensive to set aside for the winter.''
 
Prospects 'Pretty Bleak'
Even the experts are ready to confirm people's worst fears.
''There will be malnutrition because there are foodstuffs that are simply lacking, and no hard currency to buy them,'' said Emil Mutafchieff, a deputy editor at the magazine Ikonomika. ''And we are talking not just about a shortage of food, but of medicines, shoes and clothes.''
President Zhelyu Zhelev, a leader of the opposition who was elected in August in a rare moment of political compromise, has planned a trip to the United States to press for special consideration. Already, Bulgaria has asked Washington for a million tons of feed grain just to help its livestock through the winter.
''We are worried about the winter,'' Mr. Zhelev said in an interview. ''There could be food shortages, electricity shortages. We don't expect a famine in the true sense of the word, but the prospects are pretty bleak.''
Bulgaria, the smallest and most remote of Eastern Europe's new democracies, also worries that it may get lost in the great reshuffling now going on between East and West.
''We have the feeling that we are just a little bit forgotten,'' said Stefan Tafrov, foreign relations adviser to President Zhelev.
A mysterious fire in August at the headquarters of the Bulgarian Socialist Party, formerly the Communist Party Central Committee building, added a new and ominous note to the atmosphere of distrust that has prevailed here since June. At the time, supporters of the Union of Democratic Forces, the main opposition group, took to the streets in protest against the election results, setting off a summer of demonstrations.
 
Politics of Polarization
Antagonism toward the former Communists is so acute and widespead that some here wonder how long a single-party Government will be able to function.
''The camps are so polarized that a Government of Socialists would not be able to do anything with an opposition that does not want to cooperate,'' said Georgi Karasimeonov, a political scientist at Sofia University. The central issue dividing the two groups is the proposed pace and scope of economic change - issues the opposition considers nonnegotiable.
The hope among many members of the opposition, which itself is divided among moderates and radicals, is that the Socialists, overwhelmed by the country's economic problems, will soon be forced into new elections.

HEADLINE: Even With a Desperately Ill Economy, Gorbachev Balks at Radical Therapy

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Like a high-wire artist frozen in midstep, Mikhail S. Gorbachev seems neither willing to risk a perilous dash to capitalism nor able to move back to a socialist alternative. Just days after endorsing the free-market reforms drafted by his principal economic adviser, Stanislav S. Shatalin, the Soviet President called for a national referendum on a crucial feature of the plan, the legalization of private landholding.
That does not entirely surprise Western economists, who speculate that Mr. Gorbachev has only recently taken full measure of both the near-intractability of Soviet economic problems and the breathtakingly radical nature of Mr. Shatalin's proposed solution. For while the 500-day plan would by no means assure a recovery, it certainly would put a stake through the heart of the central authority that brought the economy to ruin.
 
Likely to Be Popular
Two well-publicized features of the Shatalin program guarantee it a broad measure of political and popular support. The plan would devolve control of mineral wealth, as well as virtually all power to tax and spend, to the individual Soviet republics. And it would aggressively defend the living standards of Soviet citizens during the transition, controlling excess national spending by slashing the budget for the military, the K.G.B., foreign aid and grandiose domestic projects. 
American experts, who have been frustrated by Soviet attempts to enjoy the sizzle of free markets without paying for the steak, are eager to think the best of the plan. ''It touches all the right bases,'' said Ed Hewett, an economist at the Brookings Institution. ''It looks better than anything I've seen,'' Richard Ericson, an economist at the Harriman Institute at Columbia Univeristy, agreed.
Abraham Katz, the president of the United States Council for International Business, is particularly enthusiastic about the endorsement of property rights. The plan, he said, ''has bitten the bullet on privatization.''
 
A Hurried Approach
Still, they all admit to more than a little skepticism. One problem is the inherently sketchy nature of a proposal drafted on a few months' deadline. ''I don't know how they expect to set up a banking system in 100 days,'' Mr. Ericson said.
But the more fundamental worry of the experts is: the plan promises far more than it can probably deliver. Under the plan, hardly anyone is to suffer a decline in living standards, and those who do are supposed to be swept along quickly in the rising tide of prosperity.
Padma Desai, an economist at the Harriman Institute, doubts that the budget can be balanced or agriculture successfully privatized without a sharp rise in the price of staple foods. And Mr. Katz wonders what will happen to the unemployed. ''The initial layoffs of 5 to 10 million,'' he said, ''could double or triple very quickly.''
In the initial phase of the plan, pent-up purchasing power would be absorbed by auctioning off some state-owned property and by reducing the Government budget deficit from about 12 percent of gross national product to less than 1 percent. Most subsidies to industrial enterprises, now amounting to perhaps 3 percent of G.N.P., would be eliminated. Farmers would have the option of demanding a share of land controlled by their collectives.
Later, half of all smaller enterprises would be sold. Wages would be indexed to prevent erosion of workers' incomes. By the end of the 500 days, businesses would be denationalized and the prices for 70 to 80 percent of output would be deregulated. Bloated industrial enterprises would no doubt need to shed millions of employees, the plan's advocates concede. But many of the unemployed, they expect, would find work in rapidly growing service businesses.
A fully private banking system would be ruled by a central monetary authority modeled after the United States' Federal Reserve. Foreign currency would be auctioned to the highest bidder. Antitrust laws would prevent newly independent giant enterprises from charging monopoly prices. Residence permits would be abolished, giving Soviet citizens the right to work and live where they choose.
The Shatalin rescue plan was commissioned by Mr. Gorbachev after Prime Minister Nikolai A. Ryzhkov had offended practically everyone by calling for a slow transition to free markets only after consumer purchasing power had been tamed by an immediate tripling of food prices.
 
Perestroika's Problems
But Mr. Gorbachev's own efforts at economic reform lie in tatters. Perestroika, in the words of Nick Eberstadt, an analyst at the American Enterprise Institute, has been shown to be ''nakedly bad economics.''
Mr. Hewett of the Brookings Institution is more specific. Perestroika, he explains, weakened the old-boy network of party bosses, enterprise managers and planning bureaucrats who owed allegiance to Moscow. But no practical alternative, no hidden hand of free markets, was put in place to keep the sprawling Soviet economy on track. Indeed, the system now seems on the verge of total breakdown, with Soviet cities facing shortages of bread and meat, even as part of the record grain harvest rots in the fields.
According to PlanEcon, a Washington consulting firm, Soviet output is now declining by about 3 percent a year. But falling production, Ms. Desai points out, is only one ingredient in a recipe for chaos. Soviet enterprises, no longer disciplined by central authority, have been raising wages to pacify employees. As a consequence, Ms. Desai says, far too many rubles are chasing too few goods.
 
Threat of Hyperinflation
The current 10 percent inflation strikes at the legitimacy of a regime that long boasted of perfect price stability. Worse, it threatens to explode into hyperinflation as panicky consumers rush to convert soft money into hard goods.
The present troubles of the Soviet economy serve to underline the challenge facing the Shatalin plan. Moreover, the program could be hampered by the lack of hard data on which to project everything from the book value of Government-owned limousines to the potential savings from cutting aid to Cuba. Much of this information has not been tabulated. And much of what does exist has apparently been hidden: Mr. Shatalin has complained that the central ministries, which would be abolished under a radical reform, have withheld critical data from his team.
 
Regional Disputes Expected
Others worry about the plan's shifting of economic power from ministries in Moscow to bureaucrats in the 15 republics. Mr. Eberstadt says that the richer republics, including Russia and the Baltic states, will refuse to subsidize development in poorer regions. ''I expect a noticeable drop in living standards in Central Asia,'' he said.
Mr. Ericson demurs, arguing that the republics that now benefit from Moscow's largesse will be more than compensated by the right to set their own budget priorities and avoid environmentally ruinous construction projects. He is concerned, however, that the central Government will be unable to raise the money to carry out the minimal functions of a national Government. ''I don't think it is realistic to devolve the power to tax,'' he said.
To Mr. Hewett, however, this ''unrealistic'' devolution of power may prove the plan's only memorable feature. A precondition to Soviet economic success, he argues, is the irreversible destruction of central state control that denies nationalist and ethnic differences. ''They need a framework for loose unity,'' he said, ''and Shatalin provides it.''
This does not mean the new system will work. Indeed, Mr. Hewett thinks that it is only a step to a national reordering, in which Russia will serve as the anchor for a Slavic state and the Baltics will break entirely with the confederation. That suggests years of political and economic turmoil ahead. But as Marx put it in another context, you can't make an omelet without breaking eggs.

HEADLINE: U.S. Official Sees Peace Hopes Waning in Liberia

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 20

 BODY:
After visiting Liberia to assess the civil war there, a senior American official has said prospects for a negotiated settlement of the conflict appear to be diminishing.
''I find the situation in Liberia deteriorating,'' Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said on Wednesday. ''More and more people are in danger of starvation, of death from disease,'' and ''the prospects for increased warfare are growing,'' he added.
Mr. Cohen said he had discussed the possibility that the United States might increase its role as a mediator in the conflict, but was not at liberty to say what the Government intended to do. Both rebel leaders, Charles Taylor and Prince Johnson, urged the United States to become more involved, Mr. Cohen said. 
 
Meeting Is Blocked
He added that he had hoped while visiting Monrovia, the Liberian capital, on Tuesday to meet with Brig. Gen. David Nimley, the commander of the presidential guard, but that he had been prevented from doing so ''because it was too dangerous to go very far from the United States Embassy compound.''
''Virtually throughout my time there,'' he said, ''there was firing and stray bullets were coming close to the embassy.''
He added, ''I saw large columns of smoke, indicating that large sections of central Monrovia are being burned down deliberately by the troops of the late President Doe; so that already is a very bad sign.''
Monrovia, Mr. Cohen said, ''may be destroyed before this is over.''
He also announced that the United States was increasing aid to Liberian refugees and displaced persons, including $2.3 million for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and $1.8 million for relief groups including the International Committee of the Red Cross. This was in addition to $1.6 million already pledged for refugees and the shipment of nearly 40,000 more tons of rice.
Mr. Cohen met on Wednesday with Mr. Taylor in northeastern Liberia near the Ivory Coast border town of Danane.
On Tuesday, he met briefly at the United States Embassy in Monrovia with Mr. Johnson.
After stopping in the Ivory Coast, Mr. Cohen is continuing his tour of West Africa, including visits to neighboring Burkina Faso, which has offered support to Mr. Taylor's rebel movement, and Nigeria, the main contributor to the West African peacekeeping force. Guinea, Gambia, Sierra Leone and Ghana have also sent troops.
 
Common Goal for Rebels Seen
The Ivory Coast, Liberia's eastern neighbor, has not joined the force and is widely seen as sympathetic to Mr. Taylor.
Leaders of the 16-nation Economic Community of West Africa States decided to intervene early last month, asserting that the war was no longer solely an internal conflict because thousands of their citizens were trapped in Liberia while an estimated 400,000 Liberians had fled to neighboring countries.
Fighting by the five-nation force intensified last weekend when Ghanaian planes bombed artillery positions held by Mr. Taylor's group, the National Patriotic Front. After holding talks with the two rebel leaders, Mr. Cohen said that both men ''would like to see Liberia with a truly democratic system, and they would cooperate in organizing that.''
In the past Mr. Taylor, the leader of the larger of the two rebel factions, has equivocated about his intention to hold national elections. Mr. Cohen said, however, that Mr. Taylor indicated his willingness to compromise.
''I have the feeling that Charles Taylor is prepared to negotiate everything,'' Mr. Cohen said.
Troops loyal to Mr. Taylor control most of Liberia. In the heart of the capital, however, Mr. Taylor's forces are fighting Prince Johnson's faction, soldiers loyal to President Samuel K. Doe, who was killed this month, and the West African force, which is trying to impose a cease-fire.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Soviets Urging U.N. Council To Back Iraq Air Embargo

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The Soviet Union is asking members of the United Nations Security Council to send their foreign ministers to a Council meeting next week to approve a plan tightening sanctions against Iraq and occupied Kuwait by imposing an embargo on air traffic there and seizing their merchant shipping, diplomats said today.
The Soviet aim is to underscore the Council's determination to force Iraq to evacuate Kuwait by having its 15 member countries represented by their foreign ministers instead of their United Nations representatives, these diplomats said.
The last time the foreign ministers of the five permanent members - Britain, France the United States, the Soviet Union and China - attended a Security Council session was in 1987, when the Council approved a plan for ending the Iran-Iraq war. 
The Soviet Union has requested other such convocations, but the United States and other Western members say they have rejected Soviet demands for ministerial level meetings in the past by arguing that the Security Council's business was not sufficently important to justify convening their Foreign Ministers.
 
Jordan Appeal Postponed
But they admit that this argument is no longer valid when the Council is finally trying to exercise its power under the Charter to compel compliance with its decisions and when most Foreign Ministers will be in New York anyway attending the United Nations General Assembly.
The Soviet proposal came as the Security Council postponed the issuance of a formal appeal to all nations for aid to Jordan, the country most seriously hurt by the Council's economic sanctions against Iraq and occupied Kuwait.
A diplomat said the disagreement was technical and did not reflect any disagreement about Jordan's need for assistance.
 
Lost Exports Are Cited
Under Article 50 of the United Nations Charter, which gives any country suffering economic hardship from a Security Council decision ''the right to consult the Security Council with regard to a solution of those problems,'' Jordan has asked the Security Council for $1.9 billion in additional foreign assistance to cover the cost of applying the Council's sanctions over the coming year. This includes lost exports to Iraq and Kuwait, reduced remittances from its citizens working in those countries and an end to the cheap oil Iraq was giving it at roughly half the present world price.
The World Bank recently estimated that Jordan could lose a quarter of its annual gross national product as a result of the embargo. But at least 12 other developing countries, including India, Sri Lanka, Egypt, Yemen and Pakistan, have also asked the Council for economic help running into billions of dollars to defray the cost to them of cutting off trade and other financial dealings with Iraq and Kuwait.
The World Bank believes Egypt will lose 5 percent of output and that more than 50 other developing countries face cuts of 2 percent or more in their rate of economic growth as a result of the Gulf crisis.
 
Precedent Is Feared
The United States opposed Jordan's initial request for the United Nations to organize a special pledging conference at which the world's richer countries would be asked to promise specific sums in aid. Diplomats say it feared this would set a precedent for a string of such pledging conferences to help every developing country hurt by sanctions.
Instead the Bush Administration argues that it can better help poor countries suffering from the impact of the Council's sanctions by privately asking richer nations like Germany and Japan to step up their aid.

HEADLINE: Citing a Default, Saudis Stop Sending Jordan Oil

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia today stopped all its oil deliveries to Jordan, which have long constituted about half of Jordan's daily consumption of oil, Arab oil industry executives said.
Dealing a harsh blow to the Jordanian economy, which has already been weakened by the gulf crisis, Saudi Arabia notified Jordan that it was witholding the oil because it had not received any payments for some time, the executives said.
Despite the notification, Arab diplomats here and in the gulf region said the oil cutoff was a clear expression of Saudi anger at Jordan, where popular sentiments have been running strongly in favor of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq since he invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. 
In normal times, Saudi oil shipments to Jordan have been running at an average daily rate of about 33,000 barrels, worth $1 million at current oil prices, Jordan consumes about 70,000 barrels of oil a day.
Western oil executives said the Saudis had already substantially reduced the flow of oil to Jordan through the Trans-Arabian Pipeline, and that the reductions had been especially sharp since the gulf crisis.
 
Oil as Financial Aid
This pipeline, which once ran from Saudi oil fields in the eastern province of the country through Jordan, Syria and Lebanon, has stopped functioning since the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. But its Saudi-Jordanian section was still being used to pump Saudi oil to the Zarka refinery in Jordan.
Even though some Arab oil industry officials insisted the cutoff decision was made for economic reasons, many Arab diplomats said Jordan always viewed the Saudi oil largely as part of Saudi financial aid.
Indeed, in the past, Jordan had frequently fallen behind in payments without provoking a total cutoff of oil.
The Saudi move came immediately after several Palestinian leaders, including George Habash and Nayef Hawatmeh, went to Amman for a conference a few days ago, where they expressed support for Iraq and willingness to fight against the United States. The bulk of the American troops facing Iraq are stationed in Saudi Arabia.
 
Iraq Supplies Jordan
The Arab oil industry officials, who spoke on the condition that they not be identified, said Saudi Arabia will resume pumping the oil through the pipeline ''as soon as Jordan resumes payment.''
Over the last few years, Iraq has also supplied Jordanian oil needs.
Even though Saudi Arabia slowed deliveries to Jordan just before the Gulf crisis, most Arab diplomats asserted that if the crisis had not erupted, Jordan would have had only to ask to get deliveries back to the average level.
But three weeks ago, Jordan asked that the flow be raised back to all 33,000 barrels a day and the Saudis did not not respond at all.
A senior Arab envoy in Western Europe said, ''To say this has nothing to do with the politics of Jordan in the Gulf crisis is not very believable.'' He added: ''The Saudis, as always, have left a bridge for the Jordanians to cross. If the Jordanians somehow come up with the money the Saudis will somehow find a way to resume pumping''.
But the diplomat said this was unlikely to happen soon and as long as the gulf standoff continues.
 
Jordan Hit Hard
The gulf crisis has hit Jordan hard, depriving it of hundred of millions of dollars from trucking goods to Iraq and from use of its port of Aqaba on the Red Sea as Iraq's main import outlet.
In addition, thousands of Jordanians earned hard currency working in the Gulf region and in Kuwait.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Egypt's Threadbare Economy Worn Further by Gulf Crisis

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 19

 BODY:
An Egyptian recording company owner named Hani Sabet was pondering the other day on how fortunes large or small may be won or lost in these days of crisis in the Persian Gulf. Mr. Sabet said his fortune was lost even before it was found.
He had signed a contract with a Kuwaiti entrepreneur who had demanded exclusive distribution rights for the music cassettes of two Egyptian singers, Hanan and Ihab. That was in late July. The deal was done and the contract signed. The new business partner had flown back to Kuwait to arrange payment - $40,000, half up front, half on delivery. Then, on Aug. 2, the Iraqi Army invaded Kuwait, and neither the business partner nor the money nor the contract has been heard of since. 
''End of story,'' the man said. ''End of deal.''
''Maalesh,'' said friends who heard the story, using an Arabic term that translates roughly as ''never mind.''
 
A Story Typical of Many
The story was one of many retailed here as Egyptians struggle to come to terms with the repercussions of a crisis that impinges directly upon their ability to survive in a threadbare economy that cuts the purchasing power of their money by 40 percent a year.
''It has been a catastrophe in all aspects,'' said Ismael Sabry Abdullah, a prominent economist, during a discussion of the impact of Baghdad's action on Egypt, a leading Arab adversary of Iraq's annexation of Kuwait and a leading Arab supporter of the American military buildup.
''It has set back all Arab development,'' he said of the crisis.
Before the invasion, Egypt's economy was on the skids anyway. The population of 56 million is growing at a rate that far outstrips the ability of the nation's arable land to sustain it. Half of all Egypt's food and 80 percent of its staple wheat is imported.
A foreign debt in excess of $50 billion hangs over the nation. Egypt receives $2.3 billion a year in United States aid, but to avoid suspension of the aid, Cairo has been forced to channel resources into repayment of a $7 billion debt to Washington for military hardware.
 
Meeting in Washington
Egyptian ministers are due in Washington this weekend to try to negotiate an oft-postponed agreement with the International Monetary Fund that would allow them to reschedule some debts and borrow more in return for a program of austerity at home.
Egypt's earnings in recent decades have been gleaned from exporting people to work in oil-rich countries, importing others as tourists and earning revenues from limited oil exports and the transit fees paid by vessels using the Suez Canal. But now many of the guest workers are unemployed, many tourists have been scared away and many tankers are idled for want of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil to ship.
Since Iraq's seizure of Kuwait, and its replacement of Kuwait's powerful currency with the much weaker Iraqi currency, Dr. Abdullah said, ''billions of dollars in Egyptian savings have been lost,'' and remittances from Egyptian workers in Iraq, which once totaled $5 billion a year, ''have for the great part dried up.''
The crisis has pushed up the price of oil, but as a modest exporter, Egypt stands to gain in only a small way: estimates by Western economists put the windfall at $300 million to $500 million a year. And while American warships have replaced tankers of Iraqi crude transiting the Suez Canal, overall revenues are expected to fall by $110 million dollars, the Government says.
A Government minister, Morris Makramallah, said Egypt's losses were estimated at $4.5 billion. But a Western economist said the accounting was not so precise.
Against those losses, the Bush Administration is pressing Congress to cancel Egypt's military debt, in part as a reward for sending tanks and mechanized troops alongside American forces in Saudi Arabia. Cancellation would free Egypt from having to repay $660 million this year. The European Community and Japan have offered emergency aid totaling several billion dollars to countries including Egypt.
''More money by itself does not solve the economic problems of Egypt,'' said Dr. Abdullah. ''You cannot cure a cancer with an aspirin.''
That reflected an assessment among senior Western diplomats that much depends on whether aid funds get lost in the bureaucracy of unproductive Government ministries rather than produce economic growth.
The initial assessment is that the losses could outweigh the gains from the West and the gulf states and from Kuwait's government-in-exile, which has promised to bankroll Egypt's losses and its promised deployment of two divisions in Saudi Arabia.
As for Mr. Sabet, the record company owner, he seemed to have fared better than the authorities. After the Kuwait deal fell through, he said, he courted buyers in the West and Australia for Hanan and Ihab's song and struck another deal. The price, he said, exceeded the lost Kuwait deal by an amount he prefers to keep to himself.
