HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Rejects Peace Efforts Offered by Jordan's Ruler

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The United States opposed the latest attempt at Persian Gulf peacemaking by King Hussein of Jordan and has been lobbying among the Arab nations against proposals that would offer any advance concessions to gain Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, a senior Administration official said today.
But the United States would not object if Iraq and Kuwait negotiated their territorial and oil disputes after a complete Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, the official said.
If the withdrawal takes place and Kuwait's Government is restored, the official said: ''Are we willing to talk about whatever Iraq's grievances may have been? Are we willing to ask the Emir to negotiate with Saddam Hussein in good faith on their differences? That's something very different.'' The official said, ''That kind of face-saving is innocuous and doesn't reward him for having done what he did.'' 
 
'Privileged Relationship'
But Administration officials, who insisted on not being identified, said the United States objected to provisions in King Hussein's proposal that would have linked withdrawal of non-Arab forces to Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, established an unspecified ''privileged relationship'' between Iraq and Kuwait in the future, and called for a Middle East peace conference that included the issues of Lebanon and the Israeli occupation of the West Bank.
''Like all the other plans that involve rewarding Saddam Hussein, it can't be accepted,'' the senior official said of the King's plan.
Although the King's peace plan appeared to have fallen apart before it made much headway, the official said the Administration believed ''there's a danger'' that a similar approach to ending the Persian Gulf crisis could take hold in the future.
To avoid that, the official said, ''We are pointing out, and I think very successfully, that to appear to reward what Saddam Hussein has done is to increase significantly the danger to everybody in the area and that their security, stability and everything else in the development of the region depend on saying that this behavior is unacceptable, will not be tolerated and nobody will be allowed to profit from it.''
Taking a critical tone, the official said, ''King Hussein has been looking from the time this crisis arose for what he calls an Arab solution,'' and he then indicated that all such proposals have been unacceptable to the United States.
''I haven't seen one yet that did not have some element of concession to Saddam Hussein, whether it's King Hussein's, whether it's Arafat's,'' the official said.
He said the Arab peace proposals that have surfaced thus far are ''all from people who are inclined toward the Iraqi case'' in the crisis. The official suggested that King Hussein might have trouble getting support in the gulf for any peace proposal.
The leaders of that region ''are very bitter at him,'' the official said.
But he said that what concerns the Administration is that ''the Kuwaiti ruling family is not the most beloved in the Arab world.''
That could lend momentum to another peace proposal like the King's failed initiative if the economic, military and political pressure becomes strong enough, officials said.
As the King's actions were discussed in Washington, Iraq said President Hussein wanted American television networks to broadcast a videotaped message to the American people in response to one by President Bush that was broadcast in Iraq on Sunday.
The White House said it would not interfere with the broadcasting of such a tape. But the State Department reported that Assistant Secretary John Kelly told Mohammed al-Mashat, the Iraqi Ambassador, that Mr. Hussein would have to make his own arrangements with the networks.
 
More Reservists Called Up
The White House announced that the President, who has been working to hold together the embargo against Iraq, will meet in the White House on Tuesday with President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, one of the Administration's first allies in the gulf crisis.
Mr. Bush will meet on Sept. 29 with Sheik Jabar al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the deposed Emir of Kuwait, before flying that day to New York, where he will address the United Nations General Assembly on Oct. 1.
The White House declined to comment on news reports that Mr. Bush would visit the troops in Saudi Arabia at Thanksgiving.
The Pentagon continued to bolster its military forces in the gulf region, ordering 7,106 more reserve soldiers and airmen to active duty. That increased the total number of reservists called so far to about 21,000. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said on Wednesday that he expected about 30,000 more to be called by the end of the month.
In a written statement issued by the Pentagon, Mr. Cheney dropped the Administration's objections to a move by Congress to require that the normal legislative procedures be applied to foreign contributions granted to reduce the costs of the gulf operation.

HEADLINE: Time Is Running Out for Bills on Puerto Rico

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Legislation permitting a vote by Puerto Ricans on the United States commonwealth's political future could come to the floors of the House and Senate this year, but its supporters said today that time was running out for the bill's final passage.
Legislative aides involved in the issue said they expected the full House to vote on the measure quickly, after a committee approved it on Wednesday. They hope the Senate will pass a companion bill that has already been endorsed in committee and is awaiting floor action.
But the two measures differ in crucial details, and it is not certain that there is enough time left in the legislative session, which is expected to end in early October, to work out the differences. 
 
Major Differences
The proposed referendum would allow Puerto Ricans to choose among statehood, independence or enhanced commonwealth status. The new commonwealth plan would establish procedures under which Federal laws and regulations applying to Puerto Rico could be modified in order to enhance the island's economic growth.
One major difference in the two bills involves when and how the referendum's decision would take effect. The Senate would make the referendum decision final but would delay the effective date until 1996 if statehood is chosen. The House bill would subject the referendum's decision to further Congressional review, and if the decision is approved by Congress the decision could be ratified by a final vote of Puerto Ricans in 1992.
''At this point it is really iffy,'' said Angelo Falcon, an analyst at the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, which favors the referendum but takes no position on which is the best solution for the island.
''There are a lot of issues involved here,'' said Mr. Falcon. ''The two bills are very different.'' He estimated that there is an even chance of the bill's becoming law this year, and this would allow the referendum to take place next year.
 
Votes of Nonresidents
The basic idea of a referendum is backed by the Bush Administration and by all major political parties in Puerto Rico. But the consensus ends there, with sharp divisions remaining about what the best outcome for the islanders would be, and even about who should be allowed to vote.
The House bill does not decide whether the 3.5 million residents of the Caribbean island would be the only people allowed to vote, or whether the referendum would include Puerto Ricans living in the United States. The House bill said that should be decided by the Legislature of Puerto Rico in consultation with a ''dialogue committee'' including the island's three political parties.
Under this formula, the House bill leaves open the possibility that nonresident Puerto Ricans could vote in the referendum if they or one of their parents was born on the island.
But opinion is divided on the island over whether mainlanders should be allowed to vote.
There are 2.5 million Puerto Ricans living in the United States, including 900,000 in New York City.
Mr. Falcon said it was impossible to say, based on current polling data, whether the nonresident vote would tip the decision to statehood, independence or enhanced commonwealth status.
 
Polls Show Statehood Leading
''Inside Puerto Rico, the polls have statehood way in front, with independence way back,'' he said. But he added that those opinions might well change in a campaign before a referendum.
The version of the bill before the Senate makes no provision for those living off the island to vote in the referendum.
The Senate bill is different in many other respects from the House bill, and with the Congressional recess looming it is not certain that there is enough time for the differences to be resolved by a conference committee.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Eclipsed in the Reagan Decade, Ralph Nader Again Feels Glare of the Public

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
As sightseers strolled past the Capitol a few days ago, this is what they saw: a gleaming blue sky, a majestic spill of shining white steps and a lanky man in a somber suit leaning over a nicked lectern accusing Congress of hypocrisy.
It was a timeless Washington scene - Ralph Nader on the attack - but also very much a current one. After a decade in which he and his anticorporate ethic seemed to fade from public view, Mr. Nader has been increasingly visible, in the press and in politics.
Has Washington changed, or has he?
''They say, 'Hey, he's on the ascendance again,' '' he said. ''It's the press's own creation. We've been doing what we've been doing.'' 
 
In the News
But it was this summer that Life magazine ranked him as one of the century's 100 most influential Americans. This month, a cover story in Forbes magazine derided him as ''Ralph Nader, Inc.,'' a hypocritical and paranoid empire-builder. And an article this month in Vanity Fair reported, among other things, that he recently ate a hard candy that contained a red dye he has described as unhealthy.
That detail points to Mr. Nader's twin reputations, as a man calling for safer consumer goods and man eschewing consumer goods; as the person who has done the most to make cars safe, and as the person who does not own one. Reflecting on the uneasiness between the two images, Mr. Nader says the debate about whether he is an ascetic misses the point of his work. He has tried not just to reinvent the automobile but also to reinvent the nation's idea of democracy.
''I want people to spend more time as public citizens,'' he said. ''Otherwise they won't be able to enjoy their time as private citizens.'' Asked if he is an ascetic, Mr. Nader said ''no.''
For good or ill, as he moves into his fourth decade of advocacy, Mr. Nader stands almost alone in Washington as an emblem of the difference one person can make, a sentiment shared by the various tourists happening upon this week's press conference.
 
Championing the Little Person
''He's looking out for us,'' said Bill Patterson, a 61-year-old auto lease agent from Jacksonville, Fla., as his wife snapped a photo. ''He's the champion of the little person.''
Last year, Mr. Nader played a central role in passing a California initiative that rolled back the cost of auto insurance. He also led a successful, though bitter, fight against a proposal to raise Congressional pay by 51 percent; when he stepped up to the battered lectern this week, he was seeking the repeal of a smaller increase approved by the House of Representatives.
And old seeds have been producing new harvests: last month, Mr. Nader's old nemesis, the General Motors Corporation, announced its plan to start putting air bags in all the cars it builds in this country.
Discussing perils and prospects of the coming decade, Mr. Nader argues that corporate domination of daily life is at a high and true choice in electoral politics at a low. He says the forces that used to offset corporate influence - family, neighborhood, church, and labor unions - are in decline, leaving the average citizen with fewer buffers.
As workers, he says, citizens are increasingly reliant on employers for necessities like health insurance and child care; as consumers, they are subjected to increasingly sophisticated marketing campaigns. But Mr. Nader also expresses cautious hope: that those conditions would give rise to a hypercitizenship, what he calls ''real democracy.''
''This could be the decade, because we're heading toward economic collapse,'' he said in an interview. ''If there's one thing that galvanizes people from the level of disgruntlement to action, it's an economic collapse.''
It has been 27 years since Mr. Nader, now 56, left his law practice in Hartford, and hitchhiked to Washington. Two years later, his book ''Unsafe at Any Speed,'' published by Grossman, asserted that the Chevrolet Corvair was a safety hazard and that General Motors was ignoring the flaws in order to increase profits.
When the company then hired a private detective to follow Mr. Nader, he was catapulted to national hero status. General Motors eventually paid him $425,000 for the invasion of privacy, endowing him with the money to expand his organization.
 
Reveling in Frugality
Mr. Nader went on to help establish more than two dozen public interest groups. He was also a major force behind the passage of several landmark laws, including the Occupational Safety and Health Act and the Freedom of Information Act.
Mr. Nader entered the public consciousness not only as an advocate of government regulation but as an embodiment of frugality. He said that for many years he lived in an $80-a-month rooming house and that he now lives in ''a simple room'' near Dupont Circle, though he keeps its address secret.
In the early 80's, he said he was still wearing one of the 20 pairs of shoes he bought at the PX before leaving the Army in 1959. A lifelong bachelor, he says he lives on about $15,000 a year.
The reputation for personal sacrifice is among the targets of the attack this month in Forbes, which paints a picture of a man who travels in limousines and sleeps in a $1.5 million townhouse. The magazine accused organizations affiliated with Mr. Nader of failing to file required tax forms with the I.R.S., and argued that Mr. Nader gets an inordinate amount of his money from rich trial lawyers who share his passion for lawsuits.
 
A Bit Defensive
Mr. Nader disputes those accusations, and his lawyer has sent Forbes a list of retraction demands, threatening a lawsuit. Mr. Nader said the townhouse, where he visits but does not live, belongs to his sister. He said the I.R.S. forms are on file as required, and that contributions from trial lawyers represent less than one percent of his fund raising.
As for the hard candy Vanity Fair reported him eating, he said his throat was parched and that it was the only thing within reach. The magazine said he ate an ice cream bar despite his admonitions against sugar; he said the reporter insisted on buying it for him.
Perhaps spooked by decades of inspection for signs of hypocrisy, Mr. Nader, in a phone conversation, volunteered an explanation for why he had been scratching his eyebrows during the interview: simply because they had itched. ''It might have been misinterpreted as a nervous twitch,'' he said.
Though he keeps it on a tight leash, Mr. Nader does have a sense of humor. ''I don't want to get into a excursus on eyebrows,'' he said.
 
Partial to the Courts
A more serious criticism of Mr. Nader involves his fondness not for ice cream but for lawsuits. For example, his critics point to his adamant opposition to no-fault auto insurance laws that would reimburse the injured for medical expenses but prohibit them from suing for pain and suffering. That opposition, they say, drives up the cost of insurance and channels huge sums into the pockets of middle-man lawyers.
But Mr. Nader bristles at the suggestion that the right to sue be curtailed. Without the ability to sue for pain and suffering, he said, an injured person is reduced to the ''state of a chattel.'' Mr. Nader calls the courts ''the least corruptible of the three branches of government.''
He has been called shrill, dour, and a national nag, and Mr. Nader's speaking style can reinforce the suspicion that he lives in a realm beyond normal human passions. Attempting to outline a vision of the future, Mr. Nader slips quickly into the colorless cant that has earned him a reputation as tedious: ''Rights and remedies are the foundation, and on top of that are strategies, tools, and know-how.''
The answer for problems in the home, he says, is for people ''to go to the village green and improve their polity, their community.''
 
A Dream Career
For most people the public realm is a means to an end, better schools or fewer toxic wastes. Mr. Nader often appears to view the trip to green as the end in itself. ''I just think that the striving for justice, when you spell it out, has to be seen as a source of pleasure,'' he said.
What would he do if he lived in a perfectly just society, with no more striving needed? The question delights him.
''I would be a satirist,'' he said. ''Once you live in a perfectly just world, the goal of society would be humor - what would be the point of anything else?''

HEADLINE: New Rift Is Created in Budget Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, and the Bush Administration's chief economic policymakers disagreed today over how to proceed with an agreement to reduce the Federal budget deficit once one is reached.
But for the third straight day, White House officials and the top Congressional leaders met for hours in a back room at the Capitol without reaching an accord.
The prevailing view in the Capitol is still that some resolution will be found before automatic across-the-board spending cuts go into effect in most Government programs Oct. 1, the beginning of the 1991 fiscal year. But legislators and their staffs who express this opinion say they cannot imagine how the deadlock will be broken. 
Mr. Dole offered one suggestion today that he characterized as merely procedural and not a solution to the impasse. The White House apparently rejected it, at least initially.
 
Dole Wants Two-Package Deal
Mr. Dole proposed that the budget deal be divided into two packages. One would include spending cuts and tax increases that could be agreed to by the two sides.
The other would include a capital gains tax cut and other measures that would result in reduced revenue or increased spending. Each of these, under Mr. Dole's proposal, would have to be offset by a comparable tax increase or spending reduction.
A person close to the negotiations said that John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, opposed the idea, mainly on the ground that it would diminish the prospects of a reduction in the capital gains tax rate.
Mr. Dole acknowledged tonight that the White House had balked at his plan. The Administration officials, he said, recalled that Mr. Dole had failed last year to get a capital gains measure through the Senate under somewhat similar procedures.
Mr. Dole said he thought his idea might actually ''enhance'' approval of the capital gains measure.
 
Democrats Might Agree to Plan
In any event, he said in an interview, he did not see his proposal as an ''icebreaker'' in the budget negotiations but merely as a procedural step once an agreement was arrived at.
Some Democrats have informally suggested that they might agree to a separate vote on a package of capital gains cuts and some offsetting tax on the wealthy.
Among the other deficit-increasing proposals that have been offered by the two sides are increases in child-care benefits, a lower standard deduction on Federal income tax returns, tax breaks for oil and gas producers and a more generous tax credit for poor workers.
The negotiators plan to meet again Friday.
The participants have refused to talk about the substance of their negotiations publicly. But some legislators and staff assistants received briefings this morning on the first two days of talks. Afterward, several of them said they had been told that nothing tangible had been accomplished.
The talks, in a back office of the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, involve eight men without their staffs. In addition to Mr. Foley, Mr. Dole, Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman, they are: the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, and the Republican leader, Bob Michel of Illinois; the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
 
Restating Tax Positions
For part of the meetings, said those who received a rundown on them, the two sides restated their positions on taxes.
The Republican position is that a capital gains tax cut is needed to stimulate a flagging economy, that wealthy people would actually pay more taxes with a lower capital gains rate because they would be encouraged to sell investments and that higher income taxes on the wealthy would produce a drag on the economy.
The Democratic stance is that a capital gains reduction would primarily benefit the well-to-do and that it would thus be unfair unless it were offset by some other higher tax on the wealthy.
''What we have,'' said a Democratic staff assistant, ''is two different world views.''
When the tax discussions seemed to be going nowhere, the talks turned, at Mr. Darman's suggestion, to spending cuts in entitlement programs. These are programs like Social Security, Medicare and agriculture price supports for which payments are made automatically to everyone who meets the qualifications.
 
Wear of Meetings Is Showing
Republicans want to cut these programs more heavily than the Democrats do.
The participants are beginning show the wear of the tedious meetings in their faces.
At one point today, Senator Dole left to get a haircut. ''I walked back in, and I had not missed a thing, and they never missed me,'' he said.
Asked how the Administration officials and Congressional leaders could stay at the bargaining table for so long when so little progress was being made, one official said that neither side wanted to be blamed for cutting off the talks.
 
They Don't Want to Say Goodbye
''What keeps you at the table,'' he said, ''is often not what you say but what you don't say. That is the word, 'goodbye.' ''
The other reason, of course, is the pressure both sides feel from Oct. 1 deadline, a week from Monday.
The Office of Management and Budget has said that furloughs of Federal workers would begin immediately.
Officials at the Federal Aviation Administration said that air traffic controllers would be required to take two and a half working days off every 10 days and that overtime would be abolished.
The result, the aviation officials said, would be the cancellation of about a third of the flights taking off from major airports during the peak hours of travel.
Similarly, meat and poultry inspection would be curtailed, student loans would be reduced, Social Security checks would be delayed and virtually all Americans would quickly feel the pinch.

HEADLINE: Who Should Pay for the S.& L. Bailout?

BYLINE: By Joseph P. Kennedy 2d; Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, is a member of the House Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Though pushed for now from the front pages of the newspapers, the cost of the savings and loan bailout is mounting. A year ago, President Bush said the price tag wouldn't top $50 billion. Today we know that the bailout fund will be bankrupt before Election Day, with scarcely one-third of all bankrupt and brain-dead savings institutions laid to rest.
The question is not whether to pay. It is how to pay. And it is who pays. The current bailout law raises funds according to a costly ''borrow and spend'' philosophy that adds billions to the bailout cost in interest. It drives up interest rates and the budget deficit. It also places the bulk of the bailout burden on those who can least afford to bear it: America's working and poor families. 
This deficit spending ''cure'' may be worse than the disease. We need legislation to finance the bailout on a pay-as-you-go basis so we won't jeopardize the country's economy.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that at least another $100 billion, excluding interest, is needed to pay off the depositors of failed S.& L.'s. This awesome financial burden should be borne up front over five years with three discrete measures. First, by a 7.5 percent surtax on the unearned income - interest, dividends and capital gains - of individuals earning over $100,000 per year, excluding the first $7,500 of such income. Second, by a 5 percent surtax on the income tax of corporations earning over $75,000 per year. Finally, by closing the ''angel of death'' loophole that forgives taxes on appreciated capital gains when the asset owner dies.
These provisions will raise $21.2 billion per year, paying for the bulk of the bailout in 5 years rather than 40.
Such legislation makes sense. It saves hundreds of billions of dollars in interest payments. Data from the General Accounting Office and the Office of Management and Budget indicate that the total cost of the bailout, if paid for under the current law, will be $1.369 trillion. Incredibly, over $913 billion of that amount will be spent just to pay interest on borrowed funds. That's a tab we send to our children and grandchildren because we lack the courage to pay today. And it shifts the bailout burden from those who cannot afford to bear it to those who can. Over the last decade, working and poor families have endured a double whammy: reduced earning power and higher tax rates. Families in the middle have watched their taxes creep up by over 3 percent. Their incomes have kept pace only because they work longer hours and second jobs. The income of the poorest fifth of our families actually dropped by 9 percent, while their taxes rose 3 percent.
The wealthiest Americans, however, have enjoyed a double bonus: deep tax cuts of up to 23 percent and stunning income growth. Income from dividends climbed 49 percent; from interest, 106 percent; from capital gains, an astounding 109 percent. A booming stock market also brought huge increases in corporate income. Much of this new wealth resulted from the high interest rates generated by rogue S.& L.'s as they dueled for depositor dollars.
The Federal Reserve Board estimates that 28 percent of the bailout money will pay off depositors of $100,000 or more. And that doesn't include the wealthy investors who chopped up deposits in excess of $100,000 into smaller accounts to obtain full Federal insurance coverage.
Of course, all efforts must be made to recover the ill-gotten gains of the white-collar crooks who ripped off America's S.& L.'s. The cold reality, though, is that no matter how many criminals we catch, we will recover only a fraction of the money lost. The taxpayers are stuck for the rest.
Rarely, if ever, has our Government asked less of the wealthy and powerful than it does today. As our nation faces the greatest financial crisis in its history, it is only fair that they take up their appropriate share of the bailout burden. Working families should not be asked to pay for a crisis that brought them nothing but higher interest rates on their home, business and consumer loans.
A pay-as-you-go financing plan for the savings and loan bailout will save hundreds of billions of dollars, inject fairness into the bailout process and allow our children to build a future better than the present.

HEADLINE: Rinfret Is Said to Be Sitting on Own Funds He Donated to Campaign

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
While telling Republican leaders that his campaign is broke, Pierre A. Rinfret has not spent the $540,000 of his own money that he contributed to the campaign, top Republicans said yesterday.
Instead, they said, Mr. Rinfret was trying to set up a meeting with them today in which he would insist that they raise at least $1 million for radio and television advertising before he would agree to spend his own funds. Several Republicans said he told them at a reception for Vice President Dan Quayle on Tuesday that he had transferred the funds to a separate bank account.
 
Campaigning Suspended
Mr. Rinfret's use of his own money as a lever on Republicans is particularly significant because Republican leaders have conceded that he would not have received the Republican nomination for governor if it were not for his promise to donate his own money to the campaign. The candidate, an economic consultant, has said that his net worth is $14 million. 
On Wednesday, Mr. Rinfret told Republican leaders that he had no more money for campaigning and that he was ''probably going to have to shut down our operations on Friday'' unless Republicans started supporting him financially. That strategy of pressuring party leaders prompted Mr. Rinfret's campaign manager to quit. Mr. Rinfret, who said he would now be his own campaign manager, has suspended campaigning.
Mr. Rinfret told The Associated Press last night that unless state Republican leaders made the $1 million commitment to his campaign, he might abandon the race and ''go sailing for 40 days.'' He added that he might endorse Herbert London, the Conservative Party candidate, if he did not receive the commitment.
Mr. Rinfret also told The Associated Press that he was upset with state party leadership. ''The party is a disaster. There is no party,'' he said, adding that he was referring to Republican leaders in state government.
Mr. Rinfret's running mate for lieutenant governor, George F. T. Yancey Jr., said that he had spoken to Mr. Rinfret and that in appealing to Republican leaders, he was ''rattling the cage and hoping someone will come to the rescue.'' He added that ''we need $1 million to get on TV.'' Mr. Yancey said that in any event he would continue his campaign, which has been conducted almost entirely upstate.
Peter Rinfret, Mr. Rinfret's son and business associate, declined to comment last night on whether the candidate's $540,000 was still available. ''We'll file our financial reports and then everyone will know,'' he said. The next report is due Oct. 5.
 
Two More Leave Campaign
The disclosure of the unspent money came as the Rinfret campaign shakeup continued with the ousting of the press secretary and deputy press secretary, Bryan Flood and Kelly Naioti.
The campaign staff's key survivors have few ties to the state Republican Party. They are Eddie Mahe, a Washington political consultant; John Denny, a Pennsylvanian who was recommended by Mr. Mahe and is the deputy campaign manager, and Peter Rinfret.
Republican legislative aides blamed Mr. Mahe for the pressure tactic and said Republican leaders might demand his removal from the campaign as a price of cooperation.
The disclosure that Mr. Rinfret has not spent his own money was buttressed by figures he reported to the State Board of Elections and his own statement last week that he had raised $1.25 million. It was not known whether that figure included his own funds.
He has run a relatively low-budget campaign against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that Republican political consultants doubted has exceeded $700,000. He has had no radio or television advertising and his biggest expenses during the summer were payroll and chartered aircraft for campaigning.
Several Republicans, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Mr. Rinfret's $540,000 was to be used for late campaign commercials but that he has told them he would not spend that money at all if they did not raise $1 million. Most state and local candidates in recent years have been expected to finance much of their own campaigns.
Another Rinfret campaign associate, William E. Simon, the former Secretary of the Treasury, said he had not quit as finance chairman but would '' work hard for Pierre's election within the constraints of my travel schedule.'' He said Wednesday that he would leave for the Far East next week and not return until after the November election. He spent much of the summer on his yacht in Europe.
The main figures in the negotiations with Mr. Rinfret are J. Patrick Barrett, the Republican state chairman; State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Manhattan Republican leader who recruited Mr. Rinfret as the candidate, and the Republican legislative leaders, Ralph J. Marino, the State Senate majority leader, and Clarence D. Rappleyea, the Assembly minority leader. Mr. Barrett and State Senator Guy J. Velella, chairman of the State Senate Republican Campaign Committee, planned to meet with him last night.
Mr. Goodman and Mr. Barrett are multimillionaires themselves and Mr. Goodman is sitting on at least $1 million in State Senate and Manhattan Republican campaign funds. Mr. Marino and Mr. Rappleyea have access to political action committees interested in state legislation.
 
Steering Clear of Dispute
The state's two top Republican elected officials appeared to be steering clear of the controversy. State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said he had had no contact with his running mate, Mr. Rinfret, on the matter, while Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato did not return telephone calls to his office. A press aide said he was in Washington yesterday and today.
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the party's New York City mayoral candidate last year, did not return a telephone call seeking his reaction.
The mood among other leading Republicans was mixed - either anger at Mr. Rinfret for what they considered pressure on them and his isolation from the party, or sympathy with him because the party seemed to have isolated him.
Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island, the leading Republican municipal official in the city, reflected the latter view when he said that ''you can't throw a neophyte to the wolves.''

HEADLINE: $9 Million Won For Loss of Arm In Drunken Fall

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
A dishwasher who fell onto a subway track and was hit by a train has been awarded $9.3 million in damages even though he was drunk at the time of the accident.
In one of the largest personal injury awards ever granted in New York State for loss of a limb, a Bronx jury on Wednesday awarded $9.3 million to Francisco Merino, 30 years old, a resident of Pueblo, Mexico, who lost his left arm.
Lawyers for the plaintiff said Mr. Merino had testified that he had been drinking when he fell to the tracks at the 183d Street IRT station on April 10, 1980, and was hit by a northbound train. 
But they argued that their client would not have fallen to the tracks if transit workers had followed agency procedures and removed him from the platform when they noticed that he was intoxicated.
 
Finding Called 'Ludicrous'
Lawyers for the New York Transit Authority, saying Mr. Merino was to blame for his injury, called the jury's liability finding ''ludicrous'' and its award ''excessive.'' They said they would appeal the decision.
The Transit Authority lawyers said the token clerk who saw Mr. Merino on the platform had followed agency procedures, which require transit employees to notify the transit police if they see a passenger who ''appears unable to take care of themself because of intoxication or some other reason.''
The token clerk called the station command center to report that there was an intoxicated person on the platform, the authority's lawyers said. About 15 to 20 minutes after the call was made, Mr. Merino fell to the tracks. The lawyers could not say whether the command center had notified the transit police of the problem.
The Bronx jury awarded Mr. Merino $8.6 million for future pain and suffering, $514,800 for future loss of wages, $16,875 for loss of earnings, $200,000 for pain and suffering, and $17,055 for medical expenses.
 
Cut in Award Expected
Legal experts in torts said yesterday that they expected the award to be substantially reduced on appeal. In the past when the Transit Authority has been found fully liable for the loss of a person's dominant arm, awards have ranged from $1.25 million to $1.5 million, said the legal experts, who called Mr. Merino's award one of the largest of its kind.
George C. Christie, a professor at Duke Law School and an expert on torts, said: ''If the guy were a baseball player like Jose Conseco, then an award of that size would not be out of order, because it would represent real economic loss to the person in terms of earning power. But even if it were a jogger or amateur violinist who lost a limb and could no longer pursue their passion, this would be a very large award.''
Mr. Merino, who had been working in the United States as a dishwasher for a year before the accident, said through his lawyers, Harry H. Lipsig and Partners, that he would not discuss the case. The Associated Press said Mr. Merino's wife and four children live in Pueblo.

HEADLINE: LAW: AT THE BAR;
When the Public Interest Becomes the Interest of The Corporate World

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
A few weeks ago, law school deans in New York received invitations to attend a ''Constitution Day'' banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. It was held Monday and the featured attraction was Associate Justice Anthony M. Kennedy of the United States Supreme Court, giving the first annual Gauer Distinguished Lecture in Law and Public Policy.
Not only could the deans attend the $150-a-plate dinner without charge, but they could also bring along six professors or students. (''The dress for adults is black tie,'' the invitation stated. ''Since this may create a problem for students, a dark suit and tie for the gentlemen and an appropriate dress for the young ladies will be quite acceptable.'') The tempting offer came from an organization most had never heard of but that sounded simpatico: the National Legal Center for the Public Interest of Washington. But when the academics showed up, many were taken aback. 
In contrast to most public interest law gatherings, the Waldorf event was attended mostly by older white men. There were fewer beards, more cigars. The hosts were not the usual assortment of civil rights, consumerist and women's groups but American Telephone and Telegraph, Dow Chemical, General Motors and International Paper.
For Jordana Schwartz, who as a third-year student at Fordham Law School helps run soup kitchens and a homeless shelter, it was a revelation. ''I wasn't aware that all these corporations were interested in public interest law,'' she said.
Most of those active in what is generally called public interest law say times are bad. Money is tight, interest down. But according to those at the National Legal Center for the Public Interest, which one of its leaders described as ''an anti-Nader Nader organization,'' the problem is not so much one of a bad economy or waning idealism as one of terminology.
This is a group that has taken the famous dictum of Charles E. Wilson one step further. It is no longer only what's good for General Motors that is good for America, but what's good for Dow Chemical, Amway, Shell Oil, 3M and others represented on the legal center's board of directors. And if one does not believe it, the center's officials do not let you forget that it has qualified for tax exemption under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code.
The legal center, founded in 1975, defines itself as a ''nonpartisan, educational and public service foundation'' whose core values consist of ''the rights of individuals, freedom of enterprise, private ownership of property, balanced use and protection of private and public resources and limited government.''
According to its 1989 annual report, a document filled with references to stalwart conservatives active in the group like William Bradford Reynolds, Robert H. Bork, and Bruce Fein, the center runs a ''Federal judge identification program'' (which seeks ''to identify those who believe that the appropriate role of the judiciary is to interpret the law, not make it''); organizes seminars for corporate counsels, and publishes what it calls ''white papers'' and ''monographs.''
Recent feuilletons include studies on the ''hidden costs'' of affirmative action and on the ''impossibilities'' of the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1989; upcoming is a study by Ronald Reagan on why the 22d Amendment, which limits Presidential terms to two, is ''detrimental'' to the commonweal. The center also supplies the usual conservative suspects for programs like the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour,'' including Terry H. Eastland, the center's resident scholar, and Gary L. McDowell, formerly its vice president.
Then there is the Gauer lecture, inaugurated by Justice Kennedy with a heartfelt exegesis on the framers of the Constitution in which he sounded suspiciously like a civil libertarian. Mr. Gauer, a California businessman and former finance chairman for Mr. Reagan when he was the California Governor, is now retired. But according to his wife, Marian, ''one of the very important parts of Ed's day, every day, is being an American.''
One reason he established the program, said Mr. Gauer, who is 88 years old, is to bring some clarity to the law. Lawyers, he complained, have really taken over the country. He noted in particular the Federal anti-racketeering laws, which, he said, could be applied just as appropriately to Democrats ganging up on Mr. Reagan, President Bush, or Oliver L. North as to some of the alleged malefactors being prosecuted under those statutes.
Perhaps the term ''public interest lawyer'' is what the economists describe as ''infinitely elastic.'' Or perhaps the phrase has reached that stage of terminal exhaustion and utter meaninglessness described by Orwell in ''Politics and the English Language.''
If, after all, ''the American Way'' can be usurped by liberals, perhaps ''public interest'' is fair game for conservatives. It was enough to make one dinner guest, Dean Monroe Price of the Cardozo Law School, wax nostalgic.
''One longs for the days,'' he said, ''when code words were code words.''

HEADLINE: LAW;
Suit Over Death Benefits Asks, What Is a Family?

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
In what is apparently the first Federal lawsuit of its kind, the surviving lesbian partner of a deceased A.T.&T. employee has charged the company with discrimination for refusing to pay her the same death benefits it would have paid to a husband.
Sandra Rovira, who filed the suit, says her life with Marjorie Forlini, an A.T.&T. manager who died of cancer two years ago, was as much a marriage as any heterosexual union. The women had even formalized their relationship in a 1977 ceremony for relatives and friends, and they exchanged rings and vows.
''Margie and I bought a house together and raised my kids together, and when she was sick, I washed her, I went to the doctors with her, I prayed with her,'' said Ms. Rovira, 42 years old, of New Rochelle, N.Y., who was married before she met Ms. Forlini. ''She died in my arms. But when I called A.T.&T., they treated me as if I was nothing and our whole relationship was nothing. It was so humiliating. We were a family like any other family, and we deserved to be treated like one.'' 
 
'Someone Who's Hurting'
A.T.&T. says its benefits are for legal spouses only, and since the law does not recognize homosexual unions, it does not either. ''We recognize that this is someone who's hurting, but this was not a legally protected marriage,'' said Maureen Lynch, an A.T.&T. spokeswoman.
With more homosexual couples living openly in long-term relationships, the question of what constitutes a family is becoming a pressing one -for the courts and for employers, whose benefits policies are coming under attack.
Over the last five years, many cities have recognized ''domestic partnerships'' for some limited purposes. And many other efforts to have the benefits of marriage extended to domestic partners are under way, in legislatures and in the courts.
The changing status of domestic partnerships also affects unmarried heterosexual couples, who face similar problems in obtaining health insurance and death benefits. But unmarried heterosexual couples have the option of getting married.
''I think there will be broader recognition of domestic partnerships in the next five years, at least in large cities,'' said Nan Hunter, a professor at Brooklyn Law School and former director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Lesbian and Gay Rights Project. ''The law is not very well developed yet, but I expect that there will be more cases in a variety of contexts, asserting that where a nontraditional couple's relationship functions as a marriage, it should be treated as a marriage.''
 
Issues to Be Settled
But even for those sympathetic to the concept, nettlesome questions remain. For while marriage is a clearly defined status, there is no consensus about what constitutes a domestic partnership. Do the partners have to live together? And, if so, for how long? Must they contract to be responsible for eachother's support? Or is a simple affirmation of a committed relationship enough? And should there be a formal process for dissolving the partnership?
The question of what constitutes a family comes up in many areas, including housing rights and sick leave plans:
* In 1989, New York's highest court ruled that a gay couple was legally considered a family under New York City's rent control laws. At the same time, the city board of education is being sued by gay teachers seeking health insurance for their domestic partners.
* Municipal employees in several cities, including Los Angeles, Madison, Wis., and Berkeley, Calif., are entitled to sick leave to care for a domestic partner, or bereavement leave to attend the partner's funeral. A law with similar provisions was adopted, then overturned by a referendum, in San Francisco, and will soon be back on the ballot. And in Seattle, a law was passed giving benefits to city employees' partners, but it now faces an active repeal initiative.
* A few unions and municipalities, and a handful of private employers, including the American Psychological Association, The Village Voice and Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., the Vermont-based ice cream company, offer health insurance to the domestic partners of their employees or members. But the Internal Revenue Service recently ruled that the cost of insurance premiums is taxable income for the domestic partner.
* Several places, including West Hollywood, Calif., Ithaca, N.Y., and Madison, allow all residents, not just municipal employees, to register domestic partnerships with the municipal clerks. Because private employers are not compelled by law to offer benefits to domestic partners, registering might not result in any tangible benefits, but it might help to establish the right to family membership rates at the local Y, or to visiting privileges when one partner is hospitalized.
Many experts on family law and domestic partnerships see such registrations as a necessary first step toward the widespread recognition of domestic partnerships. And, they say, homosexual partners are not the only ones who stand to gain.
''People may think of this as primarily a gay issue, but in the places where domestic partnerships are being recognized, the majority of those who take advantage of it are unmarried heterosexual couples,'' said Arthur Leonard, a New York Law School professor who writes a newsletter on gay issues.
Many municipalities that have been offering benefits to domestic partners agree, saying that about half the participants are unmarried heterosexuals.
Despite the new policies of a few employers and municipalities, advocates for gay people say changing something as fundamental as society's concept of a family is not quick work.
''It's a real uphill battle,'' said Paula Ettelbrick, legal director of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a New York-based gay rights advocacy group, and the lawyer who is representing Ms. Rovira against A.T.&T. ''We're talking about overhauling a whole system that was based on the 1930's family consisting of a male wage-earner, a nonworking wife and some kids.''
 
Lag in Benefits Programs
Ms. Ettelbrick said the A.T.&T. case, filed last month in Federal District Court in Manhattan, is a perfect example of how changes in social realities have outpaced employer benefits.
''They have a corporate policy that, like a lot of corporate policies, says they don't discriminate on the basis of sexual orientation or marital status,'' said Ms. Ettelbrick. ''But gay and lesbian employees can't get married, so because of their sexual orientation, they're denied the benefits that spouses get, even though, where there's a death, they have the same needs as any other family that's lost a wage-earner.''
Experts say private employers have been reluctant to expand benefit packages to include domestic partners. ''It's a trend in the public sector much more than in the private sector,'' said Stephanie Poe, a spokeswoman for the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonprofit research group based in Washington. ''In this economic climate most employers are not expanding their benefits and would bring in domestic partners only with extensive cost controls, such as imposing waiting periods.'' She added that they might exclude pre-existing medical conditions, and might refuse to cover those at high risk of serious illness, like those infected with the AIDS virus.
''We talk to employers and unions and insurance companies and the question that always comes up is, where do you draw the line,'' said Thomas F. Coleman, who heads the Los Angeles-based Family Diversity Project, a nonprofit research and education group. ''Having a registration system is very helpful in providing some evidence that the people are not just making it up at the last minute when they want something, but that they have considered themselves a family, and held themselves out as a family all along.''
Ms. Forlini and Ms. Rovira clearly considered themselves a family, intermingling their lives and finances for the 12 years before Ms. Forlini's death. Frank and Alfred, Ms. Rovira's two sons, lived with them from the time they were 11 and 8, and Ms. Forlini claimed one or both of them as dependents on her tax returns for many years.
Ms. Rovira took care of Ms. Forlini while she was ill. And when Ms. Forlini died, in 1988, Ms. Rovira and Frank were the ones with her.
The A.T.&T. benefits plan for managers provides for a year's pay to the spouse and unmarried dependent children under 23 of an employee who dies of an illness. In addition, the plan says A.T.&T. may, at its discretion, pay some benefit to other relatives who have been dependent on the employee.
Ms. Forlini's lawsuit seeks damages ''in excess of $75,000.'' The suit says the company breached its own policy of not discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation or marital status and in so doing violated the Federal pension laws.
 
'Not for People Like Me'
''I was Margie's executor, and when I was going through her personal things, I saw the pension and benefits book,'' said Ms. Rovira, who works as a lawyer for the Legal Aid Society. ''At first I just put it away, but then I thought I certainly felt like a spouse, so I would call A.T.&T. and ask. Their reaction was that I was being ridiculous, that this was not for people like me. Then as I thought more, I said that even if I didn't qualify, my children probably would.''
Ms. Rovira said A.T.&T. told her over the phone that there was no application for benefits and that she would not qualify. Ms. Rovira said she then sent the company a formal request for death benefits, along with extensive documentation of her relationship with Ms. Forlini. She said A.T.&T. did not acknowledge receiving her request until weeks later, when she called to inquire about its status and was told that her claim had been rejected.
A spokeswoman for A.T.&T. said the denial of benefits does not violate the company policy of not discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation or marital status.
''If we have a benefit for spouses and you don't have a spouse, that doesn't mean we've discriminated on the basis of marital status,'' said Maureen Lynch, of A.T.&T. ''If you're single, you're not being discriminated against, you just don't have anybody who's eligible for that benefit. And from a philanthropic standpoint, A.T.&T. has done a lot for the gay community, and is widely considered a very good place for gay people to work.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 21, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 4; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 1459 words

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
A VISIT to New York City can often seem surreal. But those who yearn for the surreal - for real - would do well to spend a night or two at the new Paramount Hotel at 235 West 46th Street.
Feel free to wear black. The turtlenecked maintenance workers wear black. The doormen wear black. Even the match sticks and the postcards are black.
The recently reopened 610-room hotel is the much-touted brainchild of the hotelier Ian Schrager of Studio 54 fame. It is his group's third hotel - along with Morgans and the Royalton - expressly designed to be hipper than thou. The hotel, formerly the Century Paramount, has been revamped by the French designer Philippe Starck. Mr. Starck, who once referred to himself as the ''Baader-Meinhof of design,'' designed the fashionable interiors of the Royalton, where the doormen also wear black. The Paramount, where double rooms run $110 to $170 a night, has been marketed as a budget version of that hotel, and, as at the Royalton, a major amenity is style. 
There is no sign outside. (If you have to ask - well, you know.) But the hotel is instantly recognizable from the street by the stylish doormen with landscaped hairdos and the roses sticking out of marble slots in the entrance foyer.
When we checked in on a recent weekend, the hotel had been officially open for only a few weeks. We couldn't resist the temptation to try it, even though a letter to guests written by the general manager offered this caveat: ''We appreciate your understanding that the hotel does not yet offer all the service and amenities that will be part of this exciting new idea.''
On a Friday evening, the lobby was abuzz with young European and Japanese tourists, who seemed to make up the majority of the Paramount's clientele. They frequently kissed one another on both cheeks, smoked reams of non-filter cigarettes and had the kind of natural chic that makes a ripped T-shirt with cigarette burns look glamorous.
Throughout the weekend, brigades of dreamy young tourists from abroad, who might have walked straight out of the film ''Mystery Train,'' decorated the rather austere lobby, reading their maps and green Michelin guides while parking their sunglasses on the tables.
We waited about 20 minutes to check in. In an elevator with Popsicle-orange lighting, a young man named Chris whisked us to our room, which didn't turn out to be the kind of room we had requested. It was extremely dark and had two tiny beds rather than a double. (In addition, a Chinese restaurant had surreptitiously papered the entry with a cascade of flyers.) Chris was extremely apologetic. In fact, without exception, the employees at the hotel were dedicated and friendly, despite their brutually fashionable uniforms. We went back downstairs and were told that the key to room 1636 - our new room - was ''being worked on'' and would be ready tomorrow. Master key in hand, Chris took us up to the 16th floor. We passed something called a ''weather mirror,'' a slanted glass panel with lighted lettering, designed to tell guests the latest forecast. ''Where did they get that idea?'' we wondered. ''Our owner is a weatherologist,'' Chris explained.
 
A Clever Economy
He then opened the door to Room 1636, a cleverly disguised small, bare-bones hotel room. ''I guess you know who this gal is,'' Chris said, referring to the highbrow headboard, a blow-up of Vermeer's ''Seamstress.'' He told us about the room's other amenities - a VCR and television cabinet that contained a switch for ''mood lighting.'' The mood lighting, turned on by flicking a green ball, projected white squiggles like paramecia on the ceiling. He showed us Philippe Starck's bathroom, a compact tubless wonder with a shower, with barely enough room to hang wet towels. ''And here's your cone-shaped sink,'' he said.
As in a ship's cabin, which it somewhat resembled, the room was notable for a clever economy of space. There was one wastebasket (ah, minimalism). As in a weird D. M. Thomas reverie, the room was white. Quite white. A Starck-designed light hanging over a small desk, which faced the bed, looked like a surrealistic stethoscope.
The bed - a comfortable one, as it turned out - was placed low to the floor and was covered with brass-buttoned white throw pillows and a crisp white bedspread. White may be great as a fashion statement, but unfortunately, putting white in a hotel room is a little bit like putting white on an elephant. The bedspread highlighted the spills, and even some stray hairs, left by previous occupants.
There was no refrigerator - which is probably to be expected for only $120 a night in New York. We were told that room service would be available in a couple of weeks. But there was a decent view of the theater district, especially the red ''Gypsy'' sign at the St. James Theater. We asked Chris if he had any restaurant suggestions. He had heard Orso was nice. ''It's the place I'd take my parents,'' he said, eyeing us. Between this comment and trying to share a cone sink, we suddenly felt ancient.
 
Who Needs an Alarm?
We slept blissfully - too blissfully. We never received our 8:45 wake-up call. Bleary-eyed, we ambled past the weather mirror - it said ''RAIN, WARM'' - and took the elevator, a green one this time, to the mezzanine. When we saw a man trying to read his newspaper in the balcony area clutching his table lamp like a flashlight, we opted for the brighter breakfast room. It offered a delightful buffet of fresh berries, yogurt, muffins, croissants and good coffee.
We felt fortified. Who really needed a wake-up call when Rolling Stones music was playing in the lobby?
The lobby of the more upscale Royalton, which will probably be preserved one day as an example of fin-de-siecle thinking, has an edgy, menacing, somewhat sinister quality. Furniture is shrouded in slipcovers; chairs look like intrauterine devices.
The lobby of the Paramount is friendlier - although, as at the Royalton, a visitor would be hard-pressed to enter this lobby and say, ''Now, this is New York.'' The public sitting area, plunked on checkered carpeting in the middle of the room, offers little intimacy. Though rather foreboding, a stark set of steps in the rear offers a dramatic backdrop. But despite its severe, concrete-like interiors, the lobby has something spunky about it.
Postcards, for instance, are sold from playful ''trees'' (but black-and-white postcards only). A shop sells black and white objects -watches, sewing kits, and white combs with black checks on them. It also sells newspapers and magazines from around the globe, including L'Express, Time Out, The Face and, most appropriately, Zoom, the International Image Magazine.
 
Air of Mystery
We decided to check out the ladies' room. Like many other aspects of the Paramount, the design was imbued with mystery. A silver free-form toilet-paper dispenser, which looked as if it was designed by Yves Tanguy, held not only paper, but also a single fresh rose. A cryptic mirror by the sink said ''warm air'' but offered no clue as to where it was supposed to come from. Wary of sticking our hands into strange mechanical devices, we nevertheless reached into a crevice behind the mirror, and (behold!) warm air gushed forth.
Special features of the Paramount, which were uncompleted at the time of our stay, are supposed to be finished by the end of the year. They include a 24-hour Brian McNally brasserie and a Dean & DeLuca gourmet shop (both with room service) and a nightclub downstairs where the Billy Rose Diamond Horseshoe Supper Club used to be. A 24-hour staffed day-care center and a fitness club are now open. Videotapes, rented for $6 each, include a ''New York collection'' with selections like ''Ghostbusters'' and ''Annie Hall.''
The lunch menu in the mezzanine dining room included New York kosher hot dogs on Pennsylvania Dutch potato roll ($6) and warm New York soft pretzels with mustard ($4). The latter featured a single pretzel, pelted with salt, situated majestically on a plate accompanied by a container of mustard.
 
Into the Real World
Soon, we ventured out into the sultry streets of Times Square, streets redolent of incense and shish kebab. Like the young tourists in the lobby, we were determined to conquer New York. At the corner of 46th Street and Broadway, a man was selling ''disembodied'' rubber hands that wriggled realistically in lettuce bowls, not far from a stand selling T-shirts that said ''Die Yuppie Scum.'' Who needed ''Wild at Heart''?
Back at the Paramount, the Big Macs being consumed by some Italian tourists glowed poison-green in the elevator's eerie light. The weather mirror said ''SNOW.'' Something told us this wasn't the Travelodge on the turnpike, after all.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Paramount's lobby - A spunky and spacious setting offering Rolling Stones music but little intimacy for conversation. (pg. C1); A small, bare-bones room, cleverly disguised, at the Paramount. (pg. C27) (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 21, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 20, Column 1; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 3016 words

HEADLINE: New Visions of Familiar Movie Genres

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
They are movie genres so hallowed and, alas, so overfamiliar, that they glow with the phosphorescence of cliche. They include the film-noir love triangle, the gangster movie, the historical drama, the Nazi occupation thriller and the artist's biography. Is it still possible to jump-start these tired vehicles in the age of the sequel, when previously owned movies seem to be the mother of invention? The answer is an unqualified yes, judging by the offerings at the New York Film Festival in its 28th series, which opens tonight at Lincoln Center.
Nearly half of the festival's 29 featured films from 14 countries are fresh variants on traditional themes. ''Genre-juicing - that's what we're seeing,'' said Wendy Keys, executive producer for programming at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which presents the festival. ''So many of the offerings are genre films, with a twist - a play on the expected.''
''It's remarkable how many of these offerings have a film-historical bent,'' said Richard Pena, the society's program director. ''They assume a burden of experience on the part of the audience, and they use it. But they don't refer to specific predecessors, and they don't burlesque them. Instead, they reinvent familiar film styles and take them in new directions.'' 
 
Gangsters With Ethics
This evening, for example, the festival opens with Joel and Ethan Coen's ''Miller's Crossing,'' a 1929 gangster story starring Gabriel Byrne and Albert Finney as crime kingpins who wage war against rival wise guys while competing for the same woman. The festival will conclude on Oct. 7 with Michael Verhoeven's merciless dark comedy ''The Nasty Girl,'' a film about an innocent Bavarian lass who sets out to write an essay called ''My Town During the Third Reich.'' Her investigation creates a sensation, just as the film did at this year's Berlin Film Festival, where Mr. Verhoeven won the award for best director. The movie takes a familiar subject - the legacy of Germany's Nazi past - and treats it in a way that is savagely original.
''Miller's Crossing,'' like some of its gangster predecessors, inhabits a distorted, ominous cityscape in an unnamed metropolis, but it delves more deeply into its characters' complex hierarchies and rivalries as they battle in a universe of subtly rearranged spaces. And ''instead of being a straightforward formula shoot-'em-up, it uses the convention of the gangster drama to examine some really interesting issues,'' said Mr. Byrne, who stars in the film as Tom Reagan, the enigmatic henchman of the Irish-American mob star played by Mr. Finney.
Those issues include ''power and the misuse of power,'' Mr. Byrne said in a recent interview. ''Street power, institutional power, personal power - and the kind of issues, like loyalty, betrayal and trust, that are not found in the conventional gangster movie. I mean, how many shoot-'em-ups begin with a gangster talking about ethics in the opening scene?''
The Coens have stated that they started with a familiar genre they wanted to explore - the gangster film - and that their inspiration was the crime fiction of Dashiell Hammett. ''But the film itself, though a homage to the gangster movies of previous years, deals with relationships in a very complex way,'' Mr. Byrne said. ''It's not simply a pastiche of previous films.''
The festival's other gangland melodrama - Abel Ferrara's ''King of New York,'' to be shown tomorrow and Sunday - is as different from earlier crime-genre films as it is from ''Miller's Crossing.'' It stars Christopher Walken as a drug czar who, after years spent in jail studying philosophy, returns to the streets to reclaim his illicit empire, vowing to divert his wealth to the needy.
''Gangsters are traditionally presented as hot, sexy characters, and what's so fascinating about 'The King of New York' is its coolness,'' Mr. Pena said.
 
Adultery in China
At first, ''Ju Dou,'' also to be shown tomorrow and Sunday, appears to be a love triangle in the classic film-noir tradition, a sort of ''The Postman Always Rings Twice'' set in China in the 1920's. But then the director Zhang Yimou (''Red Sorghum'') and the co-director, Yang Fengliang, abandon cliche as they consider the lifelong consequences of a passionate adulterous relationship between Ju Dou - a beautiful young woman married to an old, abusive, wealthy man - and Tian-qing, her ardent young lover.
''Ju Dou'' has the distinction of being the first Chinese film co-produced by Japan, for the equivalent of $2 million when it was shot in 1989. Given the film's subject of youthful rebellion against tyrannical patriarchy, some have viewed the movie as a metaphor for China itself, in the grip of its gerontarchs.
Both ''Ju Dou'' and ''Miller's Crossing'' introduce an important subtheme of the films at the festival: betrayal, revenge and adultery. ''It's so curious that betrayal and adultery are part of many of these films,'' Ms. Keys said. ''After an era when we've been very cynical, very calculating, very me-generation about infidelity, it's as if film makers are saying that we've reached the time to examine our responsibility for the pain we give others.''
 
Reinventing the Past
Betrayal and adultery are central to ''The Sting of Death,'' the winner of the International Critics' Prize at this year's Cannes International Film Festival. The Japanese director Kohei Oguri (''Muddy Water'') has constructed a tale that weaves the shifting social and historical context of postwar Japan into the story of an adulterous writer's attempt to make amends for his betrayal of his deranged wife. The film will be shown next Friday and on Sept. 30. Betrayal is also the text for the director Jacques Doillon's film ''A Woman's Revenge,'' to be shown Sept. 30 and Oct. 1. In this loose adaptation of Dostoyevsky's ''Eternal Husband.'' Isabelle Huppert and Beatrice Dalle star in the psychological drama about the widow and ex-mistress of a man they once shared.
Another cliche genre, the historical epic, is re-animated by Manoel de Oliveira's ''No, or the Vain Glory of Command,'' to be shown Wednesday and Sept. 29. The 83-year-old director's subject is nothing less than the social, cultural and mythological history of his native Portugal. The film uses flashbacks and surrealistic techniques in an attempt to present the legends, myths and literature of a people.
Among the festival's ground-breaking documentaries is Barbara Kopple's ''American Dream,'' to be shown Oct. 6, which reexamines the traditional labor-managment chronicle. Her new film began as an investigation of a strike against a Hormel meat-packing plant in Austin, Minn., similar to her monumental 1977 work, ''Harlan County, U.S.A.'' But the bitter worker-employer conflict quickly gives way to fierce dissension within the union itself, and this film asks fundamental questions about the survival of union traditions in 1990's America.
 
Masters and Debuts
Two French masters are returning to the festival, which will also be the showcase for the work of a rising star from Finland and two Soviet newcomers. The return of Jean-Luc Godard ''is a very exciting thing for the festival,'' Ms. Keys said, ''since it also marks a return to the work of his heyday.'' ''Nouvelle Vague,'' starring Alain Delon and Domiziana Giordano, is Mr. Godard's self-mocking analysis of political and sexual issues, as well as his celebration of the beauty, and mystery, of images. It will be shown Sept. 29 and Oct. 2.
Eric Rohmer is also back with ''A Tale of Springtime,'' the story of Jeanne, a lonely young philosophy teacher who finds herself at loose ends on the first day of spring. She encounters a new friend, Natacha, who is soon attempting to introduce Jeanne to her father. This unfolding intrigue is part of a new cycle of proposed films for Mr. Rohmer, which he calls ''Tales of the Four Seasons.'' It will be shown Tuesday and Thursday.
The recent work of the director Aki Kaurismaki will be commemorated with two films at the festival, an honor previously accorded to directors like as Godard, Rohmer, Pier Paolo Pasolini and Rainer Maria Fassbinder. The 33-year-old Finnish director ''has evolved a very sophisticated, sure style in a remarkably short time,'' Mr. Pena said. ''One encounters artists now and then whose work is very hot, and who are working at the peak of their form. A showing of only one of their films doesn't quite seem enough.''
''The Match Factory Girl,'' to be shown on Oct. 3, is Mr. Kaurismaki's spare, grimly comic tale of Iris, who performs mind-numbing work in a match factory and lives at home with her parasitic mother and abusive stepfather. ''I Hired a Contract Killer,'' Mr. Kaurismaki's first film in English, will be shown on Oct. 4. In his minimalist style, the director tells the tale of a Frenchman, played by Jean-Pierre Leaud, who is dismissed from the firm he has loyally served for 15 years. Despondent, realizing that he hasn't the courage to kill himself, he hires a contract killer to do the job for him. But when love unexpectedly enters his life, he desperately tries to cancel the contract, with dark yet hilarious results.
A provocative debut by another director, Vitaly Kanevski, is ''Freeze-Die-Come to Life,'' to be shown tomorrow and Sunday. The film, awarded the Camera d'Or as best first film at Cannes this year, is Mr. Kanevski's autobiographical story of two children who learn to survive in an isolated mining community that has one of Stalin's work camps. Mr. Kanevski, who was imprisoned in such a town for eight years as a political prisoner, portrays life in the gulag as nasty, brutish and short. The film has been viewed as a powerful indictment of Stalin's excesses, but it is also a celebration of children's ability to survive and flourish amid the privation, brutality and madness of an era that was without any moral center.
''Taxi Blues,'' the other Soviet entry at the festival, won its first-time director, Pavel Lungin, honors as best director at Cannes. It will be shown Oct. 1 and 2. It is the tale of Schlikov, a bigoted nationalist of a taxi driver, who is stiffed one night by Liocha, a drunken, gifted Jewish saxophonist who leaves the cab without paying his 70-ruble fare. Schlikov's subsequent search for the delinquent musician leads to a contemporary Soviet debate about class envy, anti-Semitism and economic frustration; it also leads to a spiky friendship. The film's examination of the violent and corrupt netherworld of Moscow may be the most harrowing of the portraits thus far to be visible through glasnost, darkly.
 
Of Art and Family
Last year's critically acclaimed newcomer, Jane Campion (''Sweetie''), is back again this year with ''An Angel at My Table.'' The film, to be shown Oct. 4 and 6, is based on the autobiographies of Janet Frame, New Zealand's most celebrated novelist. The film is at once a tribute to a quirky, idiosyncratic personality and an analysis of literary genius. It is also a retooling of that classic movie type, the artist's biography, as it portrays a complex artist in an even more complex contemporary world.
Charles Burnett, a director who is a recent recipient of one of the MacArthur Foundation's ''genius awards,'' is represented at the festival on Oct. 5 and 6 with ''To Sleep With Anger.'' The drama, starring Danny Glover, is the story of a black family from the Deep South that has relocated to Los Angeles, where it is conquered by Harry, an old pal from back home. In his devilish interference, Harry, played by Mr. Glover, demonstrates the persistence of the family's past and the tension between old rural ways and the family's new urban lifestyle.
 
The Nazi Era
''The Nasty Girl'' also reveals the pull between past and present, in its satirical depiction of a German town that has found it comfortable to repress its more uncomfortable memories. ''When Verhoeven was working on this, he didn't know that unification was around the corner,'' Ms. Keys said. ''Given its explosiveness and its reference to such contemporary events, we thought it would work very well for closing night.''
Another evocation of the Nazi era, Christian de Chalonge's ''Dr. Petiot,'' will be shown Sunday and Monday. It is based on real events that occurred during the occupation of France. The doctor, a distinguished Parisian practitioner loved by his family, is asked by his Jewish patients and acquaintances to risk his life by arranging their escape from the Nazi usurpers. If this film sounds suspiciously like a classic occupation thriller, the director turns it inside out into a macabre tale of betrayal and infamy.
 
Vigo Restored
''L'Atalante,'' this year's retrospective offering, is the only feature film of the legendary Jean Vigo, who died of septicemia in 1934 at the age of 29. The film, about quarreling newlyweds who are brought together by a charming bargeman played by Michel Simon, was chopped up, retitled and re-edited by its original distributors. Only now has it been restored to Vigo's original plan by the French company Gaumont. It will be shown tomorrow.
''Vigo was that very rare creature who worked completely on his own, outside the French film establishment,'' Mr. Pena said. ''He was a hero of the French New Wave, and his work was a forerunner for much of the independent cinema we see around the world today.''
 
Screening Times for the 28th New York Film Festival
The 28th New York Film Festival opens tonight with two screenings of ''Miller's Crossing'' and closes Oct. 7. All films are at Alice Tully Hall except the late show on opening night and the closing-night show, which are at Avery Fisher Hall. Many screenings are sold out, but tickets to those showings may be available because of returns. Remaining tickets are $9 or $10 and may be purchased at the Alice Tully Hall box office (362-1911); tickets for opening and closing nights are $15 and $20. Some films are scheduled to open commercially in New York City; those dates are noted. Here is a schedule of the festival.
 
Tonight
