HEADLINE: Market Place;
An Unusual Deal for Child World

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Child World Inc., the troubled No. 2 American toy retailer, is scheduled to be sold in a highly unusual transaction in which little cash is put down and the principal holder gets a worse deal than public investors. But stock traders appear to doubt the deal will be completed.
The agreed buyer is an investment partnership planned by Roy Disney's Shamrock Holdings, which signed a definitive agreement late last month calling for it to pay $14 a share, or a total of $28 million, for the 18 percent of Child World's shares that are in public hands. The rest of the stock, held by Child World's corporate parent, the CNC Holding Corporation, is to be bought for securities with a face value of $147.5 million. 
When the plans for the deal were first announced in July, the price of the shares rallied to close to the agreement price of $14. But they have since sagged, selling for as little as $9.625 last Friday. Yesterday, they fell 25 cents, to $10.25.
''The stock is saying it is not going to happen,'' said one retail stock analyst of the transaction. He asked that his name not be used. If the deal falls through, the shares would be expected to fall further.
The agreement calls for Trefoil Capital Investors L.P., an affilate of Shamrock, to make the purchase. A spokesman for Trefoil said the company was ''proceeding with the acquisition,'' but he noted that there were a variety of terms and conditions that needed to be satisfied before it could be completed. He said Trefoil would not comment on the market activity.
Under the takeover agreement, Trefoil need not proceed if it is unable to arrange $230 million in working capital loans for the toy retailer, which says some of its problems this year have stemmed from low inventories. And the deal is contingent on the ''absence of any material adverse change in Child World's business'' after May 5.
Just how adverse that would have to be was not detailed. But Child World's financial results seem to have deteriorated, providing Trefoil with a possible out if it wants one. For the second fiscal quarter ended Aug. 4, the company reported a loss of $8.5 million, or 75 cents a share, compared with a loss of $5.1 million, or 45 cents a share, in the comparable period of 1989.
The company attributed the losses to ''competitive pricing, higher promotional markdowns, freight costs and increased advertising.''
For toy retailers, losses in three quarters, and heavy profits in the Christmas period, are to be expected. But Child World, which operates 176 stores in 31 states has found competing with Toys ''R'' Us, the industry giant, very difficult. Results have declined in recent years, with comparable store sales falling 4 percent last year, mostly in the Christmas season.
For the fiscal year ended Feb. 4, Child World reported a profit of $5.8 million, or 51 cents a share, less than half the profits of the previous year. With losses in the first half of the current fiscal year totaling $16 million, or $1.40 a share, compared with $10.3 million, or 90 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year, the company will do no better than break even this year if it matches last year's results for the rest of the fiscal year. With the economy appearing near recession, even that could be a difficult acheivement.
CNC Holding was formed when the Cole National Corporation was taken private in a 1987 leveraged buyout. Officials of CNC and Child World did not return phone calls seeking comment.
CNC, whose other operations include smaller retailers, has been having trouble of its own, with operating losses steadily climbing. It needs cash, especially because one series of ''junk bonds'' it issued as part of its buyout have just switched from accruing interest in more bonds to accruing it in cash. Without the Child World deal, the company's cash needs would be raised by $23 million a year, with the first payment due in March 1991.
If the deal goes through, CNC will hold on to the $147.5 million in bonds from Trefoil for only a few minutes before transferring them to the First Executive Corporation, a Los Angeles insurance holding company. In return, First Executive will cancel most of that CNC junk bond issue, which it holds.
First Executive will take a bit of a haircut, because the new bonds pay interest at a rate of just 10.07 percent, only part of it in cash, compared with 13 percent on the CNC bonds it is trading in. CNC will make up part of the difference in cash for a few months.
For Trefoil, the Child World acquisition offers an opportunity to buy a company with $830 million in sales for a relatively small down payment of $28 million. If it can turn the company around, profits could be substantial. The question is whether, with Child World profits now deteriorating, Trefoil will still be willing to take the chance.

HEADLINE: Caracas Asks U.S. to Help On Oil Output

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The President of Venezuela, citing an ''inevitability of confrontation'' in the Middle East, is urging the United States to invest in increased oil production in this South American nation, which holds the largest proven oil reserves outside the Middle East.
''Venezuela is the safe, sufficient and reliable bridge towards energy self-sufficiency for the Americas,'' Carlos Andres Perez said in an interview on Monday at the presidential palace here. ''With the Orinoco Belt, Venezuela has the second-largest oil reserves in the world, after Saudi Arabia.''
Venezuela's light-to-heavy reserves - those that are easily refined - are 59 billion barrels. But the Orinoco Belt, a 20,000-square-mile area north of the Orinoco River in eastern Venezuela, contains 270 billion barrels of extra-heavy bitumen oil, which is less economical to refine but is now being tapped with an experimental technology. A Leading Source for U.S. Venezuela has alternated with Saudi Arabia as a leading source of foreign oil for the United States, which buys two-thirds of Venezuela's production. To help the world market cope with the current oil crisis, Mr. Perez has ordered a 25 percent increase in production, to 2.5 million barrels a day, by December. 
But he said that with American private and public investment, he could almost double Venezuela's production capacity to five million barrels a day by the year 2000.
''Unfortunately, if the crisis in the Middle East explodes in a conflagration that damages the oil wells of the region, the energy crisis will convert into an energy catastrophe,'' Mr. Perez said. ''We can produce more, but we don't have the wells to pump out the oil.''
In contrast to Venezuela's ambitious expansion plans, Mexico, the other large exporter to the Americas, is experiencing a decline in output and is expected to become a net importer within 15 years.
''The hemisphere should see the oil problem with a strategic vision,'' said Mr. Perez, who plans to pursue his proposal on a visit to New York in 10 days.
Earlier this month, Venezuela's Minister of Energy and Mines, Celestino Armas, visited Washington and proposed to American officials and business executives the creation of ''a hemispheric strategic oil production capacity.''
 
U.S. Concerns Bought Out
In a change of policy, Mr. Armas encouraged American oil companies to invest in refining and production in his country, which has the lowest production costs of any nation in the Western Hemisphere. American oil companies operating in Venezuela were bought out in 1975 under a nationalization program.
With a tight budget in Washington, American officials have said they favor increasing Venezuelan production through private investment.
Talks to discuss the proposed plan have been hampered because of bureaucratic reasons in Washington. The United States has not had an ambassador accredited here since July 1989. Confirmation hearings for the new Ambassador-designate, Michael M. Skol, are to be held next week.
At the palace, Mr. Perez played down reports here that with oil prices almost tripling in three months, Venezuela had hit a jackpot. He estimated that his country would earn an extra $800 million this fall - money that would go to servicing foreign debt and for increasing oil production. The country's total foreign debt is around $34 billion.
 
No Discouts to Cuba
In recent days, Government officials have battled reports that international development banks are using high oil prices to justify reducing low-interest loans to Venezuela.
The President also ruled out selling oil at a discount to Cuba. Evidently lured by rising world oil prices, the Soviet Union said last month that it would cut by 20 percent its shipments of inexpensive oil to Cuba. In response, the Cuban Government announced last week the purchase of hundreds of thousands of bicycles to help Cubans get around without cars and buses.
''Even though Cuba is from our region, it does not share our system,'' said Mr. Perez, who heads one of Latin America's longest-running democracies.
Returning to his vision of oil-rich Venezuela guaranteeing the hemisphere's self-sufficiency in energy, Mr. Perez said his proposal was congruent with President Bush's plan for a hemispheric free-trade zone.
''With the creation of the European Common Market, of the Asian market around Japan, the United States needs an alliance with Latin America,'' Mr. Perez said. ''This is a market of 500 million people, with tremendous natural resources.''

LENGTH: 821 words

HEADLINE: Bribe Charges Backed As Northrop Era Ends

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Thomas V. Jones survived a foreign bribery scandal at the Northrop Corporation in the 1970's and went on to build the company into one of the nation's largest military contractors. Now he is retiring as chairman amid allegations that he may have presided over the payment of bribes by Northrop in the 1980's in an effort to sell a fighter jet in South Korea.
The company and Mr. Jones have denied all suggestions of wrongdoing. But on Wednesday, the day Northrop announced Mr. Jones's retirement at the age of 70, reports appeared that an international arbitration service had concluded that the company paid a Korean business executive $6.25 million to help influence the sale of the F-20 fighter plane. 
 
Arbitration at Company Behest
The arbitration was conducted by the International Chamber of Commerce at Northrop's behest and with the company's cooperation. Northrop has been seeking the return of the $6.25 million, which the company contends was intended to finance the construction of a hotel in Seoul as part of a proposal to reinvest in South Korea some profits from any F-20 sales.
The arbitration report concluded that the $6.25 million payment by Northrop in 1984 to C. K. Park, an executive with close ties to top Korean Government officials, was intended ''for the purpose of promoting the F-20 fighter plane, and not to finance a hotel project.'' The report went on to say that ''Northrop's highest management,'' including three vice presidents directly involved in the F-20 sales effort ''and probably Mr. Jones,'' knew of and approved the agreement with Mr. Park.
''This is not a situation where low-ranking officers colluded to defraud Northrop, but where Northrop acted, probably illegally, through its top management,'' said the report, written by Wolfgang Kuhn, a German lawyer who served as the arbitrator. The findings were first reported today by The Los Angeles Times and The Wall Street Journal.
Northrop's efforts to sell the F-20 in Korea have been under investigation for several years. There are two Federal grand juries looking into whether Northrop violated the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which bars payoffs to foreign officials. The matter is also being investigated by a House subcommittee headed by John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan.
 
Pledged in 1975 to Halt Payoffs
After allegations in the early 1970's that it had made improper payoffs to sell warplanes abroad, Northrop, with Mr. Jones as chairman, signed a consent decree with the Government in 1975, pledging not to make any further payoffs.
Mr. Jones also pleaded guilty in the early 1970's to a single felony count of making illegal contributions to Richard Nixon's 1972 re-election campaign. In recent years, Mr. Jones and his successor as chief executive and now chairman, Kent Kresa, have endured a series of investigations into other charges of wrongdoing by the company on a variety of military contracts. Earlier this year, Northrop pleaded guilty to 34 counts of failing to test parts for fighter jets and missiles and agreed to pay a $17 million fine.
Yet, in Mr. Jones's career at Northrop, which spanned 37 years, he built the company into one of the nation's premier technology companies, winning contracts for sophisticated weapons like the B-2 Stealth bomber. Mr. Jones stepped down as chief executive at the end of last year and has not been active in managing the company since then. Tony Cantafio, a spokesman for Northrop, said the announcement of Mr. Jones's resignation as chairman had been planned and had nothing to do with the arbitration findings.
 
Northrop Disagrees With Report
Mr. Cantafio said Northrop disagreed with the conclusions of the arbitrator's report. ''It's important to point out that the ruling makes no conclusion or finding to support widespread reports and allegations the company's investment in the hotel was to be used to make payments to Korean Government officials,'' Mr. Cantafio said.
Mr. Park, who died several years ago, was not a Korean Government official, although he was known to be a close associate of former President Chun Doo Hwan, whose administration considered buying the F-20 in the mid-1980's.
Mr. Cantafio said Northrop was continuing to pursue civil litigation in South Korea to force the return of the $6.25 million.
Northrop hired Mr. Park in 1983 as part of an effort to persuade South Korea to buy the F-20, a newly designed fighter that Northrop was struggling to sell both in the United States and abroad. The next year, Northrop agreed to create a joint venture with Mr. Park to build a hotel and office complex in Seoul in keeping with the common practice of reinvesting some of the proceeds from any sale into the local economy. But the complex was never built, and Northrop never sold any F-20's to South Korea.
Northrop eventually canceled the F-20 after the United States Air Force decided not to buy the plane.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Recession Ahead? The Views Vary

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS the United States entering a recession or isn't it? The sages, here and abroad, differ.
In his Congressional testimony this week, Alan Greenspan said the risks of recession had been increased by the confrontation in the Persian Gulf, but he still saw no downward tilt to the economy. And he said the Federal Reserve would not ease monetary policy until the Administration and Congress reached agreement on a long-term plan for cutting the Federal budget deficit.
The International Monetary Fund, on the eve of its and the World Bank's annual meetings, sounded more bullish this week than Mr. Greenspan. It said the United States would avoid a recession this year and growth would pick up in 1991. 
But, on the bearish side, 58 percent of the 50 economists and forecasting groups surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators predicted that a recession would start this year or in 1991. Robert J. Eggert, Blue Chip's editor, said that in the last two months its consensus forecast for growth in real gross national product in 1991 had declined to 1.2 percent, from 2.2 percent, one of the sharpest drops in the survey's 13-year history.
What explains the differences among these people who peer into the future? Not economic indicators or other facts and factoids available to all economists, but rather three other factors: semantics, assumptions and policy.
Mr. Greenspan's position that it was ''too soon to indicate'' whether the odds on recession are greater or less than 50-50 reflected both his semantics and policy. On the semantic side, he shied away from the ''conventional'' definition of a recession - two consecutive quarters of decline in real G.N.P. - suggesting that a more useful definition was that a recession is a decline so serious that it begins to feed on itself.
If the Blue Chip consensus forecast of 1.2 percent growth in 1991 is about right, and if the Fed essentially shares it, as it apparently does, that forecast could be consistent with a recession, defined as two quarters of negative growth. Such a recession could start, for instance, in the fourth quarter of this year, and last only through the first quarter of next year - or even through the first half of next year. But that would imply a recession that ''did not feed on itself,'' followed by a relatively good recovery in the second half of 1991. In Greenspanian semantics, that would be no real recession, so a recession is not yet in sight.
On the policy side, the chairman of the Fed has two concerns: one, to keep pressure on the Administration and Congress to deal with the budget deficit; two, not to relax monetary policy too soon, lest the markets regard this as an inflationary response to political pressures. That in turn might perversely raise interest rates and give the economy a double blow of higher inflation and lower growth. Cutting the budget deficit would reduce public claims on private savings, ease rates and set conditions in which the Fed could relax monetary policy without fear of pushing up inflation.
The major difference between the more cheerful forecast by the I.M.F. and the others lies in its assumption that the world oil price, now around $35 a barrel, will average $26 for the rest of this year and come down to $21 by the fourth quarter of 1991. This prognosis is based on the assumption that the four million barrels a day lost to the world oil market from Iraq and Kuwait will gradually be replaced by extra output from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other countries, as well as the further underlying assumption that there will be no war or greater loss of oil.
How good are these assumptions? They are certainly wishful. It is true that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has not changed its reference price of $21 a barrel that was in place before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and that an OPEC representative said last week in an interview in Antalya, Turkey, that OPEC still assumes the oil price for the coming year will stay in a range of $21 to $25 a barrel.
But that would represent a steep fall from present prices. Some analysts are making more cautious assumptions. Antonio Costa, special adviser to the president of the European Community, is assuming that oil prices will range from $23 to $27 a barrel during the next 18 months. That would mean, he said, a worldwide transfer of $160 billion to $170 billion in gross revenues from oil consumers to producers; net, after deducting the flowback of payments for higher imports, the increase would represent a shift of $95 billion to $110 billion from consumers to producers - a shock big enough to give the world a new monetary recycling problem. Mr. Costa's estimate assumes a stalemate, rather than a worsening conflict, in the gulf.
Even on relatively hopeful assumptions, however, the gulf crisis, as long as it lasts, will mean somewhat higher inflation, somewhat slower growth and higher unemployment for the United States and the world economy. Policy will counteract those effects but is unlikely to eliminate them.

HEADLINE: Oil Aid Plans By the I.M.F.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The head of the International Monetary Fund predicted today that his 152-nation organization would back United States-led efforts to provide financial assistance to countries hurt by the Persian Gulf turmoil.
The I.M.F. managing director, Michel Camdessus, said his agency was exploring a variety of ways to provide financial assistance, including a plan to obtain voluntary donations to recycle higher oil profits back to nations hurt by the rise in energy prices. 
Mr. Camdessus's comments provide backing for the Bush Administration's plan to enlist both the I.M.F. and its sister lending organization, the World Bank, to provide financial help for countries being harmed by the trade embargo against Iraq.
The Administration is counting on the embargo to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. But there is concern that the embargo could fall victim to widespread cheating unless nations harmed by the loss of markets or other economic fallout are adequately compensated.
Finance officials gathered today for the start of a week of discussions as part of the annual meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank. The finance leaders were expected to review a wide range of topics, from the faltering Soviet economy to the $1.3 trillion debt burden being carried by third world nations.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
2 Named to Succeed Top SCEcorp Officer

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
SCEcorp, the parent of the Southern California Edison Company, yesterday named two successors to fill the shoes of Howard P. Allen, who is retiring as chairman, chief executive and president after 10 years at the helm of one of the nation's largest utilities.
The board elected John E. Bryson, a former state regulator, to be chairman and chief executive. He won out for the top posts over Michael R. Peevey, who received the No. 2 spot as president. Both men have been executive vice presidents. 
Mr. Allen, who turns 65 in October, remains as chairman of the board's executive committee.
Mr. Bryson, 47 years old, who is currently executive vice president and chief financial officer, joined the company in 1984 from the law firm of Morrison & Foerster in San Francisco.
From 1979 to 1982 he was president of the California Public Utilities Commission, which regulates the state's gas, electric, telephone and water utilities. Before that, for nearly three years he was chairman of the California State Water Resources Control Board, which is responsible for water rights and water quality.
Mr. Peevey, 52, joined the utility in 1984 as vice president, overseeing the revenue and governmental affairs departments. Before he joined the utility, he co-founded and served for 11 years as president of the California Council for Environmental and Economic Balance, an environmental group. Earlier, he was director of research for the California Labor Federation, A.F.L.-C.I.O., and coordinator of community programs for the Institute of Industrial Relations at the University of California, Berkeley.
SCEcorp, based in Rosemead, Calif., serves four million customers through its Southern California Edison unit in Southern and central California.
Under Mr. Allen, the utility experienced solid growth. He has been trying to make it the largest investor-owned utility in the United States by merging with the San Diego Gas and Electric Company. The $2.5 billion merger, first announced in late 1988 and opposed by the state's Attorney General, must still win approval by state and Federal regulators.
The company has also diversified into nonregulated businesses that include co-generation plants, land development and electrical construction.
Mr. Allen, a 37-year employee of the company, was known for a close eye for detail. The company biography says he demands cleanliness for Edison trucks and plants and insists that employee uniforms ''convey professionalism.''
Mr. Bryson is a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Stanford University and received his law degree at Yale University. Mr. Peevey received undergraduate and master's degrees in economics from the University of California, Berkeley.

HEADLINE: Oil Price Rise Gives Algeria a $1 Billion Windfall

BYLINE: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALGIERS

 BODY:
The sharp increase in the price of crude oil has meant a projected windfall of $1 billion for Algeria at a time when the nation is suffering from economic turmoil, social tension and a pressing foreign debt.
Algeria is neutral in the Persian Gulf conflict, opposing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and also the Western military presence in the gulf, and the Government of President Chadli Benjedid says its political stance is not economically driven.
Algeria, with a population of 25 million, is one of the few large and populous Arab countries to have oil. Because Algeria has been producing at full capacity, its economy is more sensitive to price fluctuations than the Persian Gulf producers that have small populations and large reserves. 
 
Opposed Rise in Output
Inside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, before the Iraqi invasion, Algeria tended to agree with Iraq against Saudi Arabia and Kuwait that the world price of oil was too low. Later, Algeria was part of the OPEC majority that rejected Saudi calls to increase production to make up for embargoed Iraqi and Kuwaiti supply and lower prices.
After averaging $18 a barrel this year, crude oil has risen to more than $33 a barrel following the invasion of Kuwait. Algeria can use the money. Its economy has been in disarray since the mid-1980's, when falling world oil prices halved its income.
According to the Algerian central bank, the country earned an estimated $9.1 billion in oil and gas exports last year, well below the $13.7 billion earned in 1980, especially when the drop in the dollar is taken into account. Oil is paid for in dollars.
The $1 billion windfall on top of a projected $10.1 billion in earnings this year is based on oil selling at an average of $25 a barrel to the end of the year, officials said. The windfall would be even greater were it not that gas prices, though related to oil prices, do not increase as fast. Nearly 60 percent of Algeria's oil-related exports are in gas - in liquid, natural and petroleum forms.
The United States took $1.9 billion of Algeria's exports last year, most of it in liquid natural gas for East Coast heating. Algeria bought $900 million in goods from the United States, mostly in grains and industrial products. The bulk of Algeria's trade is with the European Community. $24 Billion Debt Officials said they hoped that the windfall would aid in overhauling a $24 billion foreign debt, 70 percent of which matures by 1993. The burden is such that the Economics Ministry had designated three-quarters of this year's oil earnings for debt service, leaving little for badly needed industrial and consumer goods.
Loath to formally reschedule its debt for fear its credit rating may be damaged, the Government is negotiating with a consortium of American and French banks to lengthen repayment periods, in part through a novel plan in which the French Government in July agreed to help guarantee the refinancing of $1 billion to $2 billion with zero-coupon bonds.
Bankers had been resisting Algerian overtures, but the windfall eases Algeria's cash flow and will bolster lender confidence, a European banker said in an interview.
Algeria faces a more fundamental problem - a heavily state-run and inefficient economy gone awry. The death knell to the system was sounded two years ago when hundreds of people were killed here in riots touched off by shortages of food and consumer goods and an unemployment rate that still runs officially at 24 percent. State factories are running at 10 percent to 60 percent of capacity, Algerian analysts said.
 
Wildcat Strikes
A lack of financing, demand and management led to such debacles in recent months as a shortage of bottled lemonade, because the bottling plant ran out bottles. Wildcat strikes have become common, and even the Foreign Ministry has been paralyzed in recent weeks by 700 employees who walked out in a demand for higher wages.
An Islamic fundamentalist party, the Islamic Salvation Front, capitalized on discontent to win 54 percent of the vote in local elections in June, the first open elections to be held since the ruling National Liberation Front took power in 1963.
The fundamentalists, who say they uphold free market principles, are well positioned to win parliamentary elections next year, but aging leaders from the ruling party still uphold the revolutionary socialism of the 1960's.
Officials in the more technocratically oriented Government say they have been forced to move piecemeal to introduce decentralization and what they hope will be eventual privatization. About 300 of the state's 450 companies have been made autonomous, meaning that they must find their own supplies, sales and financing. But the Government still imposes high hiring quotas.
Even officials concede that the prescription is a formula for bankruptcy for all but the healthiest companies, but they say it is the only way they can winnow the state sector.

HEADLINE: Mexico-Chile Trade Accord

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Mexico and Chile will sign a free trade agreement next month, advancing President Bush's aim to form a continentwide zone that can compete with European and East Asian trade blocs, senior officials of both countries said yesterday.
 
President Carlos Salinas de
Gortari of Mexico and President Patricio Aylwin of Chile will meet in Mexico on Oct. 4 to sign the pact, the officials said after a meeting at Mexico's trade offices in New York. 
Jaime Serra, Mexico's Secretary of Trade and Industry, and Alejandro Foxley, Chile's Finance Minister, announced the deal, which is intended to increase the flow of commerce between the two nations, reduce tariffs on imports and eventually eliminate all trade barriers.
If successful, it would go beyond previous pacts, which have been limited to particular goods, not trade in general.
The United States and Mexico hope to reach a similar accord by the end of next year.
 
Mr. Serra said trade between
Mexico and Chile was currently very small but added, ''The potential is tremendous.''
He called the two nations' economies ''complementary,'' noting that Mexico's chief export to Chile was cars, while Chile's main export to Mexico was agricultural goods.

HEADLINE: Policing Japan's Banks Is a Matter of Persuasion

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
The deep problems afflicting the Federal fund that insures deposits at banks and savings and loan associations in the United States may look dire to Americans, but to the Japanese, they are incomprehensible.
The Government here relies on secretive and informal methods for managing problem banks, and they are so effective that most Japanese do not even know there is a deposit insurance system. In fact, the main bank deposit insurance fund has never been tapped, and a smaller fund for credit unions and smaller institutions has been used only once.
''The fact that we've never used the main fund does not mean we don't have troubled institutions,'' an official of the Bank of Japan said. ''But we handle them with means other than our insurance fund.'' 
 
Extralegal Measures
The contrast with the United States reflects one of the least known but more important examples of the extralegal measures used to govern the financial system here, where ''guidance'' done in private replaces open regulatory actions and legal action.
Effective as that system has been in the past, it is likely to be tested by the deregulation of Japan's financial system. The Japanese banking system is undergoing major shifts, albeit at a glacial pace, with interest rates increasingly determined by market forces, protective barriers coming down and banks pursuing a wider variety of businesses.
Economists and Government officials generally agree that the increased competition resulting from these changes will force some Japanese instutitions, particularly vulnerable smaller ones, to close or merge.
The record of Japanese regulators in dealing with troubled banks is barely known because they handle few cases, and those they do are often kept secret. The deposit insurance fund is thus very small and its principal function seems to be putting out a financial statement every year showing how the assets have increased.
 
A Modest Fund
The main fund's assets of 513 billion yen, or $3.66 billion at recent exchange rates, total a modest one-tenth of 1 percent of insured deposits. That is the highest ratio ever, and double the ratio of eight years ago, but it is one-tenth the ratio in the United States in 1987, when the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was at its peak, with $18.3 billion in assets.
The emphasis at the central bank and the Finance Ministry has been on preventive regulation. They aim to find problems before an institution collapses. Then - and this is the largest difference from the American system - they use informal means to prod ailing institutions toward help. There are no court battles and usually no public hearings.
''We basically don't feel enforcement of our findings should be handled with legal measures,'' said Makoto Fukuda, head of the small bank division at the Ministry of Finance, where most problems are dealt with. ''We lead management to come to the same conclusions as us.''
''Of course,'' Mr. Fukuda added, ''some won't listen to us. We would then have to take time to persuade them.''
 
Means of Persuasion
Solutions, he said, range from lowering managers' salaries to replacing them, bringing in managers from a stronger financial institution, persuading other financial institutions in the region to provide financial help in the form of low-interest deposits and, if the problems are serious enough, forcing a merger with a stronger institution. In such cases, the Government and other banks provide financial aid.
Usually a regional association to which the sick institution belongs will dip into a private ''mutual assistance fund'' and provide enough low-interest deposits to tide it over, Mr. Fukuda said. If a merger is required, the partner usually comes from this regional grouping.
When a healthy institution helps bail out a sick one, it will receive favorable consideration for profitable Government business or tax breaks later - in other words, completely informal, extralegal measures.
What is making some people here worry is whether such a system will perform well under the rigors of the 1990's. The real estate market, upon which an immense number of loans are based, is weakening. Moody's, the American credit rating agency, has reduced the ratings of several major banks and trust banks because of concerns over their future profitability.
 
Finding Merger Partners
Akio Mikuni, president of Mikuni & Company, the only independent credit rating agency in Japan, said his principal concern was that as profits get squeezed, it would become increasingly difficult for the regulators to find willing merger partners for troubled banks. The only alternative will be to start tapping the deposit insurance fund, or providing even greater forms of informal financial assistance to the healthy banks.
Others worry that tumbling real estate prices could cause severe problems, as happened in the United States. But Yukio Noguchi, a leading expert on the property market and a critic of Government land policies, said even in his worst-case scenario - a decline in land prices of 15 percent annually for three years - the financial and deposit insurance system would remain sound.
''We have been brainstorming on what future measures we may need to take,'' said Mr. Fukuda, the Government banking official. ''Right now, we have no need for a bailout plan, but that doesn't mean we're relaxed. It's a possibility.''

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); JAPAN (94%);

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Fall in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped and interest rates rose in sluggish trading yesterday, as credit market participants sold notes and bonds because of a jump in oil prices.
But traders said the price dip was not significant, adding that many of the participants were observing the Jewish New Year.
''Trading is certainly lighter than your average Thursday,'' a government bond trader said. ''The market is just lethargic.'' 
Largely overlooked was news that the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, had suggested that a contentious proposal to cut the capital gains tax rate be taken off the table in the tortuous budget negotiations. But analysts said Mr. Dole's proposal, if agreed to, could break open the deadlocked talks.
 
Value of Swift Accord
Removing the capital gains proposal ''would increase dramatically the chances of an early budget accord,'' said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a firm in Princeton, N.J., that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and fixed-income markets.
''And the sooner we get a budget deal, the sooner the Federal Reserve will be in a position to ease interest rates,'' Mr. Stone added. ''I think the Dole proposal is good news, but the market didn't react to it.''
Aside from responding to the sharp rise in oil prices, an auction of one-year Treasury bills was the highlight of yesterday's session.
At the auction, the bills were sold at an average discounted rate of 7.25 percent, down from an average rate of 7.40 percent at the last one-year bill auction on Aug. 23. It is the lowest rate on a one-year bill since the auction on Jan. 11.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 97 2/32 late yesterday, down by 11/ 32, to yield 9.03 percent, compared with a yield of 9 percent late on Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 3/32, down by an eighth of a point, to yield 8.88 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 29/32, down by 2/32, to yield 8.51 percent.
 
Four-Year Notes at 8.40%
The new four-year Treasury notes to be auctioned next Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.40 percent. And the new two-year notes to be auctioned next Tuesday were offered at a price to yield 8.04 percent in when-issued trading.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.37 percent, up by a basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late-offered rate of 7.30 percent.
Indications that the Chase Manhattan Bank is having financing difficulties were not to be found in Federal Reserve data released late yesterday. Rumors that Chase was having such problems swirled through financial markets earlier in the week.
In its report, the Fed said that borrowings by eight top New York City banks at its discount window averaged $76 million each day for the week that ended on Sept. 12. By comparison, the average daily borrowings for all banks was $974 million during the period.
Although the Fed does not break down borrowings data by institution, a sharp rise in discount window borrowings by the New York City banks would have provided evidence of a financing problem, since the Fed is the lender of last resort for banks that are in trouble.
Besides the borrowings numbers, the Fed reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week that ended on Sept. 10. The third, largest measure, M-3, fell by $3.4 billion.
The money supply report had no effect on prices in the credit markets.
 
Dillard Prices Debt
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Dillard Department Stores Inc. priced a $50 million offering of seven-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 9 5/8 percent notes, which mature on Sept. 15, 1997, were priced at $99.42 to yield 9.74 percent, 95 basis points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary market for corporate bonds was light, the dealers said. The prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most widely quoted issues fell by an eighth of a point to a quarter of a point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher In Volatile but Thin Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar mostly gained ground yesterday in light but volatile trading on world currency markets.
Traders said currencies changed hands in violent spurts that were driven by rumors. Speculation that Japan was about to raise interest rates sent ''people rushing to buy yen for the high-yield attraction,'' said Gilbert Cisneros, a trader at the Bank of Boston's New York office. 
But when the rumor fizzled, traders ''got caught short and dumped yen to buy dollars,'' he said.
Still, much of the day's activity centered on currencies other than the dollar. Lou Calvello, a trader with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said there was a wave of buying of the German mark at the expense of the Japanese yen.
Dealers continued to monitor the price of oil, which jumped to record levels. Recession worries erupted as the price of crude touched $35 a barrel before settling back somewhat.
Over all, activity in the currency markets was light ahead of the meeting tomorrow in Washington of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrial nations. Traders said the meeting could provide direction for the currency markets if the ministers issue a statement about the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 137.05 Japanese yen from 138.05 yen at Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar fell to 136.92 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 137.65 yen, down from 137.68 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8690, from $1.8855 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.8740 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.8833.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.5773 German marks, up from 1.5730; 1.3210 Swiss francs, up from 1.3105; 5.2815 French francs, up from 5.2670; 1,176.75 Italian lire, up from 1,175.00, and 1.1543 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1563.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.5795 German marks, up from 1.5680; 1.3195 Swiss francs, up from 1.3055; 5.2880 French francs, up from 5.2515; 1.7807 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7670; 1,177.75 Italian lire, up from 1,172.50, and 1.1545 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1575.

HEADLINE: New Bush Tone on Capital Gains Hints at a Budget Compromise

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
As Congressional and Administration budget negotiators wrestled with an impasse over cutting the capital gains tax rate, President Bush pointedly avoided criticizing a suggestion by the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, that the tax cut be severed from the budget package.
Mr. Bush's conciliatory tone in remarks to reporters on the White House lawn contrasted with his demand in a speech to Congress 10 days ago that any budget compromise include a decrease in the tax rate for capital gains.
On Thursday, White House officials rejected Mr. Dole's suggestion that Congress be allowed to vote separately on the tax proposal, along with other measures that would result in reduced revenue or increased spending.
 
Careful Bush Response
Today, the President said he did not want to be considered ''soft on capital gains,'' then refused an opportunity to state Administration opposition to the Dole plan. He said: ''Well, I want to get capital gains. I'm not endorsing the Dole suggestion, nor would I be -would it be appropriate for me to criticize it.'' 
''Look, we're down to the wire, and I believe that's all being discussed right now,'' he said, referring to the high-level budget negotiations. ''Bob Dole is trying to be helpful and trying to get this impasse broken.''
This small break in White House insistence came after the top five Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders and senior Administration officials have spent the last four days in private sessions looking for a way to reconcile Mr. Bush's desire for a cut in the gains rate with Democratic insistence that the cut be offest by higher income tax rates for the wealthy.
While other spending and budget process issues still divide the negotiators, the capital gains tax has become the main point of dispute in the four-month effort to slash $50 billion from the deficit in 1991 and $500 billion over the next five years. Democratic Congressional leaders are drafting a stopgap spending bill that could delay severe cuts in Federal spending beyond the Oct. 1 deadline while negotiations on what to do about taxing capital gains continue.
To some Democrats, it appeared that Mr. Dole's attempt to break the logjam might strengthen the hand of Richard G. Darman, the budget director.
People who have sat through the meetings sense that there is a split between Mr. Darman and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, on the capital gains issue. Mr. Sununu appears to believe that a cut in the capital gains rate is critical to the economy and to the Bush Presidency, while Mr. Darman is believed to think that the issue is not worth putting an overall budget agreement at risk.
The third Administration official in the talks, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, the one who is personally closest to the President, has been tightlipped on where he would come out in a contest between a gains cut or no agreement at all during the negotiations. Even many of Mr. Brady's closest aides are uncertain about where he stands on the matter because he rarely shares with them the advice he is giving the President.
Under Mr. Dole's proposal, the House and Senate would take separate votes on a package of deficit-reducing measures and a second package that included tax-cutting or new spending measures along with whatever means the two parties might recommend to pay for them. Mr. Dole today refined the proposal slightly to say that the two votes would be tied: if on final passage the package including the gains cut was defeated, the deficit reduction package would be considered defeated as well.
 
Approaching Deadlines
Although a number of Democratic negotiators have privately said they find Mr. Dole's suggestion appealing, their public comments about it today were cautious.
The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said it was ''worth exploring,'' and the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, referred to it as ''a creative idea'' at a time when the stalled budget talks need all the new ideas they can get.
While Mr. Gephardt said the negotiators had not imposed any deadlines on their deliberations, a series of deadlines that may finally force action on the budget are beginning to close in. The most pressing is Oct. 1, the start of the Government's new fiscal year.
That is the date when, without the 13 yearly spending bills that finance the operations of the Government, the Government will not have money for its operations unless Congress passes a stopgap spending bill.
It is also the date that some $85 billion in automatic spending cuts required by the balanced-budget law will take effect unless lawmakers can agree on their own budget.
On Oct. 2, temporary legislation that gives the Government authority to keep borrowing is due to expire, and Congress would have to raise the debt limit to let the Treasury sell bonds in the financial markets. Social Security checks, which are mailed out on Oct. 3, are not exempt from the automatic spending cuts, but would be worthless if the Government did not have enough cash on hand to cover them.
As of late today, Congressional leaders had not decided if a stopgap spending measure would include a delay in the automatic spending cuts. Mr. Bush has threatened to veto such a spending bill if it is sent to him before there is a budget agreement.
Some Democratic strategists believe they could muster enough votes to override that veto, particularly if the stopgap bill includes an extension of the debt limit and money the Administration is seeking for military operations in the Persian Gulf.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 26, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Bush Administration reaction to a budget compromise proposal by Senator Bob Dole referred incorrectly to Social Security checks. The checks are exempt from automatic spending cuts under the budget-balancing law.

HEADLINE: CHASE MANHATTAN TO CUT 5,000 JOBS AND TRIM DIVIDEND

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
In a telling new sign of the problems afflicting the nation's banks, the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $1 billion charge against earnings and reduce its work force by 5,000 employees. The nation's second-largest bank also took the unusual and humbling step of cutting its stock dividend by more than 50 percent as part of a drive to rebuild its financial strength.
The $1 billion charge is to cover mounting loan losses - mainly for real-estate deals - and the cost of paring employees. The charge will be subtracted from gross earnings for the three months ending Sept. 30 and should result in a loss for the quarter of about $625 million, the bank said.
Chase's actions are part of a broad cost-cutting trend in the troubled banking industry. Earlier this year, for example, Chemical Bank, one of Chase's long-time New York rivals, moved to eliminate 1,100 jobs to pare its annual costs by $60 million. Manufacturers Hanover has also announced plans to cut 1,400 workers. 
 
Bank Strength Eroding
The strength of many of the nation's major banks has eroded in the last decade because of a decline in their lending practice, as big customers realized they could borrow money more cheaply on Wall Street than from banks. They have also suffered a persistent hangover from bad loans to developing countries made during the 1970's and early 1980's.
More recently, a weakening economy and slumping real-estate prices in many regions have been adding to the damage, hurting even those banks that were previously healthy.
At Chase, the bulk of the $1 billion charge - $650 million - will be set aside to cushion the bank against growing loan losses, largely from poor real-estate deals. The remaining $350 million is the estimated cost of trimming the work force and making other changes that Chase says will cut its costs by $300 million next year.
Chase's move may encourage other banks to act more boldly in increasing reserves to protect themselves against questionable loans, Wall Street analysts said.
''This just increases the likelihood that other banks will step up to the plate,'' said James J. McDermott Jr., a banking industry analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. ''We also expect more dividend cuts.''
In other moves yesterday, the Midlantic Corporation of Edison, N.J., said it would add $285 million to its reserves for bad loans, cutting its quarterly dividend to 25 cents, from 47 cents, and projecting a third-quarter net loss of up to $160 million.
 
Move by Southeast Banking
And the Southeast Banking Corporation of Miami said it would increase loan-loss provisions by $115 million, eliminating its 10-cent quarterly dividend, and projecting a $87 million loss for the third quarter.
Chase also said yesterday that the blow to its third-quarter earnings would be softened by a a $117 million profit on the sale last week of its office in Frankfurt.
Chase's planned employee reductions, which amount to a 12 percent cut in the work force, were far larger than the 3,000 estimated by analysts in June, when the bank first announced its cost-cutting goals. The company said 3,400 would be from its domestic work force, including 1,600 who have already resigned under a voluntary severance program.
But the bank emphasized its commitment to expanding its profitable consumer banking business, which accounts for the majority of its 20,000 employees in the New York area. About 5,000 employees in Chase's computer operations are scheduled to move from Manhattan to Brooklyn upon completion of the Metrotech project there in 1994, jobs the bank agreed to keep in New York in exchange for $235 million in tax breaks and energy subsidies.
Chase said that despite the huge write-offs, it would end the third quarter with $11.1 billion in capital. That would be enough to meet new regulatory guidelines covering capital-to-debt ratios, which are measures of the solidity of banks, for the end of 1992. The bank, which had net income of $96 million for the first six months of this year, also said it planned to improve capital ratios further.
''This was a bold step to get out in front of all of the issues facing us,'' said Thomas G. Labreque, Chase's president and chief operating officer. Mr. Labreque has taken the lead in the bank's restructuring efforts since being named to succeed Willard C. Butcher as chairman and chief executive next month.
Wall Street was dismayed by the size of the third-quarter loan-loss provisions, which Chase attributed to the deteriorating market for commercial real estate. The bank expects delinquent domestic loans, on which no interest is being paid, to jump 20 percent in the current quarter, to $2.5 billion. It expects to write off $65 million in commercial real-estate loans in the quarter, up from $21 million in the second quarter.
Chase's latest move to bolster reserves follows a similar action in last year's third quarter, when the bank took a $1.1 billion loss. The loss stemmed from an increase of $1.15 billion in its reserves for losses on loans to third world countries, along with about $110 million in write-offs for bad real-estate loans in Arizona.
 
Shares Down $1, to $12.75
Chase's shares fell $1, to $12.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, with analysts expressing doubts that the bank could finish 1990 strongly enough to report a profit for the year.
But analysts praised the thrust of the bank's plans.
''They had to come out swinging and they did,'' said Mr. McDermott of Keefe, Bruyette. Mr. McDermott and other analysts said there had been rumors on Wall Street in recent days that other bankers were so worried about Chase's financial condition that the bank had found it difficult to meet routine funding needs.
Mr. Labreque said Chase had no projection for when it might reverse its dividend cut, which will drop the quarterly payout to 30 cents a share, from 62 cents. The dividend cut, along with additional sales of property and other assets, the use of $750 million in tax benefits, and earnings, are all expected to help rebuild capital ratios. Such policies are expected to allow the bank to gain approval to underwrite the sale of equities, which the Federal Reserve this week indicated that banks would be able to do for the first time in nearly 60 years.
Chase said it expected that the slump in the domestic real-estate market would continue and would force it to set aside more money in the future to cover losses in its loan portfolio, but it projects that the additional money would be no more than $200 million in the fourth quarter. As a result, the bank expects to report a net profit in the quarter of at least $140 million.
''This should put an end to the rumors about their having trouble getting funding,'' said Frank DeSantis, of Paine Webber.
Most of the $350 million charge for the reorganization will finance the work force reductions, which are expected to provide about $225 million of the $300 million in annual operating savings. But the bank will also be taking charges to dispose of low-yielding tax-exempt municipal loans, packages of residential mortgage loans and some foreign securities.
The new additions to loan-loss reserves will bring Chase's total at the end of the third quarter to about $2.9 billion, or 3.8 percent of all outstanding loans. More than half the reserves, or $1.6 billion, have been set aside against longstanding problem loans to developing nations. Excluding cross-border lending, Chase's reserve to loan ratio is 1.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Rinfret, Denouncing Republican Leaders, Vows to Stay in Race

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
Vowing to continue his campaign for governor of New York but to turn it into a populist struggle, the Republican candidate, Pierre A. Rinfret, yesterday turned on the party leaders who had nominated him and accused them of being interested only in their own political fortunes.
Mr. Rinfret lashed out at the State Senate's Republican leaders, saying they were ''in bed'' with his opponent, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and were leading the state to ''fiscal disaster.''
His wrath spared few. He called State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Manhattan Republican leader who had recruited him, ''one of the most destructive people in the state.'' 
He said that the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, was ''in bed with Cuomo'' and that Senator Guy J. Velella, the Bronx Republican leader and chairman of the State Senate Republican Campaign Committee, was ''one of the most dangerous people in the state.''
Later, at a news conference of his own, Senator Goodman speculated that Mr. Rinfret was suffering from ''mental exhaustion and fatigue.''
''The tension and fatigue of the campaign have evidently caused our candidate to say things which, on reflection, I feel sure he will wish to modify,'' Mr. Goodman said, adding: ''I'm concerned about him. I want very much for him to take off a long weekend and get some rest, and I say that most seriously.''
Mr. Rinfret, ending three days of suspense over whether he would continue his campaign, told a crowded news conference at his Manhattan headquarters that Republican leaders were ''sabotaging'' his campaign. He had unsuccessfully sought their commitment to raise $1 million for his stumbling campaign.
''They are not interested in the party winning,'' he said. ''They want me to lose because I'm going to upset their apple cart.''
He added, ''Self-styled leaders of the Republican Party turned their backs on New York and turned their backs on me.'' Several Republicans noted the similarity of Mr. Rinfret's tactics to the unorthodox and winning strategy of John R. Silber, the president of Boston University, in the Massachusetts Democratic gubernatorial primary this week.
 
'War on the Geritol Set'
Mr. Rinfret, a 66-year-old economist, said that he was ''declaring war on the Geritol set,'' a reference, he said, to the long service of Senators Marino, Goodman and Velella, who are all younger than he.
A millionaire, Mr. Rinfret contributed $540,000 to his campaign, a commitment he made to Republican leaders as a condition of his nomination, but he said yesterday that he had spent only about $100,000 of that money.
Typical of his often confusing and contradictory statements at the news conference, Mr. Rinfret said at one point that he might spend ''a couple of million'' and at another point, ''we'll play it by ear.''
''I'm in this race until Mario Cuomo and the politicians, Democrat or Republican, who are destroying this state are put out of business,'' he declared, reading from a statement.
 
Concern for Republican Senate
State Senate Republican leaders and aides expressed confidence that Mr. Rinfret's break with the party would not affect their effort to retain a State Senate majority in the face of the most determined Democratic challenge in many years. Other Republican politicians were not so sure.
Mr. Rinfret's running mates remained loyal to the party. The nominee for lieutenant governor, George F. T. Yancey Jr., a cheese manufacturer from Wayne County, said he shared Mr. Rinfret's frustrations over the lack of party support but added, ''I'm not going to build any walls between myself and the party leaders.''
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the only Republican holding statewide office, said he was ''totally disassociating myself from the name-calling and the personal attacks.'' He added that Mr. Rinfret ''ought to stick to the issues.''
Bernard C. Smith, a former State Senator from Northport, L.I., who is the Republican candidate for attorney general, could not be reached for comment. He is recuperating from an injury suffered in a fall from a ladder.
Democrats kept discreetly silent yesterday, giving the Republicans every opportunity to batter each other.
Mr. Rinfret said that Senators Marino, Goodman and Velella were ''sitting on three and a quarter million dollars'' in campaign funds and had given him nothing but a $7,000 donation from Mr. Goodman.
The Republican State Committee says it is $1 million in debt. The State Senate Campaign Committee has $1.2 million on hand, and Senator Goodman has at least $1 million available in Manhattan Republican and State Senate campaign funds. Both men contended that their funds were needed for other Republican campaigns.
In response to Mr. Rinfret's accusations, the Republican leaders generally turned the other cheek yesterday and at least publicly said they would continue to support him.
 
Marino Says 'Very Bizarre'
But Senator Marino called Mr. Rinfret's actions ''very bizarre'' and said the candidate's allegations of collusion between the State Senate Republicans and Mr. Cuomo were ''utter nonsense.'' ''He's just looking for an issue,'' Mr. Marino added. Senator Velella said that when Mr. Rinfret asked for $950,000 from the Senate Campaign Committee, the candidate warned him, ''Don't come back with an offer of $200,000 or 300,000 dollars.'' He said Mr. Rinfret was now throwing ''a temper tantrum.''
Mr. Rinfret had asked leading Republicans to meet with him yesterday to discuss his campaign finances, but J. Patrick Barrett, the Republican state chairman, said that such a meeting was ''inappropriate.''
Mr. Rinfret's criticism of Republican leaders isolated his campaign from the party even more than it had been. It had already taken on aspects of a mom-and-pop operation, with the candidate, his wife, daughter and son working at the headquarters at 575 Lexington Avenue. Mr. Rinfret is also working with Eddie Mahe, who is a Washington political consultant, and half a dozen other professionals not identified with the state Republican Party.
Mr. Rinfret's campaign manager, Assemblyman John Faso, and two press aides, Bryan Flood and Kelly Naioti, resigned this week to protest Mr. Rinfret's attacks on the party.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Bush to Revise Proposal to Sell Arms to Saudis

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Bowing to Congressional pressure, the White House today modified its plans to sell $21 billion in arms to Saudi Arabia and said it would present the package to Congress in stages, with the largest part deferred until next year.
The White House did not say how the sale would be divided. But officials familiar with the package said the first portion, to be submitted to Congress next week, was valued at $5 billion to $8 billion and would include thousands of trucks and TOW antitank missiles. The most controversial weapons included in the deal, F-15 fighter planes and M-1 tanks, would be transferred in the second stage, the officials said. 
 
Bush Makes an Appeal
In Baghdad, the Iraqi leadership issued its most bellicose statement to date in the Persian Gulf crisis, urging citizens to prepare for ''the mother of all battles'' and saying there was ''not a single chance for any retreat'' by Iraq. It also announced retaliatory expulsions of diplomats from the United States, Western Europe and Egypt. Washington responded by expelling Iraqi diplomats. [Page 4.] Apparently embarrassed by the political uproar over the weapons package, President Bush made a strong plea for what would be the largest arms sale to Saudi Arabia in history. The Saudi purchase has drawn criticism from members of Congress who fear that it would seriously erode Israel's military edge in the region.
The President said that meeting ''Saudi Arabia's legitimate defense requirements'' was essential.
The Saudi Ambassador to Washington, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, said that splitting the arms package into two parts posed no problems for Riyadh. ''We get this phase this week and we'll have another phase in the future,'' the Prince said. ''Overall, we're very happy with the way things are going.''
In a carefully worded statement this evening, the White House sought to put the best face on its compromise on the Saudi arms sale.
''Following consultations with the Saudi Government and the Congress, the Administration has determined that is in the interest of the United States to provide Saudi Arabia with additional means to defend itself,'' the statement said. ''Following our consultations with Congress, we will provide this assistance in phases.''
The White House also sought to reassure Saudi Arabia that the change in plans did not represent any diminishing of Washington's commitment to defending the kingdom against Iraq.
 
Termed Part of Strategy
''The United States has a close and valued relationship with its longtime friend Saudi Arabia,'' the statement said, adding that the arms sale ''constitutes a key dimension of our overall strategy toward the Persian Gulf and could serve as well to protect American lives.''
Saudi Arabia could go to another supplier if the United States does not meet its armament needs. In 1985, when Congressional opposition forced the Reagan Administration to withdraw a proposed sale of F-15 fighter planes to the kingdom, Riyadh ended up buying British-made Tornado warplanes.
A spokesman for the Saudi Government in Washington, Fred Dutton, said earlier today that Riyadh preferred to buy its arms from the United States, but would approach other countries if the Administration was forced to back off from the proposed deal.
''If they can't get what they want here, they'll have to go elsewhere, and will,'' Mr. Dutton said.
 
Reservations on Future Sales
Lawmakers who had criticized the Administration's handling of the Saudi deal said the emergency package would meet little if any opposition on Capitol Hill, but that any future sale of advanced weaponry would require thorough study.
''I still have serious questions about the second part of this package,'' said Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California.
Despite his comment this week that Iraq had brought the region to ''the brink of war,'' Mr. Bush said before leaving for a weekend at Camp David that he still hoped for a peaceful resolution of the crisis in the Persian Gulf.
The President told reporters on the White House lawn that he did not intend to send a signal that he was ''shifting more toward the military'' and away from economic sanctions in his effort to force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to pull his forces out of Kuwait.
But he declined to make a commitment not to start a war.
''I'm not making any commitments,'' Mr. Bush said. ''There are so many contingencies. I've spelled them out. The treatment of American citizens is one thing that concerns me greatly. The possible use of terror is another.''
 
Reports on Terrorists
Reports that Abu Nidal and several other well-known terrorists are now operating out of Baghdad were discussed at a meeting between the President and Congressional leaders this morning. Mr. Bush said he had told the leaders that ''Iraqi support for terrorism would indeed have serious consequences.''
He also said he had expressed his concern about Iraqi treatment of Kuwaitis since Iraq overran the country on Aug. 2. Widespread looting and raping have been reported in recent days, along with what Mr. Bush called ''the systematic dismantling'' of Kuwait's economic and military structure.
After a week in which Congressional criticism of some aspects of his gulf policy became more vocal, the President turned the other cheek, thanking Congress for its support. ''It's good and it's strong,'' he said.
Mr. Bush emphasized his determination to give United Nations economic sanctions a chance to end the Middle East emergency, which entered its eighth week today.
The President said that if the embargo on land and sea shipments to and from Iraq were extended to air traffic, ''obviously the United States would do its part.''
An air embargo is expected to win United Nations approval next week. Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said today that the foreign ministers of the member countries of the United Nations Security Council would meet Tuesday ''to consider the situation in the Persian Gulf and, if appropriate, to adopt a resolution.''
The meeting was called by the Soviet Union, currently the president of the Security Council, to approve the new plan to tighten trade sanctions against Iran and occupied Kuwait by cutting air links with the two countries and blocking Iraqi merchant shipping between third countries.
Mr. Bush said he would welcome a broadcast of a 90-minute tape that Mr. Hussein is sending to the United States in response to an eight-minute message from Mr. Bush that was aired in Iraq last weekend.
''This will finish him off in the United States,'' the President said, laughing. ''I can't speak for the rest of the world. It would just be, nobody could stay awake through that.''

HEADLINE: Monopoly Status Led Cable TV to Gouge

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''House Passes a Bill to Regulate Cable TV, in Part'' (front page, Sept. 11), you quote Representative Edward J. Markey, Massachusetts Democrat, as saying of the cable industry, the ''rate gouging that was going on was so great that even the most fervent supporters of the free marketplace had to recognize the rapacious nature of the industry.''
I find it surprising that at a time when Soviet leaders are learning the basics of economics, a United States Representative can't tell the difference between a monopoly and a free market. Cable television companies were able to price gouge precisely because they were not subjected to a free marketplace; local governments conferred monopoly status on them. Lack of competition is what leads to high prices, not the rapacity of an industry.
 
NORMAN LEWIS SMITH
 Pleasantville, N.Y., Sept. 11, 1990

PUB-DATE: September 22, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 409 words

HEADLINE: The Wrong Way to Clean House

 BODY:
Oklahomans voted 2 to 1 on Tuesday to put a 12-year limit on state legislators' terms. California and Colorado have similar proposals on their November ballots; opinion polls in both states indicate overwhelming public support, and national polls show the same. Has the time arrived? 
The idea is popular because people are increasingly fed up with their government - with rising taxes, inadequate public services and politicians, some crooked, who perpetuate themselves in office with fat campaign contributions.
There is one good way to fix that: Vote the rascals out. But given the rate at which incumbents get themselves re-elected these days, it may appear that forced retirement is a better way. It's not.
Proposals for capping terms are as old as the nation. The Articles of Confederation limited members of the Continental Congress to three one-year terms within five years, and a plan to limit House members came up at the Constitutional Convention. The modern movement is spearheaded by conservatives. At the national level, Republicans see it as an opening to break the Democrats' grip on both houses. But it also has strong backing from people who identify themselves as Democrats in the opinion polls. The key flaw in term limitation is that it punishes experience. It takes time to learn the ropes of government - to develop the sense to fend off self-serving bureaucrats and lobbyists, to master the intricacies of public policy and to figure out how to get things done. With experienced legislators flowing through a revolving door, power could pass from elected politicians to unelected and virtually permanent staff employees.
Limitation would also make lame ducks of all lawmakers in their final terms. For U.S. senators, serving two six-year terms, a 12-year limit would mean they'd be responsible to no one for their second six years. Looking ahead to unemployment, they would presumably be less interested in their public office than in who on the outside might help them next.
This bad idea comes from a a frustrated electorate. Advocates aim to get the issue on the ballot in a dozen more states by 1992, and are pressing a constitutional amendment in Congress. If incumbents don't like it, they would be well advised to shape up; campaign finance reform is a good place to start. If voters are still dissatisfied let them weed out the bad, one by one. That's the responsible way. Wholesale housecleaning is a cop-out.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Minister in Exile Asserts Oilfields In Kuwait Were Mined by Iraqis

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Iraqi military forces have mined Kuwaiti oil installations, Kuwait's exiled Minister of Finance said today.
The minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, also told reporters he was confident that Iran would not break the United Nations trade embargo against Iraq, a possibility that has been worrying Washington and other governments that support the sanctions.
He reported that Kuwaiti leaders in exile would be prepared to contribute substantially more than the $2.5 billion already pledged to help Middle Eastern countries being harmed by their compliance with the sanctions. The Kuwaitis also have pledged $2.5 billion to support the American military buildup in the Persian Gulf. 
 
Long-Term Damage Difficult
Speaking about the mining of oilfields, Sheik Ali said: ''We have received detailed information on this'' from ''our own people there'' in Kuwait. He said that it would be very difficult to inflict long-term damage on the fields, but that the mines could cause extensive damage on the surface and could set off ''a lot of fires that would be very difficult to extinguish.''
Oil industry experts agreed. They said it might take months to put out such fires, making it that much longer before Kuwaiti production could help to ease any shortages in world supply once the crisis has ended.
Last year, Kuwait produced on average 1.6 million barrels of oil a day, an output near its full capacity. Its oil reserves total about 94.5 billion barrels. Iraq had been producing about 3.1 million barrels and exporting about 2.75 million barrels before its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.
In recent weeks, Saudi Arabia and other oil producers have significantly increased output to try to make up the four million barrels a day of exports that had come from Kuwait and Iraq. But there are still concerns that world oil supplies will be tight in the winter, when, analysts say, an additional daily production of one million to two million barrels will be needed.
Oil prices, now about $34 a barrel, already reflect a growing pessimism that the Middle East conflict will be settled peacefully, analysts say. They said the Kuwaiti minister's assertion that Kuwaiti oilfields have been mined - an Iraqi step long rumored - is likely to increase pessimism and cause prices to rise further.
''It will be taken as an indication of the aggressiveness of the Iraqi stance,'' said Graham Duxbury, director of Petroleum Economics Ltd., a London-based consulting company.
Although Iraqi forces are reported to have ransacked Kuwait and caused extensive damage, they do not appear to have harmed the country's oilfield installations and refineries, said Sheik Ali and executives of the state-owned Kuwait Petroleum Corporation who were interviewed here.
''To our knowledge, there's no damage,'' said one of the executives, who insisted that he not be identified. He said his information came from a company executive who had left Kuwait this week.
 
Playing Games With Iran
The Kuwaiti minister said he believed that Iran would not break the trade sanctions against Iraq and that Teheran was playing games with Baghdad, its old enemy. He also said it would be very difficult for Iraq to transport oil to Iran. There have been reports that Iran has agreed to take 200,000 barrels of Iraqi oil daily for use in Iranian refineries. Sheik Ali called the reports ''a lot of nonsense.''
Iraq has reportedly also proposed that Iran and Iraq link their pipelines, allowing Iraq to export 500,000 barrels of oil a day, in return for food, medicine and cash.
But the Iranian President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, has repeatedly pledged to abide by the United Nations sanctions. Indicating he believes him, Sheik Ali said his Government's relations with Iran were ''very good.''
