HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
SAUDIS TWIST ARMS MUCH HARDER NOW

BYLINE: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Sept. 21

 BODY:
An influential Saudi Government official describes the new attitude as ''No more Mr. Nice Guy.''
He was talking about his formerly reticent Government's new determination to act far more publicly and aggressively at home and abroad to defend Saudi national interests in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
The new assertiveness, which was apparent even early in the crisis, has come sharply into focus in recent days and weeks as the kingdom has unabashedly used the leverage that its oil wealth brings - sending emissaries around the globe to court, cajole and at times, officials here say, strongly pressure foreign governments to come to the assistance of Saudi Arabia.
''We told Japan and the Europeans that if they did not contribute to our defense we would have to consider closely all future contracts by their companies in Saudi Arabia,'' a Saudi official said. ''I think they got the message.'' Previous Maneuvering Discreet This conservative Muslim monarchy has been willing to use its power before, most publicly in the 1973 oil embargo to protest Western support for Israel. 
But other Saudi maneuvering has usually been very discreet. The kingdom quietly financed the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Afghan rebels, the Nicaraguan contras and other forces and parties in Ethiopia, Chad and Somalia, among others, Western and Saudi officials say.
But current Saudi moves are distinguished, according to Western diplomats, by being far more open and un-apologetic in the use of the Saudis' oil-based economic might.
''It's a new game,'' said a Western diplomat in an interview. ''This is a far more assured and aggressive Saudi Arabia than we've seen before.''
 
Notion of Arab Unity Abandoned
Along the way, Saudi officials and Western diplomats say, the kingdom is jettisoning some of its notable discretion, as well as the refrain of seeking ''Arab unity.''
''This crisis has shaken the country,'' the senior Saudi official said. ''We don't give a damn anymore about Arab unity, which never existed anyway. You are going to see us defend ourselves.''
In part perhaps because of such frankness, the Saudis have won broad support, the most obvious instance of which is the deployment of more than 150,000 American troops here.
The Saudis have gone on to win the backing of nations as diverse as Syria, Egypt, Pakistan, France, Britain, Germany, Japan, China and Argentina, and organizations like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the United Nations, among others.
 
Moscow's Involvement Sought
In a strong sign of the new Saudi assertiveness, the Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, has just finished a visit to Moscow to restore relations with the Kremlin after a break of 52 years.
Saudi officials openly speak of encouraging Moscow to involve itself directly in the defense of Saudi Arabia, perhaps by ferrying a Syrian armored division to the contested frontier with Iraq, a country that until six weeks ago was a major Soviet client.
At home and in the region, the Saudis have if anything been even more aggressive, moving swiftly on a number of fronts.
To parry any attempt by Iran or Iraq to curry favor among fundamentalist Muslims, the Saudis have sought to buttress their standing as leader of the Islamic world, based on their role as guarantors of the holy places of Mecca and Medina.
Saudi ''ulema,'' the religous leaders of the faith and interpreters of the holy law, have been active in securing the condemnation of Iraq by the World Muslim League, which last week characterized President Saddam Hussein as a blasphemer.
Saudi envoys have also secured a firm alliance with Egypt and Syria against Iraq.
Saudi pressure saw Cairo selected as the new site of the badly divided Arab League. Saudi officials say Saudi dollars helped solidify the new open military alliance with Syria and Egypt.
A senior Saudi official said that Syria already had been given $500 million in cash assistance and another $500 million in promised development projects, an offer he said was eagerly accepted by the Syrian President, Hafez al- Assad, whose nation is financially strapped and no longer able to rely on Soviet support.
The Saudi official said the kingdom expected to give between $1 and $2 billion to Egypt as well.
 
Anger With Jordan
The Saudis are now scathing in their criticism of Arab states they see as adversaries and sympathetic to Iraq. Saudi officials speak openly of their willingness to see Jordan's King Hussein tumble from power and the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat, disappear into ignominy.
This week, oil industry executives said, the Saudis cut off oil deliveries to Jordan, citing Amman's failure to pay. But the executives said the move in fact was a clear expression of Saudi anger at Jordan.
Saudi officials say that they would like to see the United States use the gulf crisis to persuade Israel to seek a settlement with Palestinians on the West Bank, but that they do not care any longer if that settlement includes Mr. Arafat.
''We kissed Arafat on the cheek for years in the name of Arab brotherhood,'' a Saudi official said. ''No more. He's a thug.'' Those are strong words in the Middle East, where memories are long and sanctions among enemies severe. Perhaps as a consequence, the Saudis are taking quick steps to tighten their own security.
 
Triple Military Forces
They are seeking to buy more than $20 billion worth of military equipment from the United States to support a possible tripling of Saudi military forces. Saudi officials also say their intelligence service has increased internal surveillance for possible terrorist attacks.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1129 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Leaders Bluntly Prime Iraq For 'Mother of All Battles'

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Iraq's leaders today issued their most bellicose statement of the Persian Gulf crisis, urging citizens to prepare for ''the mother of all battles,'' and backed it up with the retaliatory expulsion from Baghdad of diplomats from the United States, Western Europe and Egypt.
The Government-run television in Baghdad broke into scheduled programs early today with a statement from the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, a close circle of aides and relatives of President Saddam Hussein. The Council said there was ''not a single chance for any retreat'' in Iraq's confrontation with the United States and its allies.
Western and Arab diplomats here said that in referring repeatedly to the possibility of conflict on Iraqi territory, the statement seemed intended to create the impression that Baghdad was anticipating a first strike from the American-led force building to challenge Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. 
 
No Reference to Peace
The statement was the first since the crisis began to avoid all reference to peace. Diplomats said it appeared to be a rejoinder to President Bush's warnings of ''additional steps'' to force an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, the restoration of its now-exiled Government and the release of foreign hostages.
Later, Iraq reported violations of its airspace by aircraft flying at high altitude across its southern border with Saudi Arabia, but did not identify them. The Saudi press agency denied any such incursion from its territory.
Iraq's expulsion of military attaches and other diplomatic personnel was viewed as a response to similar action against Iraqi diplomats or to other acts perceived in Baghdad as hostile, including Egypt's decision to send thousands of troops to Saudi Arabia. Many Iraqi diplomats were expelled from foreign capitals beginning last weekend in response to Iraqi violations of diplomatic compounds in Kuwait.
According to official statements in various capitals, the diplomats expelled from Baghdad today included 3 Americans, 3 Britons, 2 West Germans, 5 Italians, 2 Spaniards and 11 French embassy personnel. They were given between a week to 10 days to leave. [In Washington, the State Department said that in retaliation it was expelling three Iraqi diplomats in addition to those expelled earlier.] British Diplomats Restricted The Baghdad authorities also announced new restrictions on the remaining 22 British Embassy personnel, saying they would be required from now on to give a week's notice if they sought to travel more than 25 miles from the Iraqi capital.
A Government spokesman here said that three Egyptian diplomats had also been ordered out of Iraq, coinciding with Egypt's continued deployment of troops in support of the more than 150,000 American soldiers in Saudi Arabia. The spokesman said that in response Egypt was expelling the Iraqi military attache and two senior diplomats from Baghdad's embassy in Cairo.
A Government spokesman in Paris called the expulsions by Iraq today ''a new escalation'' of the crisis.
While the precise number of Egyptian soldiers heading for Saudi Arabia remains unclear, military officials and Western diplomats here say the deployment involves two divisions totaling more than 20,000 troops backed by 300 M-60 tanks, artillery weapons, armored personnel carriers and air defense systems. The force is being transported through the Saudi Red Sea port of Yanbu.
In an Arab world deeply divided by the American military presence in the region, Egypt has been a leading force in supporting the moves by the United States, a close ally that provides Cairo with $2.3 billion a year in economic and military aid.
 
Hussein on TV, Unsmiling
As the diplomatic isolation around President Hussein deepened, the Iraqi leader appeared on Baghdad television early today unsmiling and in military uniform after a meeting of the Revolutionary Command Council and his Baath Party, an organization that provides one sinew of Mr. Hussein's highly personalized control of the country.
In a show of defiance of the American campaign and of new international efforts to extend the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait to air traffic, a statement read by an announcer over Iraqi television and radio and monitored here said, ''Everybody must realize that this battle will be the mother of all battles, and that God wanted us to wage the battle of liberating the nation and humanity, the battle of liberating Jerusalem and the holy shrines on the land of Iraq.''
It added, ''There is not a single chance for any retreat, for any retreat from waging the battle according to principles of honor and deep faith and determination to achieve victory.''
The statement raised new doubts about the fortunes of an initiative by embattled King Hussein of Jordan -an ally of Iraq - to promote what the monarch terms an Arab solution to the crisis. Under his proposal, an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait would be linked to a United States withdrawal from the region.
 
'A Great Honor' to Do Battle
''We here in the Iraq of the Arabs and Muslims have irrevocably decided to lead this faithful host on the land of Iraq until the honorable result of God's victory,'' the Iraqi statement said. ''It is a great honor for us and we thank the one and only God for it.''
''There is no hesitating or changing goals or the path between starting confrontation and victory,'' it declared.The Council criticized the international embargo and the projected ban on civilian flights to Iraq as an attempt ''to throw the Iraqi people into prison.''
It reserved particular scorn for President Bush, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. ''What dwarfs they are,'' it said of Iraq's enemies. ''May they, most of all Bush and his servants Fahd and Hosni, be accursed.''
The newest statement from Baghdad seemed to escalate its verbal threats. On Thursday, in an interview published in Turkey, President Hussein declared that his country would not grovel before the United States. ''If need be, we will fight for three, four or five or six more years,'' he said. His Information Minister, Latif Nassif Jassem, said that, if attacked, Iraq would ''destroy all oilfields in the region.''
 
U.S. Expels 3 Iraqis
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (Special to the New York Times) The United States retaliated against Baghdad's expulsions by expelling three Iraqi diplomats from Washington.
The State Department's spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said that one of the expelled Iraqis was the military attache, to match the position of one of the ousted Americans, and that the expulsions brought the size of the Iraqi Embassy here down to 15 people.
As was the case with the American diplomats ordered out of Baghdad, the Iraqis were given a week to depart.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
In Jordan, Saddam Hussein Is 'King'

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 21

 BODY:
First, the masked men on the roof burned Israel's Star of David flag, and the crowd cheered. Then it was the turn of the Stars and Stripes, and the crowd cheered louder. Finally, it was the turn of the Soviet Union's hammer and sickle banner, and the cheers rolled on.
When thousands of Palestinians gathered on a dusty patch of ground here today for a rally in support of Saddam Hussein, the flag-burning provided a climax to two hours of impassioned speechmaking. The hero of the evening, as he has been at many such rallies in Jordan since Iraq invaded Kuwait, was the leader of the Baghdad Government. Mr. Hussein's portraits were sold at stalls and his face looked out from badges on scores of lapels. 
 
Over 50% Palestinian
Here, in a country where more than 50 percent of the 3.5 million people are Palestinians, nearly 900,000 of them classed as refugees by the United Nations, the jeers are not for those who set off a crisis by driving their tanks into Kuwait, forcing at least 500,000 Arabs to pass through here as refugees on their way home to Egypt and other countries. The names that arouse the greatest ire are George Bush, Margaret Thatcher and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, for the military buildup in Saudi Arabia, and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, for offering it his political backing.
''We like Saddam very much because he returns glory to the Arabs,'' said Nidal Rahwy, a 26-year-old clothing salesman whose family came here as refugees from the 1948 war that led to the establishment of Israel. As a crowd of youths pressed around, he added: ''All people look at Saddam Hussein as a hero. They look to him to liberate Palestine.''
But the most powerful resonance for the cries of ''Saddam! Saddam!'' that rose from the thousands who jostled for vantage points during the speeches was probably a few miles away across Amman's rolling hills, in a sandstone palace scented with blossoms of jasmine and bougainvillea.
King Hussein of Jordan returned here on Thursday from the latest round of the shuttle diplomacy he has attempted from the outset of the Kuwait crisis, this time from an apparently abortive effort, during discussions in Morocco with King Hassan II, to arrange a meeting between Saddam Hussein and King Fahd. Instead of Saudi Arabia's gratitude for seeking an ''Arab solution,'' the King received a shock: Earlier on Thursday, Saudi Arabia abruptly shut down the pipeline that provided Jordan with nearly 50 percent of its oil.
 
Anger Primed at Meeting
Apparently, Saudi anger had been primed by a meeting of Arab nationalists here last weekend that turned into a forum for radical Palestinian leaders and virulent attacks on the United States and Saudi Arabia.
That meeting, like King Hussein's diplomacy, reflected the delicate balancing act that the Jordanian monarch has attempted. With Jordan's economy deeply dependent on trade with Iraq, and with its populace enthusisastic for Saddam Hussein, the King has sought to play the conciliator. At virtually every turn, he has been rebuffed.
To outsiders puzzled by the King's persistence, diplomats here have a simple response: Go out into the streets. There, as at today's rally, the fragility of King Hussein's position is immediately apparent.
In grocery store windows, on the porches of private homes, on the mirrors in the barber shops, hang portraits of Saddam Hussein. Sometimes, the posters show the Iraqi leader with King Hussein, with the two men, smiling, handling a rifle. The body language of the portraits alone seems to suggest which of the two neighboring rulers is the more powerful.
 
The King's Frustrations
While the enthusiasm for Saddam Hussein is strongest among the Palestinians, it is widespread among native Jordanians, too.
The frustrations of the King's position - seeking to save Jordan from further pounding in a war, hoping to shore up his throne, his diplomacy rejected and even derided in Baghdad, Washington and London - was expressed by Crown Prince Hassan. Before a breakfast served in part by a retainer in the uniform of Jordan's desert police, with a red-and-white-checkered keffiyeh on his head, bandoliers across his chest and a silver dagger at his waist, the Prince expressed Jordan's exasperation.
''The meek will inherit the earth,'' he said. ''But for goodness sake, just how meek must they be?''

HEADLINE: Defenders and Detractors View Banks' New Powers

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Bank regulators and Bush Administration officials said today that the Federal Reserve's decision to further relax restrictions that had prevented commercial banks from trading corporate securities would probably not lead to the speculative stock trading and underwriting problems that caused the ban to be written into the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933.
But some members of Congress argued that the central bank's action needlessly put bank depositors and the industry at risk at a time when banks were already strained.
Regulators say that the Federal Reserve's decision Thursday permitting J. P. Morgan & Company to underwrite and trade securities does not endanger depositors because regulations make it difficult for the securities arms of bank holding companies to make use of the Government-insured deposits held by the affiliated bank unit. The securities affiliates must operate with separate management and capital to protect the rest of the bank from the risks of stock trading. 
 
Statement From Seidman
''It's appropriate to have commercial banks trading securities as long as they are done by carefully segregated units,'' said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, one of nearly half a dozen agencies that have authority over commercial banks.
But critics said the decision was unwise now because it could further strain the commercial banking industry, where profits are in a slump. They point out that the Government fund that insures bank deposits is already under stress from several bank failures largely caused by bad real estate loans.
''Clearly, the authority to deal in equity securities introduces a new element of risk for institutions insured by the Federal Treasury and the taxpayers,'' said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, chairman of the House Banking Committee. ''It is irresponsible for the Federal Reserve - under any rationale - to willy-nilly add massive new risks to the banking system at a time when the taxpayer-supported insurance fund is strained to the limit.''
John C. Coffee Jr., a professor of securities law at Columbia University, questioned whether the institutional barriers separating the banking and securities units would be adequate.
Such walls ''have proven to be porous in other situations, such as insider trading, and they could potentially be porous here,'' he said.
At the very least, banking and securities affiliates of the same holding company are expected to share customer lists and other information.
 
Savings Bailout Is Cited
Other critics drew parallels to the Federal Reserve's decision in the 1980's to deregulate the savings and loan industry. Many experts say deregulation is a prime reason that the savings industry is now being rescued in the costliest Federal bailout in history.
''In the midst of the savings and loan crisis, I'm highly skeptical that this is the best time to proceed with doing away with Glass-Steagall,'' Professor Seligman said. The Bush Administration has not directly called for the repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act, although it is in the midst of a broad study of the nation's financial system that is widely expected to call for changes in the law.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has long argued that Glass-Steagall's distinctions between commercial and investment banks should be abandoned.
''We still strongly advocate such repeal because we believe that technology and globalization have continued to blur the distinctions among credit markets,'' Mr. Greenspan said at a Congressional hearing last week. ''Outdated constraints will only endanger the profitability of banking organizations and their contribution to the American economy.''
 
Questions of Jurisdiction
Officials at the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that they would have jurisdiction over the securities arms of bank holding companies, while the Federal Reserve continues to oversee both the affiliates and the banking units.
Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, said that many of the questions of jurisdiction had been worked out last year when the Federal Reserve took the first step toward relaxing Glass-Steagall by allowing banks to underwrite corporate bonds.

PUB-DATE: September 22, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 31, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 818 words

HEADLINE: Brokers Play Down New Threat

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Securities industry executives said yesterday that J. P. Morgan & Company's newly granted ability to underwrite stocks was not much of a near-term threat. But, they said, it could lead to fundamental changes in their industry and bring new riskiness into the nation's banking system if other banks get similar authority. And Wall Street plans to take these concerns to Washington.
''Congress will find this, frankly, shocking,'' said Robert N. Downey, chairman of the Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's trade group. ''It's adding a new element of risk into institutions that are insured by the taxpayers, and in the past that has gotten them into trouble.'' 
The association's main concern, Mr. Downey said, is whether sufficient ''fire walls'' can be erected between the deposit-taking functions of commercial banks and underwriting activities.
 
Concern About Weak Walls
''I don't mind competing with Morgan bank if the fire walls are high enough,'' he said. ''But my concern is that the Fed is talking about weakening the fire walls at a time when they are more important than ever, given the experience of the savings and loan industry and all the banks that are now in difficulty''
On Wall Street, industry leaders said they did not fear a loss of business from having Morgan underwrite securities - acting as a middleman between a corporation that wants to sell stock and the public that wants to buy it.
They note that the Federal Reserve, in granting the authority to Morgan on Thursday, imposed restrictions that will severely limit the bank's securities role. For instance, Morgan cannot derive more than 10 percent of its underwriting revenues from offering equities and certain debt securities; the rest must come from underwriting Treasury debt.
 
'Let the Best Man Win'
''It doesn't mean a major thing as far as we are concerned,'' said James E. Cayne, president of Bear, Stearns & Company. ''We don't look at this as awesome or earthshaking or anything other than having one new competitor. Let the best man win.''
Robert E. Rubin, co-vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, said: ''We've always run our business to be as effective as possible. We're just going to keep doing that.''
The Fed's decision comes when Wall Street's corporate underwritings have fallen sharply as the economy has weakened, stock prices have dropped and fewer American companies are issuing new stock. The banking decision is still another problem for an industry that has been retrenching as lucrative lines of business like arranging mergers and leveraged buyouts have all but dried up.
Underwriting corporate securities is one of the few businesses on Wall Street in which price competition has remained minimal. By contrast, profit margins from trading securities have been pushed down drastically as large institutional investors continually bargain for better deals on their transaction costs. The fear is that with the commercial banks allowed to compete for underwriting business, margins there will shrink as well.
''Clearly, this is a long-term negative for the industry,'' said Michael Goldstein, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. ''It brings more competition to a highly competitive industry.''
 
'Long-Term Implications'
John S. Chalsty, chairman of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, said that while the Fed's decision is a ''moderate non-event'' at the moment, ''obviously it has long-term implications'' and ''changes the structure of the securities business.''
For that reason, some on Wall Street say there is a need for fuller discussion in Washington of the Fed's action, along with any other changes in the Glass-Steagall Act, which was enacted in 1933 and separates commercial banking and investment banking.
Some in the securities industry contend that Wall Street should now be given more banking powers.
''This is another example of the banks getting increased powers without the securities industry getting anything,'' said Donald B. Marron, chief executive of Paine Webber Inc. ''Nowhere in these discussions is the sense that if banks get securities powers, the securities industry gets bank powers. And that seems to be the heart of the issue right now. We are replacing Glass-Steagall by small pieces and with no formal process, and I don't think that's the best way to do it.''
John L. Steffens, chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company's consumer markets group, said that the Fed had, in effect, pre-empted Congress. ''The issue ends up to be whether or not Congress is happy with being out of the loop in making determinations about the financial-services industry,'' he said. ''There are implications in modifying the regulations without thinking through the overall ramifications.
''And I don't think regulatory dismantlement should take place without some legislative action,'' Mr. Steffens added.

HEADLINE: Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Crude oil prices climbed sharply yesterday, following big jumps for both heating oil and gasoline.
Traders said a flurry of buying on Thursday afternoon carried over into early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, while concerns remained high about the tense Persian Gulf situation.
Oil for delivery in November settled at $35.43, the first time that oil has sold for more than $35 a barrel since the start of trading in oil futures on the mercantile exchange in 1983. The close was $2.01 higher than the November settlement on Thursday, when the October contract expired with a rally in the closing minutes of trading. That contract ended at $34.71, up $1.53 a barrel from Wednesday's close, and the enthusiasm spilled over into yesterday's trading. 
 
Rush to Buy Contracts
Rising prices for crude oil yesterday were driven by sharper increases for gasoline and heating oil, said Robert S. Jonke, an energy futures trader at Cargill Investor Services. When the price of a barrel of gasoline and heating oil yesterday morning rose well above the cost of buying a barrel of oil and refining it, traders rushed to buy oil contracts, he added.
The price of heating oil for October delivery ended the day up by 5.35 cents, at 97.21 cents a gallon. That capped a series of large increases during the week that could mean higher bills for homeowners this winter. For the week, October heating oil was up 14.42 cents a gallon, or 17.4 percent.
Gasoline for October delivery rose 5.91 cents a gallon, to 97.45 cents, The October contracts for oil products do not expire until next Friday.
 
Anger and Investigations
If heating oil prices stay near $1 a gallon, a homeowner who has spent $1,000 a winter on oil in recent years could end up spending $1,400 to $1,500 this winter, said a New York heating oil executive who insisted that he not be identified. The result would be angry consumers and possible government investigations, he added. But prices would likely fall, he said, if war did not break out in the Middle East.
The price of heating oil usually overtakes the price of gasoline in the autumn, although the increase is usually spread out over the October and November contracts, said Thomas G. Burns, the manager of the economics staff at the San Francisco-based Chevron Corporation. This week's increase in heating oil prices ''is just a faster-than-normal movement toward that happening,'' he added.
October gasoline was up 7.09 cents a gallon during the week, or 7.8 percent, while November oil climbed by $4.27 a barrel, or 13.7 percent, to its highest level in nine years.
Heating oil stocks are fairly high in the United States, and the lack of additional storage capacity has tended to prevent companies and individuals from accumulating large stockpiles to use for speculative purposes. But the availability of extra storage in Europe has sent prices higher there and prompted some eastbound trans-Atlantic shipments of oil, pulling up prices in the United States this week, the New York heating oil executive said.
 
'Flows Toward Highest Price'
Such international movements of oil are common, and some heating oil was shipped from Europe to the United States last winter, when American prices were higher. ''Oil is international, and flows toward the highest price,'' the New York executive added.
Virginia Wiater, an energy futures broker for United Energy Inc., a New York trading company, said oil and oil product markets remained preoccupied with how high prices might rise if a Mideast war broke out and many oilfields were destroyed. ''People feel at any moment the top may be blown off,'' she added.
Traders are particularly nervous about repeated hawkish statements by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and one of his ministers, Ms. Wiater said. The Iraqi leaders have threatened to fight a war with the United States lasting for years, and to destroy all Persian Gulf oilfields during such a war.
Some traders expressed particular alarm about a World Bank estimate this week that oil prices could rise to $65 a barrel if fighting started.
 
Disagreement on Contracts
Some market participants have contended that at least part of the recent run-up in crude on the New York Mercantile Exchange has reflected the type of futures contracts traded there. But experts disagree on the effect.
The contracts are for light, sweet crude, which consists of 10 grades of oil that are less dense and have a lower sulfur content than other grades, making them easier to refine.
Iraq and Kuwait exported mostly light, sweet crude before the imposition of a United Nations trade embargo on Aug. 6, four days after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Other countries are producing mostly heavy, sour oil to make up for the shortfall, and some refineries are poorly equipped to handle this lower-quality oil.
Ms. Wiater said a shortage of light, sweet crude was driving up prices. ''People are now beginning to see that, short term, we're going to have a problem,'' she said.
 
Drop in Premium Cited
But John H. Kingston, the managing editor of Platt's Oilgram Price Report, a daily New York newsletter, said high-grade oil could not be in especially short supply because the premium for the light, Louisiana sweet grade of oil, compared with the slightly heavier and more sour West Texas intermediate grade, had shrunk dramatically in the spot market over the last week. ''That number is absolutely a dead-on barometer'' of light, sweet crude supplies, he said.
The recent increase in oil prices is based on emotion, not supplies of light, sweet crude, said Peter I. Cardillo, the director of commodities research at Jesup, Josephthal & Company, a New York brokerage. ''As far as fundamentals are concerned, there's no news to account for it,'' he added. ''It's pure speculation based on the Persian Gulf situation.''

HEADLINE: Profit? Loss? A Primer for Soviets

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Nikolai V. Panteleyev has the unenviable task of creating an accounting profession in a nation unfamiliar with profits and losses, let alone concepts like intangible assets, good will or fair value. He likens the job to teaching people to ''learn Chinese overnight.''
His rapidly changing job, called the director of the Department of Accounting of the Ministry of Finance, is one of the more daunting in the Soviet Government as it lurches toward a market economy, and also one of the most important. For the Soviet economy to attract foreign capital, it will eventually need to adopt internationally acceptable accounting standards. To do that, it will have to create an accounting system virtually from scratch. And it will need to teach the new accountants concepts alien to their whole way of thinking. 
Mr. Panteleyev, the Soviet Union's chief accountant, spent yesterday in New York at the end of a two-week visit to the United States. He managed to squeeze in a Broadway show and dinner in Chinatown. Seeing Western Practices But his primary mission was a firsthand glimpse of Western accounting practices and of the various regulatory and professional bodies that allow the system to work. Mr. Panteleyev, 58 years old, was also looking for ideas in his role as co-chairman of a group trying to develop internationally acceptable accounting standards for the 2,000 ventures that have been set up between Soviet-owned enterprises and Western partners. The expectation is that the rules will someday serve as a blueprint for the rest of the Soviet economy.
He acknowledges that it will be difficult for citizens of his country to grasp fundamental business concepts. But ''life will make them learn,'' he said through an interpreter. ''We have been experimenting for 70 years, and our people are used to changes.''
The Soviet system, or what exists of it, is far less organized than that of the United States, a country that has one licensed accountant for every 835 people, or that of England, the country that invented modern accounting, where there is one accountant for every 500 people.
Mr. Panteleyev said the Soviet Union had about 300,000 accountants - in other words, one for every 970 people. But American accountants said those professionals are actually more comparable to controllers in this country, because they are unlicensed and because they are more concerned with central planning than with the proper calculation of a company's profits or adherence to generally accepted accounting principles.
 
No Terms Exist
Nor can the Russian language always capture concepts that the Soviet people are now only beginning to learn. ''The terms just don't exist,'' said Richard Lewis, an accountant in Ernst & Young's Moscow office. ''Yesterday, we were trying to discuss inventory valuation, and were able to make ourselves understood when we discussed the weighted-average cost method.
''But when we went to talk about FIFO and LIFO,'' he continued, referring to the first-in, first-out and last-in, first-out systems of inventory accounting, ''you have to go into lengthy explanations of what they are.''
In some cases, the Soviets have simply adapted English words - like ''good will,'' or they dust off long forgotten words from academic literature, like the word for ''dividend.''
In other cases, like ''intangible assets,'' the words defy translation.
M. Zubaidur Rahman, an accounting professor at the State University of New York in Plattsburgh who along with Ernst & Young was Mr. Panteleyev's host, tried to describe the expression ''fair value'' by coining an improvised Russian term that translates to ''red price,'' because ''red'' generally connotes something desirable in Russian. But the usage did not catch on. Slow Progress While the going may be slow, the Soviet Union has been making progress under Mr. Panteleyev. In the last three months, Western accounting firms have been allowed to compete for the first time against Inaudit, a Soviet group that was the only entity permitted to audit the books of the East-West ventures.
Mr. Panteleyev said he was committed to starting a self-supporting professional institute, along the lines of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants in New York, as early as next year. The group would be expected to license accountants and create professional standards.
And he has made some headway on his goal to overhaul the rules for joint ventures. In June, the Ministry of Finance issued new rules calling for the ventures to begin accounting for their revenues on an accrual basis, which means when the money is thought to be earned, rather than when the enterprise receives the cash. The hitch: the rule has yet to be applied to expense items.
Mr. Panteleyev intends to tap the growing number of Soviet students who would otherwise have become central planners, urging them to consider accounting careers instead.
''Because the centralized planning system is being eliminated, the universities are reducing the amount of students who study in that field,'' he said, talking like an entrepreneur who is confident that supply and demand will solve his shortage. ''Because of that, we will increase the number of students studying accounting. It will just resolve itself.''
Even though market forces are in his favor, recruiting people will not be a cinch in a country where accountants have a public image that is worse than in this country.
''Unfortunately, the accounting profession is not considered prestigious,'' Mr. Panteleyev said. ''Most of the accountants are women,'' he added, noting that Soviet women have fewer career choices than men.
 
At Ministry 12 Years
Mr. Panteleyev earned a diploma as a teacher of accounting sciences from the Leningrad Financial Institute. He spent five years teaching before becoming the chief financial officer of a Siberian factory. He then accepted a series of Government jobs, joining the Ministry of Finance 12 years ago. He has been in his current post since 1985.
Asked what role American accountants could play in helping the Soviet Union, Mr. Panteleyev cited a Russian saying that revealed he was not entirely uncritical of the United States model. ''As we say in our country,'' he started with a puckish smile, ''those who are drowning should save themselves.''

HEADLINE: Robert B. Spence, 89, Psychology Professor

 BODY:
Robert Beckett Spence, a professor emeritus of psychology at Teachers College at Columbia University, died on Wednesday at his home in a retirement community in Newtown, Pa. He was 89 years old. 
He died of heart disease, his son-in-law, Donald Muntz, said.
A 1927 graduate of Columbia University with a Ph.D. in psychology, Dr. Spence joined the faculty of Teachers College in 1925 and was named professor emeritus in 1966 when he retired. He was appointed director of the Advanced School of Education at Teachers College in 1950.
He was a Fulbright Fellow in Pakistan in 1955, and from 1956 to 1961, was head of the Project for Teacher Training, a Teachers College program financed by the Agency for International Development that sent instructors to Afghanistan to help improve the school system in Kabul.
From 1942 to 1949, he worked for the War Production Board and the New York State Board of Education. He was also a consultant to the New York State Youth Commission and a member of a Governor's task force on juvenile delinquency. In 1952 he wrote a book, ''Reducing Juvenile Delinquency -What New York State Schools Can Do.'' After he retired, he was a visiting professor at the University of Georgia.
He is survived by his wife, the former Rita Pond; a daughter, Carol Muntz of Alexandria, Va.; a son, Donald, of Princeton, N.J.; two sisters, Margo Brown of Madison, Wis., and Lucy Jeffers of Sun City, Ariz., and four grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 25, 1990, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Saturday about an emeritus professor of psychology at Teachers College, Columbia University, rendered his given name incorrectly. He was Ralph Beckett Spence.

HEADLINE: Suffolk Chief Offers Layoffs, Not Tax Rise

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 21

 BODY:
Faced with a slowing economy and continued resistance to taxes, the Suffolk County Executive today proposed a 1991 budget that would lay off 295 county employees and reduce services but not require an increase in county property taxes.
The proposed $1.3 billion budget, which would begin to shrink the size of government in New York's most populated county outside of New York City, also called for the demotion of 129 county police officers and the elimination of 718 budgeted but vacant positions.
It follows a year in which the Executive, Patrick G. Halpin, said he carried out $60 million in cost-saving measures for the current budget of $1.3 billion that included unpaid voluntary furloughs for county workers, early retirement incentives and cutbacks in overtime, outside contracts, equipment purchases and travel. The budget would bring to 2,573 the number of county positions that have been eliminated since 1988, leaving a work force of 9,915, according to Mr. Halpin's office. 
 
Higher Medicaid Contributions
The earlier steps, Mr. Halpin said today, were not enough to offset the effects of a flattening-out of sales-tax returns that make up about 40 percent of county revenues and an anticipated $45 million increase next year in county contributions to Medicaid and other mandated social-services programs. Mr. Halpin said, for the first time in its history, the county would pay more for programs mandated by the state and Federal governments than for discretionary programs.
The cuts and reductions in the proposed budget were needed, Mr. Halpin said, to close an estimated $103 million gap between expected revenues and the cost of meeting expenses while keeping jobs and services at current levels. He said county property taxes, which account for about 22 percent of revenues and about 17 percent of the total property taxes the average property owner pays, would have to be increased by $195 on the average homeowner's billl to close the gap.
But he said he rejected any tax increase at a time when the county's 1.4 million residents were caught in a declining economic climate and had made clear their insistence that county taxes be frozen at current levels.
''They don't have to read my lips,'' Mr. Halpin said. ''They just have to read my budget.''
He said the layoffs and demotions could be forestalled if the police and other employees agreed to a week off without pay, deferrals of salary increases or a payroll lag that would eliminate one payday next year.
 
'Blood Bath' Predicted
The budget proposal by Mr. Halpin, who is a Democrat, was immediately attacked by the Republican and Conservative majority in the County Legislature and by the police and the independent union that represents 7,000 county employees. The proposal now goes to the 18-member legislature, where sharp debate and amendments are expected before a final budget is adopted in November.
''It will be two months of a blood bath,'' said Michael D. O'Donohoe, a Conservative county legislator from Northport.
The struggle in Suffolk will be heightened by the Republicans' and Conservatives' efforts to regain the county executive post Mr. Halpin won in 1987. Mr. Halpin's first term ends next year. Similar fiscal pressures are being felt in almost all of the state's 62 counties, said Edwin L. Crawford, the executive director of the New York State Association of Counties in Albany. ''Suffolk is in the limelight because they are out of the box with an early budget,'' he said, ''but it's pretty much the same story all over the state.''
 
Sales-Tax Revenue Slows
Most counties had seen increases in sales tax revenues of about 5 percent annually until about two years ago, Mr. Crawford said, but were now registering no increases or slight declines. In Suffolk, Mr. Halpin said, the increases averaged 11 percent annually from 1980 through 1987. From 1988 to the present, he said, the growth had slowed to 1.6 percent.
Suffolk is one of a handful of New York counties that maintains a county police force, a factor that has added to its budget pressure. With 2,583 officers and a base salary of $47,295 for a patrol officer with five years of experience, the Suffolk Police Department is the 13th-largest and among the best-paid forces in the country, said Bradford W. O'Hearn, a spokesman for Mr. Halpin.
The police district includes the county's populous five western towns and accounts for about two-thirds of county property-tax bills in those towns.
Mr. Halpin said the demotions would streamline the police department and avoid layoffs there. But Police Commissioner Daniel P. Guido has warned that the demotions would be damaging to operations and morale. Michael A. Mahoney, president of the Suffolk County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said that with the demotions. police morale ''will never be the same.''
Charles Novo Jr., president of the Suffolk County Association of Municipal Employees, said the union would lobby the legislators to restore jobs and positions.
''A lot of the problem is mismanagement by the county executive,'' Mr. Novo said.

HEADLINE: Can Heads Be Counted in a Dynamic City?

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
When New York City officials said the Census Bureau had failed to count hundreds of thousands of housing units in the five boroughs - and, they implied, the people living in them - they were challenging more than the Federal agency's arithmetic.
The sheer number of dwellings that the city contended were skipped, even when adjusted downward for vacancies and mistakes, seemed to underscore the question lawyers have been asking in New York's two-year-old lawsuit against the bureau: how can any agency hope to count the population of so vast, dynamic and complicated a place, nose by nose?
''I don't attribute any particular malice to the way the enumeration is completed,'' said Robert S. Rifkind, one of the lawyers representing the city, which has been joined in the lawsuit by other cities, states, civic and civil rights groups. ''It's just very hard to make it work.'' 
In a way, New York is pursuing two separate but mutually reinforcing strategies as it tries to insure that the Census Bureau, which has acknowledged that it missed 350,000 or so New Yorkers in 1980, does not shortchange the city this time.
Even if it fails to result in the addition of significantly more housing units and people to the bureau's counts, the challenge and the attention it received have doubtless increased the pressure on the bureau to adjust its final count using a separate, post-count survey that is the focus of the lawsuit.
In its formal challenge, issued Wednesday after the census housing counts were compared with records from city agencies and utility companies, the city's Planning Department was engaging the bureau on its own statistical turf.
Even the seemingly suspect precision with which the department reported its analysis - it said exactly 254,534 residences were missed - matched the seemingly suspect precision with which the bureau, in a preliminary estimate released in August, put the city's population at precisely 7,033,179. John J. Connolly, an assistant to the Census Bureau Director, Dr. Barbara Everitt Bryant, said there were many ways in which the agency double- and triple-checks its numbers. There are follow-up visits to housing units where residents did not send in forms or mailed back incomplete ones and field inspections of addresses declared vacant or listed as having only one occupant, a danger signal that a ''curbstoning'' census worker may not have taken the trouble to look inside.
People who have not yet cooperated with the Census Bureau can call by Sept. 30 and be recorded over the phone, Mr. Connolly said. And, of course, there is local review, the process in which the city's challenge will be considered.
 
Adjustments Debated
Census officials say they believe that many of the housing units the city said were missing were merely ''mi sallocated'' - recorded in the wrong place - and that residents of those units that the city claims were overlooked are already in the population count, while perhaps 40,000 other units are vacant.
This part of the city's strategy seems likely to result in an increase to the city's population total, but not by so much as the city would like. Peter L. Zimroth, New York City's former Corporation Counsel and who is counsel on the census case with Mr. Rifkind, calls the bureau's corrective efforts ''mop-up procedures'' that are ''inadequate to the task'' and even ''counterproductive, because they lead to lots of errors.''
He and Mr. Rifkind are seeking to have the agency make an altogether different kind of adjustment to its figures based on a separate, post-enumeration survey that is at the heart of the plaintiffs' strategy.
In this survey, the initial field work for which was completed in August, more than 400,000 people around the country were interviewed in 164,000 housing units on census blocks selected to reflect the diverse demography of the United States. Interviewers traveled around each block, listing every housing unit - including ones that the original enumeration did not get - and asking residents their name, address, age, sex, race, relation to the head of the household, whether they own or rent their home and where they lived on April 1, the census day.
 
U.S. Government Will Decide
By comparing the results of the post-enumeration survey to those of the census, the bureau can see who was counted correctly, who was counted incorrectly and who was not counted at all. Then, through extrapolation, the final census tally could be adjusted to allow for the undercount - if the Government decides to do so.
Such extrapolation is used by astronomers to count the stars, by accountants to count corporate profits and by clerks to count cereal boxes on the supermarket shelves.
The Regional Plan Association, a private research organization which has tracked the economy and demography of the region for more than 60 years, has called on the Commerce Department to use the post-enumeration survey to adjust what it believes is an undercount of 600,000 residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the bureau preliminary estimates.
But convincing the Government to use such an adjustment in determining the apportionment of the nation's Congressional districts and the states' legislative districts and the allocation of billions of dollars in Federal aid is proving difficult.
In 1980, in response to lawsuits seeking the same sort of adjustment, the bureau's staff argued that it did not have enough data to make a valid correction. And in guidelines that were issued as part of an agreement in the New York City lawsuit, the Commerce Department, the Census Bureau's parent, reserved the right to decide not to use the survey to adjust the count if the Commerce secretary sees a ''potential disruption of the process of the orderly transfer of political representation.'' While there is no language in the Constitution that deals explicitly with the question of how the population must be counted - it calls only for an ''enumeration'' of the ''whole number of free persons'' - there is a sharp debate over the constitutionality of such an adjustment.
Still, the scope of the city's challenge may make a post-count correction seem more pallatable, if only by emphasizing how far apart two government entities can be.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 25, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1150 words

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
For Cuomo, Albany Road Runs Past Washington

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 21

 BODY:
While campaigning for a third term as Governor, Mario M. Cuomo has been doing many of the things that statewide candidates traditionally do. He has worked crowds at upstate fairs, has debated commuters in Times Square and has broadcast upbeat commercials about the state's good works.
But in the most significant speeches he has delivered since receiving the Democratic nomination in June, Mr. Cuomo has taken the unconventional approach of focusing his attacks not on his opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret, but on the Republican domestic policies of the Bush and Reagan Administrations. For Mr. Cuomo, it sometimes seems, all politics is national. 
While it has never been unusual for Mr. Cuomo to mount scattershot assaults on Washington, he has assembled his thoughts this summer into a broad and forceful critique. He has argued that the Republicans have improperly ceded the fiscal obligation for national problems to the states and in the process have made the country's tax structure more regressive.
By stressing national themes in a gubernatorial campaign, Mr. Cuomo has also knowingly encouraged musing by political observers about his status as a potential Presidential candidate. After Mr. Cuomo made his case against the Republicans in a speech to a politically influential crowd at Harvard last week, the audience was consumed with conjecture about whether the Governor was laying thematic groundwork for a 1992 Presidential campaign.
 
Don't Mind the Speculation
That may or may not be the case. Other than refusing to promise to serve a full four-year term if he is re-elected in November, Mr. Cuomo has sent few signals that he is considering a run for the White House.
But what is clear is that Mr. Cuomo understands from his experience four years ago, when he first flirted with a Presidential race, that the speculation engendered by his speeches has the beneficial side-effect of bolstering his political stature.
''I don't mind you people speculating,'' he said in a recent interview. ''It's probably good for me.''
Mr. Cuomo could, of course, put an end to the speculation by declaring that he will not be a Presidential candidate in 1992. But that might reduce him to being just another governor and, at that, the governor of a state with severe fiscal problems and a mind-boggling array of social crises.
By using his speeches to denounce the Federal Government, Mr. Cuomo seeks to shift blame for those crises from Albany to Washington. And whether or not he plans to run for President, the notion that Mr. Cuomo is of Presidential caliber may buffer him somewhat from hostile public opinion generated by the state's failings.
A poll taken by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion on Sept. 10 and 11 showed that 56 percent of the 821 registered voters questioned thought that the state was headed in the wrong direction but that 65 percent had a favorable impression of Mr. Cuomo. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points.
By choosing to give his speeches at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government, at the State Democratic Convention in June and at a national judicial conference in August, the Governor selected audiences that included national opinion-makers, party leaders and political reporters. He was concerned enough about last week's speech to have a favorite lectern, which was two inches taller than a lectern availailable at Harvard, shipped to Cambridge by Federal Express.
The essence of Mr. Cuomo's case is that Republican domestic policy in the 1980's, known as the New Federalism, reduced income taxes for the wealthy while transferring responsibility for national problems like drugs, homelessness, education and a decaying infrastructure to the states.
 
Attacking the New Federalism
''The nation can no more leave it to the individual states to fight these national problems than it can expect the states' valiant militias and National Guard units to fight and win a war in the Middle East without the Federal Army, Navy, Marines, Air Force -and Treasury,'' he said at Harvard.
In realigning the roles of government, Mr. Cuomo argues, Washington has also shifted a heavy tax burden to the states. And because the states are in economic competition with each other, they have chosen to raise taxes that are least likely to push businesses across the border, he says.
In a variety of states, including New York, those taxes have predominantly been regressive ones like sales, excise and real-estate taxes, which are levied at the same rate regardless of income, rather than progressive ones like the income tax.
By explaining the cause and effect relationship between the New Federalism and a regressive tax structure, Mr. Cuomo is able to illustrate the impact that Republican policy has had on average Americans, not just on cash-strapped governors.
 
'A Rock Star Quality'
Experts on Federal fiscal policy, like Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard economist, said they will not be rewriting text books based on Mr. Cuomo's economic analysis. But they said the power of Mr. Cuomo's speeches have given new definition to a previously unfocused debate.
''The reception after his speech here had a rock star quality,'' Mr. Summers said. ''There was more thronging to shake his hand than you usually see at a university.''
Because he is the governor of the country's second-largest state and because he attracts more national attention than other governors, Mr. Cuomo says, he has an obligation to speak out against Federal policies that affect his and other states.
''I am not interested in criticizing the President,'' Mr. Cuomo said in an interview. ''I am interested in doing my job as Governor, and I have said we have an umbilical connection with the Federal Government.''
To prove his point, Mr. Cuomo's staff recently compiled a two-page compendium of nice things that he has said about President Bush. The Strongest Case? Mr. Cuomo said that in the past he has been reluctant to take his crusade against the New Federalism on the road because of fears that news organizations would view his comments as posturing for a Presidential race.
''Now I have abandoned all concern about how what I do gets interpreted because I've discovered you can't affect it,'' he said. ''The press will write what they want to write, whatever they believe. It's a better story to some of them.''
But the Governor might have had some idea that his speech at Harvard, where he spoke to a crowd filled with refugees from Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign, would set off a new round of speculation.
No less an authority than Paul G. Kirk, the immediate past chairman of the Democratic National Committee, listened to Mr. Cuomo and surmised: ''My guess is that the Governor may be asking the question, without actually asking it, 'Who among the potential candidates could make a stronger case?' ''

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1632 words

HEADLINE: At Sea With McPhee

BYLINE: By By PAUL THEROUX. 
Paul Theroux is the author of the novel ''My Secret History'' and two dozen other books.

 BODY:

LOOKING FOR A SHIP.
By John McPhee.
242 pp. New York:
Parrar, Straus & Giroux. $ 18.95.

When John McPhee explains in his characteristically lucid way the difference between ullage and innage, the subtleties of the Plimsoil mark, and the length of a Trident-class submarine, and the manner of a Fathometer tracing the contour of the sea bottom, it is hard not to think of him as ''Doc,'' the plain-spoken polymath, the voice of experience. Doc is methodical and thorough, even to the point of being a teeny bit ponderous. While the rest of us are generalizing like mad and cracking feeble jokes, Doc is simply nodding and taking notes. He has the sort of patience that makes people nervous, and an almost exasperating sanity.
 In ''Looking for a Ship,' an account of his voyage with the United States merchant marine, Doc doesn't get rattled when pirates board at Guayaquil. Doc understands the anxiety of seamen eager to be employed. ''If his neurons seemed hyperactive, they had some reason to be'' -- and isn't it just like Doc to put it like that? When a storm blows the ship sideways, Doc doesn't say exactly how he felt, but rather enumerates things that fell onto the deck -- the alarm clock and all the rest of his clobber. In Chile, Doc reads Charles Darwin. En route he reads Nathaniel Bowditch, the father of modern navigation and author of the basic text, and takes pulses. He knows the age of everyone on board. He is patient -- no record here of his losing his temper; and he is restrained -- only eight obscenities, all told, in this account of sailors. (I find Doc's habit of enumerating to be infections.) When the ship is moored in the steamy Colombian port of Buenaventura, another man might have gone boozing and roistering in the waterfront dives with the crew -- I certainly would have siezed the chance to watch this bunch of level-headed sailors lose their marbles -- but Doc heads for the hills: ''We wanted to see the jungle rising to the Cordillera Occidental.'' Typical!!
 Good-hearted, frugal, truthful, fluent, decent and humane, John McPhee is Doc to his fingertips. In the past, I have trusted him on tennis champs, on geology, physics, Alaska, camping, the construction of the birch-bark canoe and a score of other subjects. In an interview in a recent issue of Sierra, the magazine of the Sierra club, Mr. McPhee was reported as saying, ''My next book could be about a ketchup manufacturer...My next book could be about anything.'' As it happens, this, his next book, is about the sorry state of our merchant marine. Why shouldn't I trust him on that subject too? 
 If Mr. McPhee sayd the Peru-Chile trench is steep and the continental shelf is extremely narrow, I believe it. If he reports an exasperated man is saying, ''Another day in the life of Walter Mitty. Heavens to Murgatroyd, we're stuck in the lock,'' I believe that Mr. McPhee reported it correctly. When a man says, unchallenged, ''Five more years, there won't be no more Merchant Marine. It's going down the guts,'' you have to take it more or less as written -- this is the last gasp of the merchant marine. Mr. McPhee allows himself to be fanciful only now and then. Now is his reference to the fact that his Spanish is purely functional and his grammar ''tartare''; then is a passage beside which I have marked ''joke'' in the margin of my copy --I found no others. The sentence read as follows: ''The author Alex Haley is noted for riding on merchant ships as a way of isolating himself from distinctions and forcing himself to write. He could write a book called 'Routes'.''
 Surrendering to his subject while remaining somewhat obscure himself, a technique that he has just about perfected, Mr. McPhee follows the progress of a man named Andy Chase who is looking for a ship to work on. After quite a lot of hullabaloo, Andy lands himself a berth on the Stella Lykes, bound for the west cosast of South America. Mr. McPhee also boards but as a paying passenger, and he ranges over the ship reporting on the moods and experiences of the rest of the crew. It emerges that Andy is the great-great-great-grandson of Nathaniel Bowditch. But even this cannot make him colorful enough to occupy the center of the book, and he is nudged aside in favor of Capt. Paul McHenry Washburn, the Stella Lykes's skipper, who is both a brilliant captain and a self-made eccentric on a heroic scale.
 A poor student, a runaway, a circus performer (he walked on glass and did fakir tricks) and an amateur boxer, Captain Washburn, earned his master's certificate the hard way, under the tutelages of skippers such as Dirty Shirt George Price and Terrible Terry Harmon. Here is Terrible Terry in a storm: ''Do you know how to pray? Then try that. That's the only thing that's going to save us now.'' Captain Washburn has made a delightful gift for the non sequitor. He understands Columbus and is sympathetic. ''(Columbus) did not produce, and that was the bottom line. He was a maverick, an adventurer; he was not a follower of the party line. Come to think of it -- not to compare myself with Columbus -- some of those adjectives kind of fit me.'' Mr. McPhee obviously agrees, and a few pages later quotes rather a nice Washburnism (the captain speaking from the bridge) ''I would rather be here for the worst that could be here than over there (on land) for the best that could be there.''
 I would be happy to read a whole book about Captain Washburn and cannot think of a better man than Mr. McPhee to write it. Unfortunately, the captain is somewhat incidental to Mr. McPhee's purpose in describing the state of the merchant marine, he writes about the ill-assorted cargo, about stowaways, piracy and flags of convenience. It is all wonderfully set out, but Mr. McPhee makes it clear that the boat and its crew will soon be museum pieces.
 ''Russia is going to have five thousand merchant ships in ten years,'' the captain says, ''And we are going to have none.'' A crewman says, ''We can't compete with countries that pay sailors one dollar a day and feed them fish heads and rice.'' The enjoyment of reading this book is dampened by its lugubrious message: these people are more endangered as a species than the whales and green sea turtles they are among.
 Mr. McPhee is often praised for his economy of phrase and description. Certainly there is a patented McPhee similie, unusual and animal (and it probably helps to be wearing L.L. Bean clothes when you're reading it, like the men ''who fanned out around the office door like fish at the mouth of a tributary stream,'' or the ship that had its end open ''like the mouth of a sucker,'' or ''bick backhoes that look like thunder lizards.'' This is writing that might send some readers searching for an illustrated volume of natural history. There is no question that Mr. McPhee knows what he is talking abouot, but beyond that there can be few writers today -- I think Edward Hoagland and Peter Matthiessen are two exceptions -- who would use the phrase ''graceful as an allligator'' with the certainty that they had hit the nail on the head.
 Ecoomy is a virtue in magazine writing. In a book it can seem like meagerness and insufficiency. These chapters all appeared as articles in The New Yorker. What is it about that magazine? It seems to do with ink and paper what morticians do with formaldehyde. When New Yorker articles and short stories are reprinted in book form I always get a sniff of the clean inky smell of the magazine and can sense its smooth paper, and I hold the book differently, as though I were afraid I would be gouged by a loose staple. Mr. McPhee's writing -- and John Updike's and the writing of so many of us (I speak as a sometime contributor) -- is very often whiffy in this way. This is not a recent phenomenon. The writing of Dickens, Henry James and Conan Doyle also has a fusty, magazine aroma, which is like an unsmoothable wrinkle on a book page. Am I alone in having noticed this, with my exquisite sense of smell?
 I would have preferred ''Looking for a Ship'' to sprawl more; I could have had more of the captain and more of the crew -- Mr. McPhee visited them at home but gives us only the merest glimpses of their family lives. That business about Mr. McPhee's looking at the snowcapped peaks while the crew was drinking and misbehaving and -- who knows? -- using the Christian Science Reading Room; had he concieved this piece as a book, I think he would have seen the necessity of including such boisterous scenes. What looks like prudence and humility could be journalistic economy. Mr. McPhee has written thumping big books, and he has reprinted shorter articles between covers. This is an example of the latter. I wanted more. That might sound like criticism. I mean it as praise. 
COOLING OFF IN THE TROPICS
 All through the summer, everybody in New York and its perisphere had been living in the sort of climate that seals the skin and pops veins in the head: They waded in humidity...By comparison with New York, Panama was cool. The canal, creeping through the forest, was cool. The evening we left Panama, the temperature in the North Pacific was in the seventies. The weather was almost unnerving. As soon as (we) crossed the equator, you heard people say, ''It's winter now'' -- a technicality that is not persuasive there at the latitude of Borneo...We entered the Gulf of Guayaquil. Just the sound of that name -- Guayaquil -- spelled coffee and chocolate to me, spelled mangoes, bananas, guavas, and heat. At four that afternoon, though, when the temperature in New York City was eighty-nine, the temperature in the Gulf of Guayaqul was seventy-five. I finally understood where the tropics are, why the nights of the iguana are on Forty-Seventh street, and Broadway steams with rain. 
 From ''Looking for a Ship''

HEADLINE: INSURERS REDUCING MALPRACTICE FEES FOR DOCTORS IN U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
After rising sharply for more than a decade, medical malpractice insurance premiums are now declining in many states around the country.
Premiums are showing declines of 5 percent to 35 percent as states have set limits on malpractice lawsuits and as doctors, faced with the possibility of damage claims in the millions of dollars, have apparently become more careful.
Some specialists, like anesthesiologists, have adopted standards of patient care requiring new safeguards, and many doctor-owned insurance companies are holding seminars on avoiding medical malpractice.
The Medical Liability Mutual Insurance Company of New York, which is owned by doctors in the state and is the second biggest writer of malpractice insurance in the nation, has just reduced rates by an average of 5 percent.
 
Causes of Decline
''That's the first time our rates have gone down since the company was founded in 1975,'' said Donald J. Fager, vice president of the company. 
Another insurer, the St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company, the largest source of malpractice insurance in the United States, is reducing premiums in 22 of the 42 states where it writes policies for doctors. Beth M. Hamel, a spokeswoman for the company, which insures 30,000 doctors, said the cuts ranged from 6 percent to 25 percent.
Consumers could benefit from such reductions if doctors passed along the savings in the form of lower charges or, more likely, smaller increases in fees.
Experts list several reasons for the decline in malpractice premiums. Lawsuits have prompted doctors to act aggressively to prevent injuries, the experts say, and doctors are ordering many more tests in an abundance of caution known as defensive medicine. In addition, some are limiting the number of patients they see or supervise.
 
Increased Monitoring
Such practices appear to be reducing malpractice claims, but they also tend to increase the cost of health care paid by patients' insurers or government programs.
Research by the American Society of Anesthesiologists suggests that the proper use of new monitoring devices, to measure the level of oxygen in the blood, could have prevented death or serious injury in nearly one-third of the cases where anesthesiologists were accused of malpractice. In cases where the injury was deemed preventable, the patient recovered an average of $494,000 by filing a malpractice claim.
Under a standard that took effect this January, the society requires its members to use certain monitoring devices. Many insurers have recognized such efforts by reducing premiums for anesthesiologists.
Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, said 55 percent to 60 percent of doctors in private practice were now insured by doctor-owned companies. The 43 doctor-owned companies generally do not seek to make a profit and use any profits that might be earned to reduce doctors' premiums.
The doctor-owned companies systematically review claims to identify the most frequent causes of lawsuits, like brain damage to infants or the failure to diagnose breast cancer in women, and they teach doctors how to minimize the risk of such errors.
Some of the doctor-owned companies say they have reduced the number of successful claims by showing doctors how to improve ''communication skills,'' how to elicit more information from patients and how to keep better medical records, so they can defend their performance in court. ''A misfiled lab report can be disastrous,'' said Adam P. Wilczek, vice president of the Medical Inter-Insurance Exchange of New Jersey, a doctor-owned company.
 
New State Laws
About half the states have adopted laws limiting the amount or type of damages that can be recovered in malpractice lawsuits. Such laws often restrict damages for pain and suffering. Some states permit arbitration or require the screening of claims by an administrative tribunal before lawsuits can be tried in court.
Some states have also passed laws to penalize patients who file frivolous claims. Taken together, the changes seem to have made lawyers more selective in the cases they file on behalf of patients.
Michael Maher of Orlando, Fla., president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, which has 65,000 members, said doctors deserved credit for adopting guidelines and standards to reduce injuries to patients. But he said, ''Doctors are responding to the fact that they are the subject of lawsuits for negligence, and there is a great deal left to be done in encouraging quality care.''
Hospitals, state government agencies and the Federal Government are also making more systematic efforts to identify doctors with a history of malpractice. On Sept. 1, the United States Public Health Service established a national computer file to keep track of doctors who are successfully sued for malpractice or are disciplined for incompetence or improper conduct. #32% Cut M Mai As a result of such actions, malpractice insurance premiums have declined dramatically in some states. In Kansas, the premiums were cut by an average of 25 percent, effective July 1 of this year. In Pennsylvania, the insurance company owned by the state medical society reduced malpractice insurance premiums twice this year, by 6.7 percent on Jan. 1 and by a further 15 percent on July 1. In Minnesota, rates for a major underwriter dropped 15 percent on July 1.
Over the last 15 months, insurance companies have reduced malpractice premiums by an average of 10 percent in Colorado, 23 percent in Georgia and 32 percent in Maine.
From 1982 to 1988, premiums rose nationally by an average of more than 18 percent a year, according to the American Medical Association. But in the last few years, insurers say, the number and frequency of malpractice claims have declined, so they can reduce premiums because they built up enough reserves to pay claims and other expenses.
Dr. T. Glenn Williams, an orthopedic surgeon in Albany, Ga., whose annual premium dropped from $60,000 last year to slightly more than $50,000 this year, said patients would benefit because ''we won't have to raise our prices as much'' in the future.
Mark S. Freeland, an economist at the Federal Department of Health and Human Services, said there was ''a small but perceptible decline in the rate of increase in physician fees'' from January 1989 to February 1990. But he said doctors' fees had begun creeping upward again and were still rising 50 percent faster than the Consumer Price Index for all items.
For a typical obstetrician-gynecologist in Pennsylvania, the malpractice premium has dropped more than $6,000. It was $31,125 last year and is now $24,654. For an obstetrician-gynecologist in Kansas, the reduction has been even more substantial, to $49,815 from $66,643.
 
Premium Falls to $120,000
For a neurosurgeon in Nassau County, L.I., the premium charged by the doctor-owned company dropped to $120,000 in July, from $126,000. For an orthopedic surgeon in Albany, the rate dropped to $39,324, from $45,389.
Gail E. Tverberg, an actuary with the Tillinghast unit of Towers Perrin, a management consulting concern, said that while the average size of malpractice claims continued to increase, partly because of inflation, the frequency of claims was less than projected in the mid-1980's. Thus, she said, it turned out that many insurers set their premiums higher than needed.
''Competition has brought those rates back down to match the underlying costs,'' she said. ''That is why we've seen rates drifting downward.''
