SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1793 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Gave Iraq Little Reason Not to Mount Kuwait Assault

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO with MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
In the two weeks before Iraq's seizure of Kuwait, the Bush Administration on the advice of Arab leaders gave President Saddam Hussein little reason to fear a forceful American response if his troops invaded the country.
The Administration's message to Baghdad, articulated in public statements in Washington by senior policy makers and delivered directly to Mr. Hussein by the United States Ambassador, April C. Glaspie, was this: The United States was concerned about Iraq's military buildup on its border with Kuwait, but did not intend to take sides in what it perceived as a no-win border dispute between Arab neighbors.
In a meeting with Mr. Hussein in Baghdad on July 25, eight days before the invasion, Ms. Glaspie urged the Iraqi leader to settle his differences with Kuwait peacefully but added, ''We have no opinion on the Arab-Arab conflicts, like your border disagreement with Kuwait,'' according to an Iraqi document described as a transcript of their conversation.
 
Details of U.S. Diplomacy
Portions of the document, prepared in Arabic by the Iraqi Government, were translated and broadcast by ABC News on Sept. 11 and were the basis of accounts by The Washington Post and The Guardian of London. The State Department declined to confirm the accuracy of the document, but officials did not dispute Ms. Glaspie's essential message. 
As those and other details of the Administration's diplomacy have unfolded in recent weeks, its handling of Iraq before the invasion has begun to draw strong criticism in Congress, even among those who generally support the Administration's military action in the Persian Gulf. Some lawmakers have asserted that the Administration conveyed a sense of indifference to Baghdad's threats.
Interviews with dozens of Administration officials, lawmakers and independent experts and a review of public statements and the Iraqi document show that instead of sending Mr. Hussein blunt messages through public and private statements that an invasion would be unacceptable, the State Department prepared equivocal statements for the Administration about American commitments to Kuwait.
 
Arab Assurances on Invasion
The American strategy, carried out primarily by the State Department but approved by the White House, was based on the assumption that Iraq would not invade and occupy Kuwait. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, who assured the Bush Administration that Mr. Hussein would not invade, argued that the best way to resolve an inter-Arab squabble was for the United States to avoid inflammatory words and actions.
Some senior Administration officials said the strategy was also rooted in the view that Washington - and most of the Arab world - probably could live with a limited invasion of Kuwait, in which Iraqi forces seized bits of Kuwaiti territory to gain concessions.
''We were reluctant to draw a line in the sand,'' a senior Administration official said. ''I can't see the American public supporting the deployment of troops over a dispute over 20 miles of desert territory and it is not clear that the local countries would have supported that kind of commitment. The basic principle is not to make threats you can't deliver on. That was one reason there was a certain degree of hedging on what was said.''
 
Effect of a Harder Line
Even in the days before the invasion, there was a consensus inside the Administration and among outside experts that Mr. Hussein would not invade despite largely correct intelligence assessments of the military buildup on the ground.
''There would have been a lot of fluttering if there had been a partial invasion,'' said an Administration official. ''The crucial factor in determining the American response was not the reality but the extent of the invasion.''
It is not clear that taking a harder line would have made a difference in Baghdad's decision to take Kuwait, and some Administration officials argue that if they had they would now be accused of pushing Mr. Hussein toward extreme actions.
As the Administration's policy toward Iraq before the invasion has come under criticism in Congress, the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, a group of experts who report to President Bush on intelligence issues, has also begun a post-mortem on the handling of the crisis.
 
Flawed Policy on Baghdad
The Administration was following what President Bush acknowledged last week was a flawed policy toward Iraq, a policy built on the premise that the best way to handle Mr. Hussein and moderate his behavior was through improving relations with Baghdad. That assessment presumed that Iran and Iraq, both exhausted by their eight-year border war, would focus on domestic reconstruction, not foreign adventurism.
As a result, the Bush Administration failed to calibrate its policy to take into account a string of belligerent statements and actions by Mr. Hussein in recent months, including the execution of a British journalist and a threat to use chemical weapons against Israel.
''We were essentially operating without a policy,'' said a senior Administration official. ''The crisis came in a bit of a vaccum, at a time when everyone was focusing on German reunification.''
In the days before the invasion, Administration officials sent mixed signals about the American commitment to Kuwait's defense.
 
Speaking With One Voice
Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, for example, was quoted as telling journalists at a press breakfast on July 19 that the American commitment made during the Iran-Iraq War to come to Kuwait's defense if it were attacked was still valid. The same point was also made by Paul Wolfowitz, Undersecretary of Defense for Policy, at a private luncheon with Arab ambassadors. But Pete Williams, Mr. Cheney's chief spokesman, later tried to steer journalists away from the Secretary's remarks, adding that Mr. Cheney had been quoted with ''some degree of liberty.''
From that moment on, there was an orchestrated Administration campaign to speak with one voice, and speak quietly.
On July 24, when Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, was asked whether the United States had any commitment to defend Kuwait, she said, ''We do not have any defense treaties with Kuwait, and there are no special defense or security commitments to Kuwait.''
Asked whether the United States would help Kuwait if it were attacked, she replied, ''We also remain strongly committed to supporting the individual and collective self-defense of our friends in the gulf with whom we have a deep and longstanding ties,'' a statement that some Kuwaiti officials said privately was too weak.
 
Bush's Forceful Tone
Two days before the invasion, John H. Kelly, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, essentially repeated the same message in Congressional testimony.
Even after the invasion, there was unease in some quarters in the State Department over Mr. Bush's tough public stance. On Aug. 6, when President Bush clearly committed the United States to roll back Iraq's conquest of Kuwait, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d expressed reservations about the wisdom of the forceful tone of Mr. Bush remarks, according to Administration officials.
On Tuesday, at a hearing before a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee, Representative Lee H. Hamilton sharply chided Mr. Kelly for not taking a tougher stance against Iraq in his testimony before the invasion.
''You left the impression that it was the policy of the United States not to come to the defense of Kuwait,'' said Mr. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat. ''I asked you if there was a U.S. commitment to come to Kuwait's defense if it was attacked. Your response over and over again was we have no defense-treaty relationship with any gulf country.''
 
Policy Guidelines Followed
Bush Administration officials assert that Kuwait never asked for American troops or sought to join in joint military exercises with American forces.
Mr. Cheney told a breakfast group on Capitol Hill on Thursday that ''the fact was, there was literally nothing we could do until we could get access to that part of the world, and the attitude of Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf states has been consistently that they didn't want U.S. forces on the ground over there.''
On July 25, a week before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Ms. Glaspie was quickly summoned to Mr. Hussein's office in Baghdad, and she faithfully followed conciliatory policy guidelines sent to her from the State Department.
In their conversation, Mr. Hussein described an American conspiracy against him since the end of his war with Iraq, and warned the United States not to oppose his goal of getting economic concessions from Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, according to the document described as the official Iraqi transcript, which ABC News made available to the New York Times. Miss Tutwiler said Friday that the State Department would not reveal the contents of a diplomatic exchange.
 
'We Too Can Harm You'
According to the Iraqi document, Mr. Hussein also suggested that he would use terrorism to curb any effort by the United States to try to stop him from achieving his goals.
''We too can harm you,'' he said according to the document, adding, ''We cannot come all the way to the United States but individual Arabs may reach you.''
But at another point in the document, he characterized the feud with his neighbors as an inter-Arab dispute, adding that the solution ''must be found within an Arab framework and through direct bilateral negotiations.''
Ambassador Glaspie stuck to the State Department line that President Bush wanted good relations with Iraq. Citing concern about Iraq's large troop buildup on the border and threatening remarks by Mr. Hussein in a number of his statements, she said that she had received instructions from Washington ''to ask you, in the spirit of friendship - not in the spirit of confrontation -regarding your intentions.''
In a long reply, Mr. Hussein said he and the Kuwaiti leadership had agreed to negotiate their differences. ''But if we are unable to find a solution,'' he said, ''then it will be natural that Iraq will not accept death.''
Some officials say they are convinced that Iraq had already made a decision to invade when President Hussein met the American Ambassador and that Mr. Hussein's talk of a possible peaceful resolution was an effort to deceive Washington.
''To suggest that we are to blame for all of this and we lulled them into thinking they could have Kuwait is really terrible,'' a senior official said. ''But we should have had a stiffer tone. It is unlikely to have made a difference, but it might have made a difference.''

HEADLINE: On Street, Rinfret Is a Renaissance Man of Sorts

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
His gubernatorial campaign has been in disarray the last week, but in some ways Pierre A. Rinfret's public image has not suffered. On the streets of Brooklyn and Queens he is still most commonly thought of not as a political neophyte, not as a maverick underdog, but as a French artist.
That is the finding of a thoroughly unscientific survey in which 40 residents of the two boroughs were asked if they had heard of Mr. Rinfret. Twenty-five percent correctly identified him as the Republican candidate for governor, while 30 percent said he was an artist - a modern French painter, in most minds, although some classified him as a sculptor, and one man cited his work during the Renaissance. 
Mr. Rinfret was also identified as a perfume, a movie star, a drug dealer, a fashion designer, an advocate for the homeless, a chef, a television journalist, the French Ambassador, a correction officer and a goalie for the New York Rangers.
''Is he missing?'' asked Anthony Guerra, a 56-year-old retired cabdriver in Ridgewood, Queens, as he looked at a picture of Mr. Rinfret that was provided to help jog his memory. ''Nope, never seen him.'' Name-Recognition Problem Mr. Rinfret's name-recognition problem was documented in a far more reliable poll taken September 10 and 11 by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion. In the telephone poll of 821 registered voters, which had a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate, was recognized by 99.7 percent of the voters, and Mr. Rinfret was recognized by 62 percent.
After that poll was taken, Mr. Rinfret's campaign troubles received extensive publicity. On Wednesday he threatened to drop out unless the Republican Party gave more money to the campaign. Party officials then accused him of refusing to spend most of the $540,000 of his own money he had contributed to the campaign.
But all the publicity did not seem to affect his image among most of those interviewed on Friday, the day Mr. Rinfret vowed to stay in the race but denounced virtually every leading Republican in the state. Even in Ridgewood and Middle Village, Queens, where Republican candidates usually do relatively well, most residents surveyed did not know who he was.
''He's an artist,'' said Gep Truglio, 63, a retired bank guard in Ridgewood who called himself a Democrat.
''No,'' said Mr. Truglio's 62-year-old wife, Josephine, a Republican, ''he's a news commentator.''
''He's a French cook,'' said Mr. Truglio. ''He gives seminars.''
''No, he's on the news,'' Mrs. Truglio insisted. ''He's a world traveler.''
Shown Mr. Rinfret's picture, Mr. Truglio said, ''He's a French singer in Las Vegas.''
''He's an airline pilot,'' Mrs. Truglio suggested.
A middle-aged man walking near them along Fresh Pond Road called out, ''A drug dealer - yeah, that's who he is. All kinds of drugs.''
 
'He Looks Polish to Me'
''I would guess some type of French abstract artist,'' said Pete Vigliotti, a 31-year-old building maintenance worker from Ridgewood.
In Bill's Restaurant at 7324 Metropolitan Avenue in Middle Village, none of the six customers could identify Mr. Rinfret. Nor could any of the seven men sitting at Walter's Super-Cut Unisex hair salon at 1268 Myrtle Avenue in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, but one man did guess that Mr. Rinfret was a politician.
''He looks Polish to me,'' said the owner of the salon, Walter Heredia.
Eddie Mahe, a consultant to the Rinfret campaign, said that he was not surprised at the survey's results.
 
Less Television Coverage
''It's clearly true - we do not have name I.D. in the city,'' he said. ''It reflects the fact that we haven't had the money to buy millions of dollars worth of television time, and that television news has just started to decide the governor's race is important. We've had some coverage upstate, but not much in the city.''
Mr. Mahe laughed when he heard of Mr. Rinfret's artistic reputation. ''Well, he's French-Canadian, so at least they're half right about his nationality,'' Mr. Mahe said. ''But as far as I know, he's not an artist.''
A separate survey in Manhattan found a higher level of name recognition for Mr. Rinfret, although the finding might have biased by the location of the 14 interviews. They took place on the sidewalk outside Mr. Rinfret's home on Fifth Avenue on the Upper East Side.
 
His Doormen Know Him
Eight people, including two doormen at his building, correctly identified Mr. Rinfret.
''Yes, I've heard of him - the artist,'' said another Upper East Sider, a middle-aged woman rushing down Fifth Avenue in an aerobic walk.
''I've known him for years,'' said Charles Werner, 80, who correctly identified Mr. Rinfret as an economist. ''I knew him when I worked in the investment world, where he did very well. He's an unusual person and he has talent. He's very outspoken and very creative. I think he'd make a fine governor.''
Mr. Werner paused and looked uncertain. ''Wait, was I right there? What is it he's running for again?''

HEADLINE: NEW YORK WANTS CLEANEST AIR ACT

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
New York City officials, faced with continuing violations of Federal smog and carbon monoxide standards, are pressing for adoption of the strongest anti-pollution measures Congress is considering as it tries to agree on amendments to the Clean Air Act.
The 142 House and 7 Senate conferees met all summer in Washington to resolve differences between the revisions to the act that were passed by each house this spring. The 20-year-old Clean Air Act has not been revised since 1977.
Both bills would require major changes by businesses, particularly in the most polluted cities like New York, which will ultimately cost everyone more money. The Bush Administration estimated recently that the total economic cost would be at least $35 billion a year. 
Congressional conferees have reached the part of the 700-page bill that addresses motor vehicles, the source of much of New York City's air pollution. Decisions in the next few days about tailpipe-emission controls and clean-burning fuels will heavily influence when and if New Yorkers will be able to breathe healthy air.
 
Expensive Ozone Control
The conferees have already agreed to the House version of provisions to reduce smog from industrial sources. The House bill, supported by New York officials because it requires greater regulation of industrial sources, allows the city 17 more years to attain the Federal ozone standard.
The industrial-smog provisions would have far-reaching effects in the New York area. Even small businesses like dry cleaners and bakeries would have to install expensive ozone-control devices. Vehicle-control measures like car-pooling and high-occupancy vehicle lanes would most likely have to be ordered in an effort to reduce or slow the growth of traffic.
Ozone, the primary component of smog, is formed when hydrocarbons and oxides of nitrogen mix in the atmosphere in sunlight. Almost half the hydrocarbon emissions in New York come from mobile sources like cars and trucks; the rest come from sources like industrial plants, gasoline stations and paints and hairspray. Ninety percent of carbon monoxide emissions come from motor vehicles.
In recent letters to members of the New York State Congressional delegation and influential Senators and Representatives, Mayor David N. Dinkins and the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, Albert F. Appleton, said they sought the strongest possible Federal air pollution program, especially for motor vehicles.
 
Fought by Auto and Oil Concerns
''We need a tough, comprehensive mobile-source program with the strictest standards for tailpipe emissions,'' Mr. Appleton wrote. ''We need aggressive alternative fuel vehicles by bus operators, fleet operators and taxis, and mandatory use of reformulated gasoline and oxygenated fuel.''
But New York is unlikely to get all that it wants in the motor vehicle and fuels section of the clean-air bill. For one thing, it has asked for measures that are not in either bill. And the automobile and oil industries have fought hard in the House and Senate to limit what they will have to do to comply with the act. Congressional staff members said last week that those industries were pressing conferees to further weaken the provisions, particularly rules for reformulated gasoline and clean-fuel vehicles for fleets.
Both issues are important to New York. Widespread use of specially blended gasoline, which produces emissions that cause less buildup in the ozone layer, could give the city 20 percent of the reductions it needs to meet Federal smog standards without a big increase in the cost of fuel, environmental groups say.
 
Dinkins Pledges Cleaner Fleets
Irrespective of Federal mandates, the Dinkins administration has committed itself to buying more vehicles for city fleets that run on cleaner-burning fuels like natural gas. In general, the city views fleets - groups of private or government vehicles that can be centrally fueled - as important to air quality because they represent a high percentage of midtown traffic. But conferees are discussing limiting the categories of vehicles, like heavy-duty trucks, that would be required to convert to cleaner-burning fuels, Congressional staff members said.
Also, the House bill calls for a pilot program in California, where pollution is most severe, mandating the sale of thousands of individually owned cars that run on cleaner-burning fuels. New York has asked to join the program.
There are doubts about the conferees' ability to complete discussions before adjournment, scheduled for early October, but there is a chance they will return for a session after the November elections.
Besides motor vehicles and fuels, the conferees still have to deal with the contentious issues of hazardous air emissions and acid rain. It took them the entire summer to get this far, in part because the crisis in the Middle East and the nation's budget problems are dominating legislators' attention.
But powerful legislators like Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, say they want a bill this year. Mr. Dingell, who has helped block clean-air legislation in past years, said in Washington last week that he was ''strongly committed'' to a House-Senate accord as soon as possible.
Environmentalists have said the Senate bill has stronger rules on motor vehicle emissions and the House measure is tougher on urban smog.

HEADLINE: 8 Arrested in Boycott of Brooklyn Store

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
One day after Mayor David N. Dinkins called for a peaceful resolution of the eight-month boycott of two Korean-owned stores in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, scores of shoppers returned to the stores, but eight protesters were arrested for violating the court order that mandated they stay at least 50 feet from them.
The protesters vowed yesterday to continue the boycott until the Family Red Apple and Church Fruits and Vegetables on Church Avenue were shut down.
''We are here to close Church Fruits and Red Apple until every merchant learns to respect their customers,'' said Sabine Albert, a leader of the Flatbush Frontline Collective, a group that was organized around the black-led boycott. She was later arrested by the police for disorderly conduct. 
But despite cries of ''Boycott!'' that were hurled at them, a stream of customers flowed through the steady rain past the demonstrators and shopped at both stores. Many said they had been afraid to cross the picket lines in past months but were stirred to action by Mayor Dinkins's decision to shop at the stores on Friday.
 
'We Are All Immigrants'
''It is time for this foolishness to finish,'' said Patricia Quow, who lives in the neighborhood and said she had avoided the Family Red Apple because of the jeers and taunts of the demonstrators. ''This country owes everybody a living; we are all immigrants.''
About 50 demonstrators from a rally in support of the boycott gathered near the stores about 2 P.M. yesterday, carrying placards and posters of Malcolm X. A shoving match erupted when the police tried to keep the protesters behind the yellow line on the sidewalk that marked the 50-foot distance that the court had decreed the protesters had to maintain.
Six men and two women were arrested when they crossed the line. They were charged with disorderly conduct, bringing to 13 the number of protesters arrested since the police began enforcing the court order this week. They were taken for booking to a special processing unit set up nearby, where they were issued desk-appearance tickets and told not to rejoin the protest.
One man who was arrested, Guisner Etienne, was charged with assaulting a police officer. The police said the officer had suffered a sprained wrist in a scuffle with Mr. Etienne as he arrested him.
''The issue here is an issue of the political economy of the city,'' Malcolm Amorali, a protester, said to those who remained after the arrests. ''The police are not here to protect us; they are here to defend their own interests.''
 
Protesters Deride Dinkins
Two of the arrested protesters rejoined the picket line. ''It's a moral issue,'' one of them, Holly Volny, said. ''We are right and they are wrong.'' His remarks were presaged earlier in the day, when a handful of protesters stood behind barricades, angered by what they saw as the Mayor's decision to take sides in the conflict.
''Nothing can stop us!'' one protester shouted. ''We ain't going to listen to Uncle Tom Dinkins.''
One protester who declined to give his name pointed with scorn to the 100 police officers who lined the sidewalks outside both stores. ''David Dinkins has come with the state to violate our constitutional rights,'' he said. A police spokesman, Raymond O'Donnell, said a total of 400 officers were assigned to the detail that patrols the area.
The protests began last January after Giselaine Felissaint, a Haitian-American woman, said she was assaulted by an employee of the Family Red Apple. She said the worker then sought refuge across the street at Church Fruits and Vegetables. The Family Red Apple's owner has said that the woman became unruly after refusing to pay the full price of her groceries.
The employee, Pong Ok Jang, has been charged with assault, and Mrs. Felissaint has filed a $6 million civil suit against the owner of the Family Red Apple Yesterday, the protesters remained firm, and that worried one city official who has been trying to mediate the dispute. ''There are limits to what government can do to resolve a situation that has become this polarized,'' said the official, David Scott, chief of staff for the City Human Rights Commission. ''I don't think that anybody believes any single action by the Mayor could end it.''
Mr. Scott, whose agency has been talking with all sides, said the standoff had worsened. Aside from those who want to close the stores, he said, others want to see Ms. Felissaint's case resolved before ending the boycott, and still others will not be satisfied until the city begins addressing issues of economic opportunity for disadvantaged residents.
''Clearly, there are numerous positions on this and numerous objectives being sought,'' Mr. Scott said, ''and some are probably more valid than others.''
Bong Jae Jang, the owner of the Family Red Apple, said he was heartened by the number of customers coming to his store. He said that almost 400 people came on Friday, spending nearly $1,500. By the time the store closed at 8 o'clock last night, more than 250 others had come to spend their money at the formica counter across the aisle from a ''peace bench,'' a brown park bench Mr. Bong installed as a gesture of friendship to what he called ''my Church Avenue neighbors.'' More than 300 people shopped at Church Fruits and Vegetables.
Mr. Bong estimated that he had lost $100,000 in business since the protest began. He examined the corroded, dusty cans of tropical juices and worm-infested boxes of flour and added that the cost of those and other spoiled perishables will drive up his losses.
But he said his spirits were buoyed by the shoppers who followed in the Mayor's footsteps.
Mr. Bong, who is from a village 50 miles from the 38th Parallel in Korea, said he did not fear for his own safety, but was concerned about the pickets' refusal to negotiate. ''We want to talk with these people,'' he said. ''The Mayor tried, but these people won't learn.''
While the protesters vowed to continue their boycott, Mr. Bong made a vow of his own. ''I'm not worried about money. I can always make money,'' he said. ''But these people are killing my dream. But I will follow my dream. I don't want to be rich. I just want to follow my dream.''

Eight protesters were arrested yesterday for violating a court order instructing them to stay at least 50 feet from the stores. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Has Dole Found a Way Out of the Budget Impasse?

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Congressional budget negotiators, taking a break from their formal deliberations until Sunday evening, spent today trying to decide whether Senator Bob Dole of Kansas had found a way out of the current impasse with his proposal to sever capital gains tax cuts from a deficit reduction package.
The proposal, advanced this week by Mr. Dole, the Senate Republican leader, is an elaborate legislative gambit that would require negotiators to produce two budget packages that would be voted on separately but whose fates would be linked. Supporters say it could be a stroke of genius, giving rank-and-file lawmakers in both parties a little of what they want while forcing them to swallow a lot of what they do not want.
For those Republicans who have never been as keen to cut the capital gains rate as President Bush is, the Dole proposal may also provide a face-saving way to set aside that issue and free Congress for a vote on a real budget deal. If the strategy sounds complicated, that is no accident. 
 
Master of Confusion
Mr. Dole, a former chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, is a master of creative confusion, and his tactics, though not without risk, have often produced brilliant legislative victories. The idea here is to give each side an incentive to make both packages succeed, while simultaneously increasing the cost of failure.
The strategy is based on one he employed in 1986, as Senate majority leader, to link sanctions against South Africa with military aid for the rebel forces in Nicaragua. He engineered a double victory, getting the contra aid that President Ronald Reagan wanted while getting Republicans on the popular side of the South Africa issue despite Mr. Reagan's opposition to the sanctions.
Under Mr. Dole's proposal, one budget package would include unpopular spending cuts and tax increases totaling $50 billion in 1991 and $500 billion over five years. That would be voted on first.
The second package would combine the capital gains tax cut, extension of a dozen popular tax breaks due to expire at the end of this year, other revenue-losing measures and spending initiatives like a child-care program. The catch is that the second package, which would cost at least $60 billion if both parties were to get all their current wishes, would have to be financed with other tax increases or spending cuts.
 
Problem: Finding the Money
If the second package failed, Mr. Dole's proposal stipulates that the first would go down as well. But Mr. Dole's supporters argue that having passed the first package, lawmakers would have enough momentum to come together quickly on the second one, and would be reluctant to undo what both sides could bill as a historic budget deal.
The Kansas Senator has taken some heat in his own party, particularly from House Republicans who see him abandoning the party's commitment to a reduction in the tax rate on capital gains, or profits on the sale of assets, and other tax measures they say would stimulate the economy.
And even lawmakers who find Mr. Dole's proposal intriguing are hard pressed to come up with ways to pay for the measures that would be included in his second package. They note that many of the spending cuts or revenue increases that would be needed have already been tapped as part of the initial deficit-cutting package.
 
The Tough Options
One potential source of revenue would be corporate tax increases. In the proposals Democrats and Republicans have exchanged in the last several weeks of budget negotiations, corporations have been largely spared.
Other options might be deeper spending cuts in programs like Medicare, Medicaid and farm subsidies or increases in tax rates for individuals. So far Democrats have rejected the first option, and Republicans have deemed the second one unacceptable. The question for both sides is whether any of those options becomes more attractive if they are attached to a package of popular measures than they are now as solutions for deficit reduction.
''You're likely to end up having the same fight on the House and Senate floor that you are having right now at the negotiating table,'' said one Republican aide who has been involved in the bargaining. ''You have to ask yourself whether there isn't a simpler way.''
But from Mr. Dole's point of view, an open floor fight over the second package could have political advantages. Concerned that Republican support for the capital gains tax cut is allowing Democrats to portray his party as the champion of the wealthy, Mr. Dole is looking for a way to defuse the issue and call attention to Democratic demands for spending increases.
At a time when the only alternative seems to be deep automatic spending cuts that could cripple essential services across the country, Mr. Dole's strategy carries risks for both parties as they jockey for advantage. But he is wagering that at best the dual package will produce some combination of what everybody wants, while at worst it will leave the stalemated budget negotiators exactly where they are now.

HEADLINE: Bottom Line: Perception;
Budget Deal Might Not Do Much at First, But Economists Agree It's Worth Making

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
At a news conference with out-of-town reporters last week, President Bush said an agreement with Congress to reduce the Federal deficit was ''the best antidote to further economic slowdown.''
But a wide range of economists, from those who say the Federal deficit is a critical problem to those who think its dangers have been overstated, agree that a budget deal would do little to help the country weather the current economic slump and could even worsen the situation for a time.
''The budget deficit didn't cause the recession, and fixing the deficit isn't going to cure it,'' said John H. Makin, director of fiscal policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute.
Mr. Makin and most of the other economists say that cutting the deficit now is in the country's long-term interest and that the President and Congress should not abandon their negotiations just because the economy is shaky. But many say the immediate effect of raising taxes and cutting Government spending would be to slow the economy further. 
 
The Long Term and the Short
The Federal Reserve, they say, could be expected to lower interest rates in response to a serious plan to reduce the deficit. But they observe that changes in interest rates generally take six to nine months to work their way through the economy, while tax and spending changes are felt at once.
''There is no way that raising taxes or cutting spending is not going to be contractionary,'' said Benjamin M. Friedman, a Harvard economist whose book ''Day of Reckoning'' (Random House, 1988) is widely cited in support of the view that large deficits pose grave dangers. ''It does little good for people like me who believe strongly in a budget deal to say otherwise.''
Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities on Wall Street, expressed the prevailing view. ''The primary reason for reducing the deficit,'' he said, ''is not to influence the direction of the economy in the short run. We want lower deficits to slow the growth in debt and to increase long-term economic potential.''
 
The Sticking Points
Administration officials and Congressional leaders have been working since spring on a plan to cut the deficit in the Government's $1.2 trillion budget by $50 billion in the next fiscal year and by a total of $500 billion over the next five years. The deficit is now estimated at $250 billion.
Beginning two weekends ago, they met for 10 days at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland without resolving their differences. This week, a smaller group of the Bush Administration's three chief economic policy makers and the five top Congressional leaders met for four days without staff in a back room at the Capitol and still failed to reach an agreement. They plan to resume their talks Sunday evening.
Unless an accord is reached or the law is changed, across-the-board spending cuts of more than 30 percent in most Government programs would automatically take effect with the start of the 1991 fiscal year on Oct. 1. Economists say the economy would soon collapse under the strain of such large, indiscriminate spending reductions.
The main sticking point has been over President Bush's insistence on a capital gains tax cut, and the Democrats' determination to impose higher taxes on the wealthy. There is also significant disagreement on how to apportion spending reductions. Is This a Recession? Economists disagree over whether the economy is actually in a recession, is likely to enter one soon or will narrowly avoid one. The official definition of a recession is a decline in the gross national product for six months in a row, which has not occurred.
Blue Chip Economic Indicators, the monthly survey of 50 prominent economists, found this month that 25 thought a recession had started or would start this year, and that 8 expected a recession next year.
Even those others who do not see a recession at hand are forecasting a period of slow growth in which many parts of the country will feel a serious pinch. So whether a recession actually occurs is a matter of definition; economists all agree that the the economy is now weak.
Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Gerald R. Ford, said the deficit ''does not tip the economy from one quarter to another.'' But he added that it should be reduced for two reasons.
''First, the effect of deficit reduction on long-term economic growth, while small, is worthwhile,'' he said. ''Second, the deficit gets in the way of all kinds of other decisions, whenever we have to decide whether to help Poland or fight drugs or whatever.''
In ''Day of Reckoning,'' Mr. Friedman wrote that failure to lower the deficit would mean ''a lower standard of living for individual Americans and reduced American influence and importance in the world.''
 
The Interest Slice of the Pie
Other economists observed that as long as the deficit remained high, the country would have to spend a larger and larger share of its resources to make interest payments to its creditors. The General Accounting Office, the Government's chief auditing agency, noted in a report last week that interest payments were rising so fast that at the current rate they would become the largest single item in the general fund of the budget by 1992, larger than military expenditures or Medicare payments.
It is widely agreed that the country would be better off if the money were spent on education, rebuilding roads and bridges, improving the environment or countless other productive endeavors.
Most of the economists interviewed said that although raising taxes and cutting spending might worsen a recession slightly for a few months, it would be worthwhile if the financial markets perceived that the politicians were serious about reducing the deficit and making it stick.
Mr. Makin, one of the economists who has never been terribly concerned about the size of the deficit, said such a perception would lead to lower long-term bond rates. That, in turn, would allow the Federal Reserve to relax short-term rates without fear of more inflation. People and companies would be encouraged to borrow and spend more, stimulating the economy.
But that process could take months, perhaps even a year, before the effect was felt. And given the record, many economists are skeptical that the markets will trust the politicians not to change their minds.
For years, said Mr. Stein, the precise deficit-reduction targets of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law have been met by raising the ceiling or using phony accounting, and he finds it difficult to believe that the politicians have found religion all of a sudden.
''The feeling that confidence is going to be greatly restored has no basis in fact,'' he said. ''Betting on restoring confidence is chimera.''

HEADLINE: Year Later, St. Croix Is Coming Back, And Trying to Bring Tourists With It

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHRISTIANSTED, V.I., Sept. 21

 BODY:
A year ago this week, Isabelle M. Pence boarded a plane on St. Croix as she and hundreds of others fled in a scene of frenzy that she likens to the evacuation of Saigon. Carrying what little they could salvage, they left frightened and hungry from an island lost to a hurricane that hit like a wrecker's ball.
Today Mrs. Pence is in the midst of rebuilding her three-bedroom house. On St. Croix, where Hurricane Hugo damaged 90 percent of the buildings and left an estimated 22,500 people homeless, hammers are pounding and residents, including returnees like Mrs. Pence, express optimism.
''The bottom line for me is that I can't live any other place than St. Croix,'' said Mrs. Pence, a 67-year-old New Jersey native who came here as a tourist and moved in 27 years ago. 
Hugo raged through St. Croix on the night and morning of Sept. 17 and 18 on its way from the Caribbean up the East Coast. Losses in the three United States Virgin Islands, which also include St. Thomas and St. John, surpassed $1.5 billion, though only a handful of deaths were reported on St. Croix.
 
Trauma of Uncontrolled Looting
But St. Croix has more to recover from than damage to buildings, trees and utility poles. By daybreak after the storm struck, when water, power and all communication were lost, looters filled the streets and emptied the shops.
President Bush sent 1,100 Army troops to restore order, plus 80 Federal agents to take virtual command of the law-enforcement operations.
But long after the civil disturbances were quelled and the rebuilding of the island was under way, St. Croix officials worried that the tourists who are vital to the economy would be scared away indefinitely by the vivid news coverage of the looting.
 
Winter Will Tell Results
The coming winter will tell much about the recovery of St. Croix's image. Last winter's tourist season was all but lost anyway, because so few hotels were habitable.
The Virgin Islands government will spend $7 million in advertising this season, much of it meant to fight the notion that St. Croix is devastated and unsafe, said Betty Sperber, president of the St. Croix Hotel and Tourism Association.
Tourism, which pumps $700 million into the economy of the three islands every year, accounting for two-thirds of all income, was down by more than 40 percent in the first half of the year in St. Croix.
Airport arrivals, down 15.3 percent in the first seven months of the year, were up 9.8 percent in July compared with last year, according to the Department of Economic Development, although some of that increase may have been because of cut-rate fares and other aggressive promotions.
 
Temporary Pier for Ships
Cruise ships, which brought about 8,000 visitors a month, have been unable to dock because of the destroyed Frederiksted pier, but ships have scheduled 32 port calls this season, beginning next month, at a temporary pier. Last winter 120 port calls were planned before Hugo wiped them out.
The number of hotel rooms occupied during the first six months of the year fell by 53 percent from the same period last year, but at present there are 850 rooms as against 1,800 before the storm.
If Mrs. Pence felt compelled to come back, other residents did not. The Virgin Islands Department of Health estimates that a quarter of St. Croix's population of 55,000 left the island in the wake of the storm, although the exact number who stayed away is unclear.
As for services on the island, electrical and telephone service were fully restored earlier this year. The foliage is back and most stores and hotels have reopened. Schools, the hospital and public buildings are functioning in various stages of repair, or in temporary quarters, and a construction boom has helped offset the economic effects of the tourism slump.
Cruzans, as the island's residents are known, recognize that a full comeback is years away. On the streets, a section of a movie theater's corrugated metal roof still sits in a parking lot; the top half of a stadium's light pole still dangles upside down. Thousands of residents live in emergency mobile homes and modular units while others still inhabit the shells of former homes.
 
Problems Collection Insurance
About 700 homeowners and 500 businesses were unable to collect insurance after two insurers went out of business. The St. Croix government is now putting together a financing plan to honor $52 million in unpaid claims through a bond issue.
The Federal Emergency Management Agency and other Federal agencies have spent $610.1 million on recovery efforts, most of it for St. Croix, the most populated of the islands. Among the biggest projects yet to be completed are the reconstruction of St. Croix Hospital and the replacement of a 10-million-gallon water tank.
The emergency agency has also approved a $90 million loan for the Virgin Islands government to compensate for the drop in tax revenue.
In Christiansted's historic district, a vendor sits alone by his produce and housewares stand under a tarpaulin, waiting for construction workers to complete the roof in the once-bustling marketplace.
''The tarpaulin leaks when it rains,'' said the vendor, Montgomery (Beeman) Siom, 64, who has been in the business for 25 years. ''The sun burns. I lose a lot to spoilage.''
In Grove Place near Frederiksted, in the western part of the island, a family of six lives in what used to be their utility shed, awaiting a loan to repair their roofless house.
''Any time my house is finished I'll feel like my life is back to normal,'' said the mother, Eulali Francis, 55.
 
Trying to Undersand Looters
Most people on the island condemn the looting that followed the hurricane, but they have sought to understand it. They say many looters were panicked by the damage and chaos of the storm and grabbed food and other items because they feared shortages. Others, the residents acknowledge, were tempted by the absence of overwhelmed local law-enforcement officers. In any case, they say, the disturbances were distorted and sensationalized by reporters.
Although the looting was widespread, said David Nissman, chief Assistant United States Attorney for St. Croix, limited resources meant there could be only 20 prosecutions. There were 15 convictions, he said, including a bank vice president and a restaurant owner. Two police officers, accused of having joined the looting, were acquitted.
St. Croix is 80 percent black, but most businesses are run by whites, so the looting was originally perceived as having racial overtones. But Mr. Nissman said racial hostility was not a factor, nor was the need of the looters, While some looters stole food and emergency items, he noted, the majority went for items like shoes, appliances, electronic goods, even lawn mowers.
 
'People Are Kinder Now'
After having been ransacked, the Sunny Isle shopping center, the island's largest, opened up last May. Store managers said they are willing to forget, or at least to try.
''People are kinder now,'' said Robert E. Fitzgerald, general manager of Woolworth's, the island's only department store. ''They don't mess up the store as much. I may be naive but I think they feel remorse. I don't think it would happen again.''
People's Drugstore now sports security gates for its front doors, ''our weak spot,'' said the manager, Gary Schumacher, who found more than 100 people inside the store the day after the storm. He said a few later offered to pay for what they took.
''You just block it out,'' he said. But he added: ''There are one or two faces that stick. They come into the store and your stomach turns.''
On the hills overlooking Christiansted, Mrs. Pence has already cleaned out her home of most damaged belongings, including books and porcelains. Mrs. Pence, a founding member of the St. Croix animal shelter, is now accompanied only by Maggie, her 8-year-old mutt. Benji, her other dog, had to be put to sleep after being hit by a falling beam the night the three raced to a closet for safety.
 
Objects Are Less Important
''One of the things the storm did to us is that we all feel material things aren't as important as we once did,'' she said. ''I'll never collect anything again. It's going to be a different lifestyle.''
In a village of 400 federally supplied mobile homes near the airport, Aubrey Liburd, 44, his wife and three children have just been reunited.After the storm, the family's wrecked apartment was looted and they have spent most of the past years with friends and relatives.
''Hugo has caused people to see the good in people and the bad in people,'' Mr. Liburd said. ''You found out who your friends were.''
Gov. Alexander A. Farrelly will find out the degree of dissatisfaction with his performance during the disaster when he comes up for re-election this November. He is widely criticized as having failed to prepare for the storm adequately and for his reluctance to send for Federal troops to establish order.
 
Island Response Is Defended
The National Guard Bureau dismissed Adj. Gen. Robert Moorehead, commander in the Virgin Islands, for lack of leadership after Hugo.
''Given no communication, a total population of victims, we had a pretty damn good response,'' said Lieut. Gov. Derek M. Hodge, who is running on Mr. Farrelly's slate.
Last week, Cruzans commemorated the anniversary of the disaster with religious services and parties. Hugo, they said, has also brought money to those flocking to the construction trade from in and outside the island, as evidenced by a higher number of automobile and satellite dishes.
''People are optimistic that the island is getting a lot better,'' said a bar owner, Richi Black.
A similar assessment came from the Federal emergency agency's coordinator in the territory, Steven B. Singer, who said St. Croix would be better prepared for another Hugo. Telephone lines are now underground, for example, and the power distribution system has been decentralized.
''They have the perverse benefit of having experienced probably the worst,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Atlanta Seeks to Deliver City It Sold to Olympics

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The bid for the Olympic Games was one part Rhett and Scarlett and one part the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., both marketed with the entrepreneurial zeal that has been Atlanta's most consistent thread since its founding as a lonely railroad junction in 1842.
The euphoria has not abated since the announcement on Tuesday that Atlanta had been chosen over Athens as the site of the 1996 Summer Olympics. And as much as it was a source of enormous pride, the announcement has also highlighted both the constancy and the startling change in the South's most important city.
It was this contradictory blending of the Old South and the new that had veterans of the civil rights movement using imagery from the Civil War era to summarize Atlanta's victory. 
''After Sherman burned the city down, we rose back, and it seems like every 20 or 30 years, there is another great push, another great boom in Atlanta,'' said Representative John Lewis, a longtime civil rights leader. ''I see this as part of that continuum.'' Living Up to Its Image Some analysts say the estimate that Atlanta will reap $3.48 billion from the 1996 games is wildly inflated. They note that the organizers still must build $418 million of stadiums and buildings and raise $1.16 billion to stage the games.
But the Olympics are almost certain to mean an incalculable boost in international stature and an extended economic stimulant that will help the city through what looks like its first major downturn in 15 years.
Less certain is whether Atlanta will be able to live up to the idealized picture of racial and social harmony it sold not only to the International Olympic Committee but also to itself.
''What the Olympic Committee saw is what Atlanta is trying to be, not what it is,'' said the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference based in Atlanta. ''What Atlanta is saying is not that we've arrived, but that we are working like the dickens to go where we know we must go.''
 
A Century of Boosterism
If the thought of Atlanta as the site of an event of such international proportions seemed a bit startling to outsiders, it was not without precedent.
Most often cited for comparison is the Cotton States and International Exposition of 1895, where amid much ballyhoo a reborn Atlanta staked its claim as the capital of the South, promoting the idea that a New South had put the Civil War behind it.
Since then, Atlanta's leaders have worked together to expand the economic frontiers, billing the city at various times as ''Gate City of the South,'' ''Capital of the New South,'' ''A City Too Busy to Hate,'' ''Black Mecca'' and ''The World's Next Great City,''
''This will transform the city's skyline,'' said former Gov. George Busbee, chairman of the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce. ''When I was on the BBC in 1975, they didn't know if Atlanta was closer to California or Florida. After the Olympics no one will ever ask where Atlanta is.'' When Atlanta began its campaign for the 1996 games in 1988, some members of the International Olympic Committee confused it with Atlantic City.
 
Silence From Doubters
As in its earlier days, when a tight-knit business community dictated the city's economic future, Atlanta benefited from unity. While Toronto's bid, for example, was hurt by questions of whether the games would be the best use of local resources, any doubters in Atlanta stayed largely quiet.
Anita Beaty, co-director of the Atlanta Task Force for the Homeless, said homeless advocates thought it would be a major political risk to question the bid publicly.
''You could certainly say there was some fear of reprisal,'' Ms. Beaty said. ''It's hard to say too much now. The city is just hysterical about this.''
But if the links to the past are clear, the breaks from it are as startling. Most telling is the Southern city proudly trumpeting its civil rights heritage and interracial harmony, while cities like New York, Boston or Washington are torn by racial division.
Former Mayor Andrew Young, one of the main architects of the plan to snare the Olympics, recalled the words of a selection committee member: ''It was by the grace of God and your racial harmony that you all won this bid.'' As such, the bid was a remarkable statement not just about Atlanta but about the entire South.
''It's significant this international event will come to the Deep South, where 25 years ago it wouldn't have been conceivable,'' Mr. Lowery said. ''I don't know another city that is as committed to the kind of creative interdependence that Atlanta is committed to.''
Local leaders promised that the spirit of the bid would permeate the organizing of the games.
''Let us dedicate ourselves to the Olympic effort of bringing along those in our city who are poor and those who are in need,'' said Mayor Maynard Jackson as he returned from Tokyo. ''We want our city to be a better city, not just a richer city.''
 
Cracks in the Facade
Atlanta's racial picture is hardly as rosy as that presented to the International Olympic Committee. Atlanta, which is 70 percent black within its city limits, remains largely segregated residentially. Whites have largely fled the public schools for private ones, the city had the nation's highest crime rate last year and the 1980 census ranked Atlanta with Newark with the most residents living in poverty. Even some business leaders admit the city's prosperity has largely bypassed poor blacks.
Dan Sweat, the longtime head of Central Atlanta Progress, a powerful downtown business group, said many of the city's major economic projects had hurt the poor, often by displacing them for development, ''not deliberately, but we have done it.'' He said it was critical the Olympic effort not repeat that history, adding, ''This time I am going to be on the side of the poor.''
Still, if there was some soul searching this week, more common was the sort of hyperbole Mayor Jackson expressed when he got off the plane from Tokyo and announced: ''This truly is a miracle city. We are in a new orbit. Our lives will never, ever be the same.''

HEADLINE: Group of Seven Presses to Keep Interest Rates Up

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Economic policy makers from the United States and its main industrial allies agreed today that the best response to the oil-price shock would be to keep a lid on inflation and refrain from making hasty interest-rate cuts.
The finance ministers and central bank directors of the Group of Seven major industrialized nations said in a communique that they did not expect their economies to fall into recession next year, even though oil prices have risen 50 percent since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, threatening to fuel inflation and to slow growth. The officials from the Group of Seven - the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - gathered here for their first meeting since the Persian Gulf crisis began. 
The Canadian Finance Minister, Michael Wilson, told reporters after seven hours of talks that the group agreed that controlling inflation now would prevent greater problems in the future.
''If we don't get on top of inflationary pressures now the difficulties will be far more severe in the future,'' Mr. Wilson said. He said the the Group of Seven recognized that higher oil prices posed the risk of steep inflation and of recession. A tight grip on interest rates and government budgets means higher prices at the gas pump and a loss of purchasing power by consumers.
But policy makers from the major nations appear to believe that the world economy is better placed to weather the latest oil price shock than it was during the 1970's.
''We are heading toward a third round of higher oil prices in a much better position than in the previous two,'' said Karl Otto Pohl, the president of West Germany's central bank.
Industrial countries are more efficient in their use of energy, inflation is lower and oil prices have not risen as much as they did during the first two oil shocks.
During the oil shocks of the 1970's, industrial nations tried to cushion their economies by cutting interest rates and increasing government spending. That led to a new burst of inflation. ''The lessons we learned in 1973 and '74 ought not be forgotten,'' said John Major, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer. ''You simply do not accommodate inflationary pressures.''
But the Group of Seven prescription of tight budgets and high interest rates is likely to be broad enough to allow the United States to cut interest rates.
Currency rates, which have often bedeviled the Group of Seven in the past, are likely to pose little problem this time around. The dollar is sinking, but no one, including the United States, seems particularly worried.

LENGTH: 852 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Jordan's Monarch Appeals On TV to American Public

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 22

 BODY:
In an address to the American people, King Hussein of Jordan pleaded tonight for understanding of his country's increasingly difficult position in the Persian Gulf crisis but repeated his call for the removal of all American troops from the Middle East.
''I will never admit defeat because that would mean taking the easy way out,'' King Hussein said, indicating that he would not change camps and and stop supporting Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader. Still, the King added, ''The hurt is there from those who don't know the facts.''
The King's half-hour address, transmitted live by Cable News Network to the United States, came as his country's position grew more desperate amid reports from Jordanian and Saudi officials that Saudi Arabia had expelled 20 Jordanian diplomats in apparent anger over Jordan's continued support for Saddam Hussein. 
''Saudi authorities told our embassy today that these people were no longer welcome to stay,'' a senior Jordanian official said, echoing reports from the Saudi capital. Asked about the reported expulsions of Jordanians this evening, King Hussein said he had heard nothing about them and that he believed the report was ''a fabrication.''
 
Saudi Situation Worsens
Whether the envoys were expelled or not, Jordan's relationship with Saudi Arabia has grown steadily worse in the last few days. On Wednesday, the Saudi Government informed Jordan only six hours in advance that it was cutting off all oil shipments. Jordan had depended on Saudi Arabia for half its oil needs.
That led to an emergency meeting of the Jordanian Cabinet today, and a senior minister said gas rationing might have to begin soon.
Saudi Arabia is now refusing to accept most Jordanian exports as well. In an interview on Thursday, the King's brother, Crown Prince Hassan, said: ''They are opening our trucks and dumping our vegetables over the side of the road. I've kept mum about this before now because I don't want to run afoul of other disagreements with the Saudis.''
Saudi Arabia was Jordan's third-largest trading partner, behind Iraq and Kuwait. With those three markets closed, Jordanian officials say their economy is headed for ruin.
 
Arguing Jordan's Case
Still, King Hussein was unyielding this evening as he argued Jordan's, and in some cases Iraq's, case before the American people.
As he has from the beginning, the King said that he did not support Iraq's seizure of Kuwait and added that ''despite its close relationship with Iraq, Jordan had no prior knowledge of or involvement in'' Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. And he noted that Jordan still recognizes the Kuwaiti Government. Its embassy is still open here.
Even so, the King explained at some length in his address and in a question-and-answer session on CNN, the world should not so quickly dismiss Saddam Hussein's claim to Kuwait. As the King described the situation, history lends support to Iraq's case.
He offered an emotional argument for the withdrawal of American forces from the gulf.
''We strongly feel that the presence of United States forces on the land of the state which is the custodian of the two holiest shrines of Islam must be terminated within the shortest possible period of time,'' he said, ''lest it result in incalculably grave consequences for Arabs and Muslims the world over for generations to come.''
He was referring to Mecca and Medina in southwestern Saudia Arabia, several hundred miles from the nearest concentrations of American forces.
The King's address was also delivered in a letter this weekend to every member of the United States Congress, Jordanian officials said. The Jordanian clearly was appealing for understanding as an economic noose begins to tighten around this country.
Prince Hassan is planning a trip to Washington next week and has said that he want to testify before a Congressional committee.
''Jordan is considered to be in a war zone,'' the King said tonight, ''and is practically under a state of seige.'' ---- Saudis Ask Envoys to Leave NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 22 (Reuters) - Saudi Arabia said today that it had asked certain Governments to withdraw their diplomats because the envoys had sought to undermine the kingdom's security.
A Foreign Ministry statement issued by the official Saudi press agency, monitored here by the BBC, did not name the countries whose diplomats were asked to leave or provide numbers on the envoys.
But Saudi officials who spoke on the condition that they not be identified said earlier in the day that Riyadh had told Iraq, Yemen and Jordan to reduce their embassy staffs to no more than three diplomats. One official said the request had been issued 10 days ago.
Officials in Sana, the Yemeni capital, said that Riyadh had ordered out 30 Yemeni diplomats and 20 support staff. In Amman, officials said 20 Jordanian diplomats had been expelled.
King Hussein of Jordan denied the reports that 20 Jordanian diplomats had been asked to leave.
The Saudi Foreign Ministry statement cited ''flagrant infractions'' by foreign diplomats that ''undermine the security of the kingdom and its safety.''
