SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 19, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 3850 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Excerpts From Iraqi Document on Meeting With U.S. Envoy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
On July 25, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq summoned the United States Ambassador to Baghdad, April Glaspie, to his office in the last high-level contact between the two Governments before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Here are excerpts from a document described by Iraqi Government officials as a transcript of the meeting, which also included the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz. A copy was provided to The New York Times by ABC News, which translated it from the Arabic. The State Department has declined to comment on its accuracy.
SADDAM HUSSEIN: I have summoned you today to hold comprehensive political discussions with you. This is a message to President Bush.
You know that we did not have relations with the U.S. until 1984 and you know the circumstances and reasons which caused them to be severed. The decision to establish relations with the U.S. were taken in 1980 during the two months prior to the war between us and Iran. 
When the war started, and to avoid misinterpretation, we postponed the establishment of relations hoping that the war would end soon.
But because the war lasted for a long time, and to emphasize the fact that we are a nonaligned country, it was important to re-establish relations with the U.S. And we choose to do this in 1984.
It is natural to say that the U.S. is not like Britain, for example, with the latter's historic relations with Middle Eastern countries, including Iraq. In addition, there were no relations between Iraq and the U.S. between 1967 and 1984. One can conclude it would be difficult for the U.S. to have a full understanding of many matters in Iraq. When relations were re-established we hoped for a better understanding and for better cooperation because we too do not understand the background of many American decisions.
We dealt with each other during the war and we had dealings on various levels. The most important of those levels were with the foreign ministers.
 
U.S.-Iraq Rifts
 We had hoped for a better common understanding and a better chance of cooperation to benefit both our peoples and the rest of the Arab nations.
But these better relations have suffered from various rifts. The worst of these was in 1986, only two years after establishing relations, with what was known as Irangate, which happened during the year that Iran occupied the Fao peninsula.
It was natural then to say that old relations and complexity of interests could absorb many mistakes. But when interests are limited and relations are not that old, then there isn't a deep understanding and mistakes could leave a negative effect. Sometimes the effect of an error can be larger than the error itself.
Despite all of that, we accepted the apology, via his envoy, of the American President regarding Irangate, and we wiped the slate clean. And we shouldn't unearth the past except when new events remind us that old mistakes were not just a matter of coincidence.
Our suspicions increased after we liberated the Fao peninsula. The media began to involve itself in our politics. And our suspicions began to surface anew, because we began to question whether the U.S. felt uneasy with the outcome of the war when we liberated our land.
It was clear to us that certain parties in the United States - and I don't say the President himself - but certain parties who had links with the intelligence community and with the State Department - and I don't say the Secretary of State himself - I say that these parties did not like the fact that we liberated our land. Some parties began to prepare studies entitled, ''Who will succeed Saddam Hussein?'' They began to contact gulf states to make them fear Iraq, to persuade them not to give Iraq economic aid. And we have evidence of these activities.
 
Iraqi Policy on Oil
 Iraq came out of the war burdened with $40 billion debts, excluding the aid given by Arab states, some of whom consider that too to be a debt although they knew - and you knew too - that without Iraq they would not have had these sums and the future of the region would have been entirely different.
We began to face the policy of the drop in the price of oil. Then we saw the United States, which always talks of democracy but which has no time for the other point of view. Then the media campaign against Saddam Hussein was started by the official American media. The United States thought that the situation in Iraq was like Poland, Romania or Czechoslovakia. We were disturbed by this campaign but we were not disturbed too much because we had hoped that, in a few months, those who are decision makers in America would have a chance to find the facts and see whether this media campaign had had any effect on the lives of Iraqis. We had hoped that soon the American authorities would make the correct decision regarding their relations with Iraq. Those with good relations can sometinmes afford to disagree.
But when planned and deliberate policy forces the price of oil down without good commercial reasons, then that means another war against Iraq. Because military war kills people by bleeding them, and economic war kills their humanity by depriving them of their chance to have a good standard of living. As you know, we gave rivers of blood in a war that lasted eight years, but we did not lose our humanity. Iraqis have a right to live proudly. We do not accept that anyone could injure Iraqi pride or the Iraqi right to have high standards of living.
Kuwait and the U.A.E. were at the front of this policy aimed at lowering Iraq's position and depriving its people of higher economic standards. And you know that our relations with the Emirates and Kuwait had been good. On top of all that, while we were busy at war, the state of Kuwait began to expand at the expense of our territory.
You may say this is propaganda, but I would direct you to one document, the Military Patrol Line, which is the borderline endorsed by the Arab League in 1961 for military patrols not to cross the Iraq-Kuwait border.
But go and look for youselves. You will see the Kuwaiti border patrols, the Kuwaiti farms, the Kuwaiti oil installations - all built as closely as possible to this line to establish that land as Kuwaiti territory.
 
Conflicting Interests
 Since then, the Kuwaiti Government has been stable while the Iraqi Government has undergone many changes. Even after 1968 and for 10 years afterwards, we were too busy with our own problems. First in the north then the 1973 war, and other problems. Then came the war with Iran which started 10 years ago.
We believe that the United States must understand that people who live in luxury and economic security can reach an understanding with the United States on what are legitimate joint interests. But the starved and the economically deprived cannot reach the same understanding.
We do not accept threats from anyone because we do not threaten anyone. But we say clearly that we hope that the U.S. will not entertain too many illusions and will seek new friends rather than increase the number of its enemies.
I have read the American statements speaking of friends in the area. Of course, it is the right of everyone to choose their friends. We can have no objections. But you know you are not the ones who protected your friends during the war with Iran. I assure you, had the Iranians overrun the region, the American troops would not have stopped them, except by the use of nuclear weapons.
I do not belittle you. But I hold this view by looking at the geography and nature of American society into account. Yours is a society which cannot accept 10,000 dead in one battle.
You know that Iran agreed to the cease-fire not because the United States had bombed one of the oil platforms after the liberation of the Fao. Is this Iraq's reward for its role in securing the stability of the region and for protecting it from an unknown flood?
 
Protecting the Oil Flow
 So what can it mean when America says it will now protect its friends? It can only mean prejudice against Iraq. This stance plus maneuvers and statements which have been made has encouraged the U.A.E. and Kuwait to disregard Iraqi rights.
I say to you clearly that Iraq's rights, which are mentioned in the memorandum, we will take one by one. That might not happen now or after a month or after one year, but we will take it all. We are not the kind of people who will relinguish their rights. There is no historic right, or legitimacy, or need, for the U.A.E. and Kuwait to deprive us of our rights. If they are needy, we too are needy.
The United States must have a better understanding of the situation and declare who it wants to have relations with and who its enemies are. But it should not make enemies simply because others have different points of view regarding the Arab-Israeli conflict.
We clearly understand America's statement that it wants an easy flow of oil. We understand America saying that it seeks friendship with the states in the region, and to encourage their joint interests. But we cannot understand the attempt to encourage some parties to harm Iraq's interests.
The United States wants to secure the flow of oil. This is understandable and known. But it must not deploy methods which the United States says it disapproves of - flexing muscles and pressure.
If you use pressure, we will deploy pressure and force. We know that you can harm us although we do not threaten you. But we too can harm you. Everyone can cause harm according to their ability and their size. We cannot come all the way to you in the United States, but individual Arabs may reach you.
 
War and Friendship
 You can come to Iraq with aircraft and missiles but do not push us to the point where we cease to care. And when we feel that you want to injure our pride and take away the Iraqis' chance of a high standard of living, then we will cease to care and death will be the choice for us. Then we would not care if you fired 100 missiles for each missile we fired. Because without pride life would have no value.
It is not reasonable to ask our people to bleed rivers of blood for eight years then to tell them, ''Now you have to accept aggression from Kuwait, the U.A.E. or from the U.S. or from Israel.' ''
We do not put all these countries in the same boat. First, we are hurt and upset that such disagreement is taking place between us and Kuwait and the U.A.E. The solution must be found within an Arab framework and through direct bilateral relations. We do not place America among the enemies. We place it where we want our friends to be and we try to be friends. But repeated American statements last year made it apparent that America did not regard us as friends. Well the Americans are free.
When we seek friendship we want pride, liberty and our right to choose.
We want to deal according to our status as we deal with the others according to their statues.
We consider the others' interests while we look after our own. And we expect the others to consider our interests while they are dealing with their own. What does it mean when the Zionist war minister is summoned to the United States now? What do they mean, these fiery statements coming out of Israel during the past few days and the talk of war being expected now more than at any other time?
I do not believe that anyone would lose by making friends with Iraq. In my opinion, the American President has not made mistakes regarding the Arabs, although his decision to freeze dialogue with the P.L.O. was wrong. But it appears that this decision was made to appease the Zionist lobby or as a piece of strategy to cool the Zionist anger, before trying again. I hope that our latter conclusion is the correct one. But we will carry on saying it was the wrong decision.
You are appeasing the usurper in so many ways - economically, politically and militarily as well as in the media. When will the time come when, for every three appeasements to the usurper, you praise the Arabs just once?
APRIL GLASPIE: I thank you, Mr. President, and it is a great pleasure for a diplomat to meet and talk directly with the President. I clearly understand your message. We studied history at school. They taught us to say freedom or death. I think you know well that we as a people have our experience with the colonialists.
Mr. President, you mentioned many things during this meeting which I cannot comment on on behalf of my Government. But with your permission, I will comment on two points. You spoke of friendship and I believe it was clear from the letters sent by our President to you on the occasion of your National Day that he emphasizes -- HUSSEIN: He was kind and his expressions met with our regard and respect.
 
Directive on Relations
 GLASPIE: As you know, he directed the United States Administration to reject the suggestion of implementing trade sanctions.
HUSSEIN: There is nothing left for us to buy from America. Only wheat. Because every time we want to buy something, they say it is forbidden. I am afraid that one day you will say, ''You are going to make gunpowder out of wheat.''
GLASPIE: I have a direct instruction from the President to seek better relations with Iraq.
HUSSEIN: But how? We too have this desire. But matters are running contrary to this desire.
GLASPIE: This is less likely to happen the more we talk. For example, you mentioned the issue of the article published by the American Information Agency and that was sad. And a formal apology was presented.
HUSSEIN: Your stance is generous. We are Arabs. It is enough for us that someone says, ''I am sorry, I made a mistake.'' Then we carry on. But the media campaign continued. And it is full of stories. If the stories were true, no one would get upset. But we understand from its continuation that there is a determination.
GLASPIE: I saw the Diane Sawyer program on ABC. And what happened in that program was cheap and unjust. And this is a real picture of what happens in the American media - even to American politicians themselves. These are the methods the Western media employs. I am pleased that you add your voice to the diplomats who stand up to the media. Because your appearance in the media, even for five minutes, would help us to make the American people understand Iraq. This would increase mutual understanding. If the American President had control of the media, his job would be much easier.
Mr. President, not only do I want to say that President Bush wanted better and deeper relations with Iraq, but he also wants an Iraqi contribution to peace and prosperity in the Middle East. President Bush is an intelligent man. He is not going to declare an economic war against Iraq.
You are right. It is true what you say that we do not want higher prices for oil. But I would ask you to examine the possibility of not charging too high a price for oil.
HUSSEIN: We do not want too high prices for oil. And I remind you that in 1974 I gave Tariq Aziz the idea for an article he wrote which criticized the policy of keeping oil prices high. It was the first Arab article which expressed this view.
 
Shifting Price of Oil
 TARIQ AZIZ: Our policy in OPEC opposes sudden jumps in oil prices.
 HUSSEIN: Twenty-five dollars a barrel is not a high price.
 GLASPIE: We have many Americans who would like to see the price go above $25 because they come from oil-producing states.
HUSSEIN: The price at one stage had dropped to $12 a barrel and a reduction in the modest Iraqi budget of $6 billion to $7 billion is a disaster.
GLASPIE: I think I understand this. I have lived here for years. I admire your extraordinary efforts to rebuild your country. I know you need funds. We understand that and our opinion is that you should have the opportunity to rebuild your country. But we have no opinion on the Arab-Arab conflicts, like your border disagreement with Kuwait.
I was in the American Embassy in Kuwait during the late 60's. The instruction we had during this period was that we should express no opinion on this issue and that the issue is not associated with America. James Baker has directed our official spokesmen to emphasize this instruction. We hope you can solve this problem using any suitable methods via Klibi or via President Mubarak. All that we hope is that these issues are solved quickly. With regard to all of this, can I ask you to see how the issue appears to us?
My assessment after 25 years' service in this area is that your objective must have strong backing from your Arab brothers. I now speak of oil. But you, Mr. President, have fought through a horrific and painful war. Frankly, we can only see that you have deployed massive troops in the south. Normally that would not be any of our business. But when this happens in the context of what you said on your national day, then when we read the details in the two letters of the Foreign Minister, then when we see the Iraqi point of view that the measures taken by the U.A.E. and Kuwait is, in the final analysis, parallel to military aggression against Iraq, then it would be reasonable for me to be concerned. And for this reason, I received an instruction to ask you, in the spirit of friendship - not in the spirit of confrontation - regarding your intentions.
I simply describe the concern of my Government. And I do not mean that the situation is a simple situation. But our concern is a simple one.
HUSSEIN: We do not ask people not to be concerned when peace is at issue. This is a noble human feeling which we all feel. It is natural for you as a superpower to be concerned. But what we ask is not to express your concern in a way that would make an aggressor believe that he is getting support for his aggression.
We want to find a just solution which will give us our rights but not deprive others of their rights. But at the same time, we want the others to know that our patience is running out regarding their action, which is harming even the milk our children drink, and the pensions of the widow who lost her husband during the war, and the pensions of the orphans who lost their parents.
As a country, we have the right to prosper. We lost so many opportunities, and the others should value the Iraqi role in their protection. Event this Iraqi [the President points to the interpreter] feels bitter like all other Iraqis. We are not aggressors but we do not accept aggression either. We sent them envoys and handwritten letters. We tried everything. We asked the Servant of the Two Shrines - King Fahd - to hold a four-member summit, but he suggested a meeting between the Oil Ministers. We agreed. And as you know, the meeting took place in Jidda. They reached an agreement which did not express what we wanted, but we agreed.
Only two days after the meeting, the Kuwaiti Oil Minister made a statement that contradicted the agreement. We also discussed the issue during the Baghdad summit. I told the Arab Kings and Presidents that some brothers are fighting an economic war against us. And that not all wars use weapons and we regard this kind of war as a military action against us. Because if the capability of our army is lowered then, if Iran renewed the war, it could achieve goals which it could not achieve before. And if we lowered the standard of our defenses, then this could encourage Israel to attack us. I said that before the Arab Kings and Presidents. Only I did not mention Kuwait and U.A.E. by name, because they were my guests.
Before this, I had sent them envoys reminding them that our war had included their defense. Therefore the aid they gave us should not be regarded as a debt. We did no more than the United States would have done against someone who attacked its interests.
I talked about the same thing with a number of other Arab states. I explained the situation to brother King Fahd a few times, by sending envoys and on the telephone. I talked with brother King Hussein and with Sheik Zaid after the conclusion of the summit. I walked with the Sheik to the plane when he was leaving Mosul. He told me, ''Just wait until I get home.'' But after he had reached his destination, the statements that came from there were very bad - not from him, but from his Minister of Oil.
Also after the Jidda agreement, we received some intelligence that they were talking of sticking to the agreement for two months only. Then they would change their policy. Now tell us, if the American President found himself in this situation, what would he do? I said it was very difficult for me to talk about these issues in public. But we must tell the Iraqi people who face economic difficulties who was responsible for that.
 
Talks With Mubarak
 GLASPIE: I spent four beautiful years in Egypt.
 HUSSEIN: The Egyptian people are kind and good and ancient. The oil people are supposed to help the Egyptian people, but they are mean beyond belief. It is painful to admit it, but some of them are disliked by Arabs because of their greed.
GLASPIE: Mr. President, it would be helpful if you could give us an assessment of the effort made by your Arab brothers and whether they have achieved anything.
HUSSEIN:. On this subject, we agreed with President Mubarak that the Prime Minister of Kuwait would meet with the deputy chairman of the Revolution Command Council in Saudi Arabia, because the Saudis initiated contact with us, aided by President Mubarak's efforts. He just telephoned me a short while ago to say the Kuwaitis have agreed to that suggestion. GLASPIE: Congratulations. HUSSEIN: A protocol meeting will be held in Saudi Arabia. Then the meeting will be transferred to Baghdad for deeper discussion directly between Kuwait and Iraq. We hope we will reach some result. We hope that the long-term view and the real interests will overcome Kuwaiti greed.
GLASPIE: May I ask you when you expect Sheik Saad to come to Baghdad?
HUSSEIN: I suppose it would be on Saturday or Monday at the latest. I told brother Mubarak that the agreement should be in Baghdad Saturday or Sunday. You know that brother Mubarak's visits have always been a good omen.
GLASPIE: This is good news. Congratulations.
Brother President Mubarak told me they were scared. They said troops were only 20 kilometers north of the Arab League line. I said to him that regardless of what is there, whether they are police, border guards or army, and regardless of how many are there, and what they are doing, assure the Kuwaitis and give them our word that we are not going to do anything until we meet with them. When we meet and when we see that there is hope, then nothing will happen. But if we are unable to find a solution, then it will be natural that Iraq will not accept death, even though wisdom is above everything else. There you have good news. AZIZ: This is a journalistic exclusive. GLASPIE: I am planning to go to the United States next Monday. I hope I will meet with President Bush in Washington next week. I thought to postpone my trip because of the difficulties we are facing. But now I will fly on Monday.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 30, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, excerpts last Sunday from a document described by the Iraqi Government as a transcript of a meeting between President Saddam Hussein and the United States Ambassador to Iraq misattributed some remarks. The following remarks should have been attributed to President Hussein, not to Ambassador April C. Glaspie:
Brother President Mubarak told me they were scared. They said troops were only 20 kilometers north of the Arab League line. I said to him that regardless of what is there, whether they are police, border guards or army, and regardless of how many are there, and what they are doing, assure the Kuwaitis and give them our word that we are not going to do anything until we meet with them. When we meet and when we see that there is hope, then nothing will happen. But if we are unable to find a solution, then it will be natural that Iraq will not accept death, even though wisdom is above everything else. There you have good news.

PUB-DATE: September 23, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 18, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 829 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Israel Has a Unique Deal for U.S. Aid

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Sometime before Oct. 30, the Treasury will write a check to Israel for $1.2 billion. The money, almost half of the $3 billion in economic and military aid that the United States gives Israel every year, will be quietly deposited in the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and immediately start earning interest at about 8 percent.
The remaining $1.8 billion goes to the Pentagon, and a trust fund that pays for McDonnell Douglas F-15's, General Dynamics Stinger missiles, Hughes Aircraft TOW antitank missiles, FMC Bradley fighting vehicles and other goods that Israel buys from American military contractors.
This system, used only for Israel, opens the spigots for millions of dollars of interest, in effect, added aid that does not go through the appropriations process. But it is only one way military assistance to Jerusalem is different from arms transactions with Saudi Arabia, Egypt or any of the other countries playing a central role in the Persian Gulf crisis. 
 
Balance of Power
The arrangements with Israel have attracted attention during the gulf crisis. Israel has asked the Administration for additional military aid this year to help it maintain its traditional military edge in the Middle East, especially with the planned sales of $21 billion in American arms to Saudi Arabia.
The Saudis will pay cash for any arms they buy. But when Israel buys F-15's, McDonnell Douglas bills the Israeli trust fund, financed by American tax dollars, at the Pentagon.
Egypt receives somewhat less American aid than Israel - $815 million in economic support and $1.3 billion of military assistance - but Egypt, a developing country with a far lower living standard than Israel, gets much less in actual cash and none of it up front. So Cairo has less freedom to maneuver than Jerusalem.
It was as a reward for its cooperation in the gulf crisis that President Bush announced new aid for Egypt with his recent proposal to forgive $6.7 billion of Egyptian debt.
But that initiative is running into trouble among members of both parties in Congress, who see it prompting a wave of similar requests from other countries, including Israel and Poland, and worsening already serious American budget problems.
 
Favors Built In
Lawmakers and their aides said the special favors for Israel that have been built into foreign assistance laws are in recognition of the close strategic and political ties of the two democracies.
An Administration official called the assistance ''an integral part of efforts to achieve peace in the Middle East.''
Robert J. Kurz, a guest scholar and foreign aid specialist at the Brookings Institution, a Washington policy research group, noted: ''In terms of the scope of our aid program, the differences are marginal, but they are important to the Israelis. That they are embodied in law reflects the strong bipartisan support commanded by Israel in Congress.''
The interest that Israel can now earn on its $1.2 billion Economic Support Fund from the United States grows out of an an initiative in the mid-1980's by Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, and Senator Bob Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin.
Pinhas Dror, Israel's Minister of Economic Affairs, said the interest accumulated at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York totaled $76.7 million last year.
Israel is free to use the cash as it sees fit. Mr. Dror's accounts, which were submitted in a letter to the State Department's Bureau for Asia and the Near East, showed that the bulk of the fund - nearly $1 billion - went to payments of interest and principle on military debts to the United States.
 
Other Uses for the Money
The money was also used for grain purchases and transport, debt repayments to the World Bank, procurements by Israel's Ministry of Health, and loan repayments to the Agency for International Development, the foreign aid branch of the State Department.
Congress has effectively insured Israel against the aid-cutoff threats that have confronted Egypt in recent years - another factor in the President's decision to wipe out Egypt's debt. Under the 1975 Brooke-Alexander amendment to the Foreign Assistance Act, countries in arrears more than a year on military and economic loans lose all American aid, except food assistance.
To help Israel avoid this possible trap, Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, got Congress to state as a matter of policy in 1984 that Israel's economic assistance every year will be at least as much as its annual payments to the United States.
Egypt has no such assurances. It has had to come up with about $750 million in interest and amortization on its American debt and has always been just at the edge of the Brooke-Alexander deadline.
Israel's Economic Support Fund cash from the United States more than covers the $1 billion of interest and amortization that it still has to pay on $4.5 billion of debt to the United States.

HEADLINE: SOME BOAT PEOPLE WILL BE RETURNED

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Vietnam, Britain and the United Nations refugee commission have reached an agreement on the repatriation of Vietnamese boat people from camps in Hong Kong.
Officials representing Hanoi, London, Hong Kong and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees initialed a statement late Friday that laid out steps in the new program.
The statement said the goal of the program was to send back those Vietnamese ''who, while not volunteering to return to Vietnam, are nevertheless not opposed to repatriation.'' 
The agreement, initialed at the end of three days of talks in Hanoi, gives the United Nations commission an important role in insuring that there is no coercion. The commission has said that it will not endorse forcible repatriation.
 
'Significant Step' Seen
A British spokesman said today that the agreement marked a significant step toward resolving the situation of the Vietnamese boat people.
''It opens up the possibility of increasing the rate of returns'' of Vietnamese from Hong Kong, he said.
The agreement covers only Hong Kong. The British crown colony is holding in camps an estimated 54,000 people who are seeking asylum. Most do not qualify as refugees under international criteria and are ineligible for resettlement in the West.
There are also thousands of Vietnamese in camps in Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand.
Under the new agreement, the United Nations commission will submit to the Vietnamese Government lists of people to be repatriated from Hong Kong. Hanoi will then have one month to confirm the lists and authorize the people's return.
 
Vietnam Has Reacted Cautiously
Hanoi, which is trying to break out of its political and economic isolation, has been reluctant to take part in any program considered inhumane.
It came under heavy criticism from the United States when it allowed Britain to send back 51 boat people from Hong Kong in December 1989. The members of the group were awakened and taken to the airport in the middle of the night.
The British spokesman said the agreement had been initialed by Deputy Foreign Secretary Vu Khoan of Vietnam; Ambassador Emrys Davies of Britain; Sergio Vieira de Mello, the aide in official of the United Nations High Commissioner's office in Geneva with responsibility for Asia, and Alistair Asprey, Hong Kong's Secretary for Security.
Under a United Nations voluntary return program begun in March 1989, 4,361 boat people have returned to Vietnam. But countries playing host to the boat people said that program was moving too slowly.

HEADLINE: U.S. Diplomats Return in Force to Nicaragua

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 22

 BODY:
On the southern edge of Managua, workers are readying an office building for a tenant that is determined to change the neighborhood.
The building is one of the city's biggest. The reported rent, $1 million for three years, is the highest anybody here can remember. And the tenant would have been unthinkable a year ago: the United States Government. 
After a decade of little more than a token American presence here, United States diplomats and other official personnel have begun to return to Nicaragua in numbers unseen since relations between the two countries collapsed with the start of the guerrilla effort by the United States-backed contras.
Welcomed by the country's new, pro-American Government and kept busy with $300 million in American aid this year alone, the United States diplomatic mission here has increased abruptly from a low of 8 members last December to more than 60 diplomats and development officials today.
The influx has been overseen by Harry W. Shlaudeman, a veteran Foreign Service officer who was called out of retirement by President Bush to become the first American Ambassador here since Richard W. Melton and seven other embassy diplomats were expelled in July 1988.
''There's been a tremendous change from the embattled atmosphere of the past,'' said Stedman D. Howard, the new embassy spokesman. ''There's also the sense of starting all over.''
 
Envoys Were Harassed
In a decade as representatives of a superpower that was essentially at war with Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista Government, American diplomats here were followed, restricted to specified areas, ridiculed in official newspapers and broadcasts, and menaced by mobs.
But the embassy's isolation here was outstripped only by the scant attention it was paid by its own Government through most of the war. Having defined Nicaraguan politics as part of a broader East-West conflict, diplomats say, neither the Reagan Administration nor the Bush Administration placed much store in their beleaguered outpost.
With the election in February of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, whose candidacy received strong American support, the embassy's status changed overnight.
But Nicaraguan politicians say the rapid resurgence in the official American presence here has been tempered by caution about appearing to dominate Mrs. Chamorro's fledgling Government, or recalling America's ubiquitous influence over the former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle.
The embassy's political activities focus almost exclusively on the small circle of advisers surrounding Mrs. Chamorro.
The embassy's principal message, other foreign diplomats say, has been that Nicaragua's economy must be revived if the new President is to have any hope of long-term political survival. And they say that after Washington's apparent 10-year preference for confronting Sandinista influence through military means, economic emphasis seems to have become the cutting edge of the American approach.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Yale;
Course in Korean Draws 80 Students On Its First Day

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
After eight years of student lobbying, Yale College has begun offering a course in Korean language study, and the response has been overwhelming.
The administration had predicted that 40 students might take the course, elementary Korean, but more than 80 undergraduates attended the first day, cramming into a room meant for a much smaller number. Most students in the class are Korean-Americans, interested in ''learning the language of their ancestors,'' said Prof. Samuel Martin, director of the program. 
''Yale was the first place where I saw a lot of Korean faces, and that raised my ethnic consciousness,'' said Christopher Park, a junior majoring in molecular biophysics and biochemistry. ''A lot of people at Yale ask questions about how Korean they are or how American they are. Studying the language is a way to get a greater understanding of who we are and where we come from.''
Although final figures are not in, the course appears more popular than both courses in Japanese and Chinese, the two longstanding language offerings in the East Asian Studies department. Each year, about 20 undergraduates begin studying Japanese and about 50 take first-year Chinese.
 
Two Sections Added
The course's unexpected popularity left Professor Martin scrambling to find instructors for two additional sections, including a class for advanced beginners.
Korean-American Students at Yale, a group representing an estimated 200 Korean-American undergraduates, led the eight-year effort to introduce Korean to the curriculum.
''When I applied to Yale, I had no idea that it didn't have Korean,'' Mr. Park, of San Antonio, said. ''When I found out, I thought, 'Why do we need to have Swahili and Serbo-Croatian when we don't offer Korean?' ''
Some first-year students have Korean-speaking parents and can understand conversations in the language. But most have no reading or writing ability in Korean, Professor Martin said.
 
Program Expected to Grow
Professor Martin predicts that the program will grow. For several years in the late 1940's and early 1950's, the Federal Government sponsored Korean-language classes at Yale, attended by State Department employees, missionaries, military personnel and a few graduate students. The Government stopped financing for the class about the time of the Korean War, and Yale phased out the program, Professor Martin said.
Now, undergraduate interest is rising, he added, because of the large number of Korean-Americans at Yale, the longstanding foreign language requirement and Korea's emergence as an economic power.
''As people become more conscious of what's going on in the world, the name Korea will be more widely recognized,'' said John S. Lee, a junior majoring in economics and political science from Fairbanks, Alaska. ''Also, there is a lot of economic potential for business people in Korea, so it makes sense for them to know the language.''
Although the East Asian studies department will include an intermediate language course in Korean next year, a tight budget will prevent Yale from expanding Korean studies into other disciplines, Professor Martin said.
Some members of the Korean studies task force believe money is not the main issue. During their years of lobbying the administration, students were often told that ''Korea isn't an important enough country to study,'' said Yun Won Cho, a former leader of the task force.
''It reaches a point where it's ridiculous,'' said Ms. Cho, a senior from Whippany, N.J. In her four years as a history major, she said, she found only one class on Korean history, and it was last offered two years ago.
''It's not as if Yale doesn't have the money,'' she said, ''or as if the scholars aren't out there to recruit.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Seung Ja Choi, an instructor, teaching a course in Korean language at Yale. School officials had predicted that about 40 students might take the language course, which is being offered at the university for the first time, but more than 80 undergraduates attended the class on the first day. (Marc Lipsitch for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Harvard;
Athletes Invoke Muse To Fight a Stereotype

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
''Most people have misconceptions about us jocks, with our tiny brains and our sweaty socks,'' proclaimed halfback Mike Agrillo, pacing before the statue of John Harvard in the college's Yard last weekend.
Reciting his poem, ''Jocks Are People, Too,'' to 70 listeners, he continued:
 
We sweat and grunt and drink much beer,
So what exactly does everyone fear?
We're not brain-dead, our souls are alive.
What other poet can run the 40 in under 4 point 5?
For as it is, our hearts are blue,
But ladies please know that jocks are people, too.
With this poetry recital, Mr. Agrillo, a government major from Bethpage, L.I., and four other self-described ''poet-athletes,'' all freshmen, started a new Harvard organization called ''Athletes for the Cultural Development of the Community.'' The group, clad in neckties, sunglasses, sandals and togas, played rock music on a tape player and led cheers between each piece of the half-hour event, which ended at 11 P.M. 
 
'Serious, Yet Informal'
The master of ceremonies, Mike Betsy, a football offensive guard from Park Ridge, N.J., began the recitations with a statement of the organization's purpose: ''To give all students a chance to enjoy original and attributed works in a serious, yet informal, setting.''
Guido Giordano, a soccer goalie from Glendale, Calif., who intends to major in biochemistry, read Shakespeare's sonnet ''Shall I Compare Thee to a Summer's Day?'' while kneeling and clasping the hand of a young woman who had volunteered from the audience.
Then, still on bended knee, with arms outstretched, Mr. Betsy followed with his own version of the sonnet:
 
I would compare thee to a summer's day,
But when dusk comes, its beauty goes away;
Your beauty lasts the whole day through.
I would compare thee to the dew-covered grass
Where lovers frolic and lovers pass,
But when winter comes it freezes tight,
Yet the fire in your eyes still blazes bright.
I would compare thee to the blue sky above
Where couples gaze and fall in love,
But when stern clouds come it turns to gray,
While your beauty never fades away.
''I put what Shakespeare was trying to say in layman's terms -something 'even a jock could understand,' as they say,'' said Mr. Betsy. He said the group planned to hold semimonthly recitations.
 
'Sensitive Intellectuals'
Much of their subject matter - in the words of Phil Kelley, a football split-end from Foxboro, Mass. - concerns ''love and portraying athletes as sensitive intellectuals.'' Mr. Kelley, who plans to major in economics, read his own poems, including ''If I Could Just Moor in Thy Harbor Tonight'' and ''Ode to the Big Toe on My Right Foot.''
Derek Maguire, a hockey defenseman from Randolph, N.J., who will major in engineering, acted out ''The Red Wheelbarrow'' by William Carlos Williams.
''Derek's spontaneous recital of the poem among his friends was the spark that set the fire going, so to speak,'' Mr. Betsy said later. ''Maguire is really shy. He had the poem memorized from high school. When he first recited it to us, we knew we had to get him to recite it to everyone.''
Mr. Betsy, who plans a biochemistry major and pre-med studies, concluded the event with a serenade-style ''Ode to Shelley,'' delivered not to the poet Percy Bysshe Shelley, but to Shelley McDonough, a first-year student from Rockland, Mass., in the audience.
 
Oh Shelley
My love for you is as eternal as the stars in the sky,
Or so I wish.
But alas, I must see through the guise and know
That all things must come to pass.
Oh Shelley my love for you is like a ripened fruit on the vine.
It is a beautiful sight to gaze upon from afar,
Yet once picked, time becomes precious.
For though the fruit of love is sweet,
We are always left with the pits.
But if pits are treated with love and affection,
They can blossom into Mother Nature's perfection,
And our tree can bear the thing
That only my lovely Shelley can bring.
 
'A Haven for Athletes'
''The group has since received half a dozen unsolicited poems from other poet-athletes for us to read at the next session,'' Mr. Betsy said. ''We've become a haven for athletes who were previously afraid to let their literary talents show.''
He compared the discrimination suffered by athletes to that suffered by ''those people considered too academic or intellectual.'' Their interests are represented by the Harvard Society of Nerds and Geeks, founded last year by Jeremy Kahn, a senior from New York City.
Mr. Kahn, who is also the president of the Society of Nerds and Geeks (SONG), said of the new group: ''It's a wonderful idea. I've been on the wrestling team for a couple of years - sort of J.V. - and would be interested to know when these poetry recitals are held. I'm a little curious at the extent of discrimination that athletes have experienced and would actually be willing to have some sort of dialogue between SONG and this group.''
Mr. Betsy said: ''I never felt discrimination as an athlete before, but when I got to Harvard, I found I was looked down upon for playing a sport. I wasn't going to quit my sport, so I figured I'd better change the image before the school year officially got under way.''

HEADLINE: THE NEW TRIBALISM;
Changing Demographics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Richard Bernstein described the aptly named new tribalism, but didn't explain why it is occurring. It is occurring because minority racial and ethnic groups represent an increasing share of our population. As recently as 1960, 9 out of 10 Americans were white. But by the end of this decade non-Hispanic whites will account for fewer than three in four Americans and only 68 percent of the population under 35.
According to Census Bureau estimates, non-Hispanic white males now account for just 37 percent of our population, and that share will continue to decrease. What Mr. Bernstein perceives as a ''cult of otherness'' is really the recognition among ''others,'' i.e., other than white male, that their groups have become large enough in terms of numbers and economic power to stop defining themselves in terms established by what they perceive as ''other.''
I expect a good 20 years of pushing and shoving, both literal and metaphorical, until we adjust to the new realities of racial, ethnic and gender power.
 
MARTHA FARNSWORTH RICHE
Ithaca, N.Y.
The writer is the national editor of American Demographics magazine.

PUB-DATE: September 23, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 10, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1215 words

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
The Laurels Are Appropriate, but Is the Sponsor?

BYLINE: By Jennifer Dunning

 BODY:
The Bessie Awards ceremony is an annual gathering of the clan, created by Dance Theater Workshop seven years ago to honor outstanding experimentalist performers, choreographers, designers and composers. This year it became a circling of wagons, as troubling questions about the sponsorship of the Bessies were raised by the resignation of the ceremony's two hosts just before the Sept. 12 event.
Dance is still seen as a comparatively marginal art in the United States. Most marginal of all is the kind of ''downtown'' experimentalist dance and performance art produced by Dance Theater Workshop and Performance Space 122, both leading dance organizations in Manhattan, though the work represents some of the most interesting and innovative being done in the city today. It is to this part of the dance spectrum that the Bessies have brought some much-needed, validating glamour. 
Part of the appeal surrounding the ceremony, which took place this year at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's handsome opera house, lies in the fact that two of its major sponsors are Philip Morris, which provided $6,000 worth of printing services and a last-minute $10,000 challenge grant when it seemed that money woes might sink the event, and Morgan Guaranty Trust, which gave backing for the prizes themselves, also called New York Dance and Performance Awards. Both companies are longtime supporters of the Bessies, which are named after Bessie Schonberg, chairwoman emeritus of the dance department at Sarah Lawrence College and a noted teacher. Philip Morris also contributes general operating support to Dance Theater Workshop.
But therein lay the peril. Philip Morris has been a major contributor to the election campaigns of Senator Jesse Helms, the Republican from North Carolina, who has been a leader in the fight to restrict the National Endowment for the Arts. It has also contributed a five-year grant of $200,000 to the planned Jesse Helms Citizenship Center in Monroe, N. C. Philip Morris's partial sponsorship of the Bessies was the reason that Karen Finley, a performance artist who was recently denied an N.E.A. grant, resigned as host of the ceremony. The other host, Danitra Vance, subsequently resigned for the same reason. Though no reason was given for the denial of grants to Ms. Finley and three other applicants, it is widely believed that the awards were withdrawn because the sexual content of the artists' work was considered to be obscene by Senator Helms and other conservative politicians. Moreover, the Senator's increasingly strong attacks against homosexuals have been especially painful to a professional community that has traditionally offered an unjudgmental haven to gay men and lesbians, and to an art that has been so devastated by AIDS.
''My feeling at this point is that we are engaged in a war of symbols with the right wing,'' said C. Carr, a writer for The Village Voice and a member of the 23-member awards committee, in a press conference at Dance Theater Workshop last month. ''To me, accepting money from Philip Morris becomes a symbolic act. Because of the current climate, everything becomes politicized. My hope has been that the Bessies could proceed without Philip Morris's money.''
At the award ceremony, an excerpt from ''Meanwhile,'' written and performed by Paul Zaloom, used zany props to represent all the participants in the predicament. And Ms. Finley and Ms. Vance's statements have been free of the prescriptive, morally superior tone that has characterized the discourse of some other Helms opponents. Ms. Finley, who has contributed the $1,500 from her 1990 Bessie Award to the campaign of Harvey Gantt, Senator Helms's challenger in the North Carolina race, said simply that she had felt physically ill when she received her invitation to the Bessies and saw Philip Morris's name displayed as a sponsor.
But, to paraphrase a gay-rights slogan, Philip Morris is everywhere. Ms. Finley herself performed this summer in the Serious Fun festival at Lincoln Center and again last week at the Joyce Theater. Both institutions receive support from Philip Morris, which this year has given $15 million to arts enterprises ranging from American Ballet Theater to the Franklin Furnace, an embattled SoHo experimental arts center committed to presenting controversial material. And at the recent Senate hearings on the future of the Endowment, one of the most impassioned and informed calls for continuing the Endowment came from Karen Brosius, manager of cultural affairs at Philip Morris.
But in addition to Senator Helms, Philip Morris continues to support several other outspoken enemies of the Endowment, although it has also given money to more liberal politicians sympathetic to the industries in which it does business. When asked why Philip Morris had not also donated money to the campaign of Mr. Gantt, the first black mayor of Charlotte, a company spokesman said that the corporation does not contribute to more than one candidate in a race.
''Senator Helms has been extremely supportive,'' Guy L. Smith 4th, vice president of corporate affairs at Philip Morris, said in a recent conversation. ''And he is in a position to be of help to us, because of his seniority and his willingness to use parliamentary procedures to his - and our industry's - advantage.''
The best art is seldom pragmatic. And Dance Theater Workshop and its director, David White, have long been among the most idealistic advocates for dance and dancers. Mr. White has made extraordinary - and successful - efforts to improve the living conditions and morale of those in dance who are among the most needy, and he has worked hard to get national recognition for work that has often received scant attention from the public and the media. Dance Theater Workshop is clearly endangered by dwindling financial support. The dance world cannot afford to lose instititutions like it - or the kinds of public discourse it has inspired.
It certainly would have been possible to hold this year's Bessie ceremony in Tompkins Square Park, as was suggested, to avoid accepting money from Philip Morris. But a good deal of the point of the event would have been lost. Dance institutions could also scrutinize the policies of corporations that give them money more carefully, though it might be hard to find completely ''untainted'' support. And the reality is that the arts have become more dependent on private support, particularly because grants for dance have not increased over the past five years and because donations from the private sector are shrinking in the current economic climate.
''By merely switching the emphasis of the perception, the burden of the problem shifts,'' the composer Stuart Diamond recently wrote. ''If Karen Finley did host the Bessie Awards and happily acknowledged the support of Philip Morris at the Joyce Theater, then it can be argued that Philip Morris generously supports artists who produce works that are deemed 'obscene and pornographic' by the National Endowment for the Arts. Then it becomes Jesse Helms's problem. Why is the Helms museum accepting contributions from a corporation that supports such 'lewd and dangerous' artists? It's all in the language.'' And that is one of the sagest comments on the Bessies issue.

HEADLINE: MUSIC VIEW;
At 100, Carnegie Is Still the Place to Get To

BYLINE: By DONAL HENAHAN

 BODY:
As Carnegie Hall prepares to open its centennial season Wednesday night, there may be no better moment to toast not only the health of the dowager queen of American concert halls but the durable values she typifies. Carnegie was designed according to an ancient and honorable esthetic that increasingly shows signs of returning to fashion: it is primarily a place to listen to specific kinds of music (classical is the inexact but useful word) in a civilized atmosphere. By design and in practice a hall best suited for symphony orchestras, it survives and thrives as a rebuke to the all-purpose auditoriums that sprang up all across America a generation ago and that still disfigure the musical landscape.
A couple of decades ago it all appeared so simple. Our symphony halls and opera houses, like the musical institutions they housed, were done for. Their counterparts in past centuries, we were reminded, had bowed to historical imperatives and disappeared or changed almost beyond recognition. Why should the 20th century be any different? 
It was not really a chilling prospect for most of us that the American concert hall would in time be one with Nineveh and Tyre. Probably no one but antiquarians, after all, would think it useful to mourn the loss of the Athenian agora, the Roman arena or the Esterhaza music room - gathering places that helped define the societies that produced them but whose time is long and irretrievably past. Churches, which gave birth to concert halls, do survive in some recognizable form. But churches too are all but finished as creative music centers: they can hardly pretend to be the artistic force they were in Palestrina's or Bach's time, or even in Bruckner's.
But change rarely comes fast enough for those who yearn for apocalypse now. Pierre Boulez, annoyed that the world was taking its time about embracing his music and adopting the drastic esthetic changes that he and fellow avant-gardists espoused, once suggested blowing up all the major opera houses as the best solution to the problem. Other advanced thinkers of the time predicted that artists of the future would not be caught dead in a traditionally configured concert hall, but would be out in the streets improvising happenings for the art-hungry masses. Amplification, video and other technical wonders were already making this expansion of the tribal village possible. One particularly visionary composer dramatized his alienation from the traditional concert venues by performing his electronic works under water in a swimming pool.
More temperately, Leonard Bernstein, stepping down as music director of the New York Philharmonic, pondered in print whether the symphony orchestra - a creature born in the 18th century and surviving in the 20th like an appendix - could have any future. Faced with that somber question from a distinguished valedictorian, the concerned reader logically had to question whether there continued to be a need for the buildings that housed these cultural anachronisms. Not likely. Obviously, rethinking was in order. And so, reflecting a social outlook increasingly receptive to Gordian-knot solutions, cultural movers and shakers all across the nation went into action. In New York, the shabby but historic old Metropolitan Opera House was torn down and replaced in the mid-60's by a glassy faced Xanadu at Lincoln Center. Carnegie Hall itself was reprieved from death row in the 1960 only through the last-minute efforts of Isaac Stern and a few other doughty and appalled citizens, with results that most sensible people now applaud but that at the time were far from certain.
With lemminglike determination, cities of every size and cultural condition also began to abandon their old but viable halls and theaters in favor of erecting performing arts centers in apparent response to the Lincoln Center model. The central feature of these complexes was usually a bleakly utilitarian auditorium capable of seating half the town. Meant to suit a variety of performance types, it typically satisfied none. The ideal architect of the period, it seemed, was one who could design an acoustically dead hall for symphony audiences in which 5,000 or 10,000 pop-music customers also could be comfortably accommodated and a ballet dancer's toes were clearly visible from all seats. Civic planners and politicians, as the joke went, were in the grip of an edifice complex.
Inevitably, as it now seems, a few thoughtful community leaders began to react against this frenzy for piling up concrete and marble in the name of the arts. Unsuspected or forgotten qualities began to be discovered in time-worn music halls and theaters. In Chicago the monumental Auditorium Theater, the work of Frank Lloyd Wright's student Louis Sullivan, was painstakingly restored after decades of lying in ruin. (During World War II, its main floor had served as a bowling alley for servicemen.) Ornate movie houses, abandoned in the wake of the television revolution, were rescued from the wreckers and remodeled for orchestras and other performance organizations. The Detroit Symphony's 71-year-old Orchestra Hall, abandoned for half a century and saved from destruction only in 1970, was restored just the other day to its original appearance and function. St. Louis, long in need of a home for its orchestra, refurbished a handsome old movie palace and renamed it Powell Symphony Hall. The same strategy was followed in New Orleans and elsewhere.
Although not as commercially attractive as the real-estate-driven arts centers, the restored halls projected a sense of classical dignity and continuity that the grander projects could not hope to match. Even with the acoustical changes that resulted from its recent remodeling, for example, Carnegie remains a more satisfying place to experience music than any other hall in New York. Granted, it has lost some of its legendary aura, no longer challenging in that respect America's acoustical paragon, Symphony Hall in Boston. (Boston so far has resisted the urge to renovate its 90-year-old hall, possibly with Carnegie's vexing experience in mind, but the pressures to do so are sure to increase.) With such preserved treasures as Symphony Hall and Carnegie as models, an almost outmoded artistic esthetic has slipped back into fashion: specific spaces for specific musical purposes. Symphony orchestras, architects and acoustical engineers have been persuaded, need to play in their own humanly scaled music rooms that deliver traditionally rich and resonant sounds, not the hard-edged tones of simulated hi-fi.
Reversing the megalomanic trend of the arts-complex period, new halls are now being conceived with these and other hopeful visions in mind. The Minnesota Orchestra built a particularly successful single-purpose hall for itself in Minneapolis. The Philadelphia Orchestra has one in the works to replace the historic but acoustically dry Academy of Music. Dallas, with its visually plain but aurally gracious Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center, provides an especially instructive and heartening example of how some designers are approaching the problem: the I. M. Pei structure, for which Russell Johnson was the acoustician, can be adjusted for various performance requirements, chiefly by regulating the volume of hidden sound chambers that ring the hall. In fact, built-in tuning devices, a much-ridiculed feature of New York's Philharmonic Hall at its infamous opening in 1962 (remember those adjustable ''clouds'' of the original design?) might be the sound wave of the future in concert hall technology.
Is it important or necessary that America's concert halls continue to exist into the 21st century or beyond? That will be for implacable history to decide. For a congeries of social, economic and - yes, occasionally artistic - reasons, both the concert hall and the symphony orchestra that traditionally has been its most prestigious occupant proliferated and prospered in this country as nowhere else in the world. For a century, the hall designed for serious music has been a certification of civic status. Any American city that pretends to national significance must have at least one and New York is no exception.
Of late, New York's daily sins have tended to command the spotlight, but time is short and art is long. The city still can point to an unrivaled history of musical virtue, which this season's celebration of the Carnegie century should put into sharp focus.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 7, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 23 about Carnegie Hall and other concert halls reversed the roles of the architects Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright. Wright, who designed the Auditorium Theater in Chicago, was Sullivan's student.

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
Our War the Way It Was

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman

 BODY:
Its theme - the clash of countrymen, of brothers - resounds through world myth. The battles were terrible, the casualties beyond imagining. Its heroes live more vividly in national and regional memory than the Founders themselves. The root cause stirred profound beliefs, and the nation continues to struggle with the consequences. What wonder that the Civil War has never lost its hold on the American imagination or that it should attract the imagination of Ken Burns, who with his ambitious television series, ''The Civil War,'' takes his place as the most accomplished documentary maker of his generation.
The 11-hour series, which begins the PBS prime-time season tonight at 8 and continues through Thursday, is so rich in conception and so rewarding in execution that it almost redeems the promise of the medium. Mr. Burns and his associates have translated the materials of history into television drama of an epic order.
Every episode takes us deep into the old photographs of young men in blue or gray uniforms, in formal poses or horsing around; they become moving pictures. Unforgettable photographs of the faces and bodies of slaves pound home the war's moral dimension. Their eyes stare us down. As the camera drifts over battlefields, we hear, distantly, the sounds of war. Scenes of carnage, some through the lens of Mathew Brady, give way to landscapes that seem timeless yet inimitably American. 
Much of the series' magic lies in its evocation of 19th-century America, through daguerrotypes, newspaper headlines, recruiting posters and, most affectingly, the words of those who fought the war and those who bore its terrible price. There is Abraham Lincoln, of course, the hero among heroes, whose direct, inspiring prose makes one ashamed of what passes as public discourse in our own time. And there are the powerful statements of Frederick Douglass; the sensitive reporting of Mary Chesnut, following the conflict from South Carolina; the somewhat aloof observations of the New York diarist George Templeton Strong, and the simpler, deeply touching reflections of soldiers like the Union man Elisha Hunt Rhodes and the Confederate trooper Sam Watkins, and their wives and parents.
The voices (you will probably recognize some of them, notably Jason Robards as Grant, Julie Harris as Mary Chesnut, Morgan Freeman as Douglass and George Plimpton as the sophisticated Strong) are a sampling of America, North, South and West. They stir the same collective memories as the familiar tunes ''Battle Hymn of the Republic'' and ''Dixie,'' of course, and the spirituals that are always in the air. The famous battles - Fredericksburg and Vicksburg, Chancellorsville, Chickamauga and Chattanooga, the Wilderness and Gettysburg - are clearly and dramatically laid out with the help of well-designed maps. Attempts at re-creation are sensibly shunned.
Mr. Burns allows individuals to tell the story wherever possible. Tonight's episode, for example, begins with Wilmer McLean, a Virginian who moved from his farm on the battlefield at Bull Run to Appomattox to get out of harm's way and who ''could rightfully say, 'the war began in my front yard and ended in my front parlor,' '' and concludes with a heartfelt letter to his wife from Sullivan Ballou, a Northern soldier who soon after fell at Bull Run. The series is filled with the poetry of people who had no pretentions to being poets.
The pace of the series is like that of the war itself: leisurely, sometimes lyric passages are suddenly shattered by the commotion of battles fought in 10,000 places along what is described as a 1,000-mile front. The narrative, principally by the biographer Geoffrey C. Ward, is uncommonly well written ('' 'I can do it all,' McClellan said, but he did nothing''), and delivered in a blessedly straightforward way by the historian David McCullough.
Mr. Burns offers no radical interpretations either of the course or causes of the war; his list of consultants is too large and imposing (C. Vann Woodward, Eric Foner, James McPherson) to admit to a personal view. The on-screen historians are less impressive, but Shelby Foote, the Southern writer who serves as a sort of cracker-barrel commentator, delivers colorful anecdotes with down-home finesse.
The emphasis on slavery, over the other economic, political and social divisions of North and South, is in accord with the sensibilities of our own time, as is the attention given to the role played by black soldiers. The series does not court controversy: the Southern officers are credited with courage and dash, the abolitionists with moral strength. Challenges to some of the assumptions and interpretations here can be expected; but the consensual approach is a natural one for television and should make the series a welcome resource in classrooms north and south.
Tonight's episode, ''The Cause,'' begins with an eventful introduction: the consequences of the invention of the cotton gin; the publication of ''Uncle Tom's Cabin''; the Dred Scott decision, with its message that a black man had no rights that a white man was bound to respect; Lincoln's ''house divided'' speeches; the fighting over ''bloody Kansas''; John Brown's raid on Harpers Ferry; the secession of several Southern states. And it goes on to cover 1861, the first year of the war, from the fall of Fort Sumter to the Confederate victory at the first Battle of Bull Run, where Gen. Thomas Jonathan Jackson became forever known as Stonewall.
''The Cause'' reminds us of the tenuous nature of the United States a century after the Revolution, when sectional allegiances, particularly in the South, were so powerful that Robert E. Lee, although he opposed secession, refused an offer to lead the Union forces and chose instead to serve his state of Virginia. Most of the fighters on both sides, many of them in their teens and looking like children in the photographs, had never been far from home. In a later episode, Mr. Foote, noting that the men of a single town would be likely to serve together, remarks that after a battle like Antietam, some towns might be left without young men.
By the end of the year, the enthusiasm with which the war was greeted (though not by Lincoln or by Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, who prophesied early that it would not be as short or as painless as many believed, and would go on to prove the point on his march through Georgia and South Carolina) was settling into a realization of its terrible cost.
Mr. Burns owes a big debt to his team of researchers - one of the few jobs for which he does not cite himself on the long list of credits - who have come up with the elements that sustain these 11 hours. He repays them by treating the photographs and journals with the respect and sensitivity they deserve. His control of the material is masterly. The result, which tonight occupies the time usually reserved for Masterpiece Theater, comes much closer than most of that popular series' offerings to meriting the title.
 
AND ALREADY ON VIDEO
 Usually the video release of a TV documentary postdates its broadcast, but Ken Burns's 11-hour ''Civil War'' is an exception. The first tapes have been available since February, and now the entire nine-cassette series is ready for release. But you won't find the videos in stores; they can only be ordered by mail.
''The Civil War'' comes in two separate sets. The first set is for the home viewer and is issued by Time-Life Video. The tapes are $24.99 each.
A second offering comes from PBS Video, a division of the Public Broadcasting Service. This set is intended for institutions - schools, libraries, museums and the like - and with it comes an index that lists all the names and events mentioned in the series and tells where each can be found on the tapes. A time-line chart and other materials are included. The set is $350 until Oct. 30 and $450 thereafter.
The PBS cassettes can be ordered through an 800 number given on the broadcast. Callers interested in the other set will be directed to Time-Life. - Peter M. Nichols

HEADLINE: Currency;
Big Trouble for the Pound

 BODY:
The British pound dropped sharply last week, hit hard by disappointment over the dimming prospects of a quick entry into the European Monetary System. Joining the system would make the pound, notoriously volatile, more stable and therefore more attractive to investors. Karl Otto Pohl, president of the German Bundesbank, knocked the pound down first on Wednesday when he indicated that Britain's inflation rate was too far above the European average to permit the pound to be tied to the Deutsche mark. And on Friday, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the country's inflation rate, heading toward 10 percent, was still too high for immediate entry. The two blows took the pound down more than seven cents against the dollar between Wednesday and Friday's close.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
No (Painless) Cure for the Budget Deficit

BYLINE: By HENRY KAUFMAN; Henry Kaufman is president of Henry Kaufman & Company Inc., a money management and economic and financial consulting firm.

 BODY:
The United States has a huge structural budget deficit and there is no painless way to undo it. The pain could have been less if the difficult choices had been made at a more favorable time, when economic growth was more robust. That chance was missed. But doing nothing will not eliminate the pain. It will merely postpone and compound the economic and financial costs. 
There are three reasons why a serious effort to reduce the deficit must now go forward:
First, without deficit reduction, we will not be able to free up the resources to meet the challenges of the 1990's. America will become a reduced economic power, unable to generate the business investment required to keep pace with faster productivity growth in other industrial countries. It will also be unable to deal with serious domestic economic and social shortcomings - a crumbling infrastructure, a deteriorating educational system and a dangerous concentration of poverty and lawlessness in our great cities.
Second, without deficit reduction, our ability to stabilize the business cycle will degenerate. Fiscal policy must be restored as a viable policy option. Huge structural deficits essentially bar the use of fiscal stimulus to counter recessionary tendencies. Thus, the task of rekindling economic expansion falls entirely on the Federal Reserve; but its flexibility to provide monetary stimulus is severely constricted. Large budget deficits prolong our dependence on foreign financing. The Fed is then forced to maintain financial conditions that keep American interest rates competitive with foreign rates, which are already higher in most cases.
Third, without a budget compromise, Gramm-Rudman may have to be put into effect. That is no way to run a government. It would compel essentially arbitrary cuts without regard to the resulting damage.
There is no way we can grow out of the budget deficit entrapment. Assuming we could was one of the main policy failures of the 1980's. Now, a recession and a slow economic recovery could produce a budget deficit in excess of $500 billion in two to three years. Getting back to a correct budgetary track would be virtually impossible.
At the same time, the painless path described by quite a few who favor deficit reductions is also dubious. These advocates assert that deficit reductions would reassure long-term investors, hasten declines in American interest rates, lower the dollar and free up financial resources for the private sector. The happy result, they claim, would be a quick stimulant for housing, commercial construction, business investment and exports.
The notion that lower interest rates could produce a speedy offset to budgetary restraint is becoming conventional wisdom but is questionable. It assumes that reductions in Government borrowing will allow the private sector to borrow more. Under normal circumstances this would be true. But now, it is not necessarily so because many in the private sector are already heavily leveraged. Only a huge drop in interest rates could accomplish such a switch to private sector borrowing. But even then an improved financial structure for banks and corporations, an important prerequisite for sustainable economic growth, would not be in place.
There is no painless way out. We need to raise taxes. Taxpayers should make additional contributions according to their capacity. The poor don't have the capacity. The burden will have to fall on middle- and upper-income taxpayers. The Middle East crisis should not deflect efforts to reduce defense expenditures, cap and reduce poorly controlled civilian expenditures and install an effective energy program, which should yield a modest amount of revenue at the start.
