HEADLINE: Managing;
Secrets of a Cosmic Cosmetician

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Anita L. Roddick, co-founder and chief executive of Body Shop International - the fast-growing natural-cosmetics franchiser based in Britain - has been thinking about xylophones.
''There's a long, narrow corridor at our production center,'' she said, ''and I noticed something the other day: What do people do when they walk down a corridor like that? They trail their hands, or a pencil, along the sides. We need to build some sort of musical instrument into the wall so employees can make music.''
Not exactly a conventional management notion. But then the 48-year-old chief executive, who ''forged her thinking in the 60's,'' according to a company fact sheet, has pretty much defied convention since she and her husband, Gordon T. Roddick, started up Body Shop in 1976 in the belief that products that ''cleanse, polish and protect'' skin and hair are in harmony with the environment. 
Ms. Roddick regularly treks to remote regions of Nepal and Brazil in search of natural oils, muds and methods. And her company has become well known for promoting certain values. Its 320 stores in 37 countries, including 22 in the United States, exhibit posters decrying medical tests on animals. Customers carry home purchases in recycled bags. Delivery trucks are emblazoned with messages about the sanctity of the Brazilian rain forest or the importance of education and human rights.
Given this, it is not surprising that Body Shop follows an unorthodox credo in managing its 1,700 employees and hundreds of franchisees. In job applicants, enthusiasm, empathy and creativity count more than degrees or credentials, managers say. There is an environmental resources department to monitor Body Shop's ecological impact - to make sure, for example, that the company doesn't deplete natural resources in the Brazilian rain forest and that it recycles as much as possible. The company gives workers a paid half-day off each week for community work and requires franchisers to do the same. There is a charter of corporate values, written by employees.
''Work should be a playground, an inspiration, an esthetic thing, not a Monday-to-Friday sort of death,'' is how Ms. Roddick put it. Hence the xylophone. And even some management experts argue that the 60's-style credo has built a foundation for the 90's.
''The competitive advantage is now moving toward people,'' said Keith Bradley, director of the business performance group at the London School of Economics. Given the demographic dip in the working population, he said, ''getting good people is hard, and Anita Roddick is saying, in her way, that she creates an atmosphere that makes it a fun place to come and work.''
The environmental ethic also creates a corporate culture that helps motivate employees. ''The best companies have belief systems highly consistent with the way they treat customers and employees,'' said Robin W.T. Buchanan, a London-based vice president of Bain & Company, the Boston consulting firm. ''That way, employees truly believe what they're selling.''
Of course, there are fundamentals in place that allow the management credo to work. Mr. Bradley said day-to-day management is systematic and well thought out. Expectations are clearly communicated to employees in a company handbook.
But the real test of the company's style may come if an economic slowdown forces Body Shop to cut back. For the last five years, profits at the public, $156 million company have grown at double-digit levels. ''Anita Roddick appears to be a great manager, but she will have truly demonstrated that when she faces the really tough times that all businesses face,'' Mr. Buchanan said.
The Roddicks have had no formal business training and previously ran a small but successful hotel business. They are ''a team,'' Mr. Bradley said, with the charismatic Ms. Roddick out front and Mr. Roddick working behind the scenes.
Franchising has allowed the Body Shop to stay small and entrepreneurial. ''Entrepreneurial franchisers have a great opportunity because franchisees will be doing some communicating for them,'' said Mr. Buchanan. ''But then your challenge is to become an effective communicator to your franchisees.'' To that end, the company offers extensive training for franchisees and employees, including management courses using video simulations and computer games.
The bottom line, Mr. Bradley said, is that Ms. Roddick ''realizes that know-how and peoples' interactions with customers are important assets.''
 
'LIKE BEING STRUCK BY LIGHTNING'
To find franchisees, Anita Roddick courts ''people who normally wouldn't want to run a franchise'' and puts them through a drill that could hardly be called orthodox.
Helen Mills, who owned an insurance brokerage in Washington, met Ms. Roddick last year and now, with partners, runs four Body Shop franchises in the Washington area. The hiring process was startling. ''I learned a lot about corporate culture and management priorities as an insurance broker, and I've never sat through conversations like the ones I've had with Anita,'' said Ms. Mills. They ''talked about about everything: motherhood, the environment, the homeless issue - nothing to do with cosmetics.'' Even the application form is unusual, she said: ''It has to be handwritten, and it asks what countries you've visited, and what books you've read, even how you would like to die.'' There were interviews at Body Shop's American headquarters, training sessions, even a trip to the Roddick home at Christmas.
Meeting Ms. Roddick and applying for a franchise was ''like being struck by lightning,'' she concluded.

HEADLINE: All About/Investing in Agriculture;
Wall Street's Latest Diversification Strategy: Down on the Farm

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
With opulent office towers desperate for tenants and several big-city developers choking on debt, some major investors are heading for the country. Wall Street is discovering the heartland, where reliable returns often flow from the open fields.
The scene was set in 1982-87, as farmland prices tumbled in the worst recession agriculture had faced in 50 years. Farmers who had expanded during the 1970's boom confronted excess capacity and soaring interest rates. Foreclosures rose to a postwar high, exports fell sharply, agricultural banks failed at a rate not seen since the Great Depression and, in the mid-1980's, the Government had to bail out the Farm Credit System.
Now, the farm belt has largely recovered. There are fewer farms, but larger ones and debt levels are way down. Banks and other lenders have sold a great deal of their foreclosed land. Farmland began its price rebound in 1987, and by last year, prices were up at least 10 percent from their 1986 lows. Thus the interest on the part of institutional investors looking to diversify their portfolios. 
''If you look at farmland over the last 30 years or so you see annual returns of about 10 percent,'' said Kenneth J. Binkley, a senior vice president of Equitable Agri-Business Inc. Treasury bills have returned about 5 percent annually since 1960, corporate bonds about 7 percent and commercial real estate about 9 percent. Stocks returned about 12 percent, but with greater risks and volatility than farmland.
 
Pension Funds
Lured by Low Risk And Steady Returns
Several of the country's largest pension funds are beginning to invest in farmland because it offers long-term holders relatively low risk along with fairly steady returns and capital appreciation.
Financial institutions have established several funds to help investors add agricultural real estate to their portfolios. Among these vehicles are the Equitable Agricultural Property Funds, set up in January by Equitable Agri-Business, an Atlanta-based subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. Equitable Agri-Business has about $2.2 billion invested, mostly through mortgages, in 12,000 farms and ranches. The new fund has raised about $25 million for equity investments in farms this year and expects to reach $100 million by next year. The Prudential Insurance Company, Batterymarch Financial and Morgan Stanley Asset Management are among the other investors in farmland.
Their stakes in agriculture so far are tiny compared with the billions pension funds invest annually. But investment managers say that as institutions become more familiar with farm investing, they will devote large sums to it, lifting prices.
Morgan Stanley says its investments are already ''substantial,'' but will not say how much. The firm has diversified by geography and crops, with properties in corn, cotton, rice, soybeans and citrus. ''We think total return to farmland should be in the range of 10 to 17 percent a year,'' said an executive there, who asked not to be identified. ''Farmland is up 15 to 25 percent since it hit the bottom in the 1980's.''
Wider investment in farms is barred by law in several farm states - including Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, Oklahoma and the Dakotas - that prohibit corporate ownership and aim to keep farms in the hands of American families. Even so, investors say there is no shortage of opportunities. ''The rules are a restriction, but then you can still buy outside of those states,'' said Mr. Binkley. ''There are still a lot of other states you can buy in, like California, Texas, Indiana, Illinois and Florida.''
Well over half of American farmland is still owned by individual farmers, but the largest, most technologically advanced farmers are dominant. Of the country's 2.27 million farms, the 14 percent, or about 317,000, that have sales of more than $100,000 account for 75 percent of all farm sales, about 61 percent of Government farm subsidies and 86 percent of net farm income, according to 1987 Agriculture Department figures. The smallest 1.63 million farms, or 72 percent, have annual sales of less than $40,000 each, accounting for a mere 10 percent of all farm sales.
 
Recovery in the 90's
Prices Are Reviving As Debt Levels Fall
A revival in farm prices is well under way. Earlier this year, the Department of Agriculture reported that prices had risen to an average of $693 an acre in January - up 4 percent in 1989, although still well below the 1982 record of $823. Despite the disappointments of the 1980's, then, sophisticated investors are being tempted by the promise of long-term performance. To realize the returns from operating income as well as higher land values, Mr. Binkley said, institutions need skilled farm management.
Many investors consider farmland an attractive hedge against inflation for both income and appreciation. During the agricultural boom of the 1970's, the jump in farm values often outstripped inflation. Impressive returns fired the hopes of farmers who borrowed heavily to buy farmland going into the 1980's, raising prices. Economists say the farm crisis of that decade left agricultural credit tighter, probably keeping farmland from going up as fast as the inflation rate.
''Farmland will be a reasonable investment in the 90's but I don't think it will ever perform the way it did in the 70's,'' said Mark Drabenstott, an economist and assistant vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City.
Economists expect the farm recovery to strengthen and continue. Exports continue to rise this year and farm production is recovering after two years of drought. Last year real farm income climbed to about $38 billion, surpassing the 1987 high of $37.2 billion. Farm debt has been falling and now stands at about $135.9 billion, down from the 1983 high of $192 billion - making agriculture one of the first areas of the economy to become less leveraged.
 
Agricultural Politics
What of Exports, And Subsidies?
The recovery in farmland prices has by no means been even. Over the past two years, for example, prices have risen much more in the grain belt than in Southwestern states like Oklahoma, Texas and Louisiana. There, prices depend substantially on the energy business, because oil and gas companies are big land buyers. California prices never fell as low as those in many Midwestern states, so the rise has been somewhat less dramatic. The ranch states of South Dakota, Wyoming and Montana have seen some of the steepest price rises because cattle have become very profitable and ranchers have been willing to pay a premium for more space.
Not all is sunny on the farm. Small, family-owned farms will continue to be squeezed out of business. Over the short term, even the larger farmers, and investors, remain susceptible to overproduction, lower commodity prices, curtailed export markets and cutbacks in Government subsidies. The levels of subsidies and exports depend a great deal on the latest round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations, taking place in Uruguay.
But institutional investors are willing to make long-term bets that as agriculture rebounds, so will their holdings. As the executive from Morgan Stanley said, ''The farmer is about to go out and buy more land, which is positive for land prices.''
 
LITTLE TO FEAR FROM THE R.T.C.
Investors in farmland can expect more sales by banks, insurance companies and the Farm Credit System than by the Resolution Trust Corporation.
The R.T.C.'s plans to unload real estate worth hundreds of billions that belonged to savings and loans have caused some property owners to ask whether the market will be flooded, and values depressed. But real estate professionals say the sales of the portion comprising raw land will have little effect in most states. Most of the R.T.C.'s farmland is low quality, located in Southwestern states like Texas and Oklahoma. Much of it was slated for development. The R.T.C. holds almost no top-grade acreage in states like Kansas or California.
''What they really have is the marginal stuff,'' said Kenneth J. Binkley, a senior vice president of Equitable Agri-Business Inc. ''They have very little of the stuff that would affect farm prices if they sold it.''
The R.T.C.'s holdings as of April 30 included 87 parcels of agricultural land ranging from a few acres to several hundred, with an appraised value of only $59.6 million. The agency is also seeking to sell 97 parcels of ranch land, appraised at $71.2 million.
Mr. Binkley and others worry more about the remaining foreclosed farmland - half a million acres, by Morgan Stanley's estimate - that banks and insurance companies will sell in the next few years. Another half a million acres held by the Farm Credit System will also be up for sale. Compared with these holdings, said an investment manager at Morgan Stanley who oversees agricultural investments, ''The R.T.C. is not even a factor.''

HEADLINE: Pony Up $95 Million? Sure, for a Baseball Team

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
Judging by the numbers, winning one of the two National League baseball expansion franchises that will start playing in 1993 would not seem terribly attractive. The league is demanding an entrance fee of $95 million from each new team, up dramatically from the $7 million the American League charged for franchises in Seattle and Toronto during baseball's last expansion in 1977. The additional start-up costs will run at least another $25 million. It will be years before the new teams turn an operating profit.
But owning a baseball team is only partly a financial endeavor. In a nation full of people whose love of the game far exceeds the batting and fielding capabilities they exhibited in their youth, the idea of buying into the major leagues is often the next best thing to being on the field. That explains why more than two dozen groups of prospective owners, representing 10 cities, from Tampa-St. Petersburg to Buffalo and points west, are trooping into New York this month to make their pitches to the league, which will announce its selections next September.
''I'm doing this primarily out of love,'' said Martin Stone, an investor leading a group that wants to organize a team for Phoenix. ''I've had a love affair with baseball since I was old enough to walk.'' 
That is not to say that Mr. Stone or other prospective owners can afford to ignore the financial risks, or that they are oblivious to the potential rewards. The $95 million franchise fee is more than any established baseball team has sold for, except the $100 million commanded by the New York Mets in 1986, just after they won the World Series. The San Diego Padres were sold earlier this year for $75 million and the Seattle Mariners went last year for $77 million.
For a $95 million-plus investment in a new franchise to make financial sense, team values will have to continue increasing as they have over the past decade. The price tag for teams has been rising sharply as the sport's popularity has surged, with television contracts more lucrative than ever. The Mets brought only $21 million in 1980. The New York Yankees, bought by George Steinbrenner's group for $10 million in 1973, are probably worth well over $200 million now, baseball executives said.
But it is unclear whether franchise values can continue to increase so sharply. Even if they do, it could be a long time before a team in a small or medium-sized city could expect to recoup the $125 million or so it will cost to establish the franchise and get it running. ''This is a real financial gamble,'' said Stephen S. Kurtz, an accountant in Denver who is advising a prospective ownership group there.
Moreover, though no precise figures are released, few major league teams have strong operating earnings. Fortune Magazine recently estimated that the Oakland Athletics, the current World Series champions, made less than $1 million last year on revenues of more than $50 million. (For the Athletics, as for most teams, the picture is somewhat brighter when measured by cash flow, which excludes noncash charges like depreciation that are deducted from earnings.) The only teams believed to make consistently healthy profits are the Yankees, who have an extremely lucrative local cable and broadcast television contract, and the Los Angeles Dodgers, who are generally credited with having the strongest and most experienced front office in baseball.
The biggest source of revenue for most teams is television. All teams share equally in the national network and cable contracts, currently held by CBS Sports and ESPN, with each of the 26 clubs now receiving about $13.5 million a year. In addition, each team negotiates its own local broadcast and cable rights, which vary widely. The Yankees take in more than $40 million a year from their local contract; a team in a medium-sized city is likely to get less than $5 million.
Gate receipts also vary, depending on attendance and ticket prices. A team drawing 2 million fans a year, or about 25,000 per home game, generates average net gate revenues of about $14 million, after accounting for the share for the visiting team. Teams also take in several million a year in revenues from concessions, royalties and the sale of advertising space inside their stadiums.
A typical team might therefore have revenues of $35 million to $40 million, of which probably half goes to player salaries. Most of the rest is eaten up by administrative, overhead and marketing costs.
For expansion teams, operating losses are inevitable for at least a year or two. For the first season, the league has decided, the new franchises will not share the league's national television revenue, depriving them of what would be their biggest source of funds.
At the same time, the teams will assume heavy payrolls, for the players they pick up in a draft of major and minor leaguers, for other personnel and for their own systems of minor league teams. And while most of the cities vying for a franchise profess to have hordes of fans so hungry for baseball that they will gladly sit through the losing seasons expansion teams historically record, attendance levels are hard to project.
''For an expansion team, there's a great deal of learning by doing, both on the field and in the front office,'' said Gerald W. Scully, an economist at the Heritage Foundation in Washington and author of ''The Business of Major League Baseball.''
Potential owners say they are well aware of the financial realities. Still, they are lining up for a chance to own a team, scrambling to put their groups together and coordinating their efforts with state and local officials.
The groups are striving to convince current National League owners that they are well-financed and savvy business executives who can maximize revenues and keep costs manageable in an era when player pay is soaring. The league is also looking for evidence of dedicated fans and local political support, and assurances that a new team will have a stadium. Most important might be an element beyond the prospective owners' control: the size of their television markets.
Current team owners have moved slowly to add new franchises, at least in the eyes of some prospective owners and politicians from baseball-hungry states. Indeed, the current round of expansion got under way only after a group of United States Senators hinted that they might hold hearings into whether baseball should continue to enjoy its exemption from antitrust rules. There is very little financial incentive for current owners to add teams, since they would have to split the television among more franchises.
Baseball executives and some would-be owners say the leading sites for the new teams are Tampa-St. Petersburg (the nation's 14th-largest television market, according to the Arbitron ratings service), Denver (19th), Phoenix (20th) and Buffalo (38th).
They add that one of the new teams will almost certainly be in Florida, with the Tampa Bay area the most likely possibility, although Orlando (25th) and Miami (16th) are also in the running. The conventional wisdom is that the other team will be in the West, with Denver and Phoenix running even. Buffalo remains a long shot. Other cities making presentations include Washington; Charlotte, N.C.; Nashville, and Sacramento, Calif.
The prospective ownership groups are all headed by wealthy business executives, investors or lawyers, many with experience owning or running other professional teams. They are often backed by companies with high profiles in the region. Indeed, because of the high costs of winning and operating a franchise, and because the league wants to insure that the new teams will be financially stable, most of the groups have a dozen or more partners.
In Buffalo, the group is headed by Robert Rich Jr., chief executive of Rich Products, a food-processing company, and owner of the Buffalo Bisons Triple-A team, the franchise with the highest attendance in the minor leagues. In Phoenix, Mr. Stone, who built a conglomerate called Monogram Industries during the 1960's and sold it in 1982, already owns the Triple-A Phoenix Firebirds.
One of Denver's wealthiest citizens, John Dikeou, led the group there until he withdrew this summer to tend his troubled real estate empire. Now the Denver group is headed by business executives and lawyers from out of town, with the financial backing of local businesses like the Rocky Mountain News and the Adolph Coors Company. There are three competing ownership groups in Tampa-St. Petersburg - one headed by Frank Morsani, a car dealer, another by Ken Harrelson, a former major league player, and the third by S. Joel Schur, owner of the Class A St. Petersburg Cardinals.
For the cities themselves, the benefits of winning a team include additional jobs and revenues, from both the team and its stadium, for everyone from hot dog vendors to advertising executives. A study in Denver determined that a team would bring as many as 1,000 new jobs and as much as $140 million annually to the local economy. But money and jobs alone do not explain why the baseball campaigns enjoy such earnest support. For the contending cities, a baseball franchise promises the civic pride that comes with being designated ''major league.''
 
DENVER FANS HEAD FOR HOME
Winning a baseball team is not easy. Just ask the fans in Denver, who have been organizing since 1984, when the major leagues first started discussing expansion. Despite years of preparation and strong popular and political support, Denver's campaign has nearly crashed twice since June, when the National League issued specific guidelines for prospective owners and set a schedule for choosing the winners.
The first big hurdle in Denver this summer was a regional vote to impose additional taxes to build a stadium. The league has said it prefers that expansion sites have a baseball-only, outdoor, natural grass stadium, and Denver needed to be able to raise at least $100 million to build one. With the Colorado economy still recovering from the oil slump and a national recession looming, raising the sales tax one-tenth of 1 percent was a hard sell. At one point, the tax proposal was trailing 2-to-1 in the polls. It took a heavy advertising campaign by baseball proponents, to get it passed on Aug. 14 with 54 percent of the vote.
Then the city had to cope with the withdrawal of John Dikeou, whose real estate empire needed attention. That left Denver without an ownership group less than two months before the Sept. 1 deadline for franchise applications. Several prominent supporters of the baseball effort, including Gov. Roy Romer, immediately began scrambling to find new investors. Within a few weeks, they brought together a group headed by Steve Ehrhart, a lawyer from Memphis who had once helped run the now-defunct United States Football League.
As with groups in other cities, there is little public information about the Denver group's financial strength.
But Mr. Ehrhart and his associates say the Denver region has proven that it will support a professional sports franchise. Their prime exhibit: the Denver Broncos. Like the Broncos in football, a baseball team might draw fans from as far away as New Mexico, Wyoming and Nebraska. Likewise, they argue, a Denver team's television market would encompass the entire Rocky Mountain region. There is currently no major league team between Kansas City and California.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Strategy session in Denver: In shirtsleeves, left to right, Michael Monus, Steven Ehrhart, Jerry McMorris and John Antonucci of the ownership group. In jackets, Colorado Gov. Roy Romer and Denver Mayor Frederico Pena (Jim Estrin for The New York Times); chart: prices of various teams inthe 1980's, compared with the league entrance fees from the 1977 and 1990 expansions.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Prospecting for the Market Bottom

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Barton Biggs, chief global strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, is tired of advising clients to stay away from the world's stock markets. ''It is not an inspiring message and repeating it gets endlessly boring,'' he said.
So in a recent report, Mr. Biggs gave his advice in two paragraphs - stay away - and then took the suggestion of some of his friends and turned the rest of his analysis into a travelogue: an account of how he had spent his summer vacation in Switzerland (Geneva and Zermatt) and climbing Mount Borah in Idaho.
There probably has been no more artful response to the relentless decline in world stock markets, which began before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last month and has accelerated since. 
There seems to be nothing but bad news for the tumbling markets. Oil prices are now in the $33-a-barrel range, $8 higher than the $25 level many analysts expected immediately after the Aug. 2 invasion. Inflation worries are increasing. The likelihood of higher interest rates is growing. A recession is more possible here and in Britain and analysts see signs of slowdowns in European economies.
Uncertainty may be the worst poison. News bulletins send the markets up and down. But after each little rally, the Mideast crisis drags on and the markets move down another notch.
Last week, major stock markets around the world - except in the United States - fell to new lows for the year. That came after three weeks of hovering just above the previous lows, which were reached on Aug. 23.
In Germany, where the soaring cost of unification is also depressing the market, the fall in the DAX index of 30 shares has now wiped out all the gains since the Berlin Wall began to come down Nov. 9. The DAX fell to 1,446.57 on Friday, 16.39 points below the level the index was at when the wall's demise sparked hope for the future of Eastern Europe and set off rallies in many markets on the Continent. From its high on March 30, the DAX is now down 26.8 percent.
In Japan, the Nikkei index of 225 leading stocks is down 39 percent for the year. It closed at a new 1990 low of 23,602.98 on Thursday and then bounced up 174.85 on Friday, one of only three foreign markets to rally a little after touching record lows last week. Just since the Iraqi invasion, the Tokyo market has dropped 23 percent.
In France, the CAC-40 index is down 23 percent since last year and 28 percent from its 1990 high. It reached its 1990 low of 1,540.60 on Thursday and then inched up 2.93 points Friday.
In Britain, the FT-SE 100 index of leading stocks is down 16.4 percent after hitting a low of 2,016.9 on Thursday and then popping up 8.6 points Friday.
The list goes on. New 1990 lows were also set last week in Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Belgium, Austria, Italy, the Netherlands, Australia and New Zealand.
These slumps have come on generally low volume. Investors have either sold their stock and are not ready to take a chance on getting back in or didn't sell and are just holding on for the long term.
The declines have been painful not only for investors but also for analysts. Near the end of August, some analysts thought that the bottom might have been reached in many stock markets and said that brave investors could find good values. UBS Phillips & Drew in London, which made such a recommendation, has now changed its mind, backing off from a cautious buy to a sell.
''I wouldn't buy for the bank's account now,'' said Walter Seipp, chairman of Commerzbank A.G., Germany's third-largest bank and a major holder of German stocks. ''I don't think the stock market in Germany or elsewhere will recover until we see the end of the Iraqi crisis.''
For his part, Morgan Stanley's Mr. Biggs says the problem runs deeper. ''I don't really think it is the Mideast,'' he said. ''That is not what is plaguing the market. The markets are being plagued by a worldwide liquidity crunch, with interest rates going up. This is just the unfolding of the bear market.''
Mr. Biggs's only positive message is that the markets may reach bottom by mid-October. But that's a hunch, not a forecast.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Carl Hahn's East German Homecoming

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WOLFSBURG, West Germany

 BODY:
Wednesday will be one of the biggest days in Carl Hahn's life.
On that day, the 64-year-old chairman of Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest auto maker, will join Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany in laying the cornerstone of a $1.9 billion assembly plant Volkswagen is building in Mosel, East Germany.
It will be a big day for Mr. Kohl, the political unifier of the two Germanys, because the plant is by far the single largest West German investment planned for East Germany. But it will be even bigger for Mr. Hahn, the hard-nosed, down-to-earth manager who is increasingly seen as the Germanys' foremost economic unifier.
For him, the day will be fraught with emotion. He grew up near the site of the new plant and once worked as an apprentice in a nearby auto plant. He fled from East to West after World War II to escape the Communists, and has always vowed someday to help rebuild East Germany and its painfully obsolete auto plants. Now he has his chance. ''I felt very sad that nothing had been done to these plants in 45 years,'' he said. ''When you look at these old automobile factories, you see something beyond human expectation, and you see dedicated, hard-working people there.'' 
His steel-blue eyes took on a riveting intensity as he discussed his vision to help East Germany's car industry recapture its former greatness. Under Communism, ''East Germans had to wait 15 years for a car that was below human dignity,'' he said in a tone bordering on anger, referring to the waiting list to buy the underpowered, pollution-spewing Trabant.
Mr. Hahn says the 250,000 cars the Mosel plant will produce each year by 1995 are a key part of Volkswagen's strategy to stretch its lead in Europe and boost its 3-million-car-a-year output to 4 million by the mid-1990's. Since taking the helm at Volkswagen in 1982, Mr. Hahn has jazzed up its models, strengthened its position in Europe and more than restored its financial health; it had record earnings and revenues last year. With its $39 billion in sales last year, Volkswagen is West Germany's - and will be a united Germany's - second-largest company after Daimler-Benz, the auto, truck and aircraft group.
 
Rebuilding East Germany
 As Oct. 3, the official unification date, approaches, Mr. Hahn is spearheading the massive effort by West Germany's mighty industrialists to rebuild East Germany's economy and extend their reach eastward.
Daimler-Benz plans to spend $600 million to modernize East Germany's biggest truck factory. Siemens A.G., West Germany's No. 1 electronics company, will invest more than $625 million to employ 25,000 people in telecommunications, computers and other fields. Deutsche Bank, the West German banking giant, plans to spend more than $500 million to establish 250 branches in East Germany.
Mr. Hahn has traveled across Europe to urge other companies to help rebuild East Germany's economy. He has played such a pivotal role in the country's transformation that many East Germans used to say, half-joking, that the city the Communists had renamed Karl Marx Stadt -where Mr. Hahn was born and where Volkswagen plans to expand a factory to build 1,500 engines a day - should be renamed Carl Hahn Stadt. (That city has reverted to its original name, Chemnitz.) But even as Mr. Hahn basks in the spotlight, there are growing worries about cracks in the Volkswagen empire, with its 260,000 workers, the Audi luxury car group and SEAT, the Spanish auto maker:
* After five record years, car sales in Europe are expected to fall this year. Fiat, Peugeot and Volvo have announced plans to idle or lay off thousands of workers, though Volkswagen has no such plans.
* In the United States, Volkswagen's sales slipped to 154,000 cars last year, compared with 570,000 in 1970, when VW was synonymous with imports and Japanese cars were still the butt of jokes. With Japanese competition fierce and the mark strong, Volkswagen is finding it far tougher than expected to claw its way back in a land that loved the Beetle.
* In Europe, Volkswagen may soon face an all-out assault from Japan's efficient car makers. Toyota and Honda are building assembly plants in Britain to join Nissan there. And the European Community's plan for a barrier-free market could end quotas on Japanese cars, spelling more trouble for European auto makers.
''If they haven't learned any lessons from the United States, the Japanese are going to clean their clocks in Europe,'' said George Peterson, president of Auto Pacific, a Los Angeles-based consulting firm.
At the moment, however, Mr. Hahn is concentrating on East Germany. Even there, though, his grand designs could run into problems. The 6,500 workers planned for the Mosel plant will need huge amounts of retraining because they will be hired from the nearby Trabant plant, a soot-covered relic. Workers there rely on antiquated techniques; they often use hand wrenches and push car frames along the assembly line by hand. And with growing fears of overcapacity in Europe's auto industry, there is no guarantee that there will be a market for the plant's small Golfs and Polos.
 
Pressure From Bonn
 Some industry analysts question whether Mr. Hahn's plunge into East Germany has been swayed too much by emotion and other factors. ''VW is under a lot of pressure from the Government to contribute in East Germany,'' said Karl Ludvigsen, an auto analyst who runs a London-based consulting firm. ''Sometimes I think their activity there is more political than business.''
Mr. Hahn, whose father was sales director of a prewar auto maker in Chemnitz, said Volkswagen's East German strategy, involving a total of $3 billion in investment, makes perfect business sense.
''I don't think it is a risky investment for a company that is short of capacity,'' he said. Last year Volkswagen edged Fiat by a fraction of a percent to capture the lead in auto sales in Europe, its fifth straight year as No. 1. But this year, with West Germany's economy booming, Volkswagen is far out front in sales and cannot keep up with demand.
''We figure that there are 16 million East Germans and that they will buy 750,000 new cars a year,'' said Mr. Hahn, who expects to capture at least a one-third of that market.
Volkswagen has a 33 percent share of West Germany's car market, and Mr. Hahn says its strength in moderate-priced cars should win it an even larger share in poorer East Germany. He also sees opportunities in the rest of Eastern Europe.
As one example of his many activities to help the East, he hosted a meeting 10 days ago that brought together government officials and executives from Eastern and Western Europe. France's Prime Minister and Czechoslovakia's Finance Minister were there, as was the Vice President of the Russian Republic.
One thing is clear. No longer is Wolfsburg, Volkswagen's home 10 miles from the East German border, considered the Western world's industrial outpost along the hostile Communist border. ''Today this has become the center of Europe and the center of Germany,'' Mr. Hahn said.
 
The American Front
 Volkswagen executives deny that they are preoccupied with Eastern Europe. They say they have a second priority: North America.
Mr. Hahn says Volkswagen needs to make itself a force again in the United States, where it has a 1.6 percent market share, if it is to be a truly global concern. Also, learning to survive in the world's toughest auto market should force Volkswagen to sharpen its competitiveness in styling, costs and sturdiness. ''If we don't survive in the U.S., we might have problems in the rest of the world, too,'' said Ulrich Seiffert, the member of Volkwagen's managing board responsible for North America.
In 1978, Volkswagen opened the first foreign-owned auto plant in the United States. Ten years later, it closed the money-losing factory in New Stanton, Pa., which was running at 40 percent of capacity because consumers rejected the Rabbit in favor of snappier, cheaper Japanese cars.
Volkswagen sales also got clobbered when dozens of lawsuits were filed five years ago alleging that a problem with unintended acceleration in Audis had caused accidents. The allegations were never proved, but Audi's American sales plunged to 21,300 last year from 74,000 in 1985. ''What we had was the unintended acceleration of American lawyers,'' said Mr. Hahn, who headed Volkswagen's American operations from 1959 to 1964.
Mr. Hahn had been a favorite to become chairman two decades ago, but when he fell out of favor, he left to become chairman of Continental Gummi-Werke A.G., the tire company. When Volkswagen stalled badly in 1982, the supervisory board turned to him to take over and rev up the company.
This year could be a turning point for Volkswagen's American efforts: after five years of declining, sales through August are up 2.7 percent.
''It is very hard to get the attention of the market when you don't have enough market share,'' said Mr. Hahn. ''We have to do a lot of work. We cannot do this overnight.''
 
Pushing the Passat
 In addition to its Golf and Jetta, Volkswagen is pushing its new mid-sized Passat, so hot in Europe that there is an eight-month waiting list. In the United States, however, the Passat has caught on slowly because of such tough competition as the Honda Accord. To spur sales, Volkswagen has started a campaign in which buyers can return Passats, no strings attached, for three months after purchase.
Audi's American sales are up 6 percent so far this year, partly as a result of a generously priced leasing program as well as a three-year warranty program on purchases, in which Audi says all buyers have to tend to is gas and insurance.
Analysts say that for Volkswagen to score a breakthrough in the United States it must do more of what the Japanese do: Keep costs down, come out with models more frequently and keep American consumers in mind. Thomas F. O'Grady, president of Integrated Automotive Resources of Wayne, Pa., said the problem is that ''up to now Volkswagen has thought that what works in Germany should work in the United States.'' Chastened executives say they are modernizing models more often and paying closer attention to American tastes. For example, Volkswagen opened a design studio in Los Angeles, the epicenter of American trends.
Volkswagen's problems with Japanese competition in the United States could well be a prologue for the future battle in Europe. Nissan, Toyota and Honda will soon increase production capacity in Europe by 800,000 cars a year, while European demand is expected to fall to 13 million cars this year, down 3 percent from last year's record. In addition, in removing international trade barriers, the European Community plans to end national quotas on Japanese cars. West Germany has no quotas, but France limits the Japanese to 3 percent of the market and Italy to less than 1 percent.
These developments could turn Europe's auto market into a battlefield. But Volkswagen, many analysts say, is in the best position among European car makers to defend itself. The Japanese have far less penetration in Germany than in any other European country without quotas, which partly reflects Volkswagen's competitiveness. In addition, Volkswagen relies far less on its domestic market than Renault, Peugeot and Fiat, which dominate their protected markets.
''Volkswagen has the broadest base of the European producers, and it has had a very strong marketing drive the past two or three years,'' said Adrian Brundrett, a Frankfurt-based analyst with the Bank of Liechtenstein. ''It has a very strong position going into the 1990's.''
Despite Volkswagen's robust position, Mr. Hahn says the European Community should impose a Community-wide quota on Japanese imports for several years after 1992 to allow Europe's car makers to become more competitive before the Japanese enter in full force. Japanese auto makers now have 11 percent of the European market. Everyone expected French and Italian car makers to take such a protectionist stand, but when Mr. Hahn, a leading figure from a non-protectionist country, joined them, that was key to swaying Brussels to push for a transition period of five years or more.
''When our Japanese competitors were restructuring their auto industry to be fit for competition with the best, they opened the door only when they were ready,'' he said, ''Why shouldn't Europe do a little of the same thing?'' He said European auto makers were preparing for a barrier-free market and Europeans, not Japanese, should get the first benefits.
 
The Threat From Japan
 ''If the Japanese move quickly into a market that has been blocked, they would cause an enormous drop in European production,'' he said. ''I think we should cushion this in an intelligent way, in a more intelligent way than was done in the U.S.''
Volkswagen's not-so-secret weapon in combating Japanese advances in Europe is its purchase of 75 percent of SEAT from the Spanish Government in 1986. SEAT workers earn less than half what Volkswagen's West German workers earn - and about the same as British workers at the Japanese plants.
Volkswagen has already expanded SEAT's annual production from 350,000 cars to 500,000. About one-fourth of the SEAT-made cars are Volkswagen Golfs, while the rest are sporty, but small SEAT cars: Ibiza, Marbella and Malaga. Volkswagen is now building a 300,000-car-a-year plant outside Barcelona to make a larger SEAT car, the Toledo.
Volkswagen is looking increasingly to Mexico, where its Puebla plant, the nation's largest, will produce 200,000 cars this year, quadruple the level of two years ago. The plant ships Golfs and Jettas to the United States.
In contrast, Volkswagen's joint venture with Ford in Brazil and Argentina has stumbled badly because of those nations' economic maladies.
Volkswagen also hopes to expand by courting Skoda, the respected Czechoslovak auto maker, which makes 200,000 cars a year. VW also is planning a joint venture to produce 150,000 cars a year in China.
Mr. Hahn has sought to cut Volkswagen's annual costs by $600 million, with the goal of an 8 percent pretax return on profits. Despite last year's record earnings of $630 million, Volkswagen's pretax return was 5 percent, below his goal and the levels of most European auto makers.
That could be one of the few goals Mr. Hahn fails to achieve. His retirement is scheduled for the end of next year, but in Wolfsburg many people are asking whether this vigorous man, so committed to helping East Germany and Eastern Europe, won't be tempted to stay on as chairman to carry out his plans in the East.
''There is a temptation, but it is not my intention,'' he said. ''I am very optimistic that the world doesn't depend on me.''
 
IT PARKS ITSELF?
If you hate parking, Volkswagen may have your car: It parks itself.
In a demonstration, the driver pulled an experimental Futura up to a parking space too small for mere mortals even to consider. She turned off the ignition, pushed a button and got out.
Laser sensors measured the distance of the cars in front and back, while supersonic sensors scanned the curb. The car selected one of several possible maneuvers.
It then eased forward, stopped, the wheels turned automatically and it rolled back. It went forward again, back, and finally straightened out, aided by the ability of all four wheels to turn.
The Futura was three inches from the curb, and equidistant from cars in front and back. It can actually park in places just eight inches longer than itself - with no need to worry about snagging a bumper or smashing a tail light.
Winfried Bernhardt, a senior Volkswagen researcher, said the company does not yet know how expensive automatic parking will be. The system would not be available in mass-produced cars for many years.
So for now don't count on it to help you pass your next driving test.
 
SAXONY GEARS UP FOR A RENAISSANCE
Before World War II, the Saxony region, in what is now East Germany, was famous for producing stylish and powerful cars like Horch, Audi, Wanderer and DKW.
But after the war, Saxony's fame reversed. Its car industry became infamous for making the Trabant - an undersized, underpowered, homely cockroach compared with the peacocks of old.
The Trabant has not been updated since 1962, even though Trabant's engineers have developed 16 modern prototypes. ''The history of the East German car industry under Communism was one of de-creation,'' said Peter Kirchberg, a professor of transportation history at the Polytechnic University in Dresden. ''It's a history of the demoralization of engineers.''
Carl Hahn, Volkswagen's chairman, plans now to modernize the dilapidated Trabant factory in Zwickau. Moreover, Volkswagen is building a $1.9 billion factory in nearby Mosel to assemble 250,000 small Polos and Golfs a year. Next month, workers being trained at Mosel will begin assembling 50 Polos a day from kits, rising to 350 Polos a day next year. The plant will ultimately employ 6,500 workers.
Volkswagen also plans to build 1,500 engines a day at a factory in Chemnitz, and has set up a network of 450 dealers in East Germany. Mr. Hahn has persuaded several Western auto-parts companies to open factories in East Germany as well.
Volkswagen's trainees sound far less worried about the future than most East German workers. Take Holgar Kowalski, a former Trabant worker who is a trainee at Mosel: ''The new plant is better equipped and cleaner than the Trabant plant. It's more fun to work here. We're going to roll up our sleeves and get to work.''

CORRECTION-DATE: September 30, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article last week about Volkswagen A.G. referred incorrectly to a sensor used on an experimental car that can park itself electronically. It is ultrasonic, not supersonic.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 23, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1562 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/September 16-21

BYLINE: BY ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Banks Move in on Stocks
 
J.P. Morgan & Company has become the first bank since the Depression to win authority to sell and trade corporate stocks. The Federal Reserve's approval on Thursday was the largest breach in the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which divorced commercial from investment banking. For the time being, Morgan and other banks that might win similar authority may have new products but few buyers. New stock issues are few, although spreads for underwriting them remain high, since finding investors can be harder than selling, say, Government bonds. With banks like Morgan flush with corporate clients, these margins are likely to narrow. And what about the dangers of letting the banks, few as strong as Morgan, play in stocks? Morgan himself sometimes put up his own money to support other banks and pull the nation out of panics. But banks without the Morgan name or backing might find themselves with opportunities they can't afford. 
 
 Inflation Worries Rise
 
An eight-tenths of 1 percent rise in consumer prices for August came as no shock after the disruption of oil supplies from the Persian Gulf. Economists were more alarmed by a five-tenths of 1 percent increase excluding energy and food. Even as the economy weakens, said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at First Boston, ''underlying inflation is moving up.'' The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, apparently read the numbers the same way, saying last week that he was not lowering interest rates in the face of rising inflation.
 
A Peach of a Marketing Plan
 
Atlanta rented mansions for receptions, boasted of being in the best television time zone, insisted that Los Angeles, site of the 1984 Olympics, is in a foreign country and taught every violinist in town to play ''Georgia on My Mind.'' Athens appealed to sentiment and whimpered about Atlanta's profligate $7 million campaign. And so the marketing organization masquerading as a Southern city won the right last week to host the centennial Olympics in 1996. With plans to spend $1.2 billion in private money, and reap $1.4 billion in return, the Olympics could have a more profitable few weeks than even Coca-Cola.
 
F.D.I.C. Sues Neil Bush
 
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on Friday named Neil Bush, the President's son, as a defendant in a $200 million suit involving a failed savings and loan. The suit charges Mr. Bush and other former officials of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association with gross negligence. Mr. Bush, a former director, has denied any wrongdoing.
 
Another Jump for Oil Prices
 
Oil prices rose sharply last week amid shortages of higher-grade crude and fears of a Middle East war. The extra oil that several nations are pumping is heavier and higher in sulfur than the oil Iraq and Kuwait exported before last month's embargo. A barrel of crude for November delivery closed at $35.43, up $4.27 or 13.7 percent - the highest price in nine years.
 
No Payments Until January?
 
To move the merchandise, you have to offer terms. L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, proposed last week that the Government provide financing to purchasers of $50 billion in real estate and other assets from failed savings and loans.
 
Chase Tightens Its Belt
 
The Chase Manhattan Corporation announced on Friday that it will take a $1 billion charge, eliminate 5,000 jobs and cut its dividend in half. The charge includes $350 million for revamping and $650 million for bad loans, especially in commercial real estate.
 
In Brief
 
The nation's trade deficit rose in July to $9.33 billion, the second-highest monthly figure this year. Economists expect the deficit to remain near that range, with the rising cost of imported oil offsetting strong exports.
 
The subways, the traffic, the commotion and the bustle make it easy to get lost in the big city. New York City officials said last week that the Census Bureau failed to find 254,534 dwellings. We merely misplaced them, mistakenly listing their locations, responded the bureau.
 
The staid, century-old Financial Times confused with a screaming London tabloid? The Financial Times failed to win a temporary order last week to prevent The Evening Standard from printing its business section on paper of the same peach-colored paper.
 
The Federal Communications Commission gave providers of local telephone service more freedom to set access charges for long-distance carriers. Productivity incentives are meant to make the local providers more efficient. But the potential savings for consumers are unclear.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
An Important 'No' to Gorbachev
 
No sooner does President Mikhail S. Gorbachev make a move than one of his own top economic advisers calls it a mistake. On Monday, Mr. Gorbachev asked for a national referendum on legalizing the private ownership of land - a key premise of plans for creating free markets. Stanislav S. Shatalin, a prime author of these plans, dismissed a referendum as ''unworkable'' considering the urgency of economic change. ''If all progress was subject to a referendum,'' he said, ''we would all be still up in the trees throwing coconuts and stones at each other.'' He predicted that the referendum idea will soon fade; the President's proposal four months ago for a broader economic referendum was quickly scrapped.
 
Soviet Seat No Bargain
 
An independent Soviet press agency reported last week that the new Moscow Commodity Exchange is trying to sell seats for an improbable-sounding $162,000, or more than half the price of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. The exchange plans to begin trading this Wednesday. The report is not quite as laughable as it seems. The Soviet Union has natural resources to match its vast geographic expanse. The Government's own commodity traders, at home and abroad, are known for being as wily and ruthless as those in the Chicago pits.
 
The Reichmanns Cash In
 
They snapped up New York office towers at the depth of the city's mid-1970's recession, then watched the value of their holdings multiply. Now, the three Reichmann brothers are, if not exactly bailing out, certainly opening the hatch. Olympia & York, their company, is offering to sell a 25 percent interest in most of its holdings in the United States. The Reichmanns are evidently not facing a financial crisis of Trumpian proportions. More likely, they want to reduce their risks and raise more cash for their huge Canary Wharf project in London, where the real estate market is also in decline. But after their losses from backing their fellow Toronto resident, Robert Campeau, the Reichmanns' reputation for savvy investing and flawless timing has suffered.
 
COMPANIES
 
A New Opus from Jobs
 
Steven P. Jobs returned to San Francisco's Symphony Hall last Tuesday to present his Op. 2 through Op. 5. Critics say the performance of his company, Next Inc., has improved since it introduced a slow, high-priced product - the black cube - in the same hall two years ago. His four new machines, faster and mostly less expensive, are likely to improve the company's sales. But they are probably coming too late for Mr. Jobs to repeat the success he enjoyed as the founder of Apple Computer.
 
Jail for Keating
 
Charles H. Keating, the former owner of Lincoln Savings and Loan, says the accusations against him come from ''malicious bureaucrats'' too dense to understand his deals. On Tuesday, charged with deceiving investors into buying high-risk bonds, he was led to jail in chains, with bail set at $5 million, beyond his reach. Many elderly depositors have said they were told the bonds were federally insured; now, they are worthless. In this case, the bureaucrats appear to have aided Mr. Keating. The California Department of Corporations approved the sale of the bonds through Lincoln branches.
 
G.M. Waltzes With Labor
 
Labor negotiations in the auto industry look less like wrestling than a waltz. The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation agreed on a tentative three-year contract Monday with scarcely a squawk or complaint. The union extended its old contract a few days rather than call a strike. The auto companies have headed into what used to be called the strike season with low inventories, confident that production will continue. The G.M. deal gives workers a 3 percent salary increase the first year, then two annual 3 percent payments, with enhanced job security. Analysts consider ratification likely by the end of this month. Ford, the healthiest of the Big Three, appears likely to accept the same terms as G.M. But a Chrysler spokesman says the company can't afford an ''outrageous pattern settlement.''
 
In Brief
 
An airline shrivels: Pan American World Airways announced plans to cut 2,500 jobs, 8.6 percent of its total, by next month.
 
Another airline turns its suppliers into bankers: Northwest Airlines received a $500 million loan from Airbus Industrie and General Electric after agreeing to buy 75 Airbus jets, equipped with engines from G.E.
 
Mortimer J. Zuckerman, a real estate developer, is said to be negotiating with the Sony Corporation to jointly develop the New York Coliseum site on Columbus Circle.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
In Hard Times, Stay the Course in Equities

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
There is a substantial penalty for ill-timed panic in the stock market, warns Mark Stumpp, the director of research for PDI Strategies, a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America.
Stocks historically have outperformed both Treasury bills and inflation. But Mr. Stumpp calculated recently that, over the past 30 years, investors who switched from equities to Treasury bills for just 10 isolated months - the market's 10 best months, to be sure - lost virtually all the advantages of investing in equities for that entire period.
Dumping stocks might even have seemed sensible at the time, Mr. Stumpp pointed out. Four of the 10 bonanza months occurred during recessions; one encompassed the Cuban missile crisis. ''In fact, the top-10 performing months reads like a roll call of hard times,'' he said.
His strategy now? While he sees no reason to overweight a portfolio with equities, ''The collapse in stock prices over the past month has created opportunities, and we've put some cash to work.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The American Who Is Lobbying the World

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
As the Bush Administration strives to tighten the noose of United Nations sanctions around Saddam Hussein's neck, the man adjusting the rope has been doing his job with an appeal to high moral values and the lessons of history. For Thomas R. Pickering, America's representative to the United Nations, the world is engaged in the struggle it forgot to wage in the 1930's as it seeks to push Iraq's army out of occupied Kuwait.
His Security Council speeches are liberally sprinkled with references to the international community's appeasement of Hitler and the disaster that followed. He also likes to remind the world that the Security Council is merely doing what it is supposed to do - enforcing peace and international security, if half a century late. 
In the fishbowl that is the United Nations, Mr. Pickering's high moral stance is hardly out of place; this is, after all, intended to be a place where international cooperation can be realized. So his appeals to the ideal of collective security offer a compelling argument for maintaining the consensus that has allowed tough action against Iraq. Preserving that consensus has been his principal task since President Bush decided to work with the United Nations to force Saddam Hussein's invasion troops out of Kuwait.
Individual countries may have their private agendas in the gulf. But in justifying them they welcome Mr. Pickering's appeal to become advocates of international law and the rights of small nations.
Mr. Pickering's task of being point man for maintaining international unity has only been made possible, of course, by the historic changes in the Soviet Union, which have left Moscow no longer automatically siding with Washington's adversaries. The consensus has also been helped by the composition of the present Security Council, which is proving more responsive to American leadership than first expected.
Some 18 months ago, Western diplomats were dismayed at the prospect that Cuba, Romania and Yemen would join the Council this year. But the revolution in Eastern Europe transformed Romania into an ally, and while Yemen and Cuba try to protect Iraq, the Council's other third-world members - Ethiopia, Ivory Coast, Zaire and Malaysia - have firmly supported sanctions.
 
Hard Times Ahead?
 But Mr. Pickering's most difficult moments probably still lie ahead. If sanctions do not bring about Iraq's withdrawal soon, the Administration may have to choose between using force or keeping American soldiers in the Saudi desert. If Washington chooses a military solution, Mr. Pickering's task will be to persuade the Security Council to authorize a war - provided, that is, that President Bush continues to work through the United Nations. If the President abandons the United Nations and goes it alone, Mr. Pickering will have to tell its members why.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1034 words

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Is There a Cheaper Way To Attack Rising Crime?

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Should firefighters wield guns as well as hoses, and garbage collectors carry nightsticks along with trash? Should private security patrols get city subsidies, and serious criminals be tried in special courts? Should the police stop and frisk dozens in sweeps, challenging civil liberties laws?
Those are among the questions that New York City officials are weighing - with varying degrees of seriousness - now that they have committed themselves to hiring thousands more police officers and to augmenting the rest of the criminal justice system to deal with the extra arrests.
The challenge is to make the whole stubborn, sprawling process not just bigger, but better.
Mayor David N. Dinkins, in an interview taped in Washington last week with John McLaughlin, the television political commentator, called crime in New York ''an emergency situation'' that ''calls for extreme measures.'' 
In theory, there should be enough prosecutors, probation officers and parole officers, enough judges and court officers, enough jail guards and jail cells, to handle the problems the police bring in off the streets every day. But virtually no one thinks there are - or that the system they are in works very well.
So if more officers are hired and more cells are built, but trial calendars are still clogged, dismissals of serious charges are still common, caseloads for probation workers are still too high, the gap between arrest and arraignment times is still too long and the likelihood of avoiding punishment is still high even for criminals who are caught, what will have changed?
Not much, even the city officials charged with changing things acknowledge. ''It will take a tremendous amount of will, determination and managerial skill,'' said the Deputy Mayor for Public Safety, Milton Mollen. ''People are enormously resistant, and particularly institutions are enormously resistant to change.''
Just as experts disagree on what causes crime, so they differ - sometimes bitterly - over how best to combat it. Criminologists, like dentists, say the first strategy should ideally be prevention. With it, there would be fewer crimes and no need for so many system-jamming arrests.
Much of Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown's concept of community policing, in which officers are encouraged to get to know neighborhoods and take time to solve problems, is in this vein.
But senior city officials acknowledge that far more novel, even radical approaches have been raised, some of them the brainchildren of past and present officials. Each idea, however, raises a new potential problem.
For example, should firefighters, who spend less than 10 percent of their time fighting fires, be armed and sent to patrol neighborhoods between fires? Or at least drive around in their imposing trucks keeping an eye on things, instead of resting, cooking or cleaning firehouse equipment? Training would be a problem, and union resistance, both from the firefighters and the police, would undoubtedly be great.
''There is no substitute for professionally trained police officers to deliver professional police services to the city,'' Dennis Sheehan, a spokesman for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said yesterday. ''Everybody is tripping all over each other with these crazy ideas.''
Should the city support neighborhood crime patrols, offering $20,000 matching grants that would help them buy cars or hire private guards? Standards would have to be set, vigilantism could be a problem, and the money to qualify for the grants would probably be raised more often in middle-class neighborhoods than in high-crime ones.
Another idea is to beef up the Police Cadet Corps, under which college students work part-time for the department in exchange for scholarships. But the cadets, who work in gray and blue uniforms that are distinctly different from standard police dress, carry nothing more lethal than nightsticks, and officials said there would be an uproar if one was killed in the line of duty.
One option the city is seriously discussing is creating special ''major offense'' bureaus in the court system, where persistent offenders or people on trial for serious crimes would be specially tracked to prevent their cases from being dismissed for procedural problems, like the failure of a prosecutor to appear on time.
''The idea would be to have much tighter discipline in getting the cases through,'' said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. ''That requires the judges to be much tougher.''
Mr. Mollen, who was formerly the presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, is to talk with senior judicial officials about this and other ideas this week.
And what about probation and parole, the great black holes of the system, out of the public mind except when, as often happens, someone on probation or parole is arrested for a horrifying crime? On any given day, 56,000 people are on probation in the city, and 75,000 pass through the system each year, more people than are in jail statewide.
More than 70 percent of those now on probation are felony offenders, up from 56 percent in 1984, according to Catherine M. Abate, the city's Commissioner of Probation. More than 60 percent are drug abusers and more than 50 percent are unemployed. Probation officials argue that more supervision, more employment and more counseling could make probation ''the most sensible long-term solution for reducing crime,'' Commissioner Abate recently told the City Council.
There remains the problem of how to pay, and who will do so. The state bears the cost of parole, of hiring judges and of building state prison cells, and subsidizes probation and, to a lesser degree, district attorneys. But the city must carry the bulk of the burden, from hiring police to building local jails and courtrooms.
With the city already facing a probable budget gap of well over $1 billion for the coming fiscal year, there are no quick fixes. But officials say they have no choice but to try.
''All the components play an important role,'' Mr. Mollen said. ''And unless we keep our mind focused on all the elements in the criminal justice chain, we're going to be in serious trouble.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5, Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 841 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Violent Debate Over Tribal Sovereignty

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
The standoff between some 20 heavily armed Mohawks and the Canadian Army has become the rallying point for many Indians across Canada and the United States who claim vast tracts of government land and who want to establish complete sovereignty over areas they control.
But the standoff is also evidence of a power struggle within Indian communities between well armed and well financed militants and traditional Indian leaders. Since the decision in 1973 by Indian militants at Wounded Knee, in South Dakota, to take up arms, many Indians have been debating how they should carry out their struggle for rights and land. This debate has resulted in armed clashes between opposing Indian groups, most recently on the St. Regis reservation in upstate New York and in Oka, Quebec, which is 18 miles west of Montreal. 
Among the stakes are the millions of dollars in profits from gambling operations and the illicit sales of tax-free gasoline and cigarettes, two primary sources of tribal income. More important is the question of how Indian communities will press forward with their extensive land and compensation claims, how they will move to develop their economies, and what future relations will be like with state and federal officials.
''We are trying to define ourselves and our future,'' said Doug George, editor of Akwesasne Notes, which is published on the St. Regis reservation. ''The route we take to develop our local economies is the most important issue we face. Now we have an option between the Mafia-style gambling operations that have corrupted much of our youth, and relying on the income we make working in the white community. Neither of these choices is beneficial to us and we must find some way out.''
In Oka, about 20 Indian militants and 30 women and children are holed up in a white clapboard building surrounded by coils of razor wire, soldiers in flak jackets and armored personnel carriers. Indian leaders and Canadian officials are trying for an agreement to end the crisis, which began with a shootout on July 11 between Indians and the Quebec provincial police. One police officer was killed in the encounter and 400 army troops moved in to occupy most of the area on Sept. 1.
The clash evolved from a dispute over 55 acres of pine forest, which local officials wanted for a golf course, into a fight by Indian leaders for sovereignty over all the land they claim and the right to control their economic and political destiny. Trying to mollify the Indian community, the Canadian Government bought the land and has offered it to the Mohawks. But the militants say this is no longer enough.
In the last 20 years many tribes have rescued themselves from cultural extinction, teaching their native tongues to their children and turning to tribal traditions for guidance. Federal welfare programs hoisted many Indians above the poverty line, although a disproportionate number still live in poverty. Unemployment runs as high as 40 percent on reservations in the United States, according to the Bureau of Indian Affairs. But education and health have improved, and tribes are displacing government agencies that administer Indian programs.
''We are going to close one of our agency offices on the Cherokee reservation next week,'' said Carl Shaw, a spokesman for the Bureau of Indian Affairs in Washington. ''I expect that in the next few years we will be closing dozens more.'' The bureau has 84 agency offices and 12 area offices throughout the United States.
 
Playing Bingo
 Indians have also gone to the courts to get back or be compensated for land they contend was taken illegally from them. The 1.5 million Indians in the United States own about 54 million acres and are trying to regain or be compensated for millions more.
But efforts to increase land holdings have been accompanied by a loss of traditional means of economic support. Throughout the United States and Canada urban encroachment and pollution have all but obliterated hunting, fishing and farming. Reservation land, owned collectively, cannot be used as collateral for loans. And the gray area of sovereignty frightens many outside investors.
With so few alternatives, many tribes have turned to gambling. There are more than 100 bingo or gaming operations on the 310 tribes in the lower 48 states. Many of these organizations are establishing close links with the militant Indian underground and organized crime, Indian leaders contend.
Militant Mohawks, grouped around the Warrior Society, have built a multimillion-dollar business in gambling and smuggling tax-free gasoline and cigarettes on Mohawk reservations in the United States and Canada. The money has proved alluring to other Indians, especially the unemployed young. The militants have invested in high-powered weapons, such as AK-47 assault rifles, and have shown a willingness to use them. Thomas A. Constantine, the Superintendent of the New York State Police, said that the Warrior Society ''has more assault weapons than the entire New York State Police.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Mohawk Indian scuffles with a Canadian soldier on the Khanawake reserve near Montreal last week. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 934 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
As Problems Fester, Voters Send Pink Slips

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In growing numbers, Americans say they are fed up with politicians. They look around and see schools that don't teach, streets that aren't safe, doctors they can't afford. Then they look to Washington, or Sacramento or Albany or City Hall, and they see bickering and feuding and deadlock.
This gap between problems and performance is pushing the American electorate from apathy to anger. Last week the frustration boiled over at the polls in Massachusetts and Oklahoma, where voters dumped establishment political figures in favor of candidates who promised, as John R. Silber, the surprise Democratic gubernatorial nominee, put it, ''to take back your government.'' 
More of this lies ahead. There is talk of a populist rebellion, an idea consistent with the fact that so far the disenchantment is greatest in, but not limited to, the states where economic times are toughest.
The dark side of such rebellion is beginning to worry people. Both liberals and conservatives conjure images of political lynch mobs. Ann Lewis, a longtime Democratic party worker in Boston, said that after virtually every candidate affiliated with the current Massachusetts administration was repudiated last week, the mood was especially gloomy. ''I looked out my window,'' she said, and almost imagined seeing an angry mob with ''Michael Dukakis's head on a pike.''
Historically, an angry public turns to the party out of power to fix things. But on the basis of a recent public opinion survey he conducted for the Times Mirror Company, Andrew Kohut concluded that voters are losing faith in both parties.
''Things are so bad, let's fire everybody and start over again,'' Cathy Walsh, a Boston bank teller, said after voting in Tuesday's Massachusetts primary.
Ms. Walsh is expressing an exaggerated version of an anger that Americans are showing across the country and which is distinctly different from the anti-government fervor that fueled California's Proposition 13 tax revolt and swept Ronald Reagan into office. That was a rebellion against the liberal welfare state, and particularly the burden middle-class white people felt they were being asked to bear for it. But surveys show that a substantial majority of Americans now want more from government, not less - better schools, cleaner air, safer streets, less expensive health care. In some cases, they say they would accept tax increases to pay for these things.
But at the same time, people have lost faith in the ability of politicians to run things honestly and efficiently for them. Polls show that at least two-thirds of Americans think government is usually wasteful and that officials in Washington quickly lose touch with the people. They want the deficit reduced, but all they see on television are pictures of men in suits riding to an Air Force base in big cars. Nothing seems to get accomplished. In a piece of exquisite political perversity, Michael Dukakis apparently came close to defining a deep political need when he said the issue was competence. The issue is competence, although not in Mr. Dukakis's technocratic sense, as if government were just a big machine and the only trick is knowing the right lever to throw.
Kevin Phillips, the political analyst, sees a new populism on the rise. He argues that in the public eye, company presidents who take big salaries for themselves while jobs are exported are of a piece with politicians who raise their own pay but can't balance the nation's, or the state's, checkbook. Clearly, the anger and disenchantment is worse in places were the economy is more troubled, like Massachusetts and Oklahoma. But even in Washington state, where the economy remains strong, voters dumped the chief justice of the State Supreme Court and none of the professional politicians seemed to know why. But the upset winner, Charles Johnson, thought he knew. ''They wanted a new face on the bench,'' said Mr. Johnson, a little-known lawyer from Tacoma.
There are signs that a self-perpetuating cycle is developing. Americans do not believe in the politicians they elect and the politicians are terrified of the people who give them their jobs. ''We are simply afraid to make any difficult decisions,'' said Representative Ed Jenkins, Democrat of Georgia. ''We're afraid we'll make someone mad at us.''
Still, the rising mood of disenchantment does not mean that every officeholder will be summarily dumped. Incumbents often find that simply being in office gives them the power to stay there. Moreover, the Persian Gulf crisis has provided a powerful distraction from domestic discontents that often focus anger against politicians.
But there are signs that the voters are looking for ways to get the attention of even the most safely seated office holders. In Oklahoma, voters by 2 to 1 approved a measure to limit state legislators to a total of 12 years in office. James Browne, an attorney in Oklahoma City, said the new law ''means having citizen legislators in the Capitol rather than professional politicians.'' Silmilar measures will be on the California and Colorado ballots in November.
Eddie Mahe, a Republican consultant, says he fears that the same anger that draws voters to such measures, which he supports, could feed something much scarier. ''What you're getting now is aggressive alienation, aggressive hostility at the system and the people in it,'' he said. ''At that point we have a different problem as a country. If you had someone who was truly a demagogue come along he or she would be very powerful. A George Wallace with class could sweep this country like wildfire.''
