PUB-DATE: September 23, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1160 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
The Battle of the Columnists: Telling Leaders How to Think

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
In the earliest days of the Reagan Revolution, conservative activists frequently showed their disdain for the technocratic, bipartisan politics they believed prevailed in Washington by proclaiming ''Ideas matter!'' The ideological furor now roiling the conservative movement is reminding politicians and the press that idea-mongers matter too.
In recent weeks, conservative newspaper columnists, editorial pages and television commentators have been battling one another, hurling accusations of militarism and anti-Semitism at fellow members of their once-unified clan. Superficially, they are fighting over the extent of America's military commitment to the oil sheikdoms of the Middle East and to Israel. But their battle is really about the intellectual direction of the conservative movement and the Republican Party. The debate is being watched by conservatives who recall that issues like supply-side economics and the differences between totalitarian and authoritarian governments were fought in the columns before becoming Reagan Administration policy and the law of the land. 
''If politicians are to be able to decide what the electorate wants, they have to have the parameters of the debate communicated to them by the scriveners,'' said Jude Wanniski, an economics consultant who edits ''The Media Guide,'' an annual survey of the press.
Mr. Wanniski helped push the supply-side argument that large tax cuts would lead to sizeable revenue increases for the Federal Government when he was a member of the editorial board of the Wall Street Journal. But he and others credit the syndicated columnists Rowland Evans and Robert Novak with making the theory respectable enough for mainstream Washington to accept.
 
Trickle-Down Punditry
 Generally, punditry does not directly result in new policy, but in a reshaping of the ''political framework'' in Washington that allows politicians to succeed and policy to be set, said Don Sipple, a Republican political consultant. He said that pundits in Washington helped Dianne Feinstein generate money and publicity for her California gubernatorial campaign by speculating on her attractiveness as a candidate on a national Democratic ticket. ''It's the old notion of trickle-down, and the byproduct is conventional wisdom,'' said Mr. Sipple, who is advising Ms. Feinstein's opponent, the Republican nominee for California Governor, Pete Wilson. ''It can be unnerving.''
Columnists and commentators have not wielded their powerful cudgels solely in conservative circles. Official Washington credits - or blames - The New York Times columnist Anthony Lewis with providing some of the glue that united opposition to Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court in 1987. But in recent years, the conservative voices have had far more effect.
Conservatives have historically lacked powerful interest groups like trade unions and ethnic organizations to take their case directly to political leaders. The currents that influenced conservative thought - and the Republican Party - over the last two decades began flowing largely through neoconservative journals like The Public Interest and Commentary. Ronald Reagan's affection for two more traditional conservative publications, Human Events and The National Review, led many to seek access to him through the printed word.
The current conservative contretemps over America's military intervention in the Persian Gulf began as a match between two columnists who once worked as speech writers in the Nixon White House, William Safire of The New York Times and Patrick J. Buchanan of Tribune Media Services. Mr. Safire calls himself a ''geopolitical conservative'' and argues that ''the Republican Party is not going to go the route of a narrow conservative movement.'' Mr. Buchanan grudgingly accepts the appellation ''neo-isolationist'' and says, ''The old cold warriors, Catholics and others who saw Communism as evil and a threat against our country will go back to our familiar point of view - let's tend to our own affairs.''
The arguments grew more heated when other conservative columnists and editorial writers began questioning whether Mr. Buchanan, who was director of communications in the Reagan White House, was trafficking in anti-Semitism. In The Washington Times, Mona Charen, a syndicated columnist who worked under Mr. Buchanan as a communications aide in the Reagan Administration, complained that he blamed Israel for inciting the Bush Administration's intervention in the gulf and singled out American Jews as supporters of an American military response. Soon after, A. M. Rosenthal of The New York Times connected these opinions to past Buchanan columns that challenged the case against a man convicted of Nazi atrocities by an Israeli court.
Mr. Buchanan defended himself in his own Wednesday column and called Mr. Rosenthal's attack a ''contemptible attempt to stifle debate, especially on the issue of America's relations with Israel.''
Tony Snow, the editorial page editor of The Washington Times, which pays close attention to conservative affairs, attributes the bitterness over the Middle Eastern situation to a sense of ''ideological gridlock'' in the White House and the feeling that the future of conservatism is up for grabs. At stake are America's role in the post-cold war world, and the relative primacy of international and domestic issues in conservative and Republican politics.
''Many people see George Bush as part of a different era, of the time when the question was 'Are Communists good or bad?' '' he said. ''His view of social policy is noblesse oblige, not the entrepreneurial populism that's growing in the Republican Party. A lot of people are waiting for Bush to pass from the scene.''
 
Replaying the Past
 Some historians agree, and see the war among the pundits as replaying debates that preoccupied conservatives for much of this century. ''I think it's the right going back to its former policies,'' said John B. Judis, the author of a recent biography of William F. Buckley Jr. ''It's this combination of isolationism, with Israel figuring in there as an international cause about which Americans should be wary. Decades ago, the far right feared that there was an international Jewish conspiracy led by the Rothschilds and people like that. The parallels between the late 1940's and now are unmistakable.''
But today conservatives of both stripes have an effective new conduit for their ideas. ''The war between the interventionists and the neo-isolationists has moved to the weekend talk shows and the op-ed pages,'' said Mr. Buchanan. ''It is not only among journalists, like Buchanan and Safire, but between Brzezinski and Kissinger, and it moves onto shows like 'The Capital Gang,' 'Crossfire,' 'The McNeil-Lehrer News Hour,' David Brinkley's Sunday show and 'Nightline.' This is where the debate is played out. It is an unrecognized sea change in American politics.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In the Democracy Of Nicaragua, Control Control Is Still From the Top

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua

 BODY:
When Violeta Barrios de Chamorro was elected President last February, Nicaragua appeared ready to trade a long tradition of authoritarian leadership for an exuberant, if chaotic, attempt at political pluralism.
But with each passing week, Nicaraguans are learning that the habit of rule from above dies hard. The new Government's pluralistic exterior has given way to the familiar image of a closed, even secretive group of leaders, pursuing its vision of Nicaragua's future with little attention - or even advance notice - to its allies and the public.
The transformation has been all the more remarkable because it has paired Mrs. Chamorro's closest personal adviser, her son-in-law Antonio Lacayo Oyanguren, with a principal leader of the still-powerful Sandinista front, Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, in an attempt to devise a working relationship far above the heads of the voters. 
That collaboration has not been enough to guarantee social peace, or produce the united front of business, labor and government that the new administration has called for to rebuild the country's shattered economy. But it has had a profound effect on the structure of power, leaving many Nicaraguans wondering what unspoken compromises the new Government has made with the Sandinistas, and carrying Nicaragua far from the kind of democratic process that put Mrs. Chamorro in office.
''You get the feeling that the whole country revolves around the private conversations of these two people,'' a European diplomat said, referring to Mr. Lacayo and General Ortega. ''No one really knows what they say to each other, or what they have already agreed. But their relationship defines the terms of every important event here.''
Formally, Mrs. Chamorro's election coalition was made up of people with a broad collection of ideological views, ranging from Communists to conservatives. But the political diversity was largely discarded even before her inauguration; the President-elect named a technocratic Cabinet whose most important members are a few personal aides led by Mr. Lacayo, her longtime chief strategist and plenipotentiary.
From the start of Mrs. Chamorro's campaign, Mr. Lacayo, an American-educated businessman who had worked successfully in partnership with the Sandinista Government, declared that the new President would seek no revenge against the former regime, but would instead work with it to forge a new national consensus. The Government has since pursued that goal with an independence and political generosity that have enraged many of Mrs. Chamorro's conservative supporters and bewildered even her strongest personal allies, who have begun to doubt that they have been told the full extent of the concessions to the Sandinista leadership.
In one-on-one transition talks with General Ortega last march, Mr. Lacayo, acting on behalf of Mrs. Chamorro, signed a controversial accord in which the newly elected officials agreed to leave undisturbed the Sandinista-dominated army and security forces in return for Sandinista commitments to allow an orderly change in government.
 
 Meeting Resistance
 Mr. Lacayo overcame conservative resistance to that trade-off by pledging publicly that no other pacts or protocols that would limit the Government's power had been reached in secret. But Government supporters, including the Bush Administration, were then outraged when Mrs. Chamorro, at Mr. Lacayo's urging, let General Ortega remain as her highest military officer in a further gesture toward national unity. Mr. Lacayo then tried to sell the gesture to skeptical leaders of Mrs. Chamorro's coalition.
''There were 50 people in the room when he told us about the decision,'' said a conservative politician. ''Forty-seven were against it, but the three votes won.''
To mollify opposition to her retention of General Ortega, Mrs. Chamorro announced that she would serve as Defense Minister and would exert strong control over the military. But the value of that pledge has now been thrust into doubt by the appearance of two new laws, formally published this month but dated before the elections. They strip the Defense Minister of most powers and make the army commander almost invulnerable to outside control.
Asked about the new laws, which were signed by former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, Mrs. Chamorro said she knew nothing of them and dismissed them with what has become her habitual response to such questions: ''I am the one who gives the orders here.''
But Sandinista officials said the laws were fully discussed with Mr. Lacayo at the transition talks in March. And even diplomats who have strongly backed the new Government have begun to assume that the transition pact runs far deeper than the Government has admitted.
 
No Fear of Coups
 Conservatives argue that the Government does not have to make concessions to the Sandinista leadership out of fear of a coup, because even Sandinista officials admit that a military overthrow of the new President would bring near-unanimous international condemnation and perhaps American intervention.
Whatever Sandinista commitments the Government has won by its generous stance also appear to be sharply limited, given the drumbeat of Sandinista-led strikes and protests against the new regime. Those street actions, which often begin and end so abruptly as to seem choreographed, are increasingly interpreted by foreign analysts here less as genuine political events than as markers in a broader game between Mr. Lacayo and General Ortega.
The unusual partnership has been reinforced by its effective monopoly on Nicaragua's press, which is divided between two pro-Sandinista newspapers and La Prensa, the former opposition daily that is owned by Mrs. Chamorro's family and edited by Mr. Lacayo's wife.
But against a background of deepening economic crisis and public misery, the Government's reliance on high-level, closed-door deals has already taken a toll on its popular support. And with no one else to blame if it should fail, Mrs. Chamorro's small inner circle still faces the first requirement of even the most autocratic regime - that it achieve results.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Running the Gulf Coalition Is Tricky Business

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It would be hard to find another international military operation in which the raising and distribution of money has played so central a role as it has in the Persian Gulf crisis. Watching American officials traveling the globe in recent weeks collecting pledges of more than $20 billion to support the anti-Iraq coalition makes one wonder whether the United States has military allies in this affair or only limited financial partners.
Why have so many countries been more preoccupied with the movement of funds than the movement of troops to defend Saudi Arabia from the Iraqi forces that took over Kuwait? The broad answer, which Administration officials have been reluctant to articulate, is that deep down the United States understands that many of its partners are in the coalition only because of a coincidence of interests, not because they share a common sense of moral purpose. 
To be sure, the motivation of the Saudis, Kuwaitis and other gulf Arabs is obvious. Kuwait's independence is at stake and the others fear for their own survival. But the other leading members of the anti-Iraq coalition have joined for a grabbag of reasons, among them tribal feuds, desires to impress the American Congress and efforts to divert attention from their own misdeeds. Administration officials seem to understand that this is not the enduring cement of grand coalitions. They did not want to see these motives put to the test of sacrifice, and that is the main reason billions were raised to cushion four prominent front-line countries - Egypt, Syria, Jordan and Turkey -from feeling any financial pinch from the crisis.
 
No Victory Gardens
 While opinion polls show that the American people overwhelmingly support what President Bush has done, and are appalled by the actions of the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, Administration officials also fear that American taxpayers may not be committed enough to the anti-Baghdad operation to be ready to sacrifice for it, even if only in the form of higher taxes. Therefore, the officials feel that the public has to be cushioned from any financial sacrifice and the operation has to be presented as virtually cost-free. No victory gardens necessary, thank you. Such was the logic of the fund-raising trips of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady.
For now, though, the coincidence of interests that underlies the anti-Iraq coalition has come together at the United Nations to produce an international consensus that defies historical parallel, expressed in the form of six high-minded Security Council resolutions that place Iraq under sanctions and call for its unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Statesmen and politicians around the world have been impressed by President Bush's achievement in forging this consensus in the United Nations. This week, as the General Assembly opens, the Security Council is near agreement on a resolution to ban passenger and cargo flights to and from Iraq and occupied Kuwait, except on approved humanitarian missions.
But the question now is: Has Washington obtained everything from the United Nations that it could hope for, and, having done so, might it become a prisoner of the very international coalition it has forged? That international coalition was based on the lowest common denominator of interests: to keep Iraq from invading Saudi Arabia and to demand its withdrawal from Kuwait. But since those objectives were agreed upon, many in Washington have come to believe they may be too modest. Many now argue that an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, while a necessary condition for peace in the gulf, is not sufficient. Unless Iraq's military infrastructure, nuclear potential and chemical weapons plants are destroyed, the reasoning goes, President Hussein will still be able to intimidate his neighbors. For now, though, the ambitious objective of flattening Iraq appears to be very much outside the scope of the fragile international consensus.
And fragile that consensus is. An old saying in the Middle East -that all roads lead to the bazaar - comes to mind when one considers the many different interests that countries such as Syria, Turkey, Egypt and the Soviet Union have in this crisis. While the United States has sent troops from afar, infusing this situation with its traditional moralism in foreign policy, many of its partners see the confrontation as just business.
Consider Syria. The Government of President Hafez al-Assad, which in 1982 killed an estimated 20,000 of its own citizens to quell an uprising in Hama, could give even Saddam Hussein a lesson in brutality. Itamar Rabinovich, an Israeli authority on Damascus, said that for Syria the crisis ''is nothing less than manna from heaven.'' To begin with, Mr. Assad and President Hussein have been trying to kill each other for 15 years. Now Mr. Assad has a chance to finish off his Iraqi rival, and with American approval. More important, Syria, which was suffering from severe recession and inflation, can expect between $1 billion and $2 billion from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait for sending troops to the gulf. And at a time when Syria had been isolated - particularly by Washington - for its reported involvement in the bombing of a Pan Am flight over Scotland in 1988, President Assad found himself taking two friendly phone calls in a week from President Bush, inviting him to be a comrade in arms.
The end of the cold war raised questions in the West about Turkey's strategic value. The gulf crisis has let Turkey show NATO it still has a strategic role to play, and has let it show the European Community that it can provide a political and economic land bridge to the Middle East. Meanwhile, the Turks have been well compensated by Japan, Germany, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait for shutting Iraq's pipeline in their country.
Egypt too is getting full payment for its losses, as well as an opportunity to get the West to help it triumph over its most serious competitor for Arab leadership - Iraq. The Arab League's headquarters have been returned to Cairo from Tunis and Egypt is even being invited to reassert itself in the Persian Gulf.
The gulf has been the traditional area for Egypt to project its power eastward, and for that reason the Saudis have always wanted to keep the Egyptians at arm's length. The Saudis well remember that the Egyptian rulers Mohammed Ali, in the 19th century, and Gamal Abdel Nasser, in the 1960's, made power plays for domination in the Arabian Peninsula. Never mind. The Egyptians now find that their military presence is being sought, and they can expect that when this crisis is over their surplus labor will be welcome in the gulf region as never before.
Moscow is also by no means innocent of hidden agendas. No doubt its cooperation with Washington has been the keystone in assembling the broad consensus. But it is clear that Soviet officials, while they want the United States Congress to give them full credit for being cooperative in the gulf, do not want full exposure there if things go bad. They have committed no troops, no ships and no money to the international endeavor. As one Administration official mused, ''The Soviets are perfectly positioned to share in the credit if things go well or hop off the train if the war option turns messy.'' The Russians may have grown weak, but they have not grown stupid.
Given this cocktail of motives and interests, the coalition against Iraq is by nature a fragile one that limits Washington's room for maneuver. This is partly because the consensus is based on achieving only the modest objective of forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait; it could easily collapse if pressed to do more than that. The coalition is also confining because, as anyone who has raised money will attest, the minute you accept money or a political endorsement you have to take the donor's opinions into account. America may have sent planes, tanks and marines to the gulf, but others have provided the funds or political cover for their use, which means they cannot be used at will.
Some might argue that this is precisely the meaning of, and a small price for, real collective security as envisioned by the United Nations' founders. George Bush, as a former United Nations delegate, clearly identifies with the organization's aspirations to collective security and he clearly relishes the role of managing partner of this global coalition.
But there is a tension between this role and America's role as superpower, and Washington still has not come to grips with it. While it wants the legitimacy and authority that come from being the managing partner of a noble international consensus, it also wants the freedom of action to pursue its global interests, even if that should lead to destroying Iraq's military potential.
That tension was evident last week when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had to fire the Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Michael J. Dugan, for openly speculating about bombing Baghdad. Such bellicosity may come naturally to the commander of the most powerful air force on earth, who is accustomed to planning to pursue his nation's global interests with whatever force is necessary. But expressing it publicly is something else - and was especially embarrassing for the President in this case because of the concerns about preserving an international consensus with still relatively limited objectives.

PUB-DATE: September 23, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 623 words

HEADLINE: No End of Lessons on Iraq

 BODY:
Two enormous miscalculations lie at the root of the Persian Gulf crisis. The most glaring was Saddam Hussein's rash assumption that the world would do little or nothing if Iraq devoured Kuwait. But his dirty deed owed something to the world's limp response to Iraq's previous use of poison gas, its grim human rights record and its voracious appetite for mass-killing weaponry. 
Rarely has a tyranny so amply advertised its malign intentions. Yet on the very eve of Iraq's conquest of Kuwait, State Department officials were pleading with Congress not to impose economic sanctions against Baghdad. A rising chorus in Congress now faults the Administration for its past blunders. But Washington was not alone. Something went fundamentally askew in many capitals, and it is worth asking why.
The first and most understandable explanation is Western and Arab fear of Iran. When Iraq invaded Iran in 1980, Saddam Hussein seemed a lesser threat than fanatic Islamic revolutionaries. Iraq's aggression went uncondemned by the U.N. Security Council. And when Iranian troops thrust into Iraqi territory, much of the world tilted toward Baghdad.
Weapons flowed to Iraq from France and the Soviet bloc. In 1982, the State Department removed Iraq from its list of countries supporting terrorism. There was no hard evidence that Iraq had changed its pro-terrorist policies. But Washington's action opened the way for $300 million in U.S.-guaranteed loans to purchase wheat and rice. In 1984, the U.S. resumed diplomatic relations with Baghdad, and began providing satellite intelligence to Saddam Hussein's generals.
The collaboration with Iraq survived the Iran-contra scandal. It persisted despite Iraq's 1987 rocket attack on the U.S.S. Stark, killing 37 of the crew. And it fostered a protectiveness about Iraq's transgressions. When Saddam Hussein used chemical weapons against Iran and later against his own Kurdish minority, the State Department voiced its disapproval - but brought no complaint to the United Nations. Nor did any other country.
In August 1988, the gulf war ended in a cease-fire. Yet the tilt to Iraq persisted. Baghdad had become the American farmer's best customer for rice, the eighth-largest buyer of wheat and second-biggest user of U.S. commodity credit guarantees. Burgeoning trade helps explain why the U.S. muted its protests when Saddam Hussein threatened to gas Israel, and even apologized for a Voice of America broadcast on the evils of police states.
Not all the blame falls on middle-level officials, whose job it is to cultivate better relations with difficult regimes. Nor is it seemly for Jeane Kirkpatrick to ascribe self-deception to a State Department weakness for Arab strongmen. The former United Nations envoy was herself a warm advocate of Argentina's strongmen prior to and during the Falklands war.
Responsibility for fixing the tone of U.S. relations with Iraq belongs at the top, with the President and his Secretary of State. Both erred in giving Saddam Hussein the benefit of doubt, and in believing that American leverage might restrain this tiger.
They have made amends, but it remains a shortcoming in this country's political culture that when blunders occur, nobody and everybody is responsible. By contrast, when Argentina invaded the Falklands, exposing serious miscalculations in British diplomacy, the Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, felt it a matter of honor to resign.
Different rules apply inside the beltway. But while no resignations are in order, the Bush Administration can still atone for its blunders by heeding the central lesson. There's no more dangerous game for a democracy than to wink at avowed and cherished principles in currying a tyrant's favor.

HEADLINE: What Britain Sowed, Iraq and U.S. Now Reap

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''The Rules of the Game: Inertia and Force'' (Week in Review, Sept. 2), a geographic-historical graphic on the Arab world, you describe Iraq as ''awarded to Britain'' under a League of Nations mandate after World War I. It was the British who fashioned Iraq out of Basra, Baghdad and Mosul, three vilayets, or provinces of the Ottoman Empire. And what a poor design it turned out to be.
Sir Arnold Wilson, acting civil commissioner in Mesopotamia in 1917, summarized the British position: ''the idea of Iraq as an independent nation had scarcely taken shape, for the country lacked homogeneity, whether geographical, economic or racial . . . it was scarcely to be hoped that the vilayets of Basra and Baghdad could maintain their existence as an autonomous state without the revenue it was hoped might eventually be derived from the economic resources of the Mosul vilayet.'' 
The ''economic resources'' of Mosul were vast petroleum deposits in the region of Kirkuk. Unlike Basra and Baghdad, which were predominantly Arab provinces, Mosul was in Kurdish territory, as maps drawn by the Royal Geographic Society in 1910 clearly indicate. According to the Iraqi census of 1922-24, the population of the Mosul vilayet consisted of 494,007 Kurds and 166,941 Arabs. But fully anticipating control over the oil reserves under a League of Nations mandate, the British pressed for incorporation of the predominantly Kurdish province into what was to become a state dominated by Arabs. The British Government even imported a Hashemite sheik from the Arabian Peninsula to become king of the new Iraq.
Thus, the British set the stage for what was to become a chronic cycle of Kurdish uprisings and Arab repression. In the same way the British engineered the creation of Kuwait when it was discovered that beneath the sands at the tip of the province of Basra there lay a wealth of oil. Seen in this light, Saddam Hussein's annexation of Kuwait is a vastly inferior version of an earlier British model.
Now with Britain running close behind, the United States steps into the picture bringing to bear its full force of arms to keep an Arab despot from executing his own crude plot to control the oil in the region he still calls Basra. A centerpiece of the strategy of Britain and the United States is an embargo on food and medical supplies to the Iraqi people - although if Iraq is the dictatorship we all know it to be, the people of Iraq, Arabs and Kurds alike, are all its victims. What price oil, in whose name precious distinctions between democracies and dictatorships are continually eroded?
 
VERA BEAUDIN SAEEDPOUR
Brooklyn, Sept. 5, 1990
 
The writer is director of The Kurdish Program, Cultural Survival.

HEADLINE: In the Gulf, the Danger of a Diplomatic Solution . . .;
. . . And the Horrors of a Desert War

BYLINE: By James Webb; James Webb was Assistant Secretary of Defense and Secretary of the Navy in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
President Bush has not only embarked on his own voyage into the Persian Gulf, that Bermuda Triangle of Presidencies. Unlike his two immediate predecessors, he has dragged more than a hundred thousand of our troops with him. And as the President struggles at home, our troops have been learning to cope with a sun that can melt electrical wiring, sand so fine that few filters can keep it out of gear boxes and a growing ennui that seeps through even the most careful monitoring of our press corps.
The debate over our role in the Persian Gulf crisis has focused on national, rather than specific military goals. The fundamental questions, upon which all others inevitably rest, have not been addressed. Why did we send such a huge contingent of ground troops in the first place? And under what conditions are we going to use them or bring them home? 
Answers are not forthcoming. Military officials intimate that the question would expose tactical options. Administration officials talk in vague terms: Defense Secretary Cheney is telling us to prepare for a commitment that may take years. Others have been quoted as saying we may be there for a decade. At the same time we are being reassured, amidst many loud calls to initiate a war with Iraq, that the U.S. military commitment is wholly defensive.
As one who opposed the Reagan Administration's overt tilt toward Iraq which caused the Persian Gulf problems in 1987 and 1988, I have no desire to give consolation to Saddam Hussein now that he is getting the attention he deserves. But if our experience since World War II tells us anything, it is that justifiable national goals are too frequently lost through unfocused and ineffective military policy. And the strongest likelihood is that our ground buildup in Saudi Arabia is the product not of conscious strategy, but of an initial overreaction that compounds itself with the arrival of every C-5 transport.
The Kuwaiti dilemma is not new. This is the third time since 1961 that Iraq has asserted, militarily, its claim to Kuwaiti territory. As such, positioning U.S. aviation units into Saudi Arabia with ground forces to defend them was appropriate as a short-term guarantee of Saudi sovereignty. But the huge buildup of forces began after it became clear that Iraq had no military designs on Saudi Arabia. And coupled with escalating rhetoric, it has created an intractable siege, with the survival of President Bush, as well as Saddam Hussein, hanging in the balance.
The U.S., whose interests in the region are far less than Kuwait's, Saudi Arabia's, Israel's, Europe's and Japan's, is carrying the overwhelming burden. True, others are involved in small scale - the Egyptians, who stand to benefit to the tune of at least $7 billion in forgiven debts, the Syrians, traditional enemies of Iraq, who are sending a few thousand soldiers, other Arab nations whose royal families are also threatened, European and other allies who are throwing in a ship or two here, and a military unit there. We appear to have traded the promise of greater economic help to the Soviets for Mikhail Gorbachev's rather noncommital statement of support.
And now we are out on the international hustings, asking for financial contributions for our effort. Mr. Bush hastens to assure us that this does not make our soldiers mercenaries, but anyone with a relative or loved one in Saudi Arabia will quickly argue that this is not a fair trade.
And what is the impact, strategically, of the introduction of all these ground forces? In grand sum, it can only be judged as negative.
Those who have called for massive, pre-emptive air strikes against Iraq must now contemplate the detriment of tens of thousands of American soldiers within range of Iraqi chemical weapons, as well as possible terrorist attacks from Iraq and now Iran.
Those who worry about the possibility of crisis in other parts of the world must recognize that a large percentage of American maneuver forces - including as much as half of the Marine Corps - are tied down in a waiting game in the desert.
Those who believe we should use these forces offensively should realize that this would galvanize the Arab world, invite chemical retaliation and an expansion of the hostilities, produce great numbers of casualties and encourage worldwide terrorism - in short, open up a Pandora's box. This is not to say that our soldiers and marines would not fight well. The Iraqi army is not a very good army; it is also war-weary. But it demonstrated against Iran the time-honored maxim that the armies of totalitarian nations are capable of absorbing huge losses - recall the 3.7 million German soldiers who died in World War II, and the million Communist soldiers who died in the Vietnam war.
The President should be aware that, while most Americans are laboring very hard to support him, a mood of cynicism is just beneath their veneer of respect. Many are claiming that the buildup is little more than a ''Pentagon budget drill,'' designed to preclude cutbacks of an Army searching for a mission as bases in NATO begin to disappear.
Others wonder about the predominance of Texans in the Administration, and the dual benefit that higher oil prices will bring to the Southwest: a more robust economy and the concomitant salvation of many S.& L.'s. Others, myself included, worry greatly about a military commitment that has taken on a momentum of its own - or perhaps a hidden strategy.
General Colin Powell is said to have advised the President that the U.S. should take this sort of military action or it would no longer be a superpower. This calls to mind the Suez Crisis of 1956, after Egyptian leader Nasser nationalized the Suez Canal. The British were reeling from a budget affected by the military costs of maintaining the Empire. The Suez Canal was vital for transporting oil. And Anthony Eden, the British Prime Minister who had great antipathy toward Nasser for his anti-British rhetoric, wanted him ''destroyed.''
Britain went forward, largely to preserve its place at the table of the great powers, drawing in the French and the Israelis. Their attack sputtered in the desert. The U.S., their banker, threatened to withhold support for the British pound if they did not cease their invasion. The Soviets moved into Hungary. And sure enough, when the dust settled, Britain was no longer a great power.
Too much is at risk, and too many questions remain for this buildup to continue without the Administration clarifying its direction. And if offensive action is in the cards, it should be taken only after the President receives a declaration of war from the Congress.

HEADLINE: Soothing Sand And Adobe Of Mazatlan

BYLINE: By William Brand; William Brand is a reporter and columnist for The Oakland Tribune.

 BODY:
From the air Mazatlan is an urban sprawl on the edge of a wide, green, coastal plain - dotted by isolated hills and bordered by the sea. Far to the east, the Sierra Madre range disappears into an almost constant cloud bank. To really get the feel of the place, though, come on the fast, overnight train from Nogales on the Arizona border. An hour or so before arrival in Mazatlan the train breaks out of a jungle of palms and banana trees onto a low cliff overlooking the sun-soaked Pacific. The tracks parallel the shore along miles of empty beaches, then the first big hotels flash past, and the train roars into town.
The weathered, seldom washed train station is a wild mixture of vendors selling huge, freshly squeezed glasses of orange juice, cold, spicy shrimp, their eyes and feelers still attached, and tamales, stuffed with grilled fish.
The air feels languid and humid after the overnight trip through the Sonoran Desert. Temperatures range into the 80's and 90's in summer, but the heat is tempered by the ocean breeze. After the rainy season begins in July, relative humidity rises sharply to as much as 85 percent. The fall is hurricane season. Winter and spring are dry with high temperatures in the 70's and 80's. 
Mazatlan, with a population of 380,000, has more than 10 miles of white sand beaches. They are safe and usually uncrowded, even though this is a busy port. There's a beach for every taste and time of day - from Olas Altas on the south, where crosscurrents smash together creating thundering waves favored by surfers around dawn, to lonely, shell-strewn Cerritos on the north - the perfect place to wander until sunset. And unlike Acapulco and Puerto Vallarta, most of Mazatlan's major beaches are untainted by pollution.
When one tires of surf and sand, there's a city to explore, including a charming historic section. Founded as a lookout post by Spanish soldiers in 1531, Mazatlan received its first visitors in modern times about 50 years ago. They came for some of the best deep-sea fishing in the world; these days, 6,000 marlin, sail and other billfish are caught here in an average year. Those early fishermen were captivated by the city's physical setting, the narrow streets and vistas of the old quarter.
By the 1940's, visitors were flooding the city. American film stars like John Wayne and Robert Mitchum were regulars: Mr. Wayne for the fishing, the food and the parties, Mr. Mitchum for lazy days on empty beaches and the parties, said John George, the American owner of Playa Mazatlan, a large hotel complex, and a friend of both men.
Today, Mazatlan draws a half-million tourists a year. At Carnaval and five weeks later during Easter week, the city is especially crowded. Hotel and dinner reservations are impossible. The beaches are wall-to-wall bodies. But the rest of the year, there's plenty of room and just enough to do to soothe even the most stressed-out visitor.
High on the list of activities is choosing a beach. Olas Altas, the southernmost and oldest tourist beach, is on a deep cove. It's a beach for sunning and surfing, not swimming. Crosscurrents cause waves to crash into waves, occasionally making swimming dangerous.
Heading north along the seaside promenade, in the shadow of Icebox Hill, Boulevard Olas Altas becomes Paseo Claussen. Fishermen and young men who dive for oysters beach their boats here. It's a place to buy fish at dawn, not to swim.
A mile and a half north the street widens, becomes Avenida del Mar and the hotels stretch to the horizon along a shallow bay three miles wide. Hotels here tend to be moderately priced. The beach is Playa Norte. The first portion of the beach, near the Fisherman's Monument at Avenida Gutierrez Najera, has fine, white sand and gentle surf, but a sewer outlet mars the water. A few blocks farther north, the sweep of the tide keeps pollution away. Waves often strike Playa Norte with full force, but the beach drops away slowly, allowing one to wade some distance before reaching deep water.
Playa Norte ends at a rocky promontory. Avenida del Mar narrows and becomes Avenida Cameron Sabalo. This is the Zona Dorada (Golden Zone), a crowded nest of high-rise hotels, glittering shops and informal restaurants. The two-mile-long, wide, curving stretch of beach has several names, beginning with Playa Cameron, then Gaviotas and finally Sabalo, which is the best place to swim, people watch and be seen. The surf is fairly gentle because three small, offshore islands blunt the force of the waves. Most of the best hotels are here, including El Cid, Camino Real, Inn at Mazatlan and Playa Mazatlan. There are parachute rides, diversions like sailboard rentals and a profusion of vendors selling items from all over the country: folk-art puppets, silver jewelry, brightly colored blankets.
The final three miles of beach - known as Cerritos - begin just over a lagoon from the Camino Real Hotel. Except for an occasional surfer, Cerritos is empty and is a good place to check for shells at low tide. There are several restaurants with tables under umbrella-like, thatched palapas at the northernmost end. But the food is unexceptional. Better to order an iced green coconut, drink the milk with a straw, then spoon out the soft, pulpy meat. Cerritos is accessible by cab or bus; look for ''Cerritos'' written on the windshield. You can also ride a pulmonia, a peppy little open-air jeep that costs less than a cab.
Mazatlan comes from a word meaning ''place of the deer'' in Nahuatl, the language of the area's pre-Columbian inhabitants. The city was founded by Spanish soldiers led by Nuno de Guzman, the most ruthless of the conquistadors. It became an important port in the 19th century as gold and silver flowed from mines in the mountains and agriculture developed nearby. Mazatlan was blockaded by American ships in 1847 during the Mexican War, known here as the American Invasion. It was blockaded again in 1864 during the Civil War by French ships, intent on creating a monarchy in Mexico for Maximilian.
Mazatlan has one slight claim to international fame: the city's historians say the second-ever aerial bombardment occurred here in 1914 during the Mexican revolution. (The first was in Tripoli.) According to Gilbert Limon, who heads the Mexican National Tourism office in Mazatlan, supporters of the insurgent Alvaro Obregon built a crude black powder bomb, took it aloft in a single-engine biplane. They intended to drop it on forces loyal to the despotic Mexican President Victoriano Huerta. ''The problem was the pilot became a little airsick and dropped it in the wrong place - on Icebox Hill,'' Mr. Limon said. ''It exploded, killing two people and wounding several others.'' Mazatlan today is much more than a beach. The historic section has maze-like streets, where the adobe walls of many houses date back 200 years. A walk through the area, which is east of Olas Altas Beach, can include a peek inside the former opera house, built in 1860, now Teatro Angela Peralta, named for the turn-of-the-century Mexican diva who died in Mazatlan. Long a ruin, it is being painstakingly restored. Massive doors, set between stone columns, lead through thick adobe walls into a marble-floored lobby with an ornate dome. The theater, on Plazuela Machado, the oldest plaza in town, is being redone as funds become available.
Cafe Pacifico at the other end of the tree-shaded block offers tapas and capuccino at outside tables.
There's a tiny regional museum in a restored colonial house three blocks down Calle Sixto Osuna. It's worth a short visit - as much to see the inside of an acient adobe building as to view the modest collection of pre-Columbian artifacts found recently around Mazatlan.
The seaside boulevard and promenade that follows the beaches to the edge of the city begins as Boulevard Olas Altas a half-block from the museum.
The city also has a small aquarium, Acuario Mazatlan, with an impressive display of live fish taken just offshore. Tanks full of pirannahs from Brazil are especially popular with children.
Shopping centers have arrived in Mazatlan, but thousands of residents still shop daily at the big, tin-roofed central market. Aisles are stuffed with an interesting mix of tropical fruits, fish, coffee beans and tourist trinkets. Out around the beaches, there are clusters of shops with fine leather goods and bright cotton designer fashions.
Choosing a place to stay is another of Mazatlan's charms. There's a wide variety, but even top hotels like El Cid Resort and the Camino Real are inexpensive by American standards, a maximum of $250 a day for a suite on the Pacific. Large, single rooms for two with an ocean view are about $170. There's plenty of ambiance at the budget end, too. The white-washed, three story La Siesta on Olas Altas is $14 a night for two - with the same dazzling ocean view.
By United States standards it's equally inexpensive to dine. Dinner for two at Casa de Tony and Senor Pepper's, two of Mazatlan's best restaurants, costs less than $45. At Cenaduria la Negra, a simple spot with elegant food, favored by the Mexican cookbook author Diana Kennedy, one person can dine well for $5. All have menus that capitalize on the fresh seafood readily available on their doorstep: at Tony's, perhaps seafood crepes and a shrimp shish kebab followed by owner Tony Valdez's Key lime pie. At Senor Pepper's, grilled spiny lobster is a specialty.
It's possible to never take a bite of seafood and eat well in Mazatlan, but it would be a mistake. Nowhere else in Mexico do cooks turn out excellent seafood dishes so consistently as they do in Mazatlan.
If a day on the beach hasn't stripped away urban cares, the sunset will usually do the trick. The appropriate drink is a margarita with or without tequila, or a brewed-in-Mazatlan Pacifico beer. The mood is magical. Waves crash into the sparking curve of beach as the afternoon wanes. Then, in an instant, it is sunset, lush and warm and tropical. The palms become fading silhouettes; the sun flows into the Pacific, and the sky flames molten red.
Some visitors collapse after sunset, others pursue the city's restaurants, and the more hardy dance until dawn at discos like Valentino's at Punto Sabalo and El Caracol at El Cid. But something almost every visitor does at least once is visit Senor Frog's on Avenida del Mar. The founders, Chuey Juarez and Carlos Anderson, now have copies in cities around the world, but there's no place like Senor Frog's: a crazy place with zany, irreverent waiters, license plates on the walls, loud music, huge margaritas, beer served in buckets of ice, tourists dancing on tables. The food is quite good, especially the ribs.
Those party-happy fishermen of 50 years ago would be amazed at how the city has grown, but they'd be at home at Frog's, content with the knowledge that Mazatlan's reputation as a place for a good time continues to hold true.
 
PLOTTING A TRIP TO MAZATLAN ON THE PACIFIC
 
Getting There
Direct flights are offered from many United States cities on Mexicana, Alaska, Delta and Aeromexico. A cab from the airport is about $10.
The train ($35 for special first class) leaves Nogales daily at 3:30 P.M. and arrives at 9 A.M. the next morning. More information from Ferrocarriles del Pacifico, 10 Avenida Carrera Internacional, Nogales, Sonora, Mexico; telephone from the United States: 011-52-631-2-00-24.
A ferry leaves from La Paz in Baja California Sur at 5 P.M. daily and arrives in Mazatlan the next morning; a cabin for two: $76. Details from Semadur, 1465 Guillermo Prieto, La Paz, Baja California Sur, Mexico; 011-52-682-5-38-33.
 
What to See
Acuario Mazatlan, 111 Avenida de los Deportes (telephone, called locally: 1-78-15), $2.25, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily.
A number of companies offer half- day and all-day fishing trips. They furnish equipment and refreshments; patrons bring box lunches from their hotels. A long-established firm is Bill Heimpel's Star Fleet (Flota Estrella), 10 Jacarand, Loma Linda; 2-26-65; $130 for a daylong trip.
Museo Regional de Mazatlan, 76 Sixto Osuna; 5-25-02. Open weekday mornings and afternoons; free.
Teatro Angela Peralta opera house, Sixto Osuna and Carnaval, no phone, open daylight hours; free. Agencies in large hotels book various tours. A two-and-a-half-hour city tour is $10. A harbor cruise is $9. A six-hour daytrip to Copala, a restored gold-mining town in the mountains, and to Concordia, a crafts village, is $30.
 
Where to Stay
El Cid Resort offers deluxe accommodations in two towers with wrap-around, beachside swimming pools (Avenida Camaron Sabalo, Post Office Box 813, telephone: 3-33-33; room for two, $85).
Smaller, but in the same class, is the Camino Real (Punta del Sabalo, Post Office Box 538, telephone: 3-11-11; $100) Hotel Playa Mazatlan, in the middle of the Zona Dorada (Golden Zone) tourist area, is well managed (202 Rodolfo T. Loaiza, Post Office Box 207, telephone: 3-44-44; $40).
For economy, Hotel la Siesta (11 Olas Altas; telephone: 1-26-40; $14) has a bougainvillea-filled interior courtyard, but the hotel can be noisy. Insist on an oceanfront room, which is the same price as other rooms.
 
Where to Eat
Casa de Tony (111 Mariano Escobedo; telephone: 5-12-62). Seafood in an elegantly restored 19th-century house; $45 for two with wine or beer, tax and tip. Lunch 1 to 4 P.M., dinner 6 to 11 P.M.
Senor Pepper's (across Camino Sabalo from the Camino Real; telephone: 4-01-01) specializes in lobster and shrimp dishes; $60 for two. Open from 6 P.M. to 10 P.M. seven days a week.
Cenaduria la Negra (2215 Belisario Dominguez; telephone: 2-37-76) offers some of the best regional food. Chicken, marianated in a mustard-lime sauce and grilled to order, is $8. Open from 6 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays.
Don't be put off by the touristy atmosphere of the Zona Dorada. There's lots of good food available in an informal setting. At the Shrimp Factory, a lively spot at the corner of Avenida de las Garzas at Loaiza, a pound of shrimp with beer is $10. Two doors away on De las Garzas, Pepe Toro specializes in grilled carne asada; $5. A taco plate is $4.
 
What to Buy
The best stores are in the Zona Dorada. Designer's Bazaar (7 Loaiza; 3-60-39) has cotton clothing. The Indio Shop nearby has quality Mexican silver. Another branch is in town at 206 Angel Flores; 1-37-53. For the unusual, there's Sea Shell City, also on Loaiza; 3-13-01.
Don't miss Mazatlan Arts and Crafts (417 Loaiza; 3-50-22), a two-story complex with crafts from all over Mexico.
 
Information
Mexican National Tourist Office, 1300 Olas Altas, second floor; o11-52-678-5-12-22. W. B.

HEADLINE: Ireland for, Yes, the Food

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill; Molly O'Neill, a reporter on the Living-Style staff of The New York Times, writes frequently about food.

 BODY:
The people of Ireland regard the changes on the national table with the kind of self-satisfied wonder normally reserved for rainbows.
''We knew it was here all along,'' say the fishermen who trawl the pristine northerly Atlantic and the farmers who till the sloping countryside. Still, they are awed by the finesse that is nudging bland stews off the country's table. Ireland's natural larder has traditionally been turned out with a stubborn, peasant touch. But recently, as an increasing number of Irish chefs hone their skills in France, the country's cooking has moved toward a distinct cuisine.
''In Ireland, cooking was always a drudgery of making do with very little,'' said Patrick Foyle, who along with his sister Anne owns Rosleague Manor in Connemara. ''Only in the past few years with the stronger economy have Irish people had the time and money to appreciate the pleasure of cooking and eating well.'' Today, the restaurants that dot the countryside are beginning to garner cautious recommendations from guide books like Michelin and awards from Egon Ronay and to attract an audience that often brings a tradition of fine dining along with fat wallets. 
The dining revolution isn't over in Ireland. On the continuum that stretches from necessity to indulgence, Irish cooking is somewhere in the middle. To American tastes, fish and meat are frequently overcooked. Brine-cured smoked salmon seems to have set the national standard for salt. Cream, butter and roux are deployed with wholesale abandon. Yet the cooking in Irish restaurants today has the energy and altruism of a changing order. When a dish misses (an average of one out of four does) the diner can usually scrape off an overreaching sauce, push aside a mismatched accompaniment and still savor stunningly high quality fish or meat.
''The French are teaching us,'' said Mr. Foyle. The new lessons play against the bedrock of British cooking, and so sauces can be gravy-heavy. They can also soar. A perfectly whisked bearnaise does wonders for the deeply marbled salmon, satin blankets of saffron cream are perfect for the country's sweet thumb-sized mussels, the saltmarsh-grazed lamb couldn't be better roasted with garlic and thyme. Not long ago potatoes were simply boiled in their own wrinkled jackets. Today they are wafered into stylish gallettes and simmered fancifully en casserole.
After a recent 14-day, 26-restaurant tour of Ireland, from Connemara to Dublin, I can confirm the rumors: It's possible to eat well in the country today. It takes insight, patience with the foibles of a cuisine in the midst of change and a willingness to pay Manhattan prices for meals. Throughout the country, wine lists are heavy on red wine - specifically, clarets - and generally 25 percent more expensive than their American counterparts. But there's always a choice of good beer and stout. Service in the restaurants I visited was generally affable and attentive, but not polished.
By beginning in Connemara, the wind-torn jut of land between Lough Corrib and the Atlantic, the traveler encounters early Ireland, a land of savage beauty. Off-shore, black sole, brill, turbot, ray and lobster can all be taken. In brackish waters, crayfish are dense as bees around a hive. Trout and salmon run like unbroken silver ribbons in the streams. But many days are a relentless two-step of rain and fog, leaving boats docked and fish uncaught. Except for root vegetables and cabbage, vegetables are precious.
There is a folk saying in Connemara that every day has four seasons. The cooking, in response, is spontaneous and simple. The dining room at Rosleague Manor epitomizes the spirit of the region.
Flanked by a manicured lawn and gardens, Rosleague presides over mountains that roll from green into blue-green to gray toward Ballinakill Bay. Its ballroom-sized dining room is the sort of place where a sporting gentleman would preside: pumpkin-hued walls hung with landscapes, pictures of the hunt and antique plates that suggest generations in a rambling family home full of dried flowers and mismatched chintz.
On a warm, languid night, there is frothy iced cucumber and potato soup, or a mound of sweet crabmeat with lemony mayonnaise. Fillet of flounder might be poached, topped with tender lobster, glossed with a light vermouth cream sauce. On a cool, misty evening, the crab might be devilled and baked, the soup a pungent puree of lovage and potato, the lamb roasted with garlic, the ray browned in butter. Salads are a tumble of wild watercress, sorrel and lettuces from the Foyle's seven-acre farm. And the brown bread - the moist peasant-style whole-grain loaf leavened with soda and sour milk that is as dear to the Irish as the baguette is to the French - is dense and honest.
Patrick Foyle's fare is not culinary epiphany; it is simple food cooked in harmony with each day. And the same accord prevails in simpler restaurants of the area.
In Roundstone, a tiny fishing village overlooking Betragh Bay in Connemara, Beola is a tiny, subdued, peach-hued place, as close-packed as Grandma's living room set up for a dinner party. With garnishes whittled from cucumbers and radishes, all the dishes have an arty conceit. But the simpler ones - mussels baked under garlicky breadcrumbs, salmon with a slick of hollandaise and brill, lightly dusted with flour, pan-fried and served with tartar sauce - make a wonderful lunch or informal dinner.
Down the street at O'Dowd's, simplicity plays in a more traditional Irish key. The close-packed 14-seat dining room adjacent to the bar is an ageless Irish pub with its heavy wood tables and ambient aroma of stout and fried fish. And the heady, potato-thick chowder, pan-fried flounder, chips and steamed lobster are worth traveling for, at least for lunch at bargain prices. O'Dowd's is also the perfect setting in which to sample an Irish classic: oysters chased with a slug of Guinness. Oysters from these northerly waters have deeper, frilled shells and a briny, faintly copper taste that stands up to the deeply malty, bitter taste of the stout.
The breezes of early 20th-century British graciousness still waft near the top of Cashel Bay in Connemara where Cashel House Hotel serves Gallicized British fare - smoked salmon quiche and marinated mussels, salmon with hollandaise and herb-roasted chicken - in a cozy domain of chintz and leather, library tables and rattan. Cashel House is said to have been the favorite spot in Ireland of President Charles de Gaulle. That says a lot about how far Irish cooking has come in the last several decades: Cashel House is cozy, but my lunch was of the stodgy French school, circa 1950.
The premonitory winds of a more cosmopolitan cuisine whirl at the southern edge of the Connemara Peninsula at the Drimcong House, eight miles north of Galway City. Opened in 1984 by Gerry and Marie Calvin, the restaurant is two comfortable, though not particularly stylish, dining rooms on the first floor of an old manor house where traditional Irish dishes are carefully tempered with French technique and the occasional Far-Eastern touch. Mr. Calvin is a guru of the new Irish cooking, and his cerebral fare is sometimes stunning, sometimes not.
The menu reaches toward France with sweet lobster in old-fashioned Nantua sauce, a creamy, rosemary-scented sweetbread ragout and pan-fried duck and duck confit in a cassis-sweetened glaze. The kitchen veers toward Italy with slightly overcooked fettuccine drenched in a rich, satiny wild mushroom sauce. There is a Chinese pork and vegetable starter. Goat cheese baked in an overpowering armor of poppy and sesame seeds seemed like a refugee from California.
The best dishes stuck close to home: a starter of pan-fried slices of drisheen, the traditional blood pudding of County Cork, made with pork blood and oatmeal with a meaty, whisky-sweetened glaze and a warm salad of French lentils. The saltmarsh-grazed lamb - primarily raised to be exported to France - is roasted with shallots that add a honeylike sweetness to the herbacious meat. Pan-fried pigeon has a meaty, lovage-infused glaze. Trout is served with cider sauce and a sorrel mousse.
Driving south from Connemara, the coast smooths. Craggy meadow and mountain grass give way to rolling green hills, streams that rush with the passion of a just-melted glacier give way to placid kettle ponds. County Kerry is lush and civilized, its cooking tailored, cautiously stylish.
No one conjures the genre better than Matthew Darcy at Park Hotel in Kenmare on the hinge of the Ring of Kerry. He rolls pinwheels of fresh salmon and sole around threads of spinach and poaches them with a traditional dill cream sauce. Mussels are steamed in butter along with dainty julienned carrots and leeks. A leek and celery root soup is enriched with shavings of fresh local Stilton. Lamb is wrapped around an oyster and walnut stuffing, quail is stuffed with morels and served with a beetroot tartlette. Some of Mr. Darcy's combinations are daring; his cooking is some of the most confident and artful I tasted in Ireland.
His flawless technique and understated flavors are in elegant accord with the plush hotel dining room with its sparkling crystal chandeliers, silk-padded Louis XIV armchairs and exceptional service. Gothic silver candelabra flicker on the room's museum-quality antique sideboards and the windows open to a panorama of lake and hills.
Adjacent to the Park Hotel, the Lime Tree is a stone carriage house with a wood-beamed ceiling and homey gingham tablecloths. The chef and owner, Maura Foley, is credited with being among the first to apply modern French cooking techniques in her Irish kitchen. Dishes such as the timbale of smoked salmon, pan-fried salmon with sorrel sauce and the lightly breaded scallops with garlic butter, showcase her success. Others, like the pastry filled with creamed mussels and a mousseline of garlic and scallops baked under phyllo dough, are not as successful. Swimming in thick, creamy sauces, many dishes at the Lime Tree are too heavy for my taste.
Day trippers who navigate the curving drive between mountain and sea around the Ring of Kerry might just as well continue north to Dingle, a picturesque fishing hamlet where Doyle's Seafood Bar has garnered quite a reputation. With its flagstone floor and polished pine tables, the place is as cozy as a picture postcard and wildly popular with tourists. Mussels are dry in their cream sauce, squid lost in a tempuralike batter, but the smoked mackerel pate is a dream, lobster is perfectly steamed in sea water, trout delicious in a mushroom sauce.
Radiating east from Kerry, in Counties Cork, Tipperary, Wexford and Kilkenny, is the heart of Ireland's revitalized cheese industry. Fine restaurants all offer a selection, but most of the the well-wrought cheeses are best close to home. The premier cheese is Milleens, buttery, Munster-style. Cais Cleire Goats cheese is a tart, pleasantly chalky chevre, Cashel Blue a strong, buttery version of blue cheese. Two wonderful Camembert-style cheeses are the Cooleeney camembert and St. Killian. Mitchelstown Mature Cheddar is rich and sharp.
Some say this rich farmland in County Cork that rolls up from the southerly coast explains the excellent restaurants in the area. Others say it was Myrtle Allen. Twenty-six years ago at Ballymaloe, near Midleton in County Cork, the 18th-century manor house on the 350-acre farm that her husband owned and worked, Mrs. Allen began serving dinner.
''Irish people didn't go out to eat back then, no one would pay for food,'' she said. ''But mine was a wife's hobby, I didn't have to make much money, so I took chances.'' Back then, she took chances by serving several French dishes each night. Today, her 40-seat dining room is packed, the cooking school that she founded is always full and her homey cooking is that of an inspired grandmother with a generous heart and a self-taught French touch.
Her fresh pea and zucchini soup with mint, or the tart of local cheese and garden ratatouille pull the fashionable from Hollywood, New York and Paris as well as American and European families. Fish is remarkably fresh, whether it is turbot baked with lemon balm or black sole drizzled with watercress butter. The local Cloyne beef is well-marbled and perfectly aged. Duck and chicken have the full flavor and chew of barnyard birds.
Ballymaloe is such an idyll that it is hard to stray far from the farm. But Arbutus Lodge, a sedate, plush, Victorian dining room overlooking the city of Cork, serves some ambitious French food. Tourists, executives from the neighboring crystal and whisky companies and well-heeled locals claim the heavy armchairs at the well-spaced tables with their proper starched linens in the old-fashioned dining room. Char-grilled squid was delicious drizzled with herbed oil and roasted eggplant, the oysters were nicely matched with a tarragon-flecked, creamy cucumber sauce. Slivers of duck liver were irresistible astride waxy potatoes. Lobster was overcooked with its chive butter, and so was the brill with a pistachio sauce, but pigeon with garlic and ginger was a winner; lamb roasted with rosemary and thyme couldn't have been better.
Mrs. Allen jokes that, traditionally, the greatest distinction between cooking of the various regions is whether to add carrots to stew. North of Tipperary, she says, the answer is ''no''; south ''yes.'' Today, there are subtle differences in regional cooking.
Farther north, at the base of the rock of Cashel, the French cooking is homier at Chez Hans. In a thatched-roofed, Gothic church, the restaurant offered quenelles of turbot and rock oysters, tender chunks of lobster in a lemony butter sauce and a zuchinni mint soup that all elicited hosannas. Veal was overcooked and overpowered by its tarragon cream sauce, but the roast lamb with a port-sweetened glaze was delicious.
Early Ireland and the spontaneity of its cooking are alive in Connemara. The dairy industry (and tourism) whisper in the refined cooking of Kerry. The food of Cork celebrates both the county's bounty and the different cultures that have passed through it. In Dublin, the strong economy and a burgeoning fascination with dining out are bringing urbane fare to the table. As in the rest of the country, most dishes still reflect Ireland's past; brown bread is always on the table; smoked salmon, meaty Irish bacon and root vegetables are tucked somewhere on the menu. But the dining rooms have more style than in the countryside.
The three Dublin restaurants that everyone talks about are Le Coq Hardi, White's on the Green and Patrick Guilbaud.
Le Coq Hardi, a reclaimed Georgian town house on Pembroke Road, Dublin's Restaurant Row, is a respectable, old style French restaurant. Smoked fish is marbled with tomato, double cream and cheese and baked en cocotte, the beet root is diced in duckling broth, the bacon wrapped around a chicken breast stuffed with potatoes and mushrooms and baked in Irish whisky, the cabbage is slivered and braised and served under a brace of tender roasted quail.
White's on the Green, on the other hand, a flower-filled, white and green dining room, is polished, modern and forward-looking. Dishes such as the spiced beef with lovage and black currants, the soulful nettle soup, sea bass with braised leeks and noisettes of lamb sauteed with exotically spiced wild mushrooms turn Irish ingredients and notions into world-class dishes. Both the food and the stylish dining room have a confident sophistication fitting for a restaurant overlooking the winsome Stephen's Green.
Restaurant Patrick Guilbaud on James Place synthesizes solid French technique and Irish ingredients into state-of-the-art dishes. The airy, elegant white-walled atrium full of plants and Dublin's elite was my favorite in Ireland. I would consider making a special trip for the smoked salmon on crisp fried celeryroot cakes with horseradish cream and gamey pigeon served with a subtle almond mousse. Roast monkfish is delicious basted with honey and balsamic vinegar. Veal sweetbreads are enlivened with lemon and coriander.
And every dish cooked here seems to meld the innately generous heart of Ireland with the refined restraint of his cuisine. His combinations of flavors - lemon balm in the leek soup, chive and beetroot on the sauteed brill - celebrate the compelling, well-preserved naivete of Ireland, while introducing the cosmopolitan influences that the country has been slow to embrace.

HEADLINE: Wine;
Once Around the Bloc

BYLINE: BY Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
The wine bars in the lovely Old Town in Prague are far more notable for their beer. It doesn't matter, because Czechoslovak beer is great. But for a while, during a recent visit, it seemed as if the city's charms were not going to include anything vinous.
Then, at dinner one evening at the Inter-Continental Hotel, the waiter brought a wine list. Prague has many surprises for first-time visitors from the West and this was one of them: There were at least 30 different wines, from at least three Czechoslovak wine regions. 
Forget that all their names were in Czech or Slovak and thus totally incomprehensible to this linguistically backward traveler. Forget that the waiter was trained to push the house wine in about 10 languages. The truth was that the house wine, a riesling from Moravia, turned out to be quite good. And the prices were spectacularly low: $6 or so for the younger wines.
If Czechoslovakia, which is hardly world-renowned for its wines, can offer such a surprising assortment, imagine what we can expect in a few years from the rest of the emerging countries of Eastern Europe. The sale earlier this year of the vast collection of wines from the czars' cellars near Yalta was a hint of things to come.
In the darkest days of totalitarianism, the Soviet Union produced vast quantities of wine. Not long after the devastation of World War II, the Soviet leaders began to try to wean their people from vodka to wine by increasing the area under vines from a few hundred thousand acres to more than 3 million. Today, the Soviet Union is the second-largest producer of table wines after Spain, and the third in total wine production after Italy and France.
Not only do the Russians consume most of their own wine, they also import millions of gallons from other Eastern European countries, particularly Hungary. Hungary, in addition to what it ships off to its giant neighbor, has never stopped supplying the West with its precious Tokay and its robust Egri Bikaver (Bull's Blood). Yugoslavia, Romania, Bulgaria - they are all wine countries and have been for a thousand years. Even in beer-drinking Czechoslovakia, per capita consumption of wine is higher than it is in the United States. And if most of the wines are of the quality of the house wine at the Inter-Continental Hotel, there should be a receptive audience for them in the West.
It will never be a large audience; heaven knows, we have all the wine we need. But wine fans are always looking for something new. The secret - actually, it's no secret at all - will be to upgrade the quality. While visiting Hungarian vineyards and wineries years ago, we were struck by the interest in the most advanced techniques. The newer wines, from state-of-the-art wineries around Lake Balaton, were well made but lacked character. If wine makers in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe try to copy Western wine styles, they are going to be disappointed in the Western response.
Now that economic as well as political barriers are down, Eastern European wine-making equipment is likely to be upgraded and vineyards replanted and quality should improve considerably. For wine fans in the West, it will mean learning a new vocabulary. They will be comparing the relative merits of Murfatlar and furmint as dessert wines, and consulting their dictionaries to decipher Czechoslovak, Bulgarian, Russian and Georgian labels.
For better or worse, Czechoslovakia has been heavily influenced by Germany over the centuries. So it isn't surprising that its white wines - and the best Czechoslovak wines are white - are influenced by the German and Austrian styles. Prague is at the same latitude as the Rheingau and the grapes are even the same: Rhine riesling, traminer and sylvaner for the whites, and blauer burgunder and portugieser for the reds. In Moravia, just north of the Danube, the main grape is the Austrian veltliner. Probably the most varied wines come from Yugoslavia, which, it has been noted, has its feet in the Balkans, its head in the Alps and leans toward Italy. The best wines come from Slovenia in the north, where the vine rows march up to the border of Italy's Friuli district. Riesling, sylvaner sauvignon and traminer are the best-known grapes - all of them white. They are often identified as Lutomer wines, after Ljutomer, a wine-making center. The wines on the Yugoslav side of the border are not as good as their Italian counterparts, but then the Slovenian wines come mostly from cooperatives and the Italian wines from proud, individual producers.
Bulgaria has managed to quietly become an excellent host for the best French grapes: cabernet sauvignon, chardonnay and merlot. For most of its history, Bulgaria was dominated by Turkey and the Islamic laws prohibiting alcohol. That period came to an end barely a century ago, so Bulgaria's wine tradition is a relatively modern one. It will be fascinating, one day soon, to compare the best Bulgarian cabernets and chardonnays with those of the West.
In fact, we may see Bulgarian wines sooner rather than later. Bulgaria has always exported more than 70 percent of its wine, and the producers are happy to substitute Western-style labels for the traditional Cyrillic lettering. Less exotic, perhaps, but it's nice to have some idea of what you're drinking.
