SECTION: Section 6; Page 47, Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5041 words

HEADLINE: Shhh! Kids and Scholars at Work

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber; Bruce Weber is an editor of this magazine.

 BODY:
Margaret Hetley, the head librarian at the Hunts Point branch of the New York Public Library in the South Bronx, is having a typical afternoon. It's quiet, subdued - a couple of men in leather jackets killing time, reading magazines at a corner table; a woman in a nurse's uniform perusing the library's community service guide; a young mother with an infant in a stroller browsing in the neatly kept stacks - until about 3:30 P.M., when the local schoolkids begin filing in.
Hetley, a slight, bespectacled woman in her 40's, wearing jeans and running shoes and the weary, amused, authoritative expression of librarians everywhere, is showing off the branch's well-used collection of 10,000 titles in Spanish - including computer texts and auto-repair manuals as well as volumes of Spanish and Latin American literature and the complete works of Agatha Christie - when the hectic part of her day begins. A pre-teen interrupts: Where are the books on George Washington? Then there's a query from a baffled youngster desperate for what he thinks is a math text. ''That sounds like computers,'' Hetley says. ''You don't know? Honeychild, it's your homework.'' 
During a brief respite, Hetley takes a visitor to the reading room on the second floor, noting that the roof leaks and, along the way, pointing out on the stairway the building's ''intercom'' system - a coffee can filled with washers, suspended on a rope, that is rattled to call employees to the phone. Upstairs, she stops in front of a computer to chat with the high-school student in charge of teaching younger children how to use it. But her attention is diverted again. ''Don't run,'' she calls out, adding with a sigh: ''This is a recording.''
The scene at Hunts Point is expressive of the mundane yet indispensable social role played by the whole of the New York Public Library system, one of the nation's grand institutions, encompassing four nonlending research libraries and 82 branches spread out over the Bronx, Manhattan and Staten Island. (Brooklyn and Queens have independent library systems.) ''It is entirely a service organization,'' says Andrew Heiskell, for the last decade the chairman of the board of trustees, and its dual mandate - to acquire and to provide - is both the library's strength and the bane of its existence. Its 46 million separate items - books, manuscripts, journals, recordings - constitute the second-largest collection, after the Library of Congress, in the United States. And its usership - from the city's students, for many of whom the branches function as their public-school libraries, to Ph.D. scholars; from lawyers and investment bankers, who take advantage of the library's vast stores of public records from around the world, to the homeless who find solace in its quietude and warmth; from reporters (who invaded the library's map room for street maps of Baghdad and Kuwait) to novelists like E. L. Doctorow and Toni Morrison - is wider and more diverse than that of any other like institution in the world.
But in an era of proliferating information, maintaining its breadth of services and depth of resources is an ever-escalating struggle. The New York Public Library is in much the same predicament as the yeoman-spirited Hetley; for all it has and for all it does, more is always in demand.
This is a particularly pivotal moment in N.Y.P.L. history. Having completed a $307 million fund-raising campaign last December, the culmination of a decade of rejuvenation, the library has rebounded famously from veritable ruin. The campaign provided for 200,000 items, acquired but inaccessible, to be catalogued and shelved. A huge conservation effort, to save crumbling volumes or, in the case of lost causes, to preserve what was in them on microfilm, was initiated. The library's showcase, the central research facility at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue, has been largely restored to its original Beaux Arts splendor. Behind it, underneath Bryant Park, a $20 million expansion will be ready next April - one of four new facilities scheduled to open next year. The resurgence among the city's corporate and private donors of library chic is the legacy, more or less, of Vartan Gregorian, who departed last spring after eight years as president of the institution to become president of Brown University.
But by now, with the exception of $30 million that bumped the library's endowment to $180 million, the campaign money is nearly spent, leaving the place - and its new president, the Rev. Timothy S. Healy - confronting cutbacks in vital city support and a budget that calls for $19 million in private donations for fiscal year 1991. ''We're broke,'' Andrew Heiskell says cheerfully. ''With a little more muscle than we had. We can arm-wrestle a bit with City Hall. But we're broke.''
Timothy Stafford Healy is a native New Yorker, a Jesuit who came to the library after 13 years as president of Georgetown University in Washington. Now president of an institution with more than 3,000 employees and a budget this year of $132 million, he defines his job this way: ''I am the library spokesman, its principal fund-raiser and administrative head. But once you've said that, you've got a whole lot of spaghetti on your plate.''
Indeed, since being named to succeed Gregorian in April 1989, Healy, now 67, has spent much of his time simply becoming familiar with the place. A big-bellied man with a large Irish face and an intellectual swagger, Healy is a man of appetites - a smoker, an appreciator of good talk, good Scotch, good writing, good jazz. He's combative, opinionated and political, though his brawny authoritativeness is well-tempered by an instinctive democratic tolerance and a fondness for aphorisms and sardonic humor. To describe the library's financial position these days, and his own role, he resorts to a wry, self-deprecating metaphor. ''You know the old New Yorker cartoon with the guy sitting watching a squirrel in a treadmill?'' he says. ''There are two women standing in the door, and one says to the other: 'We're now due for half an hour of gloomy philosophy.' I'm the squirrel.''
Healy is, nonetheless, enraptured by the library and is apt, at the slightest provocation, to extol its assets: the books in 3,000 languages and more than 2,000 subject areas (''They tell me there's even an elegant pornography collection,'' Healy says with a raised eyebrow); the 130,000 different periodicals; the rare volumes, manuscripts and letters in the Berg Collection of English and American Literature; the 400,000 maps. Or the employee he met for the first time in the men's room, a cataloguer. ''I said, 'What do you catalogue?' He said, 'Turkish, Farsi and Urdu.' That makes you feel illiterate,'' recalls Healy. About library employees in general, he's fond of saying that ''the library's greatest assets go home every night.''
People who know both Healy and the flamboyant, effusive Gregorian contrast them with relish. ''Gregorian is a bottle of champagne, Healy's a good Port'' is the prevailing metaphor within the library walls. Asked to find similarities, Heiskell, who hired them both, says, ''They both have big paunches,'' adding after a moment, ''though Greg got his here.''
Different men, different moments. When Gregorian took over in 1981, the library endowment was in danger of being dissipated completely within five years. His task was rescue, pure and simple. Healy, on the other hand, is charged with pushing the library forward, establishing a future that will accommodate the different needs of the branches and research libraries. Particularly crucial questions have been brought on by the computer age. For instance: How much to invest in data-base systems and software products? What revenue-producing information services can the library feasibly provide without compromising its stature as a free public institution? And where to find staff capable of handling technological services, particularly in an era when library-school enrollment is diminishing and higher-paying private libraries are attracting the most qualified graduates?
This past winter, seven different committees composed of library employees met to consider these and other issues, with the purpose of helping the board of trustees determine priorities for future financing. A consolidated report, due this fall, will ostensibly provide guidelines for the aims and dimensions of another campaign, scheduled to begin in 1993 and conclude in 1995, the library's centennial year. ''It's no exaggeration,'' says Jennifer Herring, the library's vice president for development, ''to say that we're trying to decide the kind of library we want to be in the next century.''
There are more extensive research collections in the world, and branch library systems are not uncommon, but no library of equivalent size is more accessible. Not only do its branches cater specifically to the city's children and generally to the needs of its diversely ethnic neighborhoods, but as a collective research facility -unlike, say, the Library of Congress, Harvard's Widener Library, Oxford's Bodleian or the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris - the New York Public Library has no favored constituency; with the exception of a few specialized collections that are limited to scholars, virtually anyone can get to virtually anything. ''Of all the great libraries in the world,'' Healy says, ''we're the only one that's truly public.''
For the purposes of library administration, this public is composed, in essence, of two groups - serious scholars and everyone else. The distinction is made nicely by Stephen C. Klein, the regional manager for six branches in lower Manhattan and head librarian at the Jefferson Market branch in Greenwich Village. ''Basically, when people come to a branch library, they want something to take home,'' Klein says. ''If you can satisfy that need, then, by and large, you've got a happy customer.''
Unlike the research libraries, the branches depend almost entirely on the beneficence of state and city governments for their operating costs. Earlier this year, the city announced a cut of $3.28 million in support for the branches for fiscal year 1991, and though lobbying by Healy and others has helped restore some of that, the branches have lost 8 percent of their city financing in the last three years. It now seems likely that a third of the branches will be unable to meet the stated goal of staying open five days a week.
Keeping the doors open is the key issue at the branches, whose connection to their communities is often intimate and fierce. At a meeting of the branch libraries council this spring, Dean Sheehan, the head librarian at the Riverside branch on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, reported that 1,000 letters of protest were received when notice was posted that the library would no longer be open on Saturdays. ''Outrage ruled the day from the moment the signs went up,'' Sheehan said. Certain statistics help explain the devotion of branch users: People checked out more than 10 million books last year. The branches ran upward of 26,000 public programs and classes - including lectures, discussion groups, musical and theatrical performances, adult literacy workshops and early childhood programs for toddlers, among others - that were attended by more than half a million people. In short, the branches represent as welcome an outreach organization as any in the city.
''One unsolved problem,'' Healy says, as if to prove the complexity of even mundane decisions in matters of service, ''is how deeply we go into videotapes. Obviously, classical videotapes are one thing - great old movies. But do we go with the Mutant Turtles, whatever the hell that is, 20 copies per branch?''
Of course, Healy's own concerns regarding the branches tend to be more grandiose. His first practical priority is the completion of a computer link, ''so you can walk into any branch and contact any book in the system via computer, find out if it's bought, if it's catalogued, if it's shelved and who has it.''
Healy is determined to keep the branches responsive to their specific communities, particularly as the ethnic makeup of neighborhoods evolves. ''There are linguistic shifts that are tactically necessary,'' he says. ''If a district has become 80 percent Puerto Rican, we can't have a branch that acts as though it's still 80 percent Italian.''
One specific constituency targeted for attention is the city's children. Indeed, Healy is unequivocal in saying that school-age children represent the most important single group the branches serve, and he has begun seeking ways to institutionalize cooperation between librarians and teachers. Nearly a third of the city's 634 elementary schools do not have their own staffed libraries. Partly to compensate for this lack, partly because libraries and schools are natural allies, Healy, who began his career teaching English and Latin at Fordham Prep in the Bronx, sounds off on the subject with some exasperation:
''You're a high-school teacher; you assign 'Catcher in the Rye,' '' he says, giving the example recounted to him by a librarian who didn't have the books to meet the students' demand. ''The librarian said to me, 'I had one hardback and two paperbound copies.' Well, that's like a drugstore saying, 'Sorry Mac, I'm out of aspirin.' We've got to have some sensible coordination.''
In an appeal supported by Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, Healy has received a $485,000 grant from the DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund to set up an experimental library orientation program in three school districts ''that would bring the teachers together with the librarians for planning sessions, bring all the kids, in grammar school and junior high, into the library and start making sure that every kid has a card and knows how to use it.''
Beyond that, Healy has also put forward the notion of opening branch libraries inside the school buildings. ''The problem is schools close at 3 o'clock and the building shuts down,'' he says. ''There have got to be schools where an independent access can be created, and we can run a children's library in the school, with our own librarians and our own books and us in charge of its hours. I'm quite sure that would work.''
A Donne Scholar with a doctorate in English literature from Oxford University, Healy has taught at Fordham University and, before going to Georgetown, served as vice chancellor for academic affairs at the City University of New York. Obviously, his background as a scholar informs his affection for his current place of employment, particularly the research libraries.
In terms of operation, the research libraries differ from the branches in that about 60 percent of their budget comes from private sources. The city owns the buildings and maintains them, but endowment income and gifts from donors supply the lion's share of the rest.
''The branches get all the fuss,'' Healy says, ''but they're essentially immortal. Whatever the city lets us have, it will never be without branch libraries. But the center, the heart of the library, is private and vulnerable.''
What is particularly at issue, he goes on, is the New York Public Library's role as a national resource for scholarship.
''Twenty-five years ago, if you wanted to do research in the social sciences or the humanities, 80 percent of what you needed was published in this country,'' Healy says. ''That's now down to 60 percent. More internationally significant stuff than ever is being published in foreign languages, and just at the point where the need is greatest for the future of American scholarship, hundreds of university and college libraries have stopped buying in Europe because it's too expensive. We could very easily get back to where we were in the 1890's, when if you wanted to do serious academic work you had to go abroad.''
With that in mind, Healy has lately begun traveling back to Washington to garner Federal support for what he views as ''a national service.'' He wants Congress to appropriate funds for a network of great libraries - ''five or six of us,'' he says - to purchase foreign books and periodicals, whose availability would then be shared. ''We're not talking about billions,'' Healy says. ''If to each of those libraries a grant of $2 million or $3 million a year were made by the Federal Government for foreign purchases, the libraries could then divvy themselves up. The California libraries would look to Asia, the East Coast libraries could look to Europe, the Southern libraries to Latin America.''
Earlier this year, the lobbying project had already taken root in Healy's mind; since then, events have conspired in his favor. With the Bush Administration's announced intention to support the nations of Eastern Europe in their recovery from years of cultural repression, Healy is now able to bring trade bait with him to Washington.
''We're one of the best Eastern Europe collections in the world,'' Healy says, ''and for 40 years we've been in touch with the great libraries behind the Iron Curtain. We know what they need. One of the things they have problems with is bibliographic knowledge - to know what's out there that they haven't got. The second thing they need is help in acquiring things that American libraries hold. For instance, we have all the Polish state documents that were destroyed during World War II. If you want to do serious history on the Polish Government, you're better off in New York than in Warsaw. That ought to be fixed.''
It isn't a deal Healy is offering, exactly. Indeed, he's telling the Feds they'll have to pay for the copying and transporting of library materials overseas. But Healy knows a trump card when he's holding one. ''I mean, the Government is doing it, and we're saying, 'Use us,' '' Healy says. ''I guess it is a political strategy. There are only three ways of making things happen - guns, dice and politics - and I prefer politics.''
Playing politics was certainly part of Healy's job description at Georgetown, which, under his stewardship, won generous appropriations from both the Federal and District of Columbia governments. In Healy's 13 years in Washington, the university endowment increased sixfold, to $225 million. And his lobbying experience was in the forefront of qualifications that appealed to Andrew Heiskell and the rest of the six-member search committee that selected him as library president.
Healy's Georgetown tenure was not without controversy, and one in particular has dogged him. In 1980 he refused to grant university recognition - and financing - to two gay student organizations, arguing that such recognition would amount to an endorsement, antithetical to Catholic tenet, of homosexuality.
A protracted court battle ensued, concluding in 1987 when the District of Columbia Court of Appeals upheld the student claim that the D.C. Human Rights Act of 1977 superseded Georgetown's right of religious exercise, and forced the university to provide the ''tangible benefits'' it offers to other student organizations.
The case was frequently cited after Healy was named to the library post, with opponents arguing that no man of the cloth should be charged with such a secular intellectual trust. The debate was carried out for weeks in the press; this newspaper, for one, ran opposing editorials.
''It bothers some people both ways: the Catholics who say you're wasting your time with a secular enterprise, and the other way around,'' Healy says. ''A plague on both their houses.''
More than a year into his tenure, the concerns that acquisitions of material running counter to church doctrine might be curtailed seem entirely hypothetical. Within the library, employees mostly shrug off this sort of speculation; the president simply doesn't make decisions about what the library acquires. (One department head did say that a few of her employees seemed worried at first, ''but only after reading the newspapers. Oddly enough, they tended to be the Catholics.'') And this spring, in a largely unreported transaction, the library acquired an archive from the International Gay Information Center Inc. - more than 100 boxes of materials documenting the gay rights movement in the United States over the last 40 years.
''It's an obvious thing for the library to collect,'' Healy says.
The matter of acquisitions - what to collect - is, of course, at the heart of any research library enterprise; the completeness and currency of collections is what draws scholars to them, and the capacity to serve the intellectual community is how the institution itself is measured. During the 1970's, a decade that, in general, represented the low point of N.Y.P.L. fortunes, the central research facility cut hours, cut service, cut upkeep on the building and cut cataloguing - but not acquisitions. As a result, the mammoth backlog is still being catalogued. ''And what we're discovering,'' Healy says, ''is that almost one-third of it is catalogued nowhere else in the U.S.''
Indeed, the four research facilities of the N.Y.P.L. constitute a resource that has few peers. The library's annex on West 43d Street maintains an archive of hundreds of newspapers published in the world since 1800 and a patents collection second only to the United States. patent office. The Performing Arts Research Center, located at Lincoln Center, holds the world's largest research collection devoted to dance as well as a mammoth music division, a recorded sound archive with nearly half a million recordings, and a collection of more than two million items chronicling the history of the theater and entertainment. In Harlem, the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture holds five million items. And then there is the central research facility, whose size and variety tend to defy circumscription. Its divisions include general research, economic and public affairs, microforms, maps, Judaica, Slavonic and Baltic studies and United States History, local history and geneaology, and many other special collections.
But maintaining the stature of the collections is now at issue. Last winter, one of the library's planning committees was charged with determining priorities for future collecting, and as Natalie Seweryn, chief acquisitions librarian for the research libraries, puts it: ''Unfortunately, we decided we'd have to make some effort at streamlining.''
Seweryn oversees a staff of 125 selection officers, often scholars in their own right, who are responsible for library purchases in distinct subject areas. They are in touch with 70 vendors worldwide, commercial establishments in the business of supplying books to libraries. ''But bear in mind there are many learned societies, small publishing outfits, even individuals, that can't afford to do business with a vendor,'' Seweryn says. ''All sorts of groups whose titles never appear in general catalogues or bibliographies. So consequently you've got to make that kind of additional effort to find the material and get it into the library.''
Seweryn says her annual budget - currently about $8 million - has not kept pace either with rising book prices or with the increase in material available internationally. Another serious strain on acquisitions, she says, is the number of new information products that ''the library will have to consider acquiring if it doesn't want to be left behind.'' These include computerized, or ''on-line'' information services, of course, but also things like compact disks and video disks, which not only squeeze the book budget, but also create an added preservation burden. ''Nobody knows how long a C.D. is going to last or what you may have to do to preserve it,'' Seweryn says. ''Besides which, you need special equipment to play these things, and the manufacturers are constantly changing the hardware. So even if you manage to hold on to a disk for 50 years, how do you play it back if the equipment that was built to play it is no longer around?''
Already, in the main reading room, the library has the Oxford English Dictionary on line, as well as the Readers Guide to Periodical Literature, the Congressional Information Service, the Wilson Line Index and Catnyp, its own catalogue of acquisitions since 1972. (All previous acquisitions are catalogued on paper, in 800 bound volumes.) And the library does perform complex data-base searches for users who pay for the service.
''But the possibility of on-line searching is almost endless,'' Seweryn says, and that raises several other issues that the library will have to deal with. The vaster the library's on-line data base becomes, the less the library resembles, well, a library. Is the so-called library without walls a possibility, whole on-line collections made available to subscribers? Should encyclopedias be on line? Textbooks? Novels? Is there a distinction to be made between information gathering and reading?
Jennifer Herring, the development vice president, sees burgeoning technology as no less than a challenge to the library's fundamental mission: ''Can we afford to go heavily into on-line services and thus create an elite, privileged-information class among our users?'' she asks, rhetorically. ''We could spend every penny we have on technology, but then we'd be abandoning the book.
''Of course, as we agonize over these things, we're doing them.''
There is probably no better symbol of the New York Public Library's future than the Bryant Park stacks expansion, scheduled to open next spring, a grandiose, forward-looking, state-of-the art construction that will add as many complicated burdens to the library as it will relieve. Encompassing 118,000 square feet in two underground levels - only the first will be put to use right away; the subbasement will be shut until more space is needed, probably five years down the road - the expansion will double the capacity of the main research facility. To fill book requests from library users in a reasonable amount of time, orders will have to be faxed from upstairs.
Standing in the lower level, a vast, dank concrete chamber that right now resembles a parking garage more than a book repository, Paul Fasana, director of the research libraries, is rather gleefully contemplating the generous emptiness. ''We've been out of space in this building for 25 or 30 years,'' he says, his voice echoing slightly. But he also acknowledges how difficult and costly it will be to move in; estimates for the first round of moving expenses this fall have been as high as $700,000. And he's looking ahead as well to a mammoth reshuffling of library resources as collections are relocated and consolidated.
Fasana plans to use the new space to house the library's manuscript collection, currently in an annex on 10th Avenue; the original negatives for materials that have been microfilmed, and the older, less-requested books on the humanities and social sciences. Indeed, it is the long-range plan to turn the central facility into a gigantic storehouse of materials in those areas. ''When the Science and Business Library opens,'' Fasana says, ''we'll move the science and economics divisions there, which will free up more space in this building. We expect all this to allow growth space for up to 20 years.''
In fact, the Science and Business Library looms as an inevitability to library officials, though a location has yet to be chosen and financing is uncertain. The city has committed $10 million, and Healy plans to ask the state for a similar appropriation. There's talk of selling the annex, for which another $20 million might be realized. The rest - as much as $35 million - will have to be raised from private sources. ''I'd love to find some guy who's dreaming of having his name in relief over the door and raise it in one shot,'' Healy says. ''But I've never had that kind of luck. So we'll sell it off room by room. You know, 'Would you like the great reading room?' And if you're a real cheapskate, 'Would you like the men's room on the third floor?' ''
Perhaps the vastness of the library enterprise is best revealed by Healy's cheerful cynicism about his role as fund-raiser. As he speaks about finding money, donor by donor, project by project, he describes a Sisyphean chore, to which he brings a certain caginess. ''When this guy from Mitsubishi Estate, Takagi I think his name is, bought Rockefeller Center, we wrote him a letter and said 'Welcome.' I didn't think he'd get too many of those.''
The sums themselves are staggering; Healy estimates he has ''about $50 million in asks out'' for both general financing and specific uses. He mentions conservation, an ongoing expense, and the need to raise compensation for librarians whose annual salaries, after 20 years service, currently top out at less than $40,000. ''And we have to find a way to fund the branches that doesn't have a built-in conflict,'' he says, referring to the city's propensity to withdraw support when private financing is located. To that end, Healy has initiated, among other things, the ''adopt a branch'' program, which seeks individual New Yorkers to help refurbish individual branches by matching city grants of $500,000 to $1 million.
All of this is in advance of the next campaign, much of which will be devoted to augmenting the endowment. ''We've got to strengthen the base of this place,'' Healy says. ''It's $180 million now. If it were $300 million, we'd be talking about the library never running a deficit, but we'd still be basically immobile. If it were $500, there'd always be $10 million a year that you could use for expansion, renovation etc.'' He sighs. ''I'd love to make 300.''
Sitting at his desk in the enormous paneled office that overlooks Fifth Avenue, Healy finishes his recitation with a shrug and a smile. His Irish eyes crinkle into a tired squint, the expression of a man both proud of and daunted by his responsibility. He exhales cigarette smoke and considers a final query. What makes running the library different from running another institution of equivalent size and complexity? From his vantage, what makes the library singular?
''Well,'' he says with a laugh. ''Nobody hates us.''

PUB-DATE: September 23, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 32, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 2986 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
The Scam Goes On

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques; Diana B. Henriques covers Wall Street for The Times.

 BODY:
DR. ENRICO S. MANGO, A LONG ISLAND ORTHOPEDIC surgeon, was growing suspicious of his stockbrokers at Wellshire Securities, a low-budget brokerage house based in New York City. During the spring of 1989, he had bought penny stocks - shares of companies too small to be listed on a stock exchange - recommended by a Wellshire broker and lost money on them. But that July, Dr. Mango bought again: 20,000 shares of Ventura, a fledgling leasing company based in Needham, Mass., at $2.50 a share.
After weeks of abbreviated phone calls, undelivered confirmation orders, vague answers and unfulfilled promises, Dr. Mango began to record his conversations with Wellshire brokers, including Edward D. Braverman. On Aug. 11, the surgeon taped the following exchange:
MANGO: So where do we stand then?
BRAVERMAN: Your 20,000 Ventura is trading at 3, and the stock is poised for its significant move. 
MANGO: Before . . . it was going on 3 1/4, and about a week ago I thought it was 3 1/2. Wasn't it up a bit before that?
BRAVERMAN: Yeah, it's been trading around, you know. [The broker explains that a lot of people had dumped the stock but Wellshire itself is still buying.] MANGO: When do you think that something is going to happen with it?
BRAVERMAN: I think we're going to get a move now. Right now, in fact, it's being listed on the Vancouver this evening. [Braverman mollifies Mango with the promise that the stock price will now be publicly reported.] From Monday on, you can look at the newspaper. . . .
But information about Ventura and its stock price would not make the newspapers until much later, not until the Securities and Exchange Commission sued Wellshire in March of this year. Ventura, it turned out, had not even applied for a listing on the Vancouver Stock Exchange. And its stock had in fact been quoted by another broker at a price as low as 25 cents a share in 1989 - if a buyer could be found. According to trading records assembled by the S.E.C., Wellshire constituted virtually the only market for Ventura shares and often failed to execute its customers' sell orders.
During its brief, wild run on Wall Street, Wellshire Securities had promoted stock in Environmental Landfills, a tiny company it portrayed as poised to cash in on the New York-area garbage crisis. It also touted an assortment of other penny stocks such as Greenleaf Capital, Nightwing Group, Diversified Foods and Treats Enterprises. But Wellshire's ride was cut short by regulators acting on evidence from Dr. Mango and other investors. The penny stock brokerage went out of business this spring after its license was revoked by the National Association of Securities Dealers, the industry's self-regulatory agency. Attorneys for Wellshire argued that the company should not have been held responsible for the actions of a few rogue brokers. Braverman could not be reached for comment on this article.
There are some legitimate penny stocks, and some professional money managers do trade profitably, if care-fully, in this market. But after a decade of abuses by the con artists who have permeated the business, the S.E.C. stepped in. The commission has taken direct aim at boiler rooms - those hives where high-pressure brokers wield telephones to tout speculative, sometimes fraudulent, unlisted shares to people who lack both the knowledge and the wealth required to dabble in such risky waters. Since the crackdown began in the third quarter of 1988, the S.E.C. calculates that, through July of this year, the number of companies selling penny stocks had declined from 348 to 285. The House of Representatives has already approved a bipartisan bill that would give the S.E.C. even greater power in regulating penny-stock brokers, and the proposal's backers hope to win the approval of the Senate in a conference committee session this month.
Meanwhile, warns Martin Kuperberg, associate regional administrator in the commission's New York office, the agency is broadening its enforcement efforts, which so far have been aimed chiefly at the owners and top executives of boiler rooms. ''You are going to start to see that these salesmen are not going to escape commission scrutiny,'' Kuperberg says. ''They have to know, when they are making $500 on a $1,200 trade, that something is out of whack. They are going to be held responsible.''
The state regulators are cracking down as well. Colorado, which had liberalized its securities laws in the early 80's - and found itself invaded by penny-stock brokers - recently tightened its regulations. ''Fraudulent telemarketing through penny-stock boiler rooms is a multibillion-dollar business,'' says Philip A. Feigin, Colorado's top securities regulator. The entire market cannot be eliminated, he believes, because of Washington's marked preference for deregulation. ''So,'' he says, ''you can just try to keep out the bad guys.'' It isn't easy. For all the hue and cry, many boiler-room denizens have remained nonchalant about the crackdown. Says one penny-stock promoter in the Los Angeles area, ''It's a speed bump. It slows you down a little, that's all.''
In theory, the penny-stock market is a sort of capitalistic incubator, a marketplace in which investors can help finance businesses that are too small, too speculative or too new to attract either venture capitalists or major Wall Street underwriters. There are approximately 15,000 public companies whose shares trade in this market. Some of them are legitimate, offering viable products or marketable services.
Of the 435 stocks that joined the NASDAQ over the past year, an estimated 46 percent were former penny stocks, says Enno Hobbing, a spokesman for the National Association of Securities Dealers in Washington. As examples of such graduates, Hobbing cites Datronic Rental, a computer-leasing company in Palatine, Ill.; Mid-Atlantic Medical Services in Rockville, Md., and North Coast Energy, a Bedford Heights, Ohio-based oil company.
Penny-stock brokers who are considered legitimate - such brokerage houses as Carr Securities or Herzog, Heine, Geduld in New York - deal with professional money-managers and knowledgeable, well-heeled customers for whom speculative investments may be suitable. These firms insist they would never attempt to push their wares on the uninitiated - and some of their top executives express profound contempt for those brokers who do. ''You know what the S.E.C. should do when it catches these guys?'' asks Walter Carucci, the president of Carr Securities. ''It should cut their hands off so they can't use the telephone anymore.''
THE TARGETS OF HIS anger, the houses that make cold calls to the sometimes gullible public, are a multifarious lot. At the dark edge of the spectrum are firms whose officers have been charged with criminal fraud. Best known of these is Blinder, Robinson & Company, the Englewood, Colo., firm that reigned as the largest penny-stock brokerage house in the country before the legal problems of its founder, Meyer Blinder, pushed it into bankruptcy this summer. Blinder denies the allegations against him and is awaiting trial.
Another well-known firm, the Stuart-James Company, in Denver, has frequently been disciplined in civil actions by regulators. Earlier this year, Stuart-James and three top executives paid a fine of more than $2 million to the N.A.S.D. to settle a disciplinary action charging improper sales tactics. The firm subsequently agreed that it would pull out of penny stocks and focus in the future on exchange-listed stocks.
Most penny-stock dealers, however, are obscure firms that open their doors, ply their trade for a year or so and then disband - only to reassemble elsewhere under a new name. Life in such firms is anything but glamorous, to judge from the sworn accounts of disillusioned brokers questioned by the S.E.C. regional office in New York.
Wellshire's New York operation, in a shabby downtown office building, consisted of a room packed with desks, telephones and about twenty brokers. There were two stock-quote machines, only one of which seemed to work. The closet was filled with telephone directories, gathered from around the country to facilitate the pursuit of customers. Price quotes for whatever stocks the company was pushing were scribbled on a blackboard. And filling the air was the tattoo of cold calls, delivered earnestly and insistently to anybody who would stay on the line.
Charles J. Marino, a former Wellshire broker who quit in disgust, said that a variety of cold-call scripts was available, but that the basic sequence of calls rarely changed: The first was introductory, the second was to determine how much money the prospect had and the third was the clincher, the insistent pitching of boiler-room products.
S.E.C. lawyers interviewing Brian Smith, another Wellshire broker, were curious: Where did he get the names and telephone numbers?
''Through Yellow Pages,'' Smith answered. ''I like calling up doctors or funeral directors. I also have Colgate alumni phone numbers.''
Others at Wellshire favored the owners of mom-and-pop stores or building contractors. Some sold penny stocks to their college classmates and former girlfriends.
One Wellshire broker testified that he made 200 to 300 cold calls a day. All the broker needed was a few investors willing to part with a few thousand dollars each. Brokers were entitled to pocket up to half the difference between the bid and asked price for Wellshire's favorite stocks.
What helps make penny-stock scam artists so difficult to police is that they mimic the mainstream world of Wall Street. They deal in stocks and bonds, options and warrants. They use the same glib jargon about ''hot growth'' and ''undervalued assets.'' They distribute impressive, plausible-sounding research reports and investment newsletters, just like the blue-chip firms.
So how can an investor distinguish between a fraudulent boiler-room pick like Goldcor, a now-defunct company that purported to extract gold from Costa Rican beach sand, and a struggling but legitimate company like, say, the Design Institute of America, an Ohio furniture manufacturer that last year moved to the Philadelphia Stock Exchange from the ''pink sheets,'' the paper price lists that circulate each day to penny-stock brokers. A company's prospectus may be gobbledygook to unsophisticated investors. And, since the S.E.C. requires the filing of the prospectus but does not verify the claims, there is no telling how much of the prospectus is fact, and how much is fraud. Moreover, eager boiler-room touts will encourage potential investors to get into a stock without waiting for a prospectus.
Profits are made, according to prosecutors, when the promoters and a few favored investors acquire a vast amount of nearly worthless shares, mark them up manyfold, and then sell them to the last link in the chain, the unwitting boiler-room customers. When those customers try to sell, they may find that their boiler-room brokerage house quotes them a much lower price, or fails to answer its phones, and that no other brokerage house will make a bid on the shares.
But investors keep buying because boiler-room operators have an uncanny ability to market the latest investment fads. In the high-inflation days of the late 70's, it was gold mines that were always about to hit pay dirt. These days, bioengineering, superconductivity, AIDS research and pollution are the buzzwords, with a recent boom in tiny oil stocks tied to the Iraqi conflict.
Joseph I. Goldstein, associate director of enforcement at the S.E.C., says that criminal promoters often create specious companies from whole cloth. ''But these schemes can't work,'' Goldstein says, ''if you can't find retail customers to buy these stocks.''
That's why the S.E.C. has made the ''cold-call rule'' the centerpiece of its recent crackdown. The provision, imposed in January of this year, applies to the sale of stocks that are not listed on an exchange, that have less than $2 million in assets and that trade for less than $5 a share. It requires penny-stock brokers to have customers fill out a document showing their income and investment objectives before any sales can be concluded. A customer's initial telephone transactions - the first three trades, so long as each involves a different stock - are not binding until they are confirmed by the customer in writing. The aim, says Goldstein, was to give investors time to change their minds about stocks they might have been pressured into buying.
The bill that has passed the House and is awaiting action by Senate conferees would also empower the S.E.C., for the first time, to discipline the promoters and consultants, often defrocked brokers, who align themselves informally with brokerages or with individual companies.
Consider Ramon D'Onofrio of Los Angeles. Since 1971, D'Onofrio has pleaded guilty to criminal securities violations and bankruptcy fraud, served a short stint in prison and been disciplined by the S.E.C. on several occasions. These days, D'Onofrio and his son, Mark, run United Atlantic Investments, a consulting firm whose clients include current and former pink-sheet companies such as Kinesis, PSN Communications and Exten Ventures. D'Onofrio failed to return calls seeking his comment.
The proposed bill would also focus on the investment vehicles known as blind pools, which invite the public to buy shares even though no specific business plan exists, other than to shop for acquisitions. In effect, the companies the pools acquire ''go public'' without having to make a formal filing with the S.E.C. The proposed bill places limitations on the use of any money the blind pools raise, until they tell shareholders exactly how the money would be used - and investors could then pull their money back.
The N.A.S.D., meanwhile, has introduced a new electronic penny-stock bulletin board that it hopes will be an improvement on the antediluvian pink sheets, which were once the only source of information on price.
PENNY-STOCK TRICKSTERS continue to give regulators a run for their money. As soon as the cold-call rules went into effect, issuers and brokers found ways to circumvent them, including reverse splits to lift the share price above the $5 threshold and mergers that would produce the required $2 million in assets.
The S.E.C. regulation on cold calls applied only to stocks that were not listed on an exchange. Voila, penny stock promoters flocked to the nation's regional stock exchanges, including those in Boston and Philadelphia.
Some exchanges proved only too willing to waive their none-too-strenuous standards. The tiny exchange in Spokane, Wash., actually boasts of having the lowest listing standards in the country; it requires only that a company have 250,000 public shares and 300 shareholders. (By contrast, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange has recently applied to the S.E.C. to raise its standards to accept only companies that have had at least $100,000 net income in three of the last four years or shareholders' equity of at least $500,000.) The Spokane Stock Exchange has been so welcoming to penny-stock companies that the S.E.C. has refused to exempt Spokane-listed stocks from its new rules. Other exchanges have been warned by the commission that any waivers will be closely monitored.
Regulators say they have heard of brokers who sell new customers odd lots of three blue-chip stocks in an attempt to satisfy the ''three-trade'' feature of the cold-call rule, and to establish the customer as a ''seasoned'' investor. ''Then they start pushing the junk,'' one Federal official says.
And by selling abroad, boiler rooms can usually find customers beyond the reach of Federal regulators. Several recently shut-down boiler rooms, including Wellshire, had set up European offices where American stocks were sold to foreign investors.
Such tactics have drawn the attention of overseas regulators. A few years ago, says Lawrence Iason, regional S.E.C. administrator in New York, the most common inquiry the S.E.C. got from foreign securities regulators involved insider trading. Now more than half the inquiries concern penny-stock fraud. Prosecutors and regulators acknowledge the difficulties of policing the international penny-stock market at a time when the concepts of market deregulation and globalization are all the rage.
According to Scott E. Stapf, a spokesman for the North American Securities Administrators Association, a watchdog group in Washington, the next step in the penny-stock shuffle is likely to be the touting of dubious overseas stocks to investors back in North America. ''The hopscotch used to be from Florida to Phoenix to Southern California,'' Stapf says. ''Now they are going offshore and calling home.'' Low international telephone rates make the offshore touting of penny stocks and other speculative investments viable. According to Stapf, expatriate penny-stock brokers are particularly attracted to countries such as Panama that have strict bank-secrecy laws. In addition, the S.E.C. and Interpol found that Costa Rica had become a haven for expatriate Canadian stock promoters, including Leonard C. Zrnic, who styled himself ''Count Saladash of Hungary.''
Wellshire Securities itself illustrates how intractable the boiler-room problem can be. Soon after Wellshire shut its doors, some members of its staff started a new branch of Salt Lake City-based L. M. Drew, formerly West Coast Securities, in a brownstone in the heart of Manhattan.
How should a prudent investor react when a badgering broker from an unfamiliar firm calls, someone touting a hot biotechnology stock or a handful of complicated Class C warrants for some new energy-exploration outfit? Probably the best advice comes from Goldstein of the S.E.C. task force. ''The investor who is best protected,'' he says, ''is the one who just hangs up.''

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS: BUDAPEST;
Mealtime, Dealtime

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

 BODY:
For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs. But the status restaurant remains the primary locus for striking deals with meals. Most often, but not necessarily, the power meal is lunch. 
Herewith a sampling of international business eateries by New York Times correspondents and frequent contributors to this magazine.
 
BUDAPEST
There are no gypsy violinists at the Forum Grill. In fact, there is not a hint of Hungarian folklore in this simple hotel restaurant. Perhaps that's one reason it is the choice of the high-powered businessmen who come to town to do deals.
The preferred times are breakfast and lunch. Unadorned wood tables, tucked behind potted plants, fill up with the likes of Peter Zwack, the Hungarian brandy-and-cordials distiller recently named Ambassador to Washington, and other high-ranking government officials.
Two years ago, the Grill - located on the ground floor of the Forum Hotel, on the Pest side of the Danube - added chicken seasoned in yogurt to its menu of sauce-laden Hungarian specialties. Fish is grilled, veal is roasted, vegetables are fresh - all of which can make a meal here positively light, an achievement regarded by residents and frequent visitors to Budapest as a scientific breakthrough.
Gabor Hidas, one of four maitres d'hotel who work in the Grill, sighs as he describes the appeal of the restaurant's non-Hungarian cuisine. ''We have to admit,'' he says mournfully, ''this French-style food is more popular.'' The varied and plentiful salad bar at the Grill is more successful with foreigners, waiters say, than with their Hungarian guests. The chef, Laszlo Gyorgy, continues to produce local dishes - chicken paprikash, goulash and stuffed cabbage among them.
Quick service, a Western notion that has been slow to catch on in many local restaurants, is a staple here. And the Grill is located only a few steps from the lobby of the hotel, which attracts foreign visitors such as Ronald S. Lauder, the billionaire heir to the cosmetics fortune and former Ambassador to Austria, who is a partner in an investment group in Eastern Europe. The hotel's concierge offers advice in English and, nearby, international businessmen spend hours huddled around coffee tables, spreading out prospectuses, tapping out future prospects for ''jay-vees'' (joint ventures) on their calculators.
Lunch for two at the Grill, with wine or beer, is about $30, tip not included. Dessert is best taken upstairs at the Forum's prize-winning Viennese Cafe, which serves lavish Viennese and Hungarian pastries and sweets, including a local chocolate-and-cream treat called somloi galuska.
 
The Forum Grill, Forum Hotel,
Apaczai Csere Janos Utca 12-14,
Budapest. 36-1-117-8088.
American Express, Eurocard, Visa.

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS: TOKYO;
Mealtime, Dealtime

BYLINE: By DAVID SANGER

 BODY:
For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs. But the status restaurant remains the primary locus for striking deals with meals. Most often, but not necessarily, the power meal is lunch.
Herewith a sampling of international business eateries by New York Times correspondents and frequent contributors to this magazine. 
 
TOKYO
Just about everything seems reversed when doing business in Japan, and lunch is no exception.
In New York, the essence of the power lunch is visibility: a window seat at the Four Seasons or a corner table at a private club. In Japan, the essence of the power lunch - like the essence of Japanese power itself - is invisibility. At Tokyo's most exclusive Japanese restaurants, any discussion taking place somewhere other than a private tatami room probably is not worth overhearing.
Not that you would hear much out of school. Like the companies themselves, Japanese restaurants tend to be informal extensions of ''business groups.'' Nissan's executives have a small circle of favorite restaurants into which Toyota executives would rarely wander. Politicians have their own hangouts, many of them exclusive ryotei, restaurants so discreet - particularly about who is eating with whom - that only those already known to the management can make a reservation. The result is that, if you are doing business with the Japanese, it is probably best to let the natives pick the restaurant.
But if you find yourself the host, a good place to show your refined taste in Nihon ryoori, as the Japanese call their own cooking, might be the Kamogawa restaurant. It is the favorite of an eclectic if well-moneyed crowd, from the executives of the giant Mitsui & Company trading house and of Japan's biggest domestic airline, All Nippon Airways, to the diplomats who guide Japan's increasingly assertive foreign policy from the nearby Foreign Ministry. ''Unless you run into someone at the front door,'' a diplomat said recently, as we watched a waitress slide open a shoji screen, ''you'll never really know who is here. But the walls are so thin, you might make out their laughter.''
From the outside, Kamogawa is thoroughly modern; it is located on the ground floor of the New Kasumigaseki Building, one of Tokyo's biggest office towers. But inside, it has the feel of ancient Edo: aged stone lanterns, green bamboo fences and stone pathways that glisten as though it has just rained.
All the seating is in private, minimalist tatami rooms, where the food is served by women in traditional kimonos. It might be a struggle to get your legs under the low tables, but most of Kamogawa's rooms mercifully have a pit cut into the tatami, increasing the probability that you will actually be able to walk after the meal is over.
Lunch comes in set menus, changed every week - usually a mix of vegetables and soups, perhaps some fish or shrimp tempura, and small dishes of sashimi. Like most traditional Japanese food, it is meant to be as much a feast for the eyes as for the stomach.
Kamogawa is within the bounds of a moderate expense account. The least pricey lunches, served in traditional bento boxes, run from about $30 a person; the multicourse meals start at $40 and run up to about $55 for a meal including a boiled sea bream head. Beer is usually the beverage of choice at lunch, sake not being conducive to a hard afternoon's work. And in keeping with Japanese custom, there is no tipping.
Lunch itself is rarely a time to conduct business: a tatami mat is no place to spread papers. Rather than a time to negotiate, the meal is viewed as an opportunity to build relationships.
On the way out, your guest will say ''gochisoo-sama deshita,'' which roughly translates to ''what a feast.'' There is no need to be flattered. Japanese tradition requires the comment, whether it is truthful or not.
 
Kamogawa,
New Kasumigaseki Building, 3-3-2 Kasumigaseki,
Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo. 81-3-593-0550.
All major credit cards accepted.

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS: NEW YORK;
Mealtime, Dealtime

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs. But the status restaurant remains the primary locus for striking deals with meals. Most often, but not necessarily, the power meal is lunch. 
Herewith a sampling of international business eateries by New York Times correspondents and frequent contributors to this magazine.
 
NEW YORK
With cavernous, airline-terminal dimensions and sleek, masculine design, the Four Seasons has reigned for three decades as New York's premier power-lunch spot. It has done so by catering to the executive appetite for predictability and the chance to nod at other executives. In a 25,000-foot space, the architects Ludwig Mies van der Rohe (who designed the Seagram Building, in which the restaurant resides) and Philip Johnson (who designed the interior) created a public place that regulars have come to regard as their own private club. ''You know everybody,'' says Kenneth Lipper, an investment banker and a former New York Deputy Mayor. ''They're familiar faces.''
The faces on this day include real estate mogul Lewis Rudin; Vittorio C. Vellano, president of Fiat U.S.A.; Herbert J. Siegel, the head of Chris-Craft Industries. Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Primerica; S. I. New-house Jr., head of the Conde Nast publishing empire; Laurence A. Tisch, president of CBS, and Philip Johnson feast here almost daily.
Patrons dine on a seasonally changing menu that is sometimes tailored to the particular palate. Henry A. Kissinger, for instance, eats only low-calorie foods, without salt or butter, while Bill Blass has been known to order a hamburger. Executives usually favor the entrees, which, depending on the time of year, might include Maryland crab cakes, chicken pot pie or a skewer of shrimp and sausage. The Four Seasons's dark-paneled Grill Room gets the power lunch crowd (a typical meal, with wine, will cost about $60 per person), while the more elegant Pool Room is especially favored by business executives at night.
''Most have been coming here so long, I don't even have to tell them which table,'' says Julian Niccolini, the manager. Every morning, Niccolini scans newspapers to stay abreast of his clients and to watch for up-and-comers. How has the Four Seasons attracted some 6,000 house accounts? ''It's the ultrapersonalized service,'' Niccolini explains. ''I go up to clients, introduce myself and try to make friends. It's as simple as that.''
 
The Four Seasons,
99 East 52 Street, New York. 212-754-9494.
All major credit cards accepted.

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS: LONDON;
Mealtime, Dealtime

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs. But the status restaurant remains the primary locus for striking deals with meals. Most often, but not necessarily, the power meal is lunch. Herewith a sampling of international business eateries by New York Times correspondents and frequent contributors to this magazine.
 
LONDON
BUSINESS BREAKFASTS, QUIP THE have no place in any truly civilized society. But the English do consent to the business lunch. The place where the high and mighty flock is the Savoy Grill in the elegant 101-year-old Savoy Hotel in the Strand, a 5- to 15-minute ride from Westminster, Fleet Street and the City, London's financial district. 
Everybody who is anybody - cabinet ministers, peers, business executives and the literati - can be found at the 33 tables in the Grill room. These include Denis Thatcher, the Prime Minister's husband; Nigel Lawson, her departed Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Norman Tebbit, former chairman of the Conservative Party. Diana Rigg, David Frost and Jeffrey Archer are some of the entertainers and scribes who have their own tables. You might also see financiers such as Sir James Goldsmith and Lord Rothschild plotting another multibillion-dollar takeover; media magnates Robert Maxwell, Rupert Murdoch and Lord Rothermere; advertising man Martin S. Sorrell, chairman of the WPP Group, and Lord King, the chairman of British Airways.
Angelo Maresca, the longtime Grill manager, will greet and seat you. The most desirable tables are next to the windows overlooking the courtyard, and those near the wall diagonally opposite the entrance. Those tables are the preserve of regulars, but if one has not been claimed, an ordinary mortal may get it. While no special dispensations are required for a nonregular to secure a reservation, a phone call at least three days in advance is advised.
The attraction of the Savoy Grill is undoubtedly that it is a place to be seen, not its decor. The tables are far apart, which affords privacy, and the yew-wood paneling, brass fixtures and green-velvet upholstery are pleasant enough. But as the Sunday Times of London put it: The Grill ''could be the first-class dining room in an ocean liner.'' Its one extraordinary item is a silver duck press that its first chef, Auguste Escoffier, used. (To order pressed wild duck, call one week in advance.) The staff is friendly and efficient, and will be pleased to point out where Sir Winston Churchill and Noel Coward presided.
Offerings are well-prepared, although a stale roll has been known to rear its head. There is a traditional English dish on the menu each day - a mixed grill or steak and kidney pie or roast beef with Yorkshire pudding - and such gourmet appetisers as pan-fried Burgundy snails with morels in an herb butter sauce.
There are also a variety of fish dishes for the health conscious, among them the cold-poached salmon and a fillet of halibut. Along the same lines, but more of a trangression: the smoked Scotch salmon with herb marinated prawns in ginger butter and the pan-fried chicken with wild mushrooms, pine kernels and bacon.
If something is not on the menu, you need but ask. Following a long tradition, David Sharland, the maitre chef de cuisine, prides himself on meeting special requests.
The price for a lunch with appetizer, main course, one of those artery-clogging English desserts dripping with cream, a medium-priced bottle of wine and coffee will run 50 to 60 a person, about
K, excluding tip.
 
The Savoy Grill, The Savoy Hotel, The Strand, London. 44-71-836-4343. All major credit cards accepted.

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 31, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 2663 words

HEADLINE: CONSULTING;
Assignment: 90 Days on the Polish Front

BYLINE: By Joseph W. Karoly; Joseph W. Karoly is a retired RCA Corporation executive who resides in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

 BODY:
THERE I SAT ON THE morning of Jan. 5 in a Polonez sedan headed south from Warsaw. At the age of 63, retired from RCA, I had offered my services as a volunteer consultant to businesses in foreign countries. Now I found myself about to meet with the management of my first client, Polkolor, a company I was expected to help restructure over the next three months.
My briefcase contained a Polish-English dictionary and a handful of papers that Polkolor had sent me. But I had given up trying to make any sense of the papers, including some basic cost data and an organizational chart. The data were sparse. The chart, on the other hand, was huge - 26 pages - and it showed that the company employed 5,200 workers who were supervised by 400 managers, each with his or her own decision-making authority. So there I was, unable to speak the language, unfamiliar with the operations of the company, on my way to bring order to an organization that I suspected, even then, was in a state of considerable disarray.
The adventure had started with a phone call in August of last year from Peter W. Moyer, an executive recruiter at the International Executive Service Corps in Stamford, Conn. ''We are negotiating with a color television picture-tube manufacturer in Poland whose needs match up with your background,'' he said. ''Are you interested in hearing more?'' 
Shortly before retiring in 1987 as president of an RCA subsidiary in Sao Paulo, Brazil, I had sent my resume to I.E.S.C., a nonprofit organization that sends retired American executives to provide expertise to companies in developing nations as well as Central and Eastern Europe. My career at RCA - which I had joined in 1950, straight out of Seton Hall University - had included various financial and operating positions both at home and abroad.
Since leaving RCA, I had spent most of my days improving my golf handicap. But the offer from I.E.S.C. - in effect, to be part of the economic revolution sweeping Eastern Europe - was a challenge I could not resist. My wife, Ruth, was also part of the package. Her project was to put together a manual about Poland to help familiarize future I.E.S.C. volunteers and their spouses with the culture. (The fact that Ruth happens to be of Polish descent made her enthusiastic, but was of little practical value; she did not know a word of the language.) The Polkolor facility, 12 miles from Warsaw on the outskirts of the town of Piaseczno, is a sprawling complex of more than 1.3 million square feet, consisting of two plants - a glass factory and a tube-assembly factory. Polkolor is a fully integrated operation: sand for glass goes in one end, and a finished tube comes out the other.
About 75 percent of the tubes are sold within the Eastern bloc. The remainder are marketed in the West, principally to West Germany, and must therefore meet stricter standards of quality. Since the currencies of most Eastern European countries have not been convertible until recently, Western equipment has been unavailable, and Polkolor and other Eastern bloc countries have had a virtual monopoly. Polkolor has thus been selling everything it produced - a situation that has led to an emphasis on quantity rather than quality for its Eastern customers.
Those problems, and a host of others, were very much on the mind of Polkolor's general director, Jerzy Piotrowski, a bearded, bespectacled, thickset man of 44 years, who was waiting for me in his office that morning. Piotrowski introduced me to the other key people with whom I would be working: Andrzej Szweryn, the slim, energetic manager of the company's foreign-trade office, who was refreshingly outspoken about the problems facing Polkolor; Tadeusz Han, a boyish-looking fellow who had recently been appointed chief engineer, and Ermina Buballo, an affable woman who was the manager of the financial planning and analysis group. Although everyone in this meeting was more or less fluent in English, Buballo was one of the few people in the 135-person financial department - where I would be spending so much of my time - who spoke the language.
For the next hour, Piotrowski and the others talked, and I took notes. I was pleasantly surprised at their clear articulation of the issues. Only later did I learn that Piotrowski, Han and Buballo are enrolled in the equivalent of an M.B.A. program at Warsaw University; their exposure has made them aware that there is a better way to do business, and that they do not have the know-how to go it alone.
POLKOLOR HAD STARTED life in the fall of 1975, when RCA and Corning Glass Works signed turnkey agreements with the Polish Government to develop the capability to produce picture tubes for color televisions. Ground was then broken for the glass factory and the tube-assembly plant, and soon after production started in July of 1979, Polkolor was turned over to the state to run. Now, as Poland begins the transition to a free-market economy, the company will have to undergo radical changes to operate in this new environment.
During my meeting at Polkolor that January morning, we agreed I would work on two projects: restructuring the organization, which had grown like a weed because of the full-employment philosophy of the Communist regime, and recommending ways to improve productivity. I soon gathered, however, that Piotrowski, Han and Buballo also wanted me to design a cost-accounting system to measure costs at each stage of the manufacturing process. Up went my anxiety level - I had not been involved with cost accounting since the 1950's. But I took on the task.
Over the next three months, I worked on all the assignments concurrently. Polkolor provided me with a car and driver, and they appeared each morning at my home away from home, the Forum Hotel, a 31-story concrete building faced with gold tile in downtown Warsaw. The company also paid my expenses, including food and laundry as well as lodging, and gave me a spacious office near the general director's with a complicated phone I could never understand, let alone work.
POLKOLOR WAS A COMPANY grappling with change on many fronts. Until 1989, the manufacturer had one production line, with the capacity to turn out some 550,000 22-inch picture tubes annually. Last year, a second line was added to make 14-inch and 20-inch tubes, increasing output to more than 650,000. Meanwhile, inflation in Poland was soaring - since the start of 1989, raw materials costs had risen about 600 percent - and Polkolor had no system in place to identify and measure the impact of such spiraling costs.
That became only too clear during my first week, when I started reviewing Polkolor's financial system. The company had a reasonably accurate method of accounting for the total costs of all its tubes. But without a cost-accounting system, there was no way to determine the unit cost of one tube size, let alone three sizes. Thus Piotrowski and his managers were unable to calculate - and, ultimately, control - their costs at each stage of the production process.
Digging down into my memory, I was able to dredge up the details of the cost-accounting system I had used at RCA. During the next few months, I set up a comparable system and wrote a rough draft of a 14-page operating manual, with a great deal of assistance from Ruth, who was pressed into service to edit and type the document. The final version, translated into Polish by Ermina Buballo, included instructions for establishing a standard cost and for moving materials from one cost center to another. I also taught Buballo, and she in turn trained the financial and operating managers, how to work with the system. It is scheduled to be in place by the end of this month.
Inevitably, I had my share offrustrations. Working with Buballo, for instance, proved difficult at first, partly because her basic discipline was engineering and her knowledge of accounting quite limited. But she was also a habitual truant. I soon found that Buballo was not the only one. Appointments were not always kept, and there was a casual attitude toward deadlines.
I kept my cool with Buballo until early February, and then we had a confrontation. ''I'm really here to help you,'' I said. ''If you want to take advantage of that, you'll have to be more cooperative.'' Immediately, the situation improved. In her defense, and that of the other employees at Polkolor, the lack of dedication may have been a result of the Communist system, which guaranteed every citizen a job without regard to performance. In addition, the information gap about management and financial systems turned out to be much wider than I had imagined. The concepts I was trying to introduce were undoubtedly difficult for the Poles to comprehend, particularly when some of the words and ideas had no Polish equivalents. When I said I wanted to review cash flow, for example, a woman from the treasurer's department came to me and said, ''We don't pay in cash a lot. We mainly use checks.''
It took an inordinately long time to get answers to questions, particularly about accounting. With Buballo as translator, I would ask the person responsible for materials accounting, ''How do you keep track of the withdrawal of raw materials to each cost center?'' Frequently, the response would be, ''I don't have an answer, but I'll get back to you.'' When the answer finally came, an hour or so later, it would usually trigger another question, and the whole process would be repeated. On a good day, two questions might be answered to everyone's satisfaction.
In order to set up a restructuring plan, I had to identify where staff reductions could be made without affecting ongoing operations. This was no small task: Poland had achieved its full-employment goals by creating jobs, and 20 to 30 percent overstaffing was a fact of industrial life. Over several weeks, I saw every manager and reviewed his or her responsibilities. In early March, I offered Piotrowski some ideas for trimming staff.
WHEN I TURNED MY attention to assessing productivity, I became a frequent visitor to the factory, with its block-long furnaces for glass bonding and its miles of aging conveyor belts. Although the organization charts indicated that 30 foremen were assigned for each of four shifts, I could find no more than three on the floor at any one time. Where were the others? In their offices, I was told, calculating operators' wages - a task more appropriate for the accounting department.
I soon learned why there was so little incentive for foremen to supervise production. Operators were paid by the piece, generally earning $100 to $135 a month; foremen made only about $90.
Quality control was another problem. Since Polkolor was in the enviable position of selling everything it made - 1989 revenues were about $140 million - the company was under extreme pressure to crank out product. On one visit, I saw three unsupervised operators processing cracked glass panels. I told Piotrowski, and he responded by closing down all of the foremen's offices, thereby forcing them out onto the factory floor.
When I finished my manufacturing review, I made 10 specific recommendations, including the establishment of a preventive-maintenance program. At Polkolor, basic equipment was operated until it broke down; only then were repairs made. In addition, there was no centralized production planning, which led to frequent component shortages and wreaked havoc with monthly production schedules.
To address the issue of quality control, I suggested that foremen be paid more than operators and that operators, who would now be paid by the hour, participate in an incentive plan for achieving production quotas and quality standards. Such a plan has since been put into effect. The entire production team can now receive monthly bonuses ranging from 1 percent to 15 percent of their pay. Piotrowski reports that the tubes' quality has begun to improve across the board.
On paper, Polkolor was profitable, but reliable figures were sparse. The company issued only two financial reports. A monthly 14-line profit-and-loss statement was sent to Polkolor's bank as well as to the Government's Institute for Statistics. In addition, an annual balance sheet, audited by an accountant from the Treasury Department, was submitted to the bank.
Polkolor's managers needed more data to make effective day-to-day decisions, so I designed a series of internal forms to break out additional information: a profit-and-loss statement more fully identifying the major elements of cost; manufacturing cost-center reports highlighting the standard and actual costs of production and the company's variance against the standard, and tracking reports on expenses.
AT POLKOLOR, I FOUND AN active curiosity about the differences between the American and Polish systems, and a receptive climate for the changes I proposed. Yet, looking beyond this company, it seems to me that Poland has, at best, only a vague idea of what is required to shift gears. The Communist system had a cocoon effect, providing employment and subsidizing food and housing. Now the cocoon is gone: subsidies have been slashed and almost all food prices allowed to rise to market levels. In the process, unemployment has risen from almost zero to about 6 percent.
The pinch is about to be felt at Polkolor, too. In August I learned that Piotrowski, having weighed my suggestions for downsizing, is planning to dismiss some 500 employees, primarily engineers and middle managers - assuming he can get the necessary approval from the company's two unions, Solidarity and the Trade Union of Polkolor Employees.
At Polkolor, and throughout Poland, what traumas will be triggered by rising unemployment? How fast can overstaffing be addressed? And how long will it take before workers come to view their jobs not as their right, but as their responsibility? Poland wants to take a cold shower in capitalism, but the period of adjustment could last 10 years.
The country seems to be pinning much of its economic hopes on the recently enacted State Enterprise Privatization Act. Under the program, most state-run companies will be able to register to incorporate with the Ministry of Privatization. The Government will then become the corporation's sole shareholder and will sell its stock to Polish citizens. Given the undercapitalized state of Polish industry and the average worker's modest income, the plan could be in for some trouble.
The joint venture appears to be a better bet and may well become the major means to privatization. During my stay, Polkolor entered into discussions with a major Western European tube manufacturer, and I was asked to participate.
Right now, there are two main stumbling blocks to any joint venture in Poland. The first is the difficulty of assessing the economic benefits for a prospective partner because, at most Polish companies, financial data is scarce. The second is the existence of an Employees Council at every company. This elected body, whose 20 or so members represent all levels of the company, must approve the venture. (Employees Councils also have the authority to recommend dismissal of the chief executive.) Once a company goes private or is transformed into a joint venture, however, the legal requirement for an Employees Council disappears. Thus, slowly but surely, this vestige of the old regime is likely to vanish.
My assignment in Poland was more challenging and rewarding than I could have imagined. In some small way, I helped a company see the benefits of a free-enterprise system and provided some of the tools to enable it to participate. Polkolor has invited me to return later this year to review the company's progress. That may not happen, however, if the joint-venture discussions succeed, because Polkolor will then have full-time free-market expertise. And I will have to find another way to take part in the great adventure shaping up in Eastern Europe.
