HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
CITIES and the people who live in them did not find much to cheer about in the preliminary figures released recently by the United States Bureau of the Census. Around the nation, New York, Chicago, Philadelphia and nearly every other big city lost a lot of their population. Detroit fell below a million, about half what it was in the 1950's.
Closer to home, New Jersey's most urban county, Essex, dropped to 749,000 and was edged in total population by suburban Bergen County. Newark continued to hemorrhage, spilling more than 20 percent of its population, one of the biggest losses in the nation, and falling below 300,000 for the first time since the turn of the century. 
Census figures translate directly into state and Federal assistance dollars: the more people, the more money. So city officials view every dip in the census figures with alarm. The picture was bleak for Trenton, Camden, East Orange, Hoboken and just about every other major New Jersey city but one: Elizabeth.
Between 1980 and 1990, according to the Census Bureau's early count, Elizabeth actually grew, increasing to 108,637 from 106,201.
Granted that 2,436 people amount to a modest increase in a city the size of Elizabeth. But considering the state of cities today, that 2 percent rise represents a significant departure from several frustrating decades of urban retrenchment in New Jersey. And it offers a new view on the future of cities.
Analysts say Elizabeth picked up that increase without benefit of any large-scale new residential projects over the last decade. Rather, the old seaport city enjoyed an unusually successful and complete census count made possible by the same political, demographic and physical characteristics that have enabled Elizabeth to stay the course while other cities have foundered.
What sets Elizabeth most apart from other cities is its stability. It is a rare model of continuity in these instantly updated times. Thomas G. Dunn has been mayor since 1964. Downtown Elizabeth looks pretty much as it did 30 years ago because the city never went in much for urban renewal, pedestrian malls and other planning fads.
When the Singer Sewing Machine Company closed its big plant and other factories shut down, Elizabeth did not try to jump on the office space bandwagon with most other New Jersey municipalities. The city kept its middle-class sights on jobs of brawn rather than brain. The Singer complex became an industrial park.
Elizabeth builds warehouses, not atriums. It focuses on fixing up solid old houses instead of tearing them down to build flimsy new ones, and is sometimes called the aluminum siding capital of New Jersey. Trucks and trains not BMW's still course through Elizabeth's streets. In short, Elizabeth did not forget that it was a city. And, based on the census figures, neither did the city's residents, those who on a typical September afternoon fill the sidewalks on Broad Street or put the finishing touches to a new coat of paint on a Tudor-style single-family house in the Elmora section.
''What it boils down to after all the hoopla,'' said Neil De Haan, director of Elizabeth's Department of Community Development, ''is livability.''
That is not to suggest that Elizabeth has managed to solve all the problems that plague its larger sister to the north, Newark. Elizabethport, the tough section of town on the city's Arthur Kill waterfront, still looks battered and bruised. The downtown movie theaters have fled. Some areas around the train station look as bad as the worst parts of Newark and Camden.
But in the main Elizabeth remains solid, perhaps surprisingly so considering that it has always been a working-class town that never could afford the best of anything. James W. Hughes, a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University, believes that Elizabeth stands out from the rest of New Jersey's cities because it remained essentially a low-rise community, a city with lawns and two-family houses too small to attract speculators.The owners lived in them and kept an eye on who went in and out.
Mr. Hughes attributes Elizabeth's good fortunes to its political stability, its comparatively human scale and its stodgy character that kept it from chasing grand urban renewal schemes that tore the heart out of many other cities.
He also points out that Elizabeth came out of the census a winner because it took the census count far more seriously than did other cities.
Elizabeth officials started working on the census months before the census takers showed up. Eleanor G. Tevnan, a member of the Community Development staff, was relieved of her normal duties and assigned to coordinate census activities full-time from March till the day earlier this month when the city returned its local review forms to the Census Bureau.
Elizabeth built on its natural advantages as a compact, low-rise city. Most of its housing units are single-family houses or small two-family dwellings. Even its public housing projects, which rarely exceed five floors, seem less intimidating to enumerators than the big projects in other cities.
Still, Elizabeth worked to make sure the enumerators knew their way around the city. Office space for the census takers was set up in two locations, and they were well briefed on the city's neighborhoods. A local bank sponsored a wine and cheese gathering for community groups and the clergy at the Cedars restaurant on North Avenue in March to lay out the importance of cooperating with the census takers.
As the census itself drew closer, a decorated van wiggled through the streets blaring lambada music and repeating a recorded message, in Spanish and English, saying that it is very important to be counted.
Elizabeth built on its natural advantages over larger cities. The city did not stop after the census was actually taken on April 1. When preliminary figures were released last month and sent to each of the state's 567 municipalities, many local officials were unable to find the time to check their accuracy or file a documented challenge.
Elizabeth, even though it was sitting comfortably with a 2 percent increase and a solid lock on fourth place among New Jersey's 10 largest municipalities, established a special census task force to comb tax and zoning records and go back out on the streets to follow up the Census Bureau's count.
The team came back with proof that the census missed 1,321 housing units all together and had undercounted the number of people living in several hundred additional residences.
In all, the city claimed an additional 10,000 people, which would bring the 1990 population to 118,000, give or take a few hundred, and add to Elizabeth's reputation as New Jersey's most stable city.

HEADLINE: Bus Garage To Incinerator: An Itinerary For Russians

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
THE day's agenda - visiting a bus garage and sewer treatment plant in Yonkers and a garbage incinerator in Peekskill - would not have thrilled most visitors to Westchester County. But for a delegation of 14 mayors from the Soviet Union who were spending two weeks in the United States, it was close to perfect.
Propelled by the economic reforms of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's perestroika program, which seeks to restructure the central-command economy of Communism and move the nation into the free market, the mayors were here for a crash course in capitalism.
They came not from places like Moscow or Leningrad, but from Krasnodar, an agricultural center near the Black Sea, from Chelyabinsk and Tyumen in Siberia and from Magnitogorsk on the eastern slope of the Ural Mountains.
As tourists, they visited New York City, Pittsburgh and Washington. But their technical research was done in places like Newark, Yonkers and Canton and Wooster, Ohio. 
When they arrived in Westchester earlier this month, on the last full day of their trip, the mayors showed that they had done their homework. Some of their questions were pointed; others subtle. For example, they sought to learn how profits were determined when the government hired a private company to operate a public service like the county bus system, the airport or the Peekskill incinerator.
They wanted to know why the private sector was able to operate more economically than the public sector when in both instances the majority of employees were unionized. The answer, essentially, was that it was much more difficult to remove unsuitable government employees, who also have Civil Service protection, than to shed private employees.
 
How Long It Takes to Dismiss an Employee
One of the mayors' hosts in Westchester, former County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, told them: ''A private company can fire an employee if he doesn't perform or if he does something wrong, while in the government, even if he does something wrong, it takes two years to get him out of the government. The result is a loss of efficiency and a less productive work force.''
The Deputy County Executive, Roger Biagi, said, ''The motive for cost-containment is greater in the private sector, where they chase the buck, than in the public sector.'' The mayors evidently had no problem understanding the phrase, ''chase the buck,'' but one asked, ''What about defense contractors?''
The scene was a conference room at Liberty Lines, the bus company that has been operating the county system for two decades - ever since, as the company president, Arthur Bernacchia, put it - ''We were able to demonstrate that we could provide the service for 30 to 50 percent less than governments had done.''
The question about defense contractors and the high cost of military hardware led to a brief but spirited exchange about monopolies.
Edward Dubrovsky, who immigrated to the United States from the Soviet Union in 1980 and who runs a trading company in Brooklyn, served as translator. Mr. Dubrovsky, who also works as a consultant on East-West trade, planned the itinerary for the trip and traveled with the group.
 
The Importance of Watching
A mayor asked if Westchester County might not be vulnerable to similar abuse in dealing with Liberty. ''Yes,'' Mr. Biagi said, ''if we didn't watch them.'' Another mayor fired a comment at Mr. Dubrovsky, who directed it to Mr. Biagi, in English. ''But the U.S. Government is watching the defense contractors, too.'' Mr. Biagi said Westchester's scrutiny was more effective. The next question brought laughter. ''You think you are a better government?''
Mr. Biagi replied: ''Yes, and I'll tell you why. We have a five-year contract with Liberty and we watch very carefully. If we are not satisfied in the fourth year, we start a process of finding someone else.'' He also spoke of the bus service as a ''manageable scale of operations.''
Mr. Dubrovsky explained that, ''The issue is very important for Russia, because now there are only Government companies.'' ''If they privatize them, where is the protection?'' he asked. The question was drowned out in a chorus of replies.
 
'You Must Have Competition'
''You must have competition, such as you don't have in the defense system,'' Mr. DelBello said. But is there not design competition, one mayor asked. ''Yes, but after that there's no competition,'' Mr. DelBello said. ''Once they decide on an F-16, for example, the product is made by only one company. If the government spends $10 billion and a company hasn't completed its contract, the government is either out $10 billion or it's got to give the company more money to complete it.''
Mr. Dubrovsky's observation was blunt: ''So there's no difference. Private or government, there's still abuse.'' The daylong exchanges began at the trash-to-energy plant at Charles Point in Peekskill, a spit of land jutting into the Hudson River that now includes an industrial park. It is owned and operated by Wheelabrator Technologies of Hampton, N.H., and is one of 14 such plants in the United States.
 
Soviet Envy in Peekskill
The Soviet delegation was envious of the system, which turns most of the county's household garbage into electricity, at the rate of 60 megawatts per hour - enough to supply 40,000 homes. For agreeing that the plant could be built within its borders, the City of Peekskill collects about $4 million a year from Wheelabrator. It shares the money with two school districts, and residents also receive small discounts on their electric bills.
The plant's general manager, Bob Hensel, stood before a lighted diagram that demonstrated how 2,250 tons of garbage arrived each day in 150 to 200 trucks, 90 of them huge tractor-trailers from five county-operated and two commercial carter-operated transfer stations.
The trash is dumped into an 8,000-ton pit. From there enormous grapples that hold 3,000 pounds dump the trash into three boilers where it begins the conversion to steam and, finally, electricity.
One boiler is taken out of service for maintenance for 5 to 10 days every 16 weeks. Mr. Hensel said the longest period of unscheduled maintenance was 48 hours. The residue from the incinerator consists of metals - ''about 13,000 tons a year,'' Mr. Hensel said - which are sold to scrap dealers, and ash, which is buried.
 
What About Rodents?
Mikail S. Karakai, the Mayor of Krasnodar - his full title is chairman of the executive committee of the Krasnodar City Council of Peoples Deputies - said that in his city, which has a population of 600,000, ''garbage is taken to an area and kept there.'' His description of the area made clear that it was a landfill similar to that used by Westchester until 1984, when the Peekskill plant opened.
Landfills represent a growing problem for major Soviet cities because appropriate space for them is dwindling. Mr. Hensel was asked how he handled the problem of rodents. He said there was no rodent problem because the garbage was delivered to transfer stations or to the Peekskill plant the same day it was collected from households.
Mayor Karakai, a power plant engineer by training, wanted to know how residents reacted to the plant, how close it was to private homes and how plant officials dealt with complaints about it. ''It is now the first time we are asking people, 'What is your opinion?' '' he said.
''I can see we must first assure our people it is safe, then build it,'' he said. ''We can do it only after much explanation.''
Mayor Karakai thought for a moment and then sought to place the entire trip into a wider perspective. ''We have to use this knowledge,'' he said, ''to lift the level of our cities, and our people.''
 
Farms and Firefighters
Mr. Dubrovsky's itinerary, which included cities roughly the size of those represented by the Soviet visitors, was concentrated in Ohio. There, the visitors were taken through steel mills, including one now owned by the workers, to farms, wildlife centers, hospitals, shops, city halls, and police and fire departments.
''They were shown how a volunteer fire department works,'' Mr. Dubrovsky said, noting that no such system operates as efficiently in the Soviet Union. ''They timed an alarm; it took three minutes for the volunteers to get to the firehouse and drive the trucks out, and a few more minutes to get there.''
The firefighters ''burned two automobiles as part of the demonstration,'' he said, ''and they demonstrated a tool to get people out of a car.''
The Soviet visitors ''were impressed with everything, but especially with the quality and quantity of food in the stores,'' Mr. Dubrovbsky said.
Mayor Karakai, who speaks English, drove with Mr. DelBello from one site to another on the Westchester tour. ''He could not say enough nice things about the openness of American people and the nation's highways,'' Mr. Delbello said later.
Mr. Dubrovsky said the most unforgettable moment for some was a high school football game in Canton. ''Your local football is a big event,'' he said, ''a celebration, with every citizen, everybody, at the stadium - the bands, the music, the cheerleaders - it's a joy.''
 
A Theft in Manhattan
But there were also some sour moments. The group's van was broken into in Manhattan, and some money, gifts and passports were stolen. ''We went to the Sixth Precinct, another experience, and learned that such crimes are so common it was hard to get anybody to listen,'' Mr. Dubrovsky said.
''But the people,'' he went on. ''After so many years of brainwashing in the Soviet Union these city officials come over here and discover that Americans don't think about war with Russia after all. They would invite us to their homes, and they want to visit the Soviet cities.
''Even when they didn't know it was a Soviet delegation, when our van got lost, they would say 'follow me' and lead us in the right direction.''
On their final night in the United States, Mr. Dubrovsky took his charges to the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn where many Russian immigrants have settled, and to the Odessa Restaurant there.
''That was like being home,'' he said. ''Russian songs, Russian food, Russian everything.'' The next morning they were on their way home, in some cases to street protests, food and tobacco shortages and the political uncertainties they had left only two weeks earlier.

LENGTH: 1515 words

HEADLINE: When Mothers And Infants Are Addicts

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: VALHALLA

 BODY:
A WOMAN from White Plains was nearing the time to deliver her child when doctors monitoring her condition at the Westchester County Medical Center here noticed a sudden drop in the fetal heart rate and performed an emergency Caesarean section.
Baby Alexis, now 17 days old, is doing well, considering that she was born addicted to crack, the deadly cocaine derivative. She breathes normally and no longer suffers from diarrhea and vomiting. She has stopped screaming through the night, calmed by Peragoric, a mixture of alcohol and opium, and by tight swaddling, which soothes her constant tremors.
Alexis is one of a growing number of crack-addicted infants being cared for at the Regional Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at the Medical Center. Opened eight years ago to provide the latest in medical advances to high-risk babies born in the Hudson Valley region, the neonatal center has become a new battleground in the war against drug addiction. 
Doctors at the center fighting to save these babies have taken on an unexpected and formidable group of opponents: the mothers themselves. Many crack-addicted women, doctors say, are deliberately using a combination of lethal drugs to spontaneously abort an unwanted fetus. The mothers are frequently successful, but when they are not, their addicted babies end up in the neonatal center.
Some of these women leave the Medical Center alone, abandoning their newborns to the county's already overburdened foster-care system. But a growing number are being persuaded to keep and care for their addicted infants and to try to kick their own habit with the help of Dr. Stephen Piazza, assistant neonatalogist and director of the center's Follow-Up Clinic for Substance-Abused Infants.
''I believe in what I am doing,'' Dr. Piazza said. He encourages mothers to enter separate programs to treat their own addiction. ''I have a lot of success stories, where mothers are in 'detox' programs,'' he said, ''and others who come in wearing little chains that say 'I am nine months clean.' ''
 
'If Someone Will Work With Them, It Will Work'
Although a small percentage of his clients fail, and lose their children to the foster-care system, Dr. Piazza said: ''I have enough who are still taking care of their babies nine months down the line. I know if someone will work with them, it will work.''
For the last four years, Dr. Piazza's work has been supported by annual grants of $20,000 to $30,000 from the State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities. The grants allow him to run the Follow-Up Clinic, which was described by Dr. Harry S. Dweck, director of the neonatal unit and professor of pediatrics at New York Medical College, as the most important factor in keeping mother and child together.
Caring for an infant in the neonatal center costs $1,000 a day, Dr. Dweck said, and crack-addicted newborns remain in the unit from four days to two months.
Although he said he was concerned about the costs, Dr. Dweck added, ''Our function is not to police drug dealing, but to care for these kids - to make sure when they are born and when they are discharged, we have done what is necessary to allow them to live as normal a life as possible.''
Many of his patients, Dr. Piazza said, are prostitutes. ''They are selling their body to get crack, and they are so high they don't realize what they are doing,'' he said. ''Then they take extra doses to get rid of the kid.'' Other crack-addicted women, like Alexis's mother, want their babies, but are unable to stop taking drugs during their pregnancy, he said.
The neonatal center receives at least one crack-addicted newborn a day. Some were carried to term; others were born prematurely. When he first came to the Medical Center six years ago, Dr. Piazza said, he saw an average of one addicted infant each month. Now from three to eight of the 3o infants in the unit at any one time suffer from drug addiction, he said. Most experience withdrawal from the various drugs their mothers abused, which almost always include crack.
Few women realize the effect crack can have on their fetuses, Dr. Piazza said, adding that it is far more damaging than other drugs because it is a pure form of cocaine and once it enters the system of a fetus, it stays there.
If a pregnant woman takes as little as one hit of crack and never uses the drug again, Dr. Piazza said, her fetus can be damaged. Cocaine reaches the baby through the mother's placenta, where it is transformed into a fat-soluble substance too heavy to return through the placenta to the mother's body, he said. The placenta, in effect, becomes a one-way valve.
''The drug just comes in but it won't come out,'' Dr. Piazza said. ''It stays in the baby's system, constantly recirculating, and the infant keeps getting high, high, high.''
The effects can be numerous and long lasting. Infants usually withdraw from other drugs within 72 hours, but crack withdrawal does not usually begin until the baby is about eight weeks old. And the process can continue for two years.
''Crack babies sweat a lot even if they are not hot,'' Dr. Piazza said. ''They are foul smelling, and a mother will often tell me her baby sounds like he is snorting, like he always has a cold.''
The babies suffer from constant fine tremors and irritability, especially when stimulated by the sound of a telephone ringing, a radio or a light being turned on. ''I have mothers who say, 'Oh, Steve, my baby is so smart; at one month he is already standing up,' '' Dr. Piazza said. ''The truth is these infants are so stiff they cannot be bent.''
 
'It Makes You Angry'
While making his rounds one day, Dr. Dweck said, he saw a baby who was constantly in motion, even when sleeping. ''We couldn't get this kid to gain weight,'' he said. ''It makes you angry.''
Pregnant women who take drugs, Dr. Dweck said, are committing ''the most hostile act that can be done to the most passive victim.''
The problem crosses economic lines, Dr. Piazza said, adding that the mothers of more than half of the 77 infants he treated in the Follow-Up Clinic in one recent two-month period were middle-class women, some with college degrees. ''I have a couple of Wall Street stockbrokers, one veterinarian and two elementary school teachers,'' Dr. Piazza said. ''One woman comes in her Mercedes with a nanny to watch the child.'' Although those women can afford private care, they come to the clinic because few physicians in private practice want to deal with the problems of crack-addicted children, Dr. Piazza said. Doctors are unwilling to treat crack-addicted pregnant women, he said, because there is no antidote for the drug and they are concerned about the possible liability associated with the almost certain complications of pregnancy.
 
A New Program in White Plains
Four months ago, an outpatient program called ''Generations'' opened in White Plains. It offers a complete evaluation, counseling and treatment program for up to 15 addicted mothers and their infants. Thought to be the first such comprehensive program in the state, Generations is an attempt to help crack-addicted mothers and their infants survive and succeed together.
Women are referred to Generations by the Medical Center and by Child Protective Services, a division of the Westchester County Department of Social Services. They are told that completing the program, which takes a year to 18 months, is the only way to avoid having their children placed in the foster-care system.
One-third of the 30 women referred to the program are currently enrolled, said Ann-Marie Trotta, its director. ''These women don't want to lose their babies,'' Mrs. Trotta said, ''but they have a very, very hard time.''
Still, she is optimistic about the program's goals. ''We are the first group they have trusted enough to follow the treatment plan,'' she said. ''We have at least got these women to look at their addiction.''
 
A Difficult Task
Keeping women with a history of substance abuse together with their often-damaged children is a difficult task, medical experts and social service professionals agree, and they predict more crack-addicted infants will enter the foster-care system.
M. Annette Myers, the assistant commissioner with the Westchester County Department of Social Services, who oversees the foster-care program, said that of the 129 children under the age of 2 who entered the program during one recent 17-month period, 52 showed positive signs of crack or cocaine addiction. The results of the tests, done at the discretion of physicians, represent a ''guesstimate,'' she said, adding, ''I'm concerned about the cases we don't know about.''
Dr. Piazza is concerned about the future of the infants he sees. ''Crack babies are just entering school, and we really don't know what will happen to them,'' he said. ''We are sitting on a time bomb. We are waiting for the learning disabilities, we are waiting for the psychosocial problems and we are waiting to see how these parents react when their children don't perform well in school.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 45, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 820 words

HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
The Conscience of the Campus

BYLINE: By NANCY S. DYE; Nancy S. Dye is dean of the faculty and a professor of history at Vassar College.

 BODY:

UNIVERSITIES AND THE FUTURE OF AMERICA
By Derek Bok.
135 pp. Durham, N.C.:
Duke University Press. $14.95.
EARLY in ''Universities and the Future of America,'' Derek Bok, the president of Harvard University, poses two related questions: Are American universities doing enough to help the United States confront its domestic crises, like declining productivity, intractable poverty and rising rates of illiteracy? And is the academy doing all that it can to strengthen Americans' ethical awareness and sense of social responsibility? His answer to both questions is no. 
In these essays, originally delivered in 1988 as the Sanford Lectures at Duke University, Mr. Bok reflects on why this is so and offers some proposals for change. If universities are to address the root causes of declining productivity, he believes, they must rdirect their research and educational priorities. And if they are to produce socially engaged citizens, they must embrace moral education.
Since Woirld War II, American universities have put far more effort into developing semiconductors that into understanding the causes of homelessness. The reason, Mr. Bok says, is because outside resources like Federal grants and contracts are readily available for scientific research, and because science carries high prestige within the academy. There has been a good fit between what society has defined as critical to its prosperity and security and what academics have wanted to investigate. Yet Mr. Bok insists that universities, along with the foundations, corporations and Government agencies that fund them, must recognize that scientific research alone cannot make American business and industry more competitive.
Business schools could do more to enhance knowledge of selling abroad and of managing technology. They could insist that students learn foreign languages and acquire a familiarity with other cultures. Engineering faculties could strengthen programs in manufacturing and design rather than emphasizing the discovery of new products.
Mr. Bok also observes that the problems underlying our current social malaise do not generally attract much outside funding, or score high on any scale of academic prestige, and he says that if universities are to respond imaginatively to social needs, they must develop programs of instruction independent of what society chooses to pay for. Universities could allocate generous resources to their colleges of law, education, social work andpublic administration, for instance, to undertake research on social ills like poverty and adult illiteracy.
For a university president to call on the academy to match its goals to the needs of the larger community (or for higher education to respond affirmatively to such a call) is not unusual in our history. The United States has a particularly rich tradition in this regard, most notably in its land-grant and public urban universities. Mr. Bok's book links this progressive tradition with the complex realities of the postwar research university.
But questions arise. Take poverty research, for example. There has been a considerable amount of work on poverty. Too much of it has been ignored. Are additional initiatives called for, or do policy makers need to pay more attention to the findings already available?
Then, too, large-scale research can divert faculty and resources from core educational programs. At a time when many universities are finding it increasingly difficult, with the resources available to them, to provide the best possible educational opportunities to their students, should they bear the primary responsibility for research in such areas as economic productivity, which directly benefits business and industry?
The second reform Mr. Bok proposes in this book involves fostering student's moral development and sense of social responsibility through courses in applied ethics, programs. of community service, clear codes of conduct and high ethical standards for university decision making. Indeed, there are signs that this is already happening. New interest in community service and civic education is apparent on many campuses. REcent publicity about campus racial conflict has often obscured a more positive development: that college campuses are quite possibly themose diverse communities in the United States, and that many are making concerted efforts to create institutions and curriculums that respect and enhance the pluralism of American culture.
''Universities and the Future of America,'' although critical of higher education, exudes confidence in the universities' achievements and their potential - confidence that sets it apart from the spate of jeremiads that have appeared over the past few years. It is also timely. As the cold war ends, Mr. Bok's vision of socially relevant education and research ought to be taken seriously by raders both inside and outside the academy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Gt. Barrington, Mass.;
Renovation For '05 Theater

BYLINE: By JOHN A. TOWNES

 BODY:
 Several residents formed a nonprofit Save the Mahaiwe group and local officials created a special historic district, a move unanimously adopted by voters at the 1989 Town Meeting. Formal approval now is needed before the theater can be demolished or converted.
Then, this summer, Hoyts announced it had decided not to sell the theater. It had been making a profit and its operating costs were low because Hoyts owns the building, according to Morris Englander, chief executive officer of its American operations, based in Boston. 
The Mahaiwe opened in 1905 as an ornate, 750-seat vaudeville theater and it later became a movie house. It had deteriorated by the mid-70's, but has been gradually upgraded since then by its manager, Albert Schwartz. Since he restored the stage seven years ago, the theater has also been used for concerts, plays and other live productions.
Hoyts expects to spend $70,000 to $100,000 to repair the roof and heating system, paint the interior, install new carpeting, add about 200 seats and put in a mechanical "flying screen" to allow rapid changeover from movies to the stage.
Great Barrington is the largest Berkshire County town south of Pittsfield. It and the surrounding region attract vacation homeowners, tourists and new residents from large cities.
In the last decade, Railroad Street has changed from "a dingy side street into an upscale retail anchor" while Main Street has become more oriented to professional offices and retail uses, according to Richard MacDonald, sales manager at the local Apple Hill Realty. Although the economy has slowed, he added, "we're somewhat insulated from New England's problems by the proximity to New York dollars."
The Mahaiwe historic district was originally to have included the entire downtown area, but several property owners objected. Officials then narrowed the boundaries to a portion of the block around the theater, including the town hall and several nearby properties.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: CHARLES J. DUFFY;
Small Towns Have Big Problems, Too

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
CHARLES J. DUFFY is the executive director of the Council of Small Towns, an organization formed in the late 1970's to lobby for the interests of rural and suburban municipalities in Connecticut.
A native of Joplin, Mo., Mr. Duffy, 44 years old, graduated from Georgetown University School of Foreign Service, and in 1968 came to Connecticut to teach at Yale. He taught until 1973, when he became director of the Middlesex County Development Council. In 1975 he was appointed deputy director of what is now known as the State Department of Economic Development. He spent one year as Undersecretary of Employment and Training at the State Office of Policy and Management and in 1980 was appointed head of the Connecticut Retail Merchants Association.
In 1986 he left to become a lobbyist, and in 1987 formed his current company, Duffy-Stover, with Keith Stover as partner. That same year, he was appointed director of the council (a part-time job), the lobbying firm's most prominent client. The council has an annual budget of about $50,000, and about 70 of the state's 169 towns as members. 
In an interview at his office in Hartford, Mr. Duffy talked about the concerns of small towns. Here are excerpts from the conversation.
Q. With a three-way gubernatorial race this year and 38 percent of the vote considered enough for a victory, the candidates' strategy so far seems to focus on the major cities. Is there any concern that small towns will be overlooked in the rush to woo urban areas?
A. No, I don't think so, for a lot of reasons. One is the Democratic convention, because there was some competition there, which involved both candidates going out and speaking to a lot of people, including people from small towns, seeking support, so the small towns have already been heard. On the Republican side, the suburbs and smaller towns in many cases are controlled by Republican officials, and they make up the bulk of the Republican Party interests in the state.
Weicker, because of the nature of his independent campaign, has got to seek out everybody. So I don't think the campaign itself will have an effect on the big town versus small town interests. What will have an effect, is the state's general financial condition, and the problems that are going to have to be faced by whoever is elected. That is where the potential for problems exists with respect to small towns.
Q. What kind of problems?
A. One of the things that could affect them negatively in comparison with big towns is the adjustment of the formulas, like aid to education or town road aid. Sometimes when you have limited resources, this rich versus poor, small versus big, issue arises. But in Connecticut, small doesn't necessarily mean rich, and big doesn't necessarily mean poor.
We have a number of small, poor towns in Connecticut: Sterling and Voluntown, for instance. They've got very little tax base to draw on, and they are extremely vulnerable to recession. Back in 1975, when I started in economic development, those were towns that had 15 and 20 percent unemployment rates, and I think it's not inconceivable we could reach that point again in the next year and a half.
Q. Are small towns typically Republican, or Democratic?
A. Well, in the Hartford area, there's a trend in general to elect Republicans. Most of the councils have gone in the last couple of years from Democratic to Republican. But there are a lot of Democratic chief elected officials in small towns. One of the things I've found in small towns is the political party label doesn't mean much. It doesn't mean what it means in a statewide election. I live in Deep River, I'm a member of the Democratic Town Committee, and I have served as chairman of our Board of Education, and so on. But the Democratic Town Committee in Deep River is a very conservative group of people. And that is true in a lot of places. The party label really, for local politics, doesn't mean what it means in a statewide basis at all.
Q. William J. Cibes Jr. drew almost all his support at the Democratic convention from small towns yet won enough votes to force a primary that divided the party for two months. If they are conservative, why did they support such a liberal candidate?
A. Facing a $900 million budget deficit, if the state doesn't have the money, what is it going to do? It's going to cut the budget. And a major part of the budget is state aid to municipalities, particularly aid to local education, and most elected officials are concerned about that. They believe, like I believe, that every dollar reduction in state aid is a dollar increase in local property tax. My sense of the reason Bill got a lot of support from local officials is they liked what he was saying about tax reform. I think he was addressing that very directly and specifically. Plus, he had been doing a lot of road shows prior to getting into the race. He had been to a lot of the small-town Democratic Town Committees or local elected official meetings.
Q. Is that support going to force candidates to look again at small towns? Can small towns coalesce again around a particular candidate in the general election?
A. I don't think so. You've got small-town people like Doug Cutler, the First Selectman of Woodstock, supporting Lowell Weicker, you've got small-town officials supporting Bruce Morrison, you've got a number of them supporting John Rowland, strong local leaders like Bob Chatfield from Prospect. There are tons of different reasons for people to support different candidates.
Q. Is aid to small towns the major issue for small towns this year?
A. There's no question about it.
Q. Are there any others?
A. There are several, but all related. One of the other problems towns have is the things they are required to do, the mandates. Binding arbitration has been the lightning rod of state-mandated local government spending. There are lots of other examples: environmental protection, building officials, all kinds of things. I don't think it's so much the towns disagree with the need for spending in any particular area, but the thing they resent is the state saying they are going to take out of towns' hands the control over spending.
That's O.K. if the state increases its share, but if you look ahead and see that's not going to continue, you say: ''Well, you've got to un-mandate some things, you've got to give us more control. If we're going to raise our property taxes to pay for teacher salaries we want more control over the process.''
Q. Do small towns have different types of problems from large towns?
A. Certainly. About half the general assistance caseload in the state of Connecticut lives in Hartford. Hartford has an extraordinary problem with poor people. That's not a problem Deep River has, relatively. But the need to have the state pay for the reconstruction and repair and rehabilitation of highways is relatively more important to Deep River and Essex and northwestern Connecticut than it is to the city of Hartford.
Q. Are there problems where towns and cities get together?
A. Everybody has a problem with education costs. The state this year for the first time has not been able to meet its commitment, has been sliding back from the goal of paying half the cost of local education. Those are issues the big and small towns won't divide on. And there are regional issues, such as transportation problems, bus and rail, that face the Fairfield County towns, small and large.
Q. Do any towns belong to both COST and the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities?
A. Sure, as a matter of fact, John Blaschik, the First Selectman of East Haddam, is chairman of COST and on the board of CCM. George Hill, the Mayor of Mansfield, is on both boards.
Q. Then what's the reason for two organizations representing municipalities?
A. COST came together because the legislature wasn't paying attention to small town issues. The feeling was then we needed some organization that would pick four of five things each year and pound away on them. Two years ago we went back to the organization and said look, this organization has been around for 10 years: Do you want to change the purpose? Do you want to do more programs for members? The membership put together a committee to examine the organization and decide what it should be doing.
The decision was COST is important, and it should do more, which meant doubling the dues of the association. We got some new people in, and some people who had been critics have become very involved, both active and critical, moving the organization forward.
Q. Did you lose any towns because of the growth during the mid-1980s?
A. We didn't lose them because of that growth, and we didn't lose them when we raised the dues, but we did lose some this year because of their budget problems. They told us when they were laying off teachers they couldn't justify the dues.
Q. Are any of COST's accomplishments particularly noteworthy?
A. Some of our members say the organization was totally responsible for the fact the state funds local road projects, provides $30 million a year for that. Some of the rational conclusions to some of these housing issues have been attributable to COST, and I don't mean keeping things from happening. We were an integral part of the affordable housing appeals legislation. Another is the siting of ash landfills. When I first started with COST, the legislature had a proposal I thought was very unfavorable to towns, and we got together and generated the principles that were embodied in the law that passed in 1988.

GRAPHIC: Photo; Charles J. Duffy, head of the Council of Small Towns (Dave LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
IRAQIS THREATEN TO ATTACK SAUDIS AND ISRAELIS IF NATION IS 'STRANGLED' BY EMBARGO

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 23

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq threatened today to attack oilfields in Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries and to use force against Israel if Iraq was ''strangled'' by the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations.
After meeting with Iraq's other top leaders in Baghdad, Mr. Hussein had a bellicose statement issued in the name of the Revolutionary Command Council that appeared to bring the possibility of war in the Persian Gulf a step closer, Western diplomats said.
In previous pronouncements since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, Mr. Hussein has spoken of striking at Saudi oilfields and at Israel in response to any American attack on Iraq. This time he appeared to be saying that Iraq might mount a pre-emptive strike, though he did not say whether it could come through military or terrorist action.
 
Says It Will Prevail
Iraq also declared today that it was ready for any strike mounted by the United States, and that it would prevail in an ensuing conflict. 
But the statement, read over Baghdad radio and television, centered on the effect of the trade embargo that has cut off all but a small proportion of Iraq's trade, including food imports that had met more than 70 percent of the country's requirements. [Excerpts, page A12.] Blaming the United States for the sanctions, the Iraqi leaders said the penalties had been imposed ''in a way that exceeds all humanitarian limits'' and that was cruel even by the standards of those who ''believe in the law of the jungle''.
 
A Vow to Strangle 'the Cause'
''We will never allow anybody, whoever he may be, to strangle the people of Iraq without having himself strangled,'' the leaders warned. ''If we feel that the Iraqi people are being strangled, that there are some who will deal a sanguinary blow to it, we will strangle all those who are the cause of this.''
''The oil areas in Saudi Arabia and in other states of the region, all the oil installations, will be rendered incapable of responding to the needs of those who came to us as occupiers in order to usurp our sovereignty, dignity and wealth,'' the statement said.
It added, ''Israel will be affected in all actions that affect the owners of the homeland'' - meaning Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Hussein alluded to the possibility of pre-emptive strikes more than once. The statement said that anyone threatening Iraq should be warned that ''We will turn the whole area, including the oilfields, into flames,'' adding:
''Those who wish the flood to overtake the Iraqi people and the nation, and are planning for this, should remember well that the waves of the flood will overwhelm them before they overwhelm the Iraqi people.''
 
More Militant Tone
After a flurry of actions last month that seemed to be aimed at easing tensions, including the release of many foreign women and children among the 11,000 Westerners then trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, Mr. Hussein has turned lately to increasingly militant words and actions.
The statement today reinforced the impression that the 53-year-old Iraqi leader is implacably opposed to any compromise that would avert the threat of war between Iraq and the alliance massed against it. The United States, several Western European nations, Saudi Arabia and other countries have joined in confronting Iraq by stationing troops in Saudi Arabia and in the Persian Gulf.
An announcer in a dark suit read the statement on Baghdad television this evening. Before the statement was broadcast, Mr. Hussein was shown smiling broadly as he convened a joint meeting of the Revolutionary Command Council and top leaders of the governing Baath Party who authorized the statement. The 17 officials wore military-style uniforms and were seated at a rectangular conference table.
 
Location of Session Unknown
The report did not say where the meeting was held. Reports circulating recently in Baghdad have suggested that Mr. Hussein moves frequently from one site to another in a motorcade of identical Mercedes-Benzes.
In the tape shown on television, Mr. Hussein appeared to be reading a statement to the leaders, and the document issued later reflected the polemical style of his speeches. The statement described Iraq's occupation and decision to annex Kuwait as an Iraqi province as ''an eternal decision from which there can be no retreat under any circumstances or conditions.''
Those who have condemned Iraq and sent forces to confront it were described as ''poisonous wasps,'' ''evil-doers'' and ''back-stabbers.'' Even King Hussein of Jordan, who has sought to mediate between Baghdad and those demanding the country's withdrawal from Kuwait, was bluntly told that any search for a face-saving Iraqi exit was a waste of time.
The statement said that ''Arabs who are launching good offices'' served the ''tactics of the enemies and their supporters'' by implying that Iraq could be assuaged. Such efforts push aside the ''major issues'' raised by Iraq, Baghdad asserted, and substitute ''minor issues'' as part of a proposed settlement.
 
Jordan's Proposal
King Hussein of Jordan, who has argued for an ''Arab solution'' since the crisis began, recently proposed that an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait be predicated on a pledge that territorial and other disputes be open to negotiation at a later stage.
But the Iraqi leaders said today in their statement that their ''prime objective'' remained ''the liberation of Palestine from the usurpation of the Zionist usurpers.'' Their remarks turned the clock back to a proposal put forward by Mr. Hussein on Aug. 12, just 10 days after the invasion, when he linked any Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to an Israeli withdrawal from occupied territory.
The Iraqi statement reiterated Mr. Hussein's formula for a settlement, which calls for the withdrawal from the region of all ''foreign forces,'' including those sent by the United States, after which the issues raised by Iraq's takeover of Kuwait could be discussed among Arab nations.
''In order to avoid war, those concerned should withdraw their troops, forces and fleets as soon as possible,'' the statement said.
Baghdad had previously belittled the United Nations embargo. Food lines have been growing in the capital and in other Iraqi cities, and rations for bread, rice, cooking oil and other scarce foodstuffs declared in early September were halved within a week. But diplomats in Baghdad had believed that no food crisis would emerge for some time, possibly several months.
 
Diplomats Suspect Anxiety
But after the statement was released today, diplomats reached by telephone in the Jordanian capital said it appeared that Mr. Hussein might be more anxious about the embargo's effects than he had previously admitted.
One reason for the anxiety, the diplomats said, may be that the United Nations Security Council is expected to meet this week to approve a proposal to extend the trade sanctions to air shipments, which have been used to circumvent the sea blockade. [Asked today about Mr. Hussein's threat on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d did not respond directly, The Associated Press reported from Washington. But he noted that the Security Council planned to meet soon ''at the foreign minister level'' to consider ''possible steps.''] One hint of Baghdad's efforts to overcome the embargo came in a meeting today in the Iraqi capital between Mr. Hussein and a delegation from Tunisia, one of the Arab countries that has refused to condemn Iraq for its seizure of Kuwait.
After showing Mr. Hussein sitting on a sofa with the leader of the Tunisian delegation, the television announcer said the two men had discussed ''economic cooperation.''
In a step that may have serious implications for foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait who do not hold Government ration cards, Baghdad also announced that the Kuwaiti currency, the dinar, would immediately be abolished. An official decree said that people with Kuwaiti currency would have 48 hours beginning Monday to exchange their money for Iraqi dinars, on a one-for-one basis. That amounts to a two-thirds devaluation from the rate at which the Kuwaiti dinar was trading before the invasion.
To avoid starvation, tens of thousands of Arabs and Asians still trapped in Kuwait, as well as at least 370,000 others at refugee camps in and around Baghdad, have reportedly been buying food on the black market with Kuwaiti dinars.
Relief agencies have been seeking ways to get food supplies to the foreigners. But aside from an arrangement with India to funnel food to Indian nationals, relief shipments have been blocked by Baghdad's insistence that the supplies be distributed by Iraq. Western Governments say that restriction could result in the food being diverted to the Iraqi forces.
 
Iraq Apologizes to France
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 23 (AP) -Iraq unexpectedly apologized to France today for the raid on the French Ambassador's residence in Kuwait that set off a series of diplomatic expulsions and prompted President Francois Mitterrand to send troops to the gulf.
The official Iraqi News Agency quoted a Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying that an investigation showed that the Iraqi soldiers who entered the house did not realize that it was the residence of ''the former French Ambassador.'' Iraq has referred to ambassadors in Kuwait as former envoys since it ordered that embassies in the country be shut down.
Iraqi officials previously had denied any raid took place.
Four Frenchmen, including the military attache, were captured by the troops who forced their way into the Ambassador's residence. The attache was released later in the day.
The spokesman said the other three had been flown to Baghdad and were staying at the Melia-Mansur Hotel. ''No measures were taken against them except they were prevented from travel,'' he added.

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1717 words

HEADLINE: Commuters Agonize as Road Repairs Spread

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
It is 2 P.M. on the Cross-Bronx Expressway, and for thousands of cars inching toward the George Washington Bridge, the air is heavy with exhaust. Half a mile ahead, where the highway and the Henry Hudson Parkway feed into the bridge's seven westbound lanes, traffic is stopped.
As unlikely as this scene might appear at midday, it is repeated almost every hour on highways throughout the New York metropolitan region. As long-overdue repairs close lanes on dozens of bridges and highways, some of the worst traffic jams in recent years have become commonplace, making it a gamble to drive into New York or across the region.
But if traffic seems bad now, transportation officials say, it is likely to get worse - possibly much worse - in coming years as the widespread repairs continue. 
 
'It Will Get Worse'
''We're repairing everything at once, because they all need it,'' said Lucius J. Riccio, New York City's Transportation Commissioner. ''But it will get worse before it gets better. We'll be closing more lanes than opening ones in the next two or three years. And it will take at least 10 years to get the roads and bridges into a good state of repair.''
The work is under way seemingly all at once in the city, on Long Island, and in Westchester County, Connecticut and New Jersey in an effort to overcome decades of neglect. Its effect is crippling because the number of vehicles on the road has grown far faster than the population, and many highways were already jammed beyond capacity.
Transportation experts warn that the resulting delays are not only raising frustrations that are already high, but are also contributing to air pollution and to hundreds of millions of hours in lost productivity each year. The declining quality of transportation, they say, is making New York less attractive to businesses and casts an added cloud over the region's long-term economic well-being.
In the meantime, traffic jams have returned the driving experience in both city and suburbs to the excruciating stop-and-go of the pre-interstate era.
After a generation of little maintenance or expansion, many of the region's 75,000 miles of roads and 11,500 bridges are antiquated and deteriorating. Hundreds of repair projects have begun, including ones that have closed lanes on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, the New England Thruway, Connecticut Turnpike, Cross-Westchester Expressway, and bridges including the Queensboro, Whitestone, Throgs Neck and George Washington.
Among other projects scheduled in the next few years are a $580 million reconstruction of the Gowanus and Brooklyn-Queens Expressways; a $1 billion effort to resuscitate the West Side Highway; $706 million for the Long Island Expressway, and a nearly $1 billion plan to repair all four East River bridges into Manhattan.
All told, about $10 billion will be spent in the region in the next five years, if current levels of Federal, state and local financing can be maintained. Nearly half of that will be spent in New York City.
 
Suburb-to-Suburb Commuting
But officials say that they have barely half the money needed just to maintain roads and mass transit, and that building new highways and bridges to ease automobile travel is virtually impossible.
Despite one of the nation's most extensive mass-transit networks and relatively slow population growth, traffic in the New York region increased substantially in the 1980's, largely because of more commuting from one suburb to another, rather than to and from New York City.
Nine million vehicles now travel 100 billion miles a year in the region. Those numbers are expected to grow by nearly half in the next 25 years, according to an estimate by the Bi-State Transportation Forum, which represents the six major transportation agencies in New York and New Jersey.
Meanwhile, mass-transit use has declined, and there is little political will to discourage driving through methods like higher gasoline taxes and tolls.
 
Little Maintenance Investment
''There are really two related traffic problems: infrastructure maintenance, which hasn't been done over the years as it should have been, and road capacity and congestion,'' said Franklin E. White, the New York State Transportation Commissioner.
Roads and bridges throughout the country have deteriorated because of a failure to invest in maintenance over the last 10 to 15 years. And in New York, many of the region's arteries are among the nation's oldest, and were not designed for the number of cars or the size of trucks that now use them. Potholes are endemic, and many highways have narrow lanes and lack shoulders. A single breakdown can cause a major traffic jam.
A recent report by the Bi-State Transportation Forum estimated that keeping the region's highway system in good repair over the next 25 years, with limited expansion, would cost $82 billion. But if current financing continues, only $35.7 billion will be available.
Federal, state and city budget problems, however, could reduce transportation spending. As for building more roads and bridges, officials say little is likely after the last 20 miles of Interstate 287 - from Montville, N.J., to Suffern, N.Y. - is completed in 1994.
 
No Room, So No Tunnels
Not only is there no money for new roads, they say, but acquiring land and rights-of-way in densely populated areas is nearly impossible, and new construction, in any case, would send the wrong message by encouraging driving.
''We won't build more vehicle tunnels into Manhattan, because there's no room for more vehicles in Manhattan,'' said Anthony J. Barber, the director of tunnels, bridges and terminals for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
While the road network appears frozen in place, the number of cars using it has grown drastically.
From 1981 to 1989, the number of cars registered in New York City alone rose to 2,035,000, from 1,471,000, and vehicle traffic in Manhattan increased by 18 percent. Every day, more than one million vehicles crowd into Manhattan. Most commuters across the East River are from Brooklyn and Queens, not, as many suppose, from New York suburbs.
 
Half Speed Limit Is Rare
Bridges undergoing repairs, like the George Washington and Queensboro, which carry 285,000 and 154,000 cars a day, respectively, are often so choked with traffic that roads for miles around are paralyzed.
Even on major highways, the volume of traffic is so great much of the day that cars rarely travel at even half the speed limit. On the Long Island Expressway in Queens, which is used by about 125,000 cars a day, city officials say the average afternoon speed is from 11 to 14 miles an hour.
''Even if our road system were in good repair, there still wouldn't be enough capacity,'' Mr. Barber said. ''All corridors between New York and New Jersey are already at or above capacity.''
Traffic is increasing fastest in the suburbs, where more and more people commute to jobs in other suburbs, rather than in New York City. Among the highways already jammed with such commuters are the Long Island Expressway in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, the Cross-Westchester Expressway from Port Chester to the Tappan Zee Bridge, the Connecticut Turnpike in Fairfield County and Route 1 in New Jersey between Trenton and New Brunswick.
Pat Kriss of South Salem, N.Y., who is typical of this new breed of commuter, has spent the last five years driving 80 miles a day between her home and her job in Bronxville, at opposite ends of Westchester County.
''On a good day, it takes 52 minutes one way, and on a bad one, three hours,'' she said.
That kind of commuting is spreading congestion further and further into the countryside, where there is little public transportation.
Other contributors to the congestion include the decline in mass-transit use, the growth of truck traffic and perennial problems like double parking in the city and delays at tollbooths.
Subway ridership hovered around one billion a year throughout the last decade, and fell by 3.4 percent in the first six months of this year. Bus ridership in New York City declined about 20 percent in the 1980's. After several years of growth, total ridership on the region's commuter railroads has fallen in the last few years.
 
If Just 5% Switched
Though more than 80 percent of commuters into New York City use mass transit, if just 5 percent more switched from cars to trains or buses, traffic would be significantly eased, said Mr. Riccio, the city's transportation commissioner.
Trucks, which handle more than 90 percent of the region's freight and account for about 7 percent of the vehicles traveling between New Jersey and New York City, are both a major cause and victim of traffic problems. Many of the area's older, narrower roads -with 10-foot- instead of 12-foot-wide lanes - cannot accommodate newer, larger trucks. Trucks' operating costs in New York are significantly higher than the national average, in large part because of traffic delays.
Tollbooths also cause delays that many experts say could be reduced.
''They are a medieval way of raising revenues,'' said Mark Kulewicz, a traffic engineer with the Automobile Club of New York. ''Just the normal delays to pay tolls at the Holland Tunnel or the Whitestone Bridge add up to about 100 hours a year for the average commuter.''
 
Patchwork Policy-Making
Many transportation officials say the costs of driving in congested areas should be increased to reduce traffic. Tolls and gasoline taxes, which are a fraction of those in most other countries, should be raised, and tax deductions for business-related parking expenses should be eliminated, they say.
Efforts to address the region's traffic problems - whether by repairing or building highways, encouraging mass transit, increasing rail-freight lines or discouraging driving - have been hampered by a lack of coordinated planning and policy-making among state and county governments and a host of independent agencies like the Port Authority.
There is a sense of urgency that if the region's traffic problems are not eased soon, it will pay a price in quality of life and economic competitiveness.
''If we can't keep people and goods moving,'' Mr. Barber said, ''the region strangles.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
After Silence, Japan's Army Pushes for Armed Gulf Role

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 23

 BODY:
After four decades of silence, Japan's military has openly split with some of the country's political leaders in a bitter debate over whether and how Japan should contribute forces to the Persian Gulf in what may become the military's first excursion abroad since World War II.
Because of its history as the moving force behind the rightist Government that plunged Japan into the invasions of China and Southeast Asia, and ultimately into a disastrous war against the United States, Japan's military has stayed out of virtually all political discourse since being reconstituted as the Self-Defense Forces in the 1950's.
 
'This May Be the Moment'
Since that time, the ''peace constitution'' written for Japan by the United States has been interpreted as barring the country's military forces from venturing beyond the Japanese archipelago, even as part of United Nations peacekeeping forces.
But the Iraq crisis, and demands from the United States, are driving many in the Japanese Government to put more at risk than just its money. Suddenly the country is facing the issue of whether Japan is psychologically or legally prepared to use military forces to protect its vast economic interests abroad, even in noncombat roles as part of a United Nations or international force. 
''This may be the most heated and emotional debate since the end of the war,'' said Masashi Nishihara, a professor at Japan's leading military college and an influential figure in the country's struggle to define a role that goes beyond that of economic superpower. ''It is a question that Japan has never faced squarely. But this may be the moment.''
The issue has taken on a particular urgency within the Government because it seems bound to come up later this week when Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu prepares to go the United States for a United Nations General Assembly session and a meeting with President Bush.
But just as the Prime Minister is leaving, his initial proposal - to create an unarmed, civilian ''United Nations cooperation force'' to provide behind-the-lines support to American and other forces in Saudi Arabia - has begun to collapse, under attack from opposition parties, the Japanese military establishment and even leaders of Mr. Kaifu's own party.
 
Socialists Are Opposed
The largest opposition party, the Japan Socialist Party, has never recognized the legitimacy of the Self-Defense Forces, contending that their existence is a violation of the Japanese Constitution.
The party has said it will oppose any effort to send Japanese abroad into a war zone, charging that Mr. Kaifu's ''peace cooperation team'' is simply a guise for sending military forces. Indeed, under Mr. Kaifu's original proposal many members of the team would be soldiers from the Self-Defense Forces, though the others would include police officers, firefighters and doctors. In theory, they would provide communications support, surveillance and medical treatment, but stay out of the front lines.
Because the Liberal Democrats lost control of the upper house of Parliament a year ago, the Socialists and smaller opposition groups could bottle up Mr. Kaifu's ''U.N. Cooperation Law'' for months.
Moreover, they could probably win popular support along the way. Polls show that more than 60 percent of the Japanese public opposes sending Japanese personnel to the Persian Gulf. Opposition is even higher among older Japanese, who blame the military for the chaos and ruin brought on by the war.
In conversations, many Japanese of all ages question whether the United States is being foolhardy or trigger-happy; many say they would prefer to pay more for oil than be pressed by Americans to send Japanese personnel to the gulf to protect sheikdoms.
But the bitterest criticism of Mr. Kaifu's proposal has come not from the left, or from the public, but from within the Liberal Democratic Party's own leadership. With support from the military establishment, many are arguing that Mr. Kaifu's unarmed force, without military training and discipline, would be ineffective and vulnerable to slaughter.
''It is nonsense,'' a senior officer in the Self-Defense Forces said a few days ago. ''We would be laughed at as a toy army. Frankly speaking, I think if I asked my troops to go under those conditions, many would refuse.''
 
No Longer on the Sidelines
Japan took up a similar issue once before, in 1987, when it was under pressure to send minesweepers to the gulf to rid the area of mines believed to have been planted by Iran. But the debate was far less intense, and in the end the minesweepers never left port.
Now the country fears that inaction could lead to international condemnation of Japan, which is heavily dependent on Middle East oil.
''What we are doing is wasting time,'' said Moto Shiina, a former member of Parliament and a leading defense expert. ''We have to identify our national interest in this post-cold-war era and make ourself available to our allies. The political structure, though, is not prepared to deal with it. At least not yet.'' What separates the current debate from past discussions about the scope of Japanese power is that this time the military is hardly sitting on the sidelines.
Technically, neither the uniformed officers nor the civilian heads of Japan's military have any role in debating defense policy. When Mr. Kaifu was first formulating a response to American demands for help, he pointedly kept the Defense Minister, Yozo Ishikawa, out of the meetings. But both the civilian bureaucracy and the uniformed services have deep ties to the Liberal Democratic Party, and already their efforts to head off Mr. Kaifu's hopes for a nonmilitary force are showing results.
The military has also been insisting that any personnel sent to the gulf carry sidearms, at the very least. ''It is a matter of definition,'' a senior officer in the Maritime Self-Defense Forces said. ''If you are carrying a pistol or a rifle, that is essentially unarmed. But to this country, unarmed means completely unarmed.''
The other day Mr. Ishikawa backed away from his earlier contention that Japan could do nothing, and publicly termed Mr. Kaifu's proposal a ''half-measure.'' He urged a reinterpretation of the law, which would not require parliamentary action.
On Saturday, Noboru Takeshita, the former Japanese Prime Minister and one of the governing party's most powerful figures, told reporters that the Government should push through a revision of the Self-Defense Law that would permit military personnel to be sent to the gulf, in uniform, as part of the multinational force.
Ichiro Ozawa, the secretary general of the party, split with Mr. Kaifu by arguing that it made more sense to revise Japan's Self-Defense Law and enable Japanese forces to take part in multinational peackeeping efforts rather than to draw up a new law.
That is exactly what Mr. Kaifu and Japan's Foreign Ministry have been trying to avoid for fear that any revisions of the Self-Defense Law would give Southeast Asia exactly what it is often looking for: evidence that Japan seeks a new regional role beyond its borders.
''Southeast Asian countries, which suffered during World War II, have shown a serious interest in this issue,'' warned Taro Nakayama, Japan's Foreign Minister. ''It is extremely important to draw up a flawless bill.''
Even in Japan there is an unspoken fear that someday the Japanese military could once again spin out of control, and that it is unwise to set a precedent for overseas ventures. It is a fear that some Japanese say the country must finally get over.
''What is the use of elections, of a democracy, if you do not think it will enable you to control the country's policy?'' Mr. Shiina asked.
The issue is ambiguous enough, however, that the one country with the biggest stake in the outcome - the United States - is remaining silent. The constitutional ban on offensive forces was formulated by Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur, who commanded the American occupation of Japan. Now it is the United States that, warily, is seeking greater help from Japan.
''It is something for the Japanese to decide,'' a senior American diplomat here said the other day. ''I can't imagine that if the United States took a position it would do anything than make things worse.''
