HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
With Its Huge Banks Weakening, Japan Cuts Lending to the World

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 23

 BODY:
At Japan's powerful banks, which in recent years have served as financiers to the world, profits are tumbling and a global investment spree is slowing.
The Persian Gulf crisis has hit the Tokyo financial markets hard, sending stock prices plummeting and interest rates climbing. The stock market, which also had a tumble several months ago, is now down 39 percent this year, making an already difficult time for the Japanese banks even grimmer. 
In the last decade, the seemingly limitless flow of Japanese capital has been vital for everything from financing the United States' yawning budget deficits to aiding developing nations. Japanese banks - 8 of the world's 10 largest - have been the principal intermediaries for this flood of money. Now they are tightening the spigots. Taizo Hashida, chairman of Japan's leading bankers' association and president of Fuji Bank, the third largest in Japan and the world, predicted last week that Japanese banks would put ''severe'' limits on their lending. Experts expect that to put upward pressure on interest rates in the United States and the developing world, The move comes as world monetary officials appear to be adjusting to an era of higher interest rates. Finance ministers gathering for meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Washington endorsed a strategy over the weekend to maintain tight monetary polices. [Page D1.] And in the United States, Federal Reserve Board officials are trying to freeze interest rates in view of the risk of recession. [Page D1.] The impact of the Japanese move is likely to be felt first overseas, where Japan's banks have marketed their services aggressively. The banks are likely to move away from high-volume, low-profit-margin businesses aimed at building market share, toward more profitable but potentially risky operations that rely on market savvy, in which they have little experience.
More than anything, the banks' problems demonstrate how dependent they had become on inflated Japanese stock prices to fuel their spectacular growth. The difficulties are also likely to make painfully clear how dependent the American capital markets have become on inflows of Japanese capital.
''The bubble period is over,'' said Yoh Kurosawa, president of the Industrial Bank of Japan, a powerhouse here. ''We have to face reality.''
Because of the stock market's steep slide, banks are suddenly having trouble meeting new international standards for bank capital. Bankers here have begun suggesting that Japan may seek to postpone the deadline set for the new rules fully to take effect in March 1993. That is a potentially explosive issue.
The guidelines, enacted by the Bank for International Settlements, which is based in Switzerland and is a central bank for central banks, require commercial banks to maintain capital equal to 8 percent or more of their assets as a cushion against financial difficulties.
Just a year ago it appeared the booming Japanese banks would have no difficulties meeting the standard. Now they are facing the prospect of having to shrink to make the minimum or paying steep rates for the fresh capital they need to grow.
In Japan, unlike in America, banks are allowed to build up huge stock portfolios by acquiring up to 5 percent of industrial and other concerns. They can also count 45 percent of the value of those stocks as capital.
 
Shrinking Capital Levels
When the Tokyo market was soaring, the banks' capital received a fillip. But when the market fell sharply, their capital levels shrank. And with stock prices sliding, the Japanese banks are also no longer able to raise capital by issuing shares as they had before; in the previous two years, they raised more than $60 billion in capital by selling securities.
Making matters worse, about half the profits earned by Japanese banks in recent years came not from lending money, but from selling some of the shares held in their swollen stock portfolios.
''In the late 1980's, it was like the Japanese banks were on steroids,'' said Kenneth Courtis, chief economist here for Deutsche Bank.
The downturn in the Tokyo market also comes at a time when the banks' traditional business of lending to companies is being eroded. Japanese corporations have grown so wealthy that they do not need large bank borrowings; when they do want capital, they generally go to the securities markets.
 
Unprofitable Core Lending
''The core lending business of Japanese banks is simply not profitable any more,'' said Robert Zielinski, a senior analyst with Jardine Fleming Securities. ''The stock market was a kind of drug they lived off of. They have now been cut off from their opium.''
Real estate lending, especially in Tokyo, was another booming business for Japanese banks in recent years. But the steep increases in interest rates are threatening to undermine the property market, on which tens of billions of dollars of bank loans rest.
Although few people are expecting a sudden huge decline in property values, a drop of 10 to 15 percent a year for several years could reduce bank profits significantly, analysts say. Moody's Investors Service has lowered the credit ratings of two major banks and said it is reviewing the ratings of three other banks, largely because of concerns over the property market.
 
Weakened Balance Sheets
To be sure, Japanese banks are likely to remain big and tough internationally. They are, however, facing the challenge of an emerging European market and a downtrend in the United States at a time when their balance sheets are in a weakened state.
At this stage, Government officials have said there is no effort to ease the Bank for International Settlement capital rules. Some economists said any such move would be a mistake because it would erode the credibility of the international organization. Clearly, some banks - most of which have now slipped under the 8 percent capital minimum - are using the squeeze as an excuse to argue away the bothersome new guidelines rather than bite the bullet and shrink.
Easing the rules is an enticing notion not only for Japan. American officials, threatened with a slowdown of Japanese capital investment just as the country slips toward a recession, might also find a postponement worth considering to avoid a painful credit shortage in the United States.
 
Delay Would Be Welcome
Several Japanese bankers said that no matter who initiated such a move, they would welcome a postponement of the 8 percent capital standard.
''From the beginning, I had some doubts about it,'' said Mr. Kurosawa of the Industrial Bank of Japan, echoing comments made privately by several other leading bankers here.
Mr. Kurosawa said his bank would not cut back on its lending in the United States, but he made clear it would examine lending proposals with a more critical eye. For instance, he contended the capital rules were behind the reluctance of Japanese banks to provide more capital to finance the tunnel under the English Channel between England and France.
An official at the Bank of Tokyo, which has extensive operations in the United States, said it would not be pulling back but that the combination of the weaker American economy and the capital shortage would certainly slow the bank's overseas growth.
''It's not such an easy market in the United States to expand in today,'' said Masaharu Hamakawa, deputy general manager of the planning department at the Bank of Tokyo. ''It's getting harder and harder.''
''This is a testing time,'' he added. ''It's going to take a little time to adjust.''
 
Looking to Europe and Asia
With the American economy sliding and Japanese bank loans there souring, they are looking more to Europe and Asia for expansion.
The Bank of Tokyo, for instance, is about to form a division for new financial products, including swaps, futures and options. There is subsantial risk in this business, but margins tend to be higher. The Industrial Bank of Japan has just formed a merger advisory subsidiary on Wall Street.
Moving into these businesses is much easier said than done, of course.
''Each of these businesses has its own risks and they are a lot more complicated than traditional lending activities,'' said Mr. Courtis of Deutsche Bank. ''Also, the insurance companies here also want to move into some of these businesses, like asset management, so the competition is going to be much keener than anything they've experienced before.''

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1314 words

HEADLINE: Jobless Executives Get Solace and Aid In Support Groups

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 20

 BODY:
One by one, in a brightly lighted church annex, they introduced themselves: corporate lawyers, controllers, marketing executives, commercial bankers, all from the secure suburbs of Fairfield County and all ''in transition,'' the current euphemism for being out of work.
''I'm Richard Taylor,'' announced a former director of marketing, neatly dressed in wide-wale corduroys and a crew-neck sweater. ''My company folded its New York operation two months ago. I'm 34. I have a wife and two kids. I started off on a real high, but then I crashed.''
Gatherings like these may well become the support groups of the 1990's. Books with titles like ''Fired for Success'' and ''Rites of Passage at $100,000+'' were passed around. Advice on getting through to the person with hiring power was plentiful. And men and women were told to find strength in the ''four F's'': faith, family, fitness and friends. 
After a decade in which corporations cut away at middle management and mergers and acquisitions eliminated entire layers of executives, thousands of administrators, professionals, executives and managers in the New York region are rolling out of bed in the morning with no place to go.
With such large numbers of once high-powered people out of work, many of the unemployed and those who counsel them say there is less stigma to being jobless today. At the same time the fact that so many are on the sidelines has prompted hundreds to turn to unusually open forums in support groups, like the one here, both to help one another in their job searches and with emotional stress.
The loss of a blue-collar job is no less traumatic, of course. But the public nature of plant closings and union backing have tended to make those layoffs shared experiences. Now, with white-collar unemployment burgeoning, the once private pain of the jobless executive has also turned public.
Today's ranks of unemployed professionals are caught in a double bind, searching for work at a time when a shaky economy has cast their own financial well-being in doubt and when many corporations, to save money, are choosing not to fill available positions. ''The jobs go poof, so there are more people looking for fewer opportunities,'' said Robert J. Graham, a senior vice president and general manager of the Stamford office of Drake Beam Morin Inc., an executive job placement concern.
 
Northeast Badly Hurt
The employment outlook in the Northeast is more dismal than anywhere else in the country, the United States Department of Labor says, with New York, Connecticut and New Jersey all ranking in the bottom 10 states in terms of job growth.
Cutbacks have affected every suburban area around New York City, as well as the city itself. Some jobless professionals enjoy a safety net of considerable savings to keep their households afloat during a potentially long hunt. But many find themselves in a race against time as their six months of severance pay or unemployment benefits are used up.
Even in two-career families the loss of a job can be devastating. Lyn Carlton of South Plainfield, N.J., was laid off last March from the First Fidelity Bank, where she was paid $56,200 as a vice president in project and systems support. Her 26 weeks of severance pay ended Sept. 6, and now, with no job prospects in sight after 200 resumes and six interviews, she and her husband are making contingency plans.
''My salary was 60 percent of the household income,'' said Mrs. Carlton, 44, the mother of a 4-year-old girl and 10-year-old boy. ''This was not for luxuries and ballet classes. This was for mortgage payments and car payments and the necessities of life. Unfortunately we were terrible savers, so we have no cushion.
 
Willing to Take Half Pay
''At this point, I'd take an administrative assistant position at half of what I was making,'' she said, adding that she and her husband were also trying to change the variable rate on their home equity loan to a fixed rate as a hedge against a worsening economy.
Many executives say that in today's tight job market the process of interviewing has slowed to a crawl. John J. Troy, 45, of Stamford, lost his job as a senior vice president and regional manager at the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company in January. He was interviewed for the president's post at one bank in March and didn't return for a second interview until this month. He is still waiting to hear. ''Employers are reacting to the economy, so everything has become drawn out,'' said Mr. Troy, sitting in a mini-office for use by unemployed executives at Drake Beam Morin in Stamford. ''Whereas before they'd make their decision in six to eight weeks, now it takes them three to four months. They're asking themselves whether they can do without this position or if they can fill it with someone part-time.''
If anything can assauge the frustrations and fears felt by unemployed executives, it is comfort in numbers. Daylong job search seminars sponsored by the Roman Catholice Diocese of Bridgeport have drawn hundreds of people. And support groups have sprung up in affluent suburbs like Rye, N.Y., and Greenwich and Ridgefield in Connecticut, a sign that, for many, being out of work does not carry a sense of shame or personal responsibility.
 
'Cutting Back to the Bone'
''Companies used to think there was something wrong with the unemployed person we'd present to them,'' said Robert Larson of Berman & Larson Associates in Paramus, N.J., a computer industry headhunter. ''But there's no longer a stigma. It used to be that companies would lay off the fat, but now they are cutting back to the bone.''
At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Joseph Davis, a parishioner and founder of the monthly support group, holds a good-paying, rewarding job as the managing director and executive vice president of a health-care advertising agency in Manhattan. But he remembers how frightening it was several years ago when he twice found himself out of work, once for eight months and the next time for six months.
''When you're in transition, you really feel like you're out there by yourself, and we're trying to encourage the idea that you're not isolated, that you're part of a community and there's help,'' said Mr. Davis, an affable moderator who strikes a balance between the emotional and the practical.
Ranging in age from 34 to 63 and sporting everything from top siders to wing tips, blue jeans to khaki suits, the 17 men and one woman sat in a circle here and alternately commiserated and coaxed one another.
 
Two Minutes to Score
They practiced their ''two-minute drills,'' concise sales pitches combining personal history and business skills to kick off an interview or a networking session. ''If you fumble the first two minutes, it's hard to recover,'' Mr. Davis said. ''You have to rehearse the first two minutes like you're an actor on Broadway. Be ready to spring into this at any moment - on the train, on the plane.''
They learned to think in terms of short-term goals, such as obtaining an interview rather than the job itself. ''Otherwise you've got a zillion defeats and one victory,'' one participant said.
And they were drilled in the importance of maintaining a positive self-image, with living proof of its effectiveness in Brad Hughes, a former support group member who returned Thursday night to give a pep talk. After scouring the area for a job for eight months, Mr. Hughes, 49, of New Canaan, was hired last month by Warner Computer Systems Inc. in Fair Lawn, N.J., as vice president for finance and administration.
 
Accenting 'Little Things'
''I paid attention to a lot of little things,'' he explained. ''I used engraved stationery. I lost 30 pounds. I shined my shoes once a day. I had a haircut every week. If you know you're looking your best and feeling your best, it helps put you in an up mood.''

Joseph Davis, rear, leads a support group in Darien, Conn., where unemployed professionals assist one another in job searches and stress management. (Suzanne DeChillo for The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: El Salvador Chief Lobbying to Stop U.S. Aid Cuts

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador begins an intensive three-day lobbying campaign on Capitol Hill on Monday in an effort to thwart legislation that would cut United States military aid to his country by 50 percent next year.
Salvadoran diplomats here said Mr. Cristiani would try to meet with as many as 60 Senators and members of the House panel that has been investigating the slaying of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador last November.
If Mr. Cristiani fails, the Salvadoran Ambassador, Miguel A. Salaverria, said the lawmakers could inadvertently encourage leftist rebels to abandon negotiations and begin a military offensive.
An influential Salvadoran Army officer, who spoke on the condition that he not be named, agreed. ''President Cristiani knows a cut in aid might be inevitable,'' the officer said, ''but he wants them to know what they are doing. And maybe then they won't do it.'' 
The six Jesuits were among the leading critics of the Government in Salvadoran intellectual circles. They, their housekeeper and her daughter were killed in their university quarters by gunmen. An army colonel and seven lower-ranking soldiers were arrested in January, but judiciary officials have complained that tampering with evidence by the army has hindered prosecution of the case and investigation into whether the slayings were ordered by higher military officers.
 
Movement to Cut Aid
The slayings mobilized the strongest movement in Congress to cut military aid to El Salvador since the early 1980's. The House has already passed a bill to withhold 50 percent of the $85 million in military aid that the Bush Administration had proposed to send El Salvador next year, and the Senate is about to consider similar legislation.
More than $4 billion in economic and military support and hundreds of military advisers have been sent to El Salvador since 1980, and many Democrats and Republicans in Congress question whether the largest American investment in a counterinsurgency campaign since the Vietnam War has been worthwhile. While they grant that the Bush Administration has made a stronger pitch for human rights there than did the Reagan Administration, they complain that a corrupt and violent military still dominates the civilian Government.
Some members of Congress argue that Mr. Cristiani is a worthy politician but lacks the power to change his country.
''It's not enough for him to say he's going to try and do this and try and do that,'' said Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, the chairman of the House Rules Committee. ''The members want to see results.''
 
'His English Is Perfect'
The argument for cutting back the United States commitment to El Salvador has been strengthened by the realization that with the cold war over, the threat of Soviet expansion in Central America has diminished, no matter who wins the Salvadoran civil war.
''A lot of people think El Salvador is a tar baby and it's time to say goodbye,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, who is chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, which early next month will consider a bill to cut aid to the country. But Mr. Leahy added: ''Cristiani could have an effect on some votes. People like him and think he's trying. His English is perfect, too, and that helps.''
Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, has privately agreed that the Administration would accept some cuts in military aid - up to 30 percent - as long as Congress gave President Bush more discretion over the aid. Seeking to forge a bipartisan policy on El Salvador, Mr. Aronson has proposed that military assistance be channeled through President Cristiani rather than directly to the armed forces.
During his stay in Washington, Mr. Cristiani will also meet with Vice President Dan Quayle. He will confer with President Bush in New York next week.

HEADLINE: De Klerk Arrives in the U.S. for Talks With Bush

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa, citing the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as an inspiration for the changes he has begun in his own country, arrived in Washington today for talks with President Bush.
After four decades in which Washington has kept South Africa at arm's length because of apartheid, Mr. de Klerk stepped off his South African Airways jet into a red-carpet reception at Andrews Air Force Base.
Mr. de Klerk, who was invited to Washington in February by President Bush after he released the black South African leader, Nelson Mandela, from prison and began negotiations to end white minority rule, clearly relished the moment.
''I am deeply aware of the historical importance of this visit,'' Mr. de Klerk said to the Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, Herman J. Cohen, who headed the American welcoming party. ''South Africa has embarked on a great journey. It is a journey towards full democracy at home and abroad, full participation in the family of nations. It is a journey that I sincerely believe will bring the fruits of both justice and economic well-being to every South African family.'' 
 
Anti-Apartheid Sanctions
''In a few moments, we will begin our visit to Washington at the Reflecting Pool,'' said Mr. de Klerk, referring to the ceremony where he was formally welcomed by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. ''It is there where the reflections of the great monuments to Washington and Lincoln come together. And it was there that many thousands of Americans heard the Rev. Martin Luther King describe his dream for an America of justice and harmony through nonviolence.
When Mr.de Klerk referred to the ''family of nations,'' it was no idle oratorical flourish. To be welcomed at the White House on Monday, with the South African flag waving next to the Stars and Stripes, will be for him and other white South Africans the ultimate sign that their country is finally breaking out of its pariah status.
It was striking that moments after Mr. de Klerk's plane landed, almost all of the South African Airways flight attendants gathered around one of the United States Marine honor guards and asked him to pose for a picture with them next to the aircraft, which he gladly did. The flight was the airline's first to land in the United States since Congress banned air links with South Africa as part of the 1986 anti-apartheid sanctions.
Although the small official welcoming party that met Mr. de Klerk was in marked contrast to the tumultuous tickertape parades that greeted his negotiating partner, Mr. Mandela, the African National Congress leader, last June, it did not diminish the South African leader's evident satisfaction. He is the first South African head of Government to visit the United States since 1945.
 
'With Charity for All'
''The words and deeds of Presidents Washington, Lincoln and Dr. King still ring out to us all,'' continued Mr. de Klerk, 54, who at the time of Dr. King's civil rights activities in the 1960's was an enthusiastic advocate of apartheid. ''Inscribed in stone above Lincoln's statue are the great words, 'With malice towards none, with charity for all, let us do all which may achieve a just and lasting peace among ourselves and with all nations.' These are words which also describe our efforts today in South Africa.''
Mr. de Klerk's reference to Dr. King and his famous 1963 speech, one of the most inspiring of the civil rights movement, was seen as offensive by some American black leaders.
Randall Robinson, executive director of the African-American lobby TransAfrica, argued that Dr. King ''died in a lifelong effort to perfect American democracy,'' while ''South African blacks are fighting to establish the very essentials of a democratic system against a white minority, including de Klerk, that has insisted on retention of its privileges.''
Mr. de Klerk was closeted with his aides much of the day and dined this evening with Vice President Dan Quayle. Monday morning, he will meet with Mr. Bush. After a working lunch at the White House, the South African President will go to the State Department for talks with Mr. Baker. On Tuesday he will deliver an address at the National Press Club and also meet with Congressional leaders.
 
A New Constitution
During his talks in Washington, the South African leader is expected to receive mixed messages from the White House and Congress.
Administration officials say he will hear praise for his bold decision to release political prisoners in return for the suspension of armed struggle by the African National Congress, and for his decision to begin talks with Mr. Mandela on how to draft a new constitution to govern a post-apartheid South Africa.
The Bush Administration wants to heap enough praise on Mr. de Klerk to encourage him to keep moving forward and give him something to point to when his rightist white critics ask what, if anything, his reforms have gained for South Africa abroad.
But this praise, Administration officials say, will be tempered by admonitions that the African leader still has not gone far enough in his reforms to justify a lifting of sanctions by Washington.
Mr. de Klerk, officials added, will also be questioned about how he plans to contain the factional violence in South Africa's black townships, which threatens to undermine the constitutional negotiations. Many black leaders have accused the South African police and right-wing organizations of instigating some of that violence, which has led to more than 1,700 deaths this year.
 
'A Sad and Tragic Situation'
These and other issues explain why not everyone in Congress welcomes the de Klerk visit. TransAfrica is planning a demonstration across from the White House while Mr. de Klerk is in the Oval Office. And on Saturday the Congressional Black Caucus announced that it was canceling a scheduled meeting with Mr. de Klerk.
Mr. Robinson, of TransAfrica, said he had encouraged the cancellation because of his group's feeling that the de Klerk visit is nothing more than a ''superficial photo opportunity, staged with the assistance of President Bush, to put a smiling face on a sad and tragic situation.''
The American public, Mr. Robinson said, ''must be reminded that the major pillars of apartheid remain firmly in place in South Africa.''
A senior Administration official briefing reporters at the White House before Mr. de Klerk's arrival said, ''We recognize, as will this visit, that President de Klerk has played a major role in bringing changes about.''
The Administration official said, though, that he was certain that Mr. de Klerk was under no illusion that the sanctions against South Africa, embodied in the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act, would be lifted.
''The United States has specific legislation relating to sanctions, and those cannot be relaxed until such time as certain conditions in the law are met,'' the official said. ''And he understands, as do we all, that those conditions have not yet been met.''

HEADLINE: Khrushchev Memoir Tells of Castro Plea For Attack on U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Fidel Castro urged the Soviet Union to attack the United States in 1962 because he feared an American invasion of Cuba during the Cuban missile crisis, Nikita S. Khrushchev said in portions of his memoirs published today.
The new excerpts, in Time magazine, include material deemed by Khrushchev's relatives and friends to be too incendiary or delicate for publication in the two volumes of memoirs printed in the United States in 1970 and 1974.
Khrushchev seems to confirm a longstanding rumor about the missile crisis. He quotes the Cuban leader as saying in 1962 that the Kremlin ''should launch a pre-emptive strike against the U.S.'' to prevent destruction of the Soviet missiles in Cuba. 
''Castro was hotheaded,'' Khrushchev says. Mr. Castro ''totally failed to understand'' that Soviet missiles had been placed in Cuba to deter an American attack, not to attack the United States, he said.
 
'The 'Missing Tapes'
Khrushchev's account may appear somewhat self-serving. But experts on Soviet affairs say it is plausible.
The third volume of Khrushchev's memoirs, based on tapes dictated from 1965 until his death in 1971, is to be published next month by Little, Brown & Company. The ''missing tapes,'' as Time calls them, were translated by Jerrold L. Schecter, former diplomatic editor of Time magazine, and Vyacheslav Luchkov, a Soviet affairs expert.
In the Time excerpts, Khrushchev bluntly acknowledges political and economic failures of the Soviet system. He says the Kremlin should not be afraid to let its citizens leave their country.
In the latest memoirs, Khrushchev says that Stalin made ''a very secret approach to Hitler'' with peace overtures in World War II.
''I think it was in 1942,'' Khrushchev says. ''Stalin wanted to reach an agreement that would let the Germans keep the territory they occupied in the Ukraine, Byelorussia and even certain areas of the Russian federation. One of our people was sent to Bulgaria and instructed to inform a German contact there that the Soviet Union was willing to make some territorial concessions.''
''There was never any answer from Hitler,'' Khrushchev says. ''Apparently, he felt the Soviet Union's days were numbered.''
Stalin could say he was just stalling so he could build up Soviet forces and eventually win back what he had given away, Krushchev wrote. ''But to gain time at the cost of such concessions!''
Khrushchev also says that Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were executed in 1953 after being convicted of conspiring to pass American atomic secrets to the Soviets, provided ''very significant help in accelerating the production of our atom bomb.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Strains of Gulf Crisis;
Sharp Questioning by Congress Comes Amid Jockeying Among Bush Officials

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
After seven smooth weeks of handling the Persian Gulf crisis, the White House is fumbling several critical gulf issues on Capitol Hill and finds itself grappling with internal tensions that strain its vaunted air of collegiality.
Administration officials admit privately that they were taken aback by the sharpness of the Congressional questioning on why the Reagan and Bush Administrations supplied the military and economic aid that helped Saddam Hussein establish himself as a regional strongman.
They are nervous about continued Congressional investigation into whether the Administration misread signals in late July that Mr. Hussein was set to invade Kuwait. And both White House officials and Congressional Republicans say that while overall support for the Persian Gulf policy is strong, lawmakers' questioning of individual aspects is likely to grow.
By their own admission, Administration officials were unprepared for the extent to which Congress would rake through their Iraq policy. 
''We got lulled by the fact that the crisis management by Bush and the whole team was so good and Congress was away for most of the time,'' a senior official said. ''We didn't realize that once the novelty and the early tendency to rally behind the President wore off, it would become politics as usual.''
 
Grumbling Over Arms Sale Plan
Taken together, the events of the last week have forcefully reminded Mr. Bush that political support for military operations can drain away quickly, threatening both the political vitality of a President and the comity among his main advisers.
White House officials have started to privately accuse the State Department of trying to steal credit for the response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, while grumbling about the Pentagon's handling of a proposed $21 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, called the proposed sale ''a gross miscalculation of Congress.''
The Congressional criticism of previous policy toward Iraq has also focused an unaccustomed and uncomfortable glare on the State Department and, by implication, the Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d. Lawmakers have so far not directly blamed him, but the crisis is testing Mr. Baker's widely envied political skills.
Last week, it produced the unusual spectacle of the Secretary and his staff hunkering down in Foggy Bottom while a new lineup of ''golden boys'' - notably Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Brent Scowcroft, the National Security Adviser - stepped forward. Mr. Baker broke his public silence with a television appearance today in which he evaded the central questions: Was American policy before the invasion misguided and was he responsible?
And, while Mr. Bush works to maintain Congressional support for his Gulf policy, Administration officials have started complaining - very quietly -about lawmakers who backed American overtures to Mr. Hussein and made their own missions to Baghdad, including a group led by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader.
''You don't see any of those guys coming out to remind people about it now,'' a senior official said with evident pique. Harbinger or Temporary Bump? While these tensions have come into sharp focus in the last week, lawmakers and Administration officials said they were probably just a temporary bump. But some worried that they might be a harbinger of deeper trouble.
''These do not represent an insurmountable problem if events work out with regard to the possible conflict with Iraq,'' said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ''If events do not work out, it's the tip of the iceberg.''
Perhaps the most dramatic setback for the Administration came in the Congressional examination of its overtures toward Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait, particularly the now-famous conversation on July 25 in which the American Ambassador to Iraq, April Glaspie, told Mr. Hussein that the United States did not want to be involved in Iraq's border dispute with Kuwait.
Mr. Baker and his staff were clearly unprepared for the uproar, and the Secretary, who is widely believed to have Presidential ambitions but who has taken an unusually low profile at other times in the crisis, became less visible again last week until his television appearances today.
There is no doubt that Mr. Baker is still a commanding presence. In a revealing private moment, he strode out of a National Security Council meeting on Thursday at the head of the pack of Mr. Bush's top advisers and led them across the West Wing lobby for a follow-up meeting.
 
'You Bet' Baker's Involved
But appearances are critical in Washington. And before Mr. Baker reappeared today on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' his spokeswoman and loyal aide, Margaret D. Tutwiler, found herself in an extremely odd position - assuring reporters that her powerful boss, the President's best friend, was still engaged in the most critical foreign policy issue on the agenda.
''Is he involved in - continuously involved in - the gulf crisis?'' she said testily. ''You bet he is.''
There are signs of real, if subtle, shifts within the Administration. By virtue of their natural roles in this crisis, Mr. Scowcroft, Mr. Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have formed a new axis of power in the White House.
The last week has displayed a marked difference in the operating styles of Mr. Cheney and Mr. Baker.
After the Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Michael J. Dugan, talked to reporters about contingency war plans, Mr. Cheney had him cleaning out his desk within 24 hours.
At the State Department, Ms. Glaspie and John Kelly, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near East and South Asian Affairs, have been left to take the brunt of the criticism of United States policy toward Iraq from members of Congress without their boss offering much of a public defense or putting them out of their misery by moving them to other jobs.
Today, during ''Meet the Press,'' Mr. Baker cited not his own view, but a newspaper article about the issue. He spoke of ''some 20-20 hindsighting'' that he said has ''been highly critical of some career public servants.'' But he refused to say whether the criticism was justified or whether it should be directed at him and not Mr. Kelly and Ms. Glaspie.
 
Criticism of Cheney
Mr. Baker also sidestepped a question about how he now viewed the pre-invasion policy. ''The President has said in hindsight, maybe there were some things we should have done differently,'' he said. Mr. Baker paused and added, ''I agree with that of course.''
An Administration official said: ''Kelly and Glaspie are twisting in the wind. But what can Baker do, since they were clearly just following Department policy?''
While Mr. Cheney's image has been polished by his overall handling of the gulf crisis, he has come in for some internal criticism, officials said.
The firing of General Dugan was widely supported, but there was concern that it left the impression of ''not so tight a ship,'' an official said.
Lawmakers and Administration officials said Mr. Cheney also mishandled the arms sale to Saudi Arabia, the size of which circulated among reporters before Congress or Israel were consulted. The White House was later forced to back down and seek Congressional approval of the sale in two separate phases. And the Pentagon stirred trouble with a suggestion that the Administration spend billions of dollars in foreign contributions to the gulf operation without Congressional supervision.

HEADLINE: Dole Hints at Willingness to Alter Income Tax Rate in a Budget Deal

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
In the first public hint that Republican opposition to income tax rate increases may be cracking, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas said today that budget negotiators were looking at ways to raise taxes for wealthy Americans that would ''pierce the so-called bubble.''
His reference was to an anomaly in the tax system under which married couples with incomes of $78,400 to $185,730 pay a tax rate of 33 percent on their last dollar of income, while married couples with incomes of more than $185,730 pay a 28 percent rate on their last dollar of income.
Although Republican negotiators have tentatively accepted other types of tax increases, like increases in excise taxes, and have discussed a variety of possibilities for increasing the tax burden on the wealthy, they have been adamant in opposing an actual increase in income tax rates.
The comments of Mr. Dole, the leader of the Senate's Republican minority, came in a television interview several hours before Administration officials and the top five Congressional leaders resumed budget negotiations late today amid signs of increasing friction between the White House and Congressional Republicans over how to reach a deficit cutting deal. 
 
Critical Deadline in a Week
If no agreement is reached by Oct. 1, just a week away, automatic spending cuts totaling $85 billion will be imposed on a wide array of domestic and military programs, forcing layoffs of thousands of Federal workers and affecting vital services like air traffic control.
There are also signs of division in the Administration on strategy, with some advisers recommending that President Bush allow the automatic spending cuts to take effect so as to force a budget agreement.
''It may be the only thing that will focus the attention of Congress,'' said one Administration official.
Other advisers had recommended that Mr. Bush personally step into the negotiations to hasten a compromise, and officials said he may become more directly involved early this week.
The negotiators have been deadlocked over Republican insistence on a cut in the capital gains tax rate, which President Bush says is needed to stimulate the weak economy. Democrats are equally adamant that they will not accept such a cut unless it is accompanied by tax increases on the wealthy taxpayers who would be the primary beneficiaries of the reduction.
Democrats have long maintained that they could accept a reduction in the capital gains rate if the ''tax bubble'' were eliminated by increasing the highest income tax rate for the wealthy.
 
Seeking Republican Votes
Mr. Dole said today that the White House insistence on the capital gains tax cut arose largely from concern about winning enough votes from House Republicans to pass a budget package. ''We've got to have enough votes,'' Mr. Dole said. ''That's why the White House is so concerned about the capital gains issue, in my view. In addition, it's a promise that President Bush made in the campaign.''
The Senator spoke on the CBS News television program ''Face The Nation,'' where he appeared with the Senate Democratic majority leader, George Mitchell of Maine. After agreeing with Mr. Mitchell's assessment that capital gains and the whole issue of tax fairness had become the major sticking points in the budget talks, Mr. Dole said the negotiators were trying to address the fairness question.
''We're looking at ways to achieve what the majority leader suggests,'' he said, ''and that is, how we can increase taxes on upper income in a way that will, in effect, maybe pierce this so-called bubble, but maybe not go clear up to 33 percent.''
 
Criticism of Dole Expected
Administration officials said Mr. Dole appeared to be speaking for himself. But in discussions before the formal talks between Congress and the White House, the White House Budget Director, Richard G. Darman, had floated the idea of raising the top tax rate for the wealthy to 31 percent.
Mr. Dole was not available to elaborate on his comments today, but his suggestion is likely to provoke strong criticism from rank and file House Republicans, many of whom have signed a letter saying they will block any budget package that touches tax rates.
Mr. Dole has already incurred the wrath of the White House and conservative House Republicans with his suggestion last week that budget negotiators sever the capital gains cut from the deficit reduction package.
Mr. Mitchell said Democrats would be prepared to consider that suggestion but that the Administration seemed to have ruled it out.
''If this were a negotiation just among the members of Congress, that is the Congressional leadership, we could have had an agreement a couple of weeks ago,'' Mr. Mitchell said.

HEADLINE: Canada Has Created Model Health System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a physician who has trained and practiced in both Canada and the United States, I can attest to the superiority of the Canadian medical system and its feasibility here. It is an efficiently administered plan in an immense country that also has a large underclass, and it results in better health for the average person. 
It produces greater consumer satisfaction than the system of any other country in the industrial world, in contrast to substantial and growing dissatisfaction in the United States. All this with a smaller share of the gross national product devoted to health in a country less wealthy than the United States.
Yes, the system has flaws. Democratically elected governments underfinance hospitals in some provinces, preferring to use tax dollars elsewhere. Some people have to wait for nonurgent surgery. Governments tend to skimp on the latest high-tech machinery, but no more than Canada's equally cautious private sector. Pressures north of the border are similar: an aging population, high public expectations, a proliferation of expensive procedures.
According to an analysis in the August Consumer Reports, balancing health-care premiums, co-payments and deductibles against the increased taxes to match the system in the United States, the average family would come out approximately even. This is before computing the value of time lost in filling out forms, paying bills and communicating (usually arguing) with providers.
I have met only three types of Americans, who, given the facts, prefer this country's nonsystem: doctors, employees of the health insurance industry and the politicians who receive contributions from the other two.
 
LEONARD LEVEN, M.D.
Elmsford, N.Y., Sept. 7, 1990

HEADLINE: Soviet Union Needs Modernized Banking

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Economic and social deterioration in the Soviet Union (''The Bread Shelves in Moscow Shops Suddenly Go Bare,'' front page, Sept. 4) threatens the best opportunity that country's talented and dynamic peoples have ever had to become democratic masters of their own destiny. Time is not on their side. The assistance that outsiders can offer the Soviets may be of profound importance.
A model for such assistance is a continuing program of the American Bar Association, with seminal support from the Soros Foundation, for training Soviet lawyers in the United States. This program has enjoyed signal success thus far.
The bar's nonnegotiable criteria for the program - consideration only of candidates with high competence in English and selection entirely by the American hosts - insure well-prepared Soviet participants of integrity and spunk.
A modernized banking system will be central to Soviet economic achievement. The 500-day plan that was unveiled Sept. 3 at a meeting of the Russian Parliament and intended to bring radical economic reform, now has the joint support of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic. It puts banking high on the list for action in the critical first 100 days.
Would the Soviets welcome American assistance in establishing the legal and regulatory structures for their new banking system and in developing appropriate domestic and international banking institutions and procedures and training?
Representatives of the American Bankers Association and the American Bar Association and others are beginning to explore those questions together. Their efforts deserve broad support from their members and other bankers and lawyers, from schools of business and law and government, and others - in the interest of the United States as much as the Soviet Union.
 
CHRISTOPHER MAY
Washington, Sept. 11, 1990
 The writer is a lawyer.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Shanghai Breezes

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
On a foggy morning about a dozen years ago, passengers on a flying jalopy were told that Beijing was socked in and the pilot had been diverted to Shanghai. We landed at a deserted airfield; no planes were expected at Shanghai that morning, and nobody on the ground quite knew what to do with a planeload of transients. Hungry and disconsolate, we sat in a barren waiting room, a handful of Westerners stranded in a Communist wasteland.
Then an aged, bent Chinese woman, muttering to herself, came bustling onto the dreary scene with a large tray holding bowls of noodles. Not your ordinary noodles, but a wondrous Shanghai breakfast with chunks of chicken and an exotic green vegetable in a broth dominated by wide, slippery, handmade noodles. 
I can taste that magic bowl of noodles today, in my mind's tastebuds, as I overlook a city of 13 million from the 37th floor of the Shanghai Hilton, having just ordered a waffle with Vermont maple syrup for breakfast, while watching a live satellite telecast of the ''NBC Nightly News.''
Tourist China ain't the same. In the 70's, you could count on unrelieved mustiness, uncomprehending telephone operators and stark white dining rooms with Western guests strictly segregated; drains in the bathrooms were plugged by rubber stoppers attached to rusty chains, and only your shortwave radio kept you in touch with the outside world. The visitor's life was uncomfortable in many ways, but the feeling was gloriously foreign.
Today, the momentum of the economic open door of the 80's is carrying China's major cities into the 21st century. High-rise hotel and convention complexes create new skylines. The mustiness has been replaced by the smell of metal polish, because proud new managers of these half-occupied glass and chrome palaces live in terror of tarnish; the well-trained young help eagerly and courteously address even Japanese visitors in English. They all want to make you feel at home, as if home were not the place you wanted to get away from.
Some things have not changed: off the tourist track, the real China exists in all its bravery and squalor. Outside the travelers' cocoon, the dead hand of Communism stifles dissent just as it did in the 70's.
But the sense of repression is not the same everywhere. Let's use two contrasting cities to illustrate the forces going head to head in China today.
Shanghai is to Beijing as New York is to Washington: bigger, more colorful and cosmopolitan, its people more outspoken and sassy, resentful at having to pay taxes to prettify the parasitic capital but warily respectful of its greater power.
Shanghai is a real city, unplanned, with traffic-clogged narrow streets and no state security goons tailing resident foreign reporters; Beijing is laid out to rule, majestic in its wide boulevards, conscious of history in the Forbidden City and Tiananmen, the national center of control and corruption. Political Beijing hustles; businesslike Shanghai bustles.
Beijing, permeated by a fear of chaos if a billion people break loose, represents the stiff spirit of order. Shanghai, which did not shoot its protesters last summer and does not join in the jamming of the Voice of America today, stands for the spirit of enterprise that flourishes in a freer atmosphere.
We cannot carry this analogy too far; Shanghai was the hotbed of Maoist radicalism that was defeated by Dengist reformers. But the point is valid: the farther you get from the socialist center, the more China becomes Chinese.
Shanghai's Mayor, Zhu Rongji, although a friend of Beijing's fearsome Li Peng, bears a curious resemblance to former New York Mayor Ed Koch. When I tried to set him up with an opening softball question at a dinner last week, Mayor Zhu responded with a bit of politico-media wisdom that deserves adage status: ''A softball question is usually followed by a hardball question.'' The man is wryly hip and slyly practical; will his ilk, who could attract foreign investment, run China after the great funeral?
Not even a peripatetic Bigfoot knows for sure. China could go completely totalitarian, or break completely free, or muddle down the middle until the Beijing way or the Shanghai style emerged triumphant.
But I can conjure a vision. The stultifying octogenarians are gone; the Politburo is meeting in the Forbidden City; the opposing forces are in deadlock, getting hungry and irritable. Suddenly, this aged, bent Chinese woman, muttering to herself, appears with a magic bowl of Shanghai noodles . . .

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
When Decline Hurts

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Massachusetts voters turned angrily against incumbents in primaries last week, and many other states report a mood of hostility toward politicians. Why? The experts talk of high state taxes, corruption, cynicism. But a far more profound phenomenon may underlie the discontent.
I believe we may be seeing an early sign of the process that Professor Paul Kennedy described in his book: ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers.'' That is the economic decline of a great power even as it continues to exercise its military might in the world. 
The United States right now is marshaling large military forces in the Persian Gulf. But in order to pay for that effort it has had to hold a tin cup out to allies and friends. There could hardly be a clearer demonstration of the gap between the ambitions of our policy abroad and the weakness of its economic base at home.
The same fiscal bankruptcy that makes us ask for help on Gulf costs has had devastating domestic effects. In particular, it has put a heavy strain on state and local governments.
During the Reagan years the Federal Government taxed less and spent more - on weapons. The Reagan Administration's non-answer to the resulting deficit was to cut, indeed virtually to eliminate, all kinds of Federal aid to the states. The money saved was piddling compared with the deficit, but the local pain inflicted was great.
Some things just have to be done. When the Federal Government reduces payments for hospital care of the indigent, cities and states must somehow find the money.
Massachusetts and New York and New Jersey and other states are now feeling the responsibilities dumped on them by Washington. In boom times the burden could be borne. Now it demands higher taxes or bloody budget cuts. The states cannot run deficits. The voters have to pay, and they are angry.
A curious result of our federal system is that the anger is misdirected. The politicians close at hand are the targets. They have done plenty of things wrong, but those really responsible are in Washington - and somehow hardly anyone associates them with the pain.
Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York has called attention to this political curiosity. President Reagan's ''new federalism'' amounted to making state and local taxpayers bear new burdens, but they did not notice who had done it.
Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts made a similar point when I asked him about the reasons for voter discontent. ''It's a combination,'' he said, ''of 10 years of Washington kidding the public about paying the bills, and the steady dropping of more and more burdens on the states.''
Of course it is not economic folly alone that has put the United States into an economic decline - and made it a country with bad schools, inadequate health care, uncompetitive technology. It is failed political leadership.
Vested interests scream at any proposal that would touch them, and the politicians draw back. Steps obviously needed right now - such as higher gasoline taxes and realistic pricing of Medicare for the well-off elderly - are dismissed. All President Bush suggests to balance the budget is more tax cuts for the rich.
The challenges to reviving the American economic base obviously could be met. But so far there is no sign that they will be. The political will is just not there. Perhaps the greed and folly of Reaganism did too much damage. But that was the political leadership we wanted.
That is why Professor Kennedy's historical warnings are so troubling. For what we are experiencing in the United States may be more than a mistake here and there. It may be a leadership failure that reflects a people's unwillingness to meet the responsibilities of a dynamic society.
In a piece written for New Perspectives Quarterly, Professor Kennedy said of the American commitment in the Persian Gulf that ''the cause may be just, the deployment impressive.'' But in the 17th century, he said, Spain was impressive in deploying armies abroad, while at home it was sagging in ways that proved decisive: ''Massive debts, inefficient industries, reliance on foreign manufacturers, vested interests. . . .
''The emperors, kings, prime ministers and presidents of great powers have always preferred the heady world of diplomacy, war and international affairs to the unglamorous realm of fiscal reform, educational change and domestic renewal. . . . It is left to later generations to pay the price.''

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
New York City On the Rocks? Don't Bet on It

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
A looming recession, coupled with soaring energy prices, presage the loss of nearly 100,000 jobs in the first year of the new decade and will keep the number of employed New Yorkers from expanding at all in the next 10 years.
That forecast was the product of a computer program that used 1,500 equations and 1,400 variables. It was also wrong.
While other aspects of the Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates 1980 projection proved prescient, it failed to anticipate the financial services boom that contributed to an increase of more than 300,000 jobs, or 10 percent, in the 1980's. 
''The major thing that changed it,'' said William J. Lawrence, an economics professor at Pace University's Graduate School of Business who designed the computer model, ''was what happened down on Wall Street.''
That the projection failed to register the first whirrings of an engine that would drive the city's economy through much of the decade is less a reflection of the formula's efficacy than of the vicissitudes of forecasting the consequences of events that are still evolving or events that have yet to occur.
Even if the forecast for yesterday was rain and it didn't, deciding on the basis of yesterday's experience to leave your umbrella home the next time rain is predicted would be imprudent. The burden of being prepared is likely to be outweighed by the costs of getting soaked. Being prepared does not demand, though, that you open your umbrella or move to an arid locale just because it is cloudy.
Dire forecasts about New York City's fate have been precipitated by its latest economic slump, social malaise and understandable preoccupation with crime. No forecaster can say with certainty, though, whether the city is slipping into another cyclical recession or whether it is headed for a permanent decline.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has been saying that a social, political and economic crisis confronting the city today is far more serious than the fiscal crisis it survived in the 1970's.
The Ford Administration's initial response to the city's plight then - capsulized by The Daily News as ''Drop Dead'' - provoked an outcry that persuaded out-of-towners that their prosperity was inexorably linked to the city's.
In contrast, Mr. Rohatyn said, reaction has been muted to President Bush's recent assessment that New York ''is becoming more expensive, more difficult and more dangerous than ever before.''
One reason, Mr. Rohatyn said, is that many people, himself included, largely concur. Another, he said, is that the city lacks the structured cooperation between business and labor and the strategic alliance between the city and state that enabled it to cope with the last fiscal crisis.
''There is a feeling of helplessness about the city's long-term problems,'' he lamented last week at a forum sponsored by New York University's Urban Research Center to discuss a new book, ''Urban Politics: New York Style'' (M. E. Sharpe: Armonk, N.Y.).
Two weeks ago Time magazine trumpeted the ''rotting'' of the Big Apple. Now, another magazine, NY, published by the Manhattan Institute, a policy research center, asks, ''Is New York going down the tubes?''
Peter D. Salins, the author of the article and chairman of the Department of Urban Affairs and Planning at Hunter College, says no, because New York has the nation's strongest municipal economy and will remain preeminent if only it reduces business taxes, shrinks government and improves many services that should not be sacrificed to austerity.
''The question is not whether New York will survive, but will New York thrive,'' Mr. Salins wrote.
Many economists - among them, Robert A. Dye, director of state forecasting for the WEFA Group, Wharton Econometrics' successor - have trouble, though, identifying an industry that, without a major rebound on Wall Street or changes in Federal spending priorities, will drive the city's revival, much as financial services did a decade ago.
Mr. Salins suggested that the city would capitalize on the ''world information economy.'' Dr. Lawrence predicted that revival would be spurred by small businesses that might become even more profitable after a recession made labor and land costs in New York more competitive with costs in the rest of the country.
''But,'' said Dr. Lawrence, who designed the computer model on which the gloomy 1980 Wharton forecast was based, ''I tend to be overly optimistic about the city.''

LENGTH: 1448 words

HEADLINE: On the Sidewalks, Business Is Booming

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Steven Frost makes his living on the street, selling toy spiders that jump when you squeeze a rubber ball. They are $3 each, two for $5.
''This is better than working in an office,'' the bushy-haired peddler said recently while standing on Broadway near 39th Street. ''I'll eat lunch and then maybe go to the movies.''
Mr. Frost's occupation has never seemed more common. As sales in stores across the city lag, commerce on the sidewalk is brisk. Peddling may be one of New York City's few remaining growth industries. 
Peddlers have set up shop on Fifth Avenue, which until recently was largely forbidden territory, have turned parts of Canal and 14th Streets, among others, into bazaars, have set up shop in Astoria, Queens, and are stirring animosities on 125th Street, where many white and Asian shopkeepers are competing with black street vendors.
''It's hard to find a block where you don't see someone doing it,'' said Carol O'Cleireacain, the New York City Finance Commissioner, who knows that the city is losing tax revenue from much of the curbside business, but does not have an estimate of how much. ''It's part of the third worldization of New York City.''
New York limits the number of licenses for general merchandise vendors to 853, although military veterans, who are automatically entitled to a license, have pushed the total above 1,000. This year the city's Consumer Affairs Department will issue about 50 licenses, drawing from a waiting list that has 710 names and has been frozen since 1988.
But many vendors, like Mr. Frost, do not wait for licenses or heed regulations that, with a few exceptions, prohibit even licensed vendors from peddling anything but food and printed material in much of midtown and downtown Manhattan.
As part of the proliferation of curbside commerce, sides of newsstands are being turned into mini-malls of clothing, sunglasses, jewelry and souvenirs, even though the stands are not supposed to sell goods - other than publications - that cost more than $2. Several newsstands near Madison Square Garden are so filled with other merchandise that it is hard to find any publications.
Vendors are also subletting store windows or the space in front of them for their own displays, creating stores-within-stores that are especially common along 14th Street and around Times Square. The destitute and the homeless add to the clutter, spreading assortments of used clothes, battered furniture and magazines on the sidewalks.
Although city officials and urban planners refused even to estimate the total number of peddlers, licensed and unlicensed, in New York City, there is a consensus that the number has risen sharply, propelled not only by economic forces but also by changes in the city's demographics.
Many of the new sidewalk merchants emigrated from countries like Senegal, where peddling is a tradition. High rents have also pushed more business onto the sidewalks, where the city's heavy pedestrian flow provides a steady stream of customers. And the faltering economy seems to have made some New Yorkers eager for bargains, turning the curbside sale of T-shirts, books, costume jewelry, cologne, video and audio cassettes, telephones, and, of course, umbrellas into big business. One peddler has been spotted lugging a room-size rug around the Upper West Side.
 
Counterfeit Merchandise
Although the authorities say the peddlers are usually not selling stolen merchandise, they quickly add that much of it is counterfeit, such as watches that look like Rolexes and T-shirts with unlicensed reproductions of Gucci, Chanel or Fendi logos or the snarling countenance of Bart Simpson.
''I honestly believe we are talking about $100 million in gross sales revenues,'' said Tom Cusick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, which represents some of the city's toniest -and most anti-peddler - merchants. Unpaid sales and income taxes on the curbside transactions add up to millions of dollars, he believes.
Mr. Cusick estimates that book stands, which are exempt from many city regulations under the Constiution, generate $250 to $300 a day in gross revenues, with about $40 in cash going to the vendor, who is often an employee. A T-shirt stand can gross $1,000 a day, he believes. ''This is a well-organized activity,'' he said. ''The people on the street are largely employees, and it's all a cash business.''
Mr. Frost, who tried selling other ersatz insects before discovering the spiders, which are imported from Poland, says he grossed $75,000 in the best of his three years as a peddler.
 
Arrested 15 Times
''But if you get arrested, it's three days in jail and they take away your stuff,'' Mr. Frost said, adding that he has been arrested 15 times.
As illegal peddling has grown, the Peddler Task Force, a group of 25 police officers and five supervisors who cover Manhattan from the Battery to 59th Street, found that many of their summonses - which totaled 50,374 in 1985 alone - were being issued over and over to the same people, who considered the fines a cost of doing business. So the squad began arresting illegal peddlers and confiscating their goods. Last year, it made 3,411 arrests and 5,174 confiscations.
But an arrest ties an officer up for hours, and the city's courts and jails are already crowded with defendants accused of more serious offenses. And the peddlers, in response to the confiscations, have learned to keep inventories thin. Watches hawked for $20 to $30 are packed into briefcases in hotels on the West Side, so if a peddler is caught he will lose only the watches in his case. The peddlers also enlist look-outs and money-runners.
Lieut. Robert J. Louttit, the peddling squad's commanding officer, said he would need twice as many officers to ''to enforce the regulations as they exist.'' But reinforcements do not seem likely anytime soon. Earlier in the year, his officers found themselves being assigned other duties, like policing demonstrations, and the squad's $375,000 overtime budget was cut.
A letter-writing campaign by merchants moved City Hall to restore the squad's overtime budget, and the squad staged a series of sweeps in July that resulted in 700 arrests.
But even as the police were making inroads, a group of peddlers were winning in court what amounts to a special franchise on city sidewalks. Joseph Kaswan convinced a judge in January that a state law allowing disabled veterans like him to peddle goods in any street or alley took precedence over city regulations that ban even licensed merchandise vendors from many streets. Now many veterans peddle wares on Fifth Avenue.
''I'm not trying to upset people,'' said Mr. Kaswan, 72 years old, who took up peddling a few years ago. He has suggested that some of the stores on Fifth Avenue might want to help peddlers build gentrified versions of the pushcarts that plied the Lower East Side so long ago, but indicates that the response has been less than encouraging.
 
Trouble at Tiffany's
Tensions rose in front of Tiffany's -an establishment with a relationship with vendors that ''is not considered cordial,'' according to Fernanda Gilligan, a Tiffany's group vice president -when a row of white planters appeared on the sidewalk in front of the store where Milton Brown and other disabled veterans wanted to set up their tables.
''The security guards started calling us names,'' Mr. Brown said the other day, as he sold T-shirts for $5 in front of the burnished facade of Gucci, an establishment he said was more sympathetic. ''It almost got into a physical confrontation.''
''These people are very unfair -we're the smallest guys on the block,'' said Mr. Brown, who adds that he pays taxes and issues receipts.
Mr. Cusick of the Fifth Avenue Association said the police are doing the best they can under the circumstances. He talks about an effort to seize counterfeit goods from vendors, though he is not likely to get city police officers to carry it out.
 
Not on Rodeo Drive
The peddlers clog already congested sidewalks, often deprive the city of tax revenue and ''bring down the whole image,'' Mr. Cusak said. ''On Rodeo Drive, you won't see a single vendor anywhere.''
But instead of shooing peddlers from place to place, John A. Gaber, an assistant professor of city and regional planning at Pratt Institute, suggested that the city lure them to special districts, like 14th Street. In contrast to Fifth Avenue, Professor Gaber notes that some merchants there welcome the peddlers, who pay rent for display space and attract potential customers.
''These are people who are making a living,'' he said. ''They're an important element of Manhattan street life.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Spent $21.5 Billion in 1989 To Support Families of Teen-Agers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
The Federal Government spent more than $21.5 billion last year on welfare programs for families started by teen-agers, said a report released today.
The amount is $1.7 billion higher than for 1988, partly because of inflation and expansion of Medicaid benefits but also because of an increase in births to teen-agers, said the report by the Center for Population Options, a private organization that concentrates on worldwide population issues.
The center said the figures illustrated the need for greater efforts to prevent pregnancies among teen-agers, including sex education, family planning, counseling, support for celibacy, access to contraception and medical services, including abortion. 
''We can no longer let our youth stumble into parenting, a course that should be embarked on only when one is ready, willing and able to become a parent,'' the report said.
The costs of pregnancies for teen-agers go far beyond those of public support, the report said, adding that child-bearing too early often impoverishes ''the lives of girls brought too soon into the rigors and responsibilities of motherhood, of boys bewildered and unable to parent and provide adequately, of babies not planned or welcomed.''
 
Widespread Burden
''It places a heavy burden on families and communities and contributes to our country's unconscionably high rates of low birth weight and neonatal mortality,'' it said.
The most alarming increases in such pregnancies are occurring among 15- to 17-year-olds, the report said. After a decreasing rate of births in this age group from 1970 into the mid-1980's, the rate began increasing. It jumped from 30.6 per 1,000 teen-agers in 1986 to 33.8 in 1988, according to the National Center for Health Statistics.
In estimating Federal spending on families started by teen-agers, the center included families headed by mothers now in their teens as well as those in which the mother is 20 years or older but had her first child as a teen-ager. The cost includes the Federal Government's share for Aid for Families with Dependent Children, Medicaid and food stamps received by these families.
The center also calculated the public cost for five states and two cities for 1989, adding in the welfare expenditures of the states, cities and towns.
These were: Louisiana, $360 million; New Mexico, $80 million; Oregon, $174 million; Vermont, $39 million; Wisconsin, $437 million; Baltimore, $246 million, and St. Louis, $81 million.

HEADLINE: Sharon Ostow, Publisher, Is Married

 BODY:
Sharon E. Ostow, the founder and publisher of The Northeast Equine Journal in Keene, N.H., was married yesterday in New York to James A. Rousmaniere Jr., the editor and president of The Keene Sentinel. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated at the Water Club.

She is the founder and the former publisher of Leisure Weekly in Keene. Her father is the former president of Sharon Mills and the vice president of Ostow & Jacobs, a home furnishings manufacturer in New York.
The bridegroom, 45, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rousmaniere of Southbury, Conn. He is a graduate of Harvard University and a former economics reporter for The Baltimore Sun. His father is a fund-raising consultant. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of the bride.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
After 2 Decades of Silence, a Novel on Alcoholism

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Sams in a Dry Season
By Ivan Gold
244 pages. Houghton Mifflin/Seymour Lawrence. $19.95.
In the early 1960's, Ivan Gold published ''Nickel Miseries,'' a collection of stories, some of which he had written as an undergraduate at Columbia and as a disciple of the teacher and critic Lionel Trilling. The collection's tough, economical style and acute moral vision of society's outsiders made Mr. Gold a writer to watch, especially in light of the decade's upheavals. A novel, ''Sick Friends,'' followed in 1969; it was full of talent but self-indulgent. Then Mr. Gold fell silent. No more books for two decades. One quickly learns why at the opening of his newly published novel, ''Sams in a Dry Season.'' The first chapter is called ''Still Drinking After All These Years.'' The year is 1976. Jason Sams is a creative-writing teacher at the University of Greater Boston and about to lose his job to an English novelist named Fiona. 
''He was entering his eighth year of marriage, father of one and author of two (in marked contrast to Fiona, divorced dam of seven, perpetrator of six), 43 and intermittently aware that alcohol had become less useful to him than once it had been, at some indeterminate period in his life. He knew there might well come a day (comfortably in the future) when he would elect to give it up entirely.'' But that future is more imminent and less comfortable than Jason anticipates. In the pages that follow, he will descend on New York City to see if he can scare up still more advance money for the new book he isn't writing and to drop in on his parents, who have stuck it out in an apartment in the deteriorating East Village.
There will be no more advance money; publishing times have changed, and the editor who once succored Jason has dropped dead on a golf course at the age of 37. But when Jason visits his parents on the Friday night Sabbath, he learns that his father's twin brother has died and will be buried Sunday. So the trip has a point after all. Jason will stay on for the funeral.
Though time trickles away unaccountably, the weekend is not a lost one. Bad memories keep Jason from oblivion. Wrestling with these, Jason finds he doesn't just need a drink. Drink has become the whole point. On the Saturday night before the funeral, meaning to nurse a glass of Scotch, he ends up downing two entire bottles.
But on Monday aboard the train home, a miracle occurs in the form of panicked withdrawal. Back in Boston, he staggers to Alcoholics Anonymous. By the end of the novel, he is keeping a journal. The book in the reader's hands is the story's ultimate resolution. It is an occasion for cheering. Though the details are fictional, the story strikes one as too close to autobiography not to engage the reader in what one inevitably reads as Mr. Gold's personal struggle.
But one wants the book to be more than an inspirational story. One wants Jason's alcoholism to have some deeper meaning. Mr. Gold tries. At several points in the story, he links Jason's drinking to his writing, as if he were going to confront the great mystery of why so many American writers drink. But he won't romanticize Jason or let him kid himself. Jason may drink because writing makes him anxious, but the only effect of alcohol is to interfere further with his writing. Jason is long past the stage when drinking can do him any good creatively, if in fact it ever did.
Mr. Gold also tries to fashion a prose style that reflects the effect of alcohol on his character's awareness. As Jason goes off on his weekend bender, the novel's sentences begin to fragment and collide. The technique may even be a conscious tribute to certain of Mr. Gold's predecessors. ''In his time . . . he had become as smashed as Papa ever got, in Cuba or the Keys, as creatively looped as Faulkner ever got in his own barn, ah now, that bastard, I devoured him, even read Mosquitoes twice and tried like hell to read the poetry, then for years wrote just like him, if you believe that, Jewish kid from the Lower East Side of Manhattan playing Ivy League aristocrat way up there on Morningside Heights knowing he would never make it until one day having read and reread all the works of the great William Faulkner published to that time began writing like the mind of the South, struggling toward a style, until one day confronted the man himself. . . .'' And so on for whole pages.
But such a style suggests inebriation only at several removes. It is even far from the prose disintegration of Malcolm Lowry's Consul in ''Under the Volcano.'' It is closer to what a sober mind might apprehend watching a drunken mind reeling.
In the end, Mr. Gold is really too tough-minded to find high art in the subject of alcoholism. As Jason falls in step with the routines of A.A., he learns that the objective is to get through one day at a time and that, as members themselves often say, the reason drunks drink is that they are drunks.
In the end, ''Sams in a Dry Season'' is worthwhile simply because it is the well-told story of a man's recovery. Now that Ivan Gold has written that book, he can move on and write others.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ivan Gold (Houghton Mifflin/Seymour Lawrence)
