LENGTH: 1442 words

HEADLINE: In Shift, Fed Puts Emphasis on Inflation

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
After 15 months of gradually lowering interest rates to avoid a recession, the Federal Reserve has shifted strategy and is trying to freeze rates at their present levels, having concluded that inflation is now the greatest threat to the American economy.
The inflationary impact of rising oil prices is the primary reason for the strategy shift. The Federal Reserve's resolve has been bolstered by other leading industrial nations, which are also holding up interest rates. The Group of Seven industrialized nations endorsed the strategy in a communique on Saturday.
But above all, Federal Reserve officials insist that the United States economy, although sluggish, is not in a recession and, therefore, lower rates are not justified, no matter what the other industrialized nations might do in the future. 
''There isn't a convincing signal to move interest rates dramatically up or down,'' said Robert T. Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. Nine of the Federal Reserve's 17 regional bank presidents and governors offered the same opinion, in recent interviews and public statements. And Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, insisted that the nation was not in a recession.
Mr. Greenspan, in fact, offered a new, more stringent definition of recession, one that requires the economy to go into a steep decline. He suggested that the Federal Reserve might refuse to ease interest rates if the nation entered what most economists consider to be a recession, namely six months in which the gross national product shrinks.
''Mr. Greeenspan is defining recession as more complex than simply two quarters of negative economic growth,'' said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and the chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. ''This new definition of his, which is new to me, leads me to believe that Mr. Greenspan seeks maneuvering room not to ease interest rates despite weak economic data.''
However the experts define a recession, millions of Americans believe the nation is in one now, public opinion polls show. Layoffs, rising unemployment, salary freezes, the decline in home prices and other hardships have brought them to this conclusion. But some Fed officials hesitate to use the word recession, even for the Northeast, the region widely considered to be experiencing the greatest economic hardship.
''Things are undoubtedly in a downturn in New England, but conditions are mixed,'' said Richard F. Syron, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, which covers the New England region.
 
Major Economic Danger
Absent a recession, as the Federal Reserve defines the word, Mr. Greenspan raised inflation as the ''major danger'' to the economy, particularly if rising oil prices lead people to demand higher wages. Once ''oil prices have either stabilized or come down, you still have got the wage inflation in there to contend with,'' he told the Joint Economic Committee in testimony last week.
Then he, in effect, ruled out another reduction in interest rates soon. ''I think it is very clear that there are actions that we can take in the short run, which would be perceived to have short-term benefits, but could have intermediate and long-term major negatives,'' he said.
Mr. Greenspan and other Federal Reserve officials believe that lower interest rates would stimulate the American economy, perhaps within a few weeks, by encouraging people and companies to borrow for consumer spending and investment. The construction industry and home sales, in particular, would get a push.
But the officials also contend that while high interest rates tend to reduce spending and investment, over the long run they hold down prices by reducing the demand for available goods.
Mortgages and most other consumer loans now carry rates of 10 percent or more, a level that has helped to weaken the economy in recent months.
 
Stable Monetary Policy
The Group of Seven's communique, issued on Saturday, noted that higher oil prices posed a risk of inflation and recession and asserted that inflation was the greater immediate danger. It said ''stability-oriented monetary policy'' was the ''correct policy response.''
The Federal Reserve subscribed to the communique, although Mr. Greenspan contends that his central bank can split away and manipulate American interest rates separately, if an American recession or rising inflation should require such action. The United States economy is far weaker today than the economies of most of the other industrial nations.
Two developments could end the Fed's interest rate freeze over the next few weeks. One involves bank lending practices. As the economy weakens, banks, fearful of defaults, have made fewer loans. To offset the credit squeeze, the Federal Reserve reduced interest rates in July and could do so again, although Fed officials say bank lending has not become more restrictive in recent weeks.
 
Budget Accord a Factor
The Federal Reserve might also lower rates if Congress and the Bush Administration agree to a plan to reduce the budget deficit, although Fed officials insist that a budget agreement will not automatically produce a drop in interest rates.
''There has been a perception from Alan Greenspan's testimony that as soon as a believable budget accord is struck, the Fed will ease,'' said Roger Guffey, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo.
''That is too simplistic,'' he said. ''What would happen is that once a credible accord was struck, long-term bond rates would come down and the Fed would happily confirm the lower rates. It would not lead the process.''
A credible agreement requires tax increases and spending cuts that reduce the budget deficit by $50 billion in the fiscal year beginning on Oct. 1 and by $500 billion over five years, Mr. Greenspan said last week. Such a cutback would probably convince the bond markets that inflation is under control, he has said.
Without a budget agreement, the decision to postpone another reduction in interest rates means the nation may find itself deep in a recession before the Federal Reserve acts again. That happened during the 1981-1982 recession, which was nearly a year old before the Federal Reserve, then led by Paul A. Volcker, the chairman, reduced rates.
Mr. Volcker's resistance to lower rates drew sharp criticism from Reagan Administration officials, and in 1987 Mr. Reagan replaced Mr. Volcker with Mr. Greenspan. Mr. Volcker, however, had to deal with a Consumer Price Index that rose by more than 10 percent in some years.
 
Seeking a Balance
Until the Middle East crisis, the Consumer Price Index has risen at an annual rate of 5 percent or less during most of Mr. Greenspan's three years as chairman. As a result, he has been free to make minor adjustments in interest rates, trying to keep the economy free of recession while trying to reduce the inflation rate to well under 4 percent.
Mr. Greenspan once told Congress that if the economy falls into recession, the recession should be attributed to a mistake in Federal Reserve policy. He and other Fed officials still hold the view, but say they have not made a mistake so far and the economy, despite its weakness, is not in recession.
Now, Mr. Greenspan seems to be hedging that earlier statement. The gross national product, measuring the total value of the goods and services created in the nation, has grown at an annual rate of only 1.5 percent this year, and Mr. Greenspan suggested the G.N.P. could tilt into one or two quarters of mildly negative growth without being in recession.
 
Steeper Decline Necessary
A true recession, he argued, requires a much steeper decline, one in which inventories of unsold goods pile up as consumer spending declines. This leads to sharp cutbacks in new orders, falling corporate profits and widespread layoffs. This process has caused some postwar recessions, in which the G.N.P. has contracted for two straight quarters, but not all of them.
Whatever Mr. Greenspan's new recession requirements, the Federal Reserve for months had made preventing a recession a top priority. From June 1989 until last month, the Fed had shaved 1.5 percentage points off short-term interest rates in small steps, most of them taken last year.
This gradual approach brought criticism from Bush Administration officials, who called on the Federal Reserve to bring down rates more quickly as the economy weakened earlier this year. Lately, however, the criticism has declined, and the Administration has even agreed with Mr. Greenspan that the economy is not in recession.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Economic Analysis

HEADLINE: Finance Chiefs Back Money Rein

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Most of the world's industrial and developing nations decided this weekend not to try to shield consumers from higher energy prices, endorsing a strategy of tight monetary policies that increases the risk of a recession.
The world's finance ministers, at a series of meetings here, agreed to refrain from subsidies or price controls to cushion their countries from the short-term effects of the turmoil in the Persian Gulf.
The finance ministers are gathered for the preliminaries to the 45th joint annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and its sister lending organization, the World Bank, which begins Tuesday.
 
Strength Is Seen
The prevailing view of economic managers of the seven leading industrialized countries, the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, who met for seven hours on Saturday, is that their economies are still strong enough to resist a downturn. 
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said that although economic growth was ''slower than it should be, I don't accept the use of the word recession.'' He added, ''There is underlying power in this economy that's still with us.''
He told reporters that nothing had happened here this weekend to cause him to alter his thinking that financial markets would take heart from a bipartisan agreement to cut the Federal budget deficit and provide the latitude for further cuts in interest rates.
 
'Correct Policy Response'
A communique issued Saturday night after the finance ministers of the seven industrial countries met noted that the rises in oil prices brought the twin risks of inflation and lower economic growth and said that ''stability-oriented monetary policies and sound fiscal policies constitute the correct policy response.''
The task now, Mr. Brady said, was to ''navigate between those two risks.''
Advocates of the new strategy say that to act otherwise would be to repeat the policy mistakes of the 1970's, when oil prices also rose sharply. At that time interest rates were cut and efforts were made to cushion consumers through subsidies and price controls. But inflationary pressures continued to rise, leading to the stringent tightening of monetary policies in the late 1970's and the recession of 1981-82.
As Canada's Finance Minister, Michael Wilson, put it, ''If we don't get on top of inflationary pressures now, the difficulties will be far more severe in the future.''
The strong disinflation of the early 1980's, said Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, laid the foundation for the exceptionally durable period of noninflationary growth in the main industrial countries throughout the past eight years.
Still, he called it an ''uncomfortable message'' in countries like Britain, where interest rates have been high for a considerable period and output is slowing.
While the focus has been on the general economic policy response to rising oil prices, great attention is also being paid to aid packages for the developing countries most severely affected by the seven-week crisis in the Middle East.
 
Aid From Rich Countries
Such aid is being prepared by rich surplus countries, like Japan, Germany and Saudi Arabia, and by both the monetary fund and the World Bank, which are being pushed by their members to be more flexible and responsive to the needs of their more distressed members.
Many third world countries have been hit not only by costlier energy and a slowdown in growth in industrial countries, which hurts their exports, but also by the loss of billions of dollars in worker remittances.
Egypt, Jordan, India, Bangladesh and other countries now have to house and feed thousands of workers who have returned from Kuwait and Iraq and whose earnings in support of relatives back home had been an economic lifeline.
''Let's assume that countries do what they have to do, and in particular that they accept to pass through to consumers the effects of this oil shock,'' said the fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus. ''Then the international institutions have to help.''
 
About $20 Billion Pledged
Donor countries have pledged about $20 billion, which is intended both to offset costs of the United States-led military operation in the Persian Gulf and to help the most seriously affected countries.
Both the I.M.F. and the World Bank, which have recently gotten members to approve big infusions of capital, plan to disburse more loans faster to these countries. In addition, the agencies have been called upon by donor countries to coordinate the money flows those nations are providing.
The precise role that the agencies will play is expected to come up during the annual meeting. Mr. Brady, for example, has specifically requested that a special emergency mechanism in the I.M.F., known as the Compensatory and Contingency Financing Facility, be expanded to deal with the crisis.
Also, he wants the fund to consider measures on a temporary basis to increase the access of members to fund resources. Other members are likely to back this request.
 
Recycling by Institutions
In contrast to the 1970's, when most of the recycling of petrodollars was handled by commercial banks, this time around, most experts are agreed, most of the recycling will be by governments and international financial institutions.
Banks have taken substantial losses on third world loans and are not anxious to make new loans to many of these countries. But some private bankers here noted that developing countries that are competitive and creditworthy can still count on commercial bank support.

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Rose by 23% Last Month

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Aided by a sharp increase from domestic manufacturers, new orders for American-made machine tools jumped 23 percent in August from the previous month's level, according to a monthly report being released today by the Association for Manufacturing Technology. But analysts said the rise was not significant because it was primarily the effect of an industry trade show.
The August level of machine tool orders rose to $288 million, from $234.2 million in July. The figure also represented a 26.8 percent increase from the level of machine tool orders in August of last year. For the first eight months of the year, machine-tool orders increased 1.8 percent from the similar period last year. 
Economists and analysts said that the August increase represented more of a surge in buying stimulated by the recent industry trade show in Chicago than any significant change in manufacturers' plans to increase their capital spending. Machine-tool orders typically rise whenever the trade show is held.
 
A Period of Uncertainty
''From all the estimates on what will happen in the economy, capital spending is going to be up just barely this year,'' said James J. Paper, an analyst with Kirkpatrick, Pettis, Smith, Polian Inc. in Omaha. ''We're going to have to wait and see what impact higher oil prices have on the economy and, then, on factory orders. It's possible that machine tool orders could trend south again.''
Albert W. Moore, president of the association, said that the figures did indeed represent increased buying by manufacturers. ''Many analysts see a shaky economy in the coming months,'' Mr. Moore said. ''But you wouldn't know it by watching the level of activity the last two weeks,'' he added, referring to the activity at the industry trade show.
Richard O. Priebe, a spokesman for the Cross & Trecker Corporation, a big machine tool producer based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., said his company had not yet seen any downward trend or slackening of orders from automobile manufacturers, who account for nearly half of its orders.
''There has been anticipation of a significant drop-off in spending,'' Mr. Priebe said. ''But there has been no sign of it yet. But then, there are no signs, either, of continuing upward movement.''
The August figures included a 25.4 increase in orders from domestic customers. Orders from foreign customers, which had shown particular strength through most of the year, were down 2.7 percent in August, the report said. Indeed, for the first eight months of 1990, orders from foreign customers were 13.3 percent higher than for the same period last year, while domestic orders were up only a tenth of 1 percent.
 
'Critical Indicators'
Machine tools are power-driven devices for cutting or shaping metal parts used in products as varied as appliances, vehicles, aircraft and construction materials. The strength of tool orders generally reflects the strength of industrial production, and economists consider patterns of machine tool sales critical indicators of capital spending by manufacturers.
Shipments of machine tools were up 3.8 percent in August from July's level, to $242.3 million. Shipments to foreign customers soared 75.3 percent in August, from July's level, while those to domestic customers were down 3.6 percent. Shipments were up 7.3 percent compared with August of last year, and up 8.7 percent for the first eight months of this year, compared with the period last year.
Orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, soared 64 percent in August, from July's level. That segment of the industry typically accounts for three-fourths of new orders. Orders for metal-forming tools dropped 45.6 percent in August.
The machine-tool order backlog stood at $1.61 billion, up from $1.56 billion in July. The figure for August 1989 was $2.13 billion.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Inventory Data Can Be Deceptive

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE sluggish American economy is in danger of sliding into a recession. Few Americans dispute that; yet they are being told by economists to take comfort. The national economy will muddle through, as long as companies maintain small stockpiles of unsold goods. The problem with this thesis is that when sales plunge recessions can be born anyway, no matter how small the stockpiles.
A shoe store owner, for example, might keep in inventory only four pairs of size 9D men's shoes, instead of the eight pairs he had maintained in inventory just before the 1981-1982 recession. Overnight delivery from his supplier keeps the stock at a steady four pairs. But if sales suddenly drop from three pairs a day to one, then the store owner has to drastically reduce his daily order or his inventory will quickly rise beyond four pairs. 
The factory that supplies the store owner, in turn, has to cut back production and lay off workers. This process of production cutbacks, shrinking profits and layoffs, when it occurs across many industries, is what in the past has pushed a weak American economy into recession.
''Everybody argues that inventories have been under great control, and that is true,'' said Gerald Donahoe, a Commerce Department economist. ''But the issue isn't inventory levels, it is how quickly they might rise, even from a low level, if sales collapse.''
What is more, computer monitoring of inventories and just-in-time overnight delivery, much praised by economists and business executives as a means of keeping down inventories, could work against the economy. ''It means that businessmen might start canceling orders sooner than in the past,'' Mr. Donahoe said.
When inventory accumulation does occur, the starting point is usually the retail sector. Stockpiles build up in stores as sales fall, then at the wholesale and distributor level as orders are canceled, then among manufacturers. In fact, an inventory buildup might be getting under way at the retail and wholesale levels now, although the Commerce Department is slow in catching changes.
Monthly inventory surveys, based on questionnaires filled out by a few thousand companies, produce national statistics with a 60-day delay. July inventories, for example, were published only last week, and they are incomplete. The statistics cover primarily the manufacturing sector. Supplies held in stock by service companies, the construction and mining industries, airlines, telephone companies and the agricultural sector are calculated annually, not monthly. And they can account for 20 percent of the nation's total inventories, Mr. Donahoe notes.
Still, the July inventory report showed that manufactured goods held by retailers rose to $236.4 billion in July from about $232.7 billion in March and April. A similar rise to $236 billion late last year raised concerns then about recession, but sales held up and inventories declined, without forcing drastic cutbacks in production and layoffs.
''The issue is always sales, not inventory levels,'' says A. Gary Shilling, an economics consultant. Retail sales weakened notably in August, and now the question is whether the weakness will continue into the Christmas season, finally bringing on a classic recession in which the nation's industries produce so little wealth that the gross national product shrinks in value.
Although retailer inventories are rising, retailers often can keep their stocks misleadingly low by forcing wholesalers and distributors to hold inventories. Retailers then tap these inventories when their sales are brisk. And from the other end, manufacturers put the same pressure on wholesalers and, to a lesser extent, also on retailers - pushing their production from the assembly line into the marketplace as quickly as possible.
In a weak American economy, the upshot of this dynamic is that wholesale inventories swelled from May through July to an average of $192.3 billion a month, compared with a $189.7 billion monthly average in the February-through-April period.
Through it all, manufacturers' inventories have ranged between $370 billion and $373 billion since February, and production has held up, in part because exports have helped to offset weak sales at home. The linerboard industry is a good bellwether. Linerboard is used to make the corrugated boxes in which many products are shipped, so when manufacturing production declines nationwide, the demand for linerboard also falls.
Right now, linerboard manufacturers are operating at a healthy 94.4 percent of production capacity, and their inventories total a 5.7 week supply, at present sales levels. The danger signal, requiring production cutbacks, is more than six weeks. ''We have been braced for a recession, but we don't see it yet in our business,'' said Timothy McKenna, a spokesman for the Union Camp Corporation, a packaging manufacturer in Wayne, N.J.
Even when a recession comes, the Commerce Department's inventory figures might not announce the arrival. In hindsight, economists decided that the 1981-1982 recession began in July 1981, but the sharp jump in inventories as sales declined was not obvious in the data until August and September. And when the public learned of the inventory problem from the publication of these figures, in November, the recession was already well under way.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Vision of Los Angeles Leads to a Magazine: Buzz

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
A year and a half ago, Eden Collinsworth, a young New York book publisher who often came to Los Angeles on business, began to notice profound changes taking place there. ''A cumulative effect had been going on in Los Angeles,'' she said. ''It was becoming far more confident and sophisticated a city.''
So, never having lived in Los Angeles or worked on a magazine, in the worst period for magazine advertising in well over a decade, when city magazines in particular are reeling from the decline in retail advertising, and in a city that may well have too many magazines already, Ms. Collinsworth is starting a new magazine: Buzz, The Talk of Los Angeles. But why? Because young entrepreneurs have been starting publications since the days of the penny press. In the last five years more than 2,000 magazines were started. Of course far more fledglings die than survive, but Ms. Collinsworth, like generations of entrepreneurs, is convinced that there is a market for her magazine. 
 
Reasoning Behind a Vision
''The editorial side of my brain told me that there were other magazines but none in terms of business, science and the arts that said that there had been this extremely successful progressive change,'' Ms. Collinsworth said. ''And the business side of my brain told me that Los Angeles was now the richest and most populous metropolitan area in the United States and the nation's fastest-growing large city.''
Buzz, which hits the newsstands Oct. 2, will compete directly against Capital Cities/ABC's 30-year-old Los Angeles, the same company's newly acquired Exposure, and American Express's L.A. Style. Also in direct competition is the regional magazine California, formerly known as New West. A slew of other publications with largely non-paid circulation includes The Brentwood Bla Bla, In Beverly Hills, Angeles and L.A. West.
''I just don't see a need that is not being filled,'' said Geoff Miller, founder and publisher of Los Angeles, which has a circulation of 172,000 and is the only profitable city magazine in Los Angeles. ''It's a very tough market. The city is not constructed on conventional grids and truly is a collection of towns. It takes a long time to find the real issues and concerns that pull these communities together. It took us a good decade to break even.''
 
Contrast in Assessments
Thomas Ryder, president and executive publisher of the American Express Publishing Corporation, which publishes the 85,000-circulation L.A. Style, put it more bluntly: ''Given the state of the marketplace generally and the competitive nature of the Los Angeles marketplace specifically, I think the odds of Buzz surviving on its own is less than one in 10,000,'' he said.
But Porter Bibb, managing director, corporate finance, at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, who has been involved in the start-ups of about 30 magazines, thinks otherwise. ''It's unbelievable,'' he said. ''My business is investment banking and I've never in my life seen someone say they are going to do this in a six months time-frame and do it,'' he said. ''To raise the money in this economic environment is really remarkable.''
When Ms. Collinsworth first got the idea to start Buzz she had just left her posts as president and publisher of the Arbor House Publishing Company because its merger with William Morrow & Company had changed her job. She asked Allan Mayer, the editorial director of Arbor House and a former journalist at Newsweek and The Wall Street Journal, to be the editor in chief. Mr. Mayer went home and wrote down his editorial vision for the magazine. ''That memo became this magazine,'' Ms. Collinsworth said. They were soon joined by Susan Gates, now publisher of Buzz, who had experience in developing advertising and circulation-marketing plans and budgets.
 
The Business Plan
Ms. Collinsworth, who is president and chief executive of the venture, showed her business plan for the new magazine to a variety of private investors. She and her colleagues formed a corporation, Buzz Inc., sold 30 percent of the stock and within nine months raised $1 million. When there was no money to pay for start-up services, Ms. Collinsworth gave people cartoons drawn by her husband, William Hamilton, the author and New Yorker cartoonist.
''It was the only way I could think of paying them,'' she said.
The business plan, which calls for an investment of $5 million over the first three years, contained two pivotal stipulations - that the first direct-mail test achieve a 2.8 percent response rate and that the first issue contain 35 pages of advertising. The direct-mail test, which went to 55,000 people, received a remarkable 11 percent response. The first issue will have 52 pages of paid advertising.
Investors came aboard in various ways. On a flight, Ms. Gates told the man sitting next to her about the proposed magazine. He gave her his card and asked her to send him the business plan. Dubiously, she did. He turned out to be Lawrence Ellison, president and chief executive of the Oracle Corporation, a computer software company with revenues of $236 million, and became a primary investor in the magazine.
 
Issues and Circulation
Eight issues a year are planned, and the initial circulation will be 50,000 - 22,000 paid subscriptions, 20,000 newsstand sales (including 5,000 in New York, San Francisco and Santa Fe, N.M.) and 8,000 unpaid subscriptions to a selective list of power and society people. The circulation goal is 150,000 within five years.
The first issue of the sleek, glossy magazine is a mix of news, gossip, reflections and commentary by journalists, writers, artists and members of movie land about life in Los Angeles - ''the buzz of a good dinner party,'' Buzz editors like to say. There is a long piece on Los Angeles's water woes and a photo essay on the Port of Los Angeles.
Ms. Collinsworth, 38 years old, said she could not believe how fast Buzz had been pulled together. ''I came to Los Angeles with no place to live, no furniture, no bank, no accountant, no lawyer and no staff,'' she said. ''I find myself bemused by it all.''

SECTION: Section D; Page 5, Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Proposals for a U.S. Energy Policy: Some Possible, Most Not

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
From the day Ronald Reagan arrived in Washington until the day before Saddam Hussein's troops reached Kuwait City, energy policy was a fringe issue in the United States. Now, the deployment of American troops in the Persian Gulf to assure a steady flow of oil has left many policy makers wondering whether the United States has options other than force to insure an adequate supply of energy.
But many proposals - including driving at the speed limit, paying high taxes on gasoline, running cars on natural gas and bicycling to work - seem a radical departure from how Americans work and play and live and how they think about natural resources. Here are 10 frequently mentioned proposals and their prospects for adoption:
 
1 Reduce Speed Limits And Enforce Them
A car that gets 28 miles a gallon at 55 miles an hour gets about 21 miles a gal lon at 65 miles an hour, the Insurance Institute for High way Safety says.
Driving more slowly would seem to benefit both individuals' pocketbooks and the nation's balance of payments and energy security, not to mention side effects like saving lives and reducing pollution. (Remember Earth Day?) But a few minutes on any Interstate highway demonstrates that when it comes to getting from point A to point B, most drivers agree that the proper speed is as fast as possible. 
In New York, where the speed limit is 55 miles an hour, a vacationer who toured 180 rural miles of the New York Thruway at 60 miles an hour last month was the slowest vehicle on his stretch of road. Even the proverbial milk wagon went faster.
After the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74, when most people worried where their next tankful of gas was coming from and children on Halloween dressed up like OPEC ministers, Congress responded to the new national mood by imposing a national 55-mile-an-hour speed limit. Most people actually slowed down almost to that speed.
But when gasoline once again became inexpensive, Washington responded by allowing the states to raise their speed limits to 65 miles an hour.
Speed aside, encouraging drivers to keep their tires fully inflated, and providing air hoses at a time when fewer gas stations do, would also increase gas mileage considerably.
PROSPECTS: No change unless a crisis mentality takes hold or law-enforcement officials deploy their troops to stop speeding.
 
2 Insist on Cars With Better Mileage
Six million bar rels of oil a day, out of total domestic consumption of 16 million, is used to provide fuel for cars and light trucks. Federal policy has already had a major impact on gas mileage; alarmed by the Arab oil embargo in 1973-74, Congress required car makers to raise the mileage of cars, step by step, until the average of all cars sold reached 27.5 miles a gallon.
As new cars were built and old cars retired, the average efficiency of cars on the road in the United States has risen from 13.3 miles a gallon in 1973 to about 20 miles a gallon today, an improvement of 50 percent. Even if the Government does nothing more, average fuel economy will improve as new cars replace older ones.
But the collapse of crude oil prices in 1986 pushed gasoline prices so low that car buyers stopped demanding the more efficient models. Between the 1988 and 1990 model years, buyers moved so heavily to bigger cars with bigger engines that average fuel economy declined by 3 percent. The average fuel economy of 1990 model-year cars is 27.8 miles a gallon, down from 28.6 two years ago. (On the other hand, cars do accelerate more quickly. The 1990 models, on average, go from 0 to 60 miles an hour in seven-tenths of a second less than it took the 1988's.) A bill in the Senate would raise the corporate average fuel economy standard by 40 percent by 2001, to about 40 miles a gallon. That would save nearly three million barrels a day when the new cars are fully phased in, according to the bill's supporters. This is a big number in relation to the seven million barrels a day currently being imported and far exceeds the 730,000 barrels a day that the United States had been getting from Iraq and Kuwait.
Supporters say the Senate bill, sponsored by Richard H. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, would stimulate the development of engine and transmission technologies, along with increased use of lightweight materials.
But the auto makers say they used almost every trick they knew to double fuel efficiency from the mid-1970's to the mid-1980's. Nearly all cars made today have front-wheel drive instead of rear-wheel drive, and use fuel injectors instead of carburetors; all have been redesigned to cut wind drag. If substantial advances are to be made, the manufacturers say, it will have to be by making the cars smaller.
''I don't think it's reasonable to hold that the most mobile society in the world can meet its personal and business transportation needs with a fleet of mini-compacts, subcompacts and compacts,'' said Thomas H. Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association.
''Sales, the only barometer of consumer preference, support this,'' he said. ''In 1989, cars rated at 50 miles per gallon or better accounted for less than 3 percent of U.S. sales.''
But rather than making smaller cars, designers could increase mileage merely by cutting horsepower, forcing drivers to wait a second or two longer to go from 0 to 60. But that, Detroit says, does not sell cars.
PROSPECTS: A law increasing mileage standards is likely to pass in some form.
 
3 Substitute Pedals For Petroleum
Half of all trips to work are estimated to be five miles or less. That is a com fortable bicycle ride for a healthy adult.
But bicycles do not mix well with rain, snow, extreme heat, or the proper attire required by many companies. They also compete poorly for road space with automobiles, and in most places, local governments do not think they are important enough to warrant bicycle paths. Many employers provide parking for cars; fewer provide secure bicycle racks, or showers.
Cycling already saves about 50,000 barrels of oil a day, said Charles Komanoff, an energy consultant and electricity expert in New York who is the president of Transportation Alternatives, a bicycle advocacy group. Part of the savings comes from the three million people who commute by bicycle; a larger part comes from people who cycle for pleasure, rather than going for a Sunday drive. Another part comes from trips by children who do not have to be ferried in cars, he said.
If 10 percent of the work force shifted to bicycles for most of the year, from less than 3 percent now, the country could save an additional 25,000 barrels of oil a day, he calculates. Only 30 percent of car miles involve going to or from work, but bicycles could still substitute for part of the other 70 percent.
The public is skeptical, and some interest groups go so far as to suggest that bicycling is almost un-American. One major chemical company, the Ethyl Corporation, seeking to build public support for a gasoline additive that it said would save oil, ran full-page newspaper ads showing photos of cyclists commuting in Beijing, with a caption that said some solutions to the energy problem were not practical here.
PROSPECTS: Barring a dramatic change in personal habits and how people are required to dress for work, no change.
 
4 Tax Gasoline At a Hefty Rate
Most other indus trialized countries tax vehicle fuel by $1.50 to $3 a gallon; the average in this country, combining state, Federal and local taxes, is about 25 cents.
Oil companies and car makers agree that recent decades have demonstrated that the most effective way to decrease consumption is to increase the price. The idea is hardly new. John B. Anderson, a former Representative from Illinois, built a Presidential campaign on the issue 10 years ago. The idea's appeal to voters, as measured by the Electoral College, was zero.
Mr. Anderson, who now teaches law at Nova University Law School in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said he believed such a tax was unlikely to prove any more popular now.
And not everyone agrees that a higher tax would reduce fuel use. ''I don't think that consumption taxes do much except buy a bigger government,'' said Theodore Eck, the chief economist at the Amoco Corporation. Even with a 50-cent-a-gallon tax, he said, ''the incremental cost of driving a mile is low as heck,'' compared with fixed costs like the purchase price of the car and the insurance cost. ''Not too many people are going to hang it up and walk,'' he said. The oil industry also argues that the tax would fall more heavily on poor people, who can least afford it and who often drive the oldest, thirstiest cars.
To encourage national policy goals, Americans like tax breaks, not tax increases. Raising the tax on beer and liquor to keep up with inflation has been difficult in recent years. And gasoline is one of the few consumer products more popular than beer.
PROSPECTS: Fair to poor.
 
5 Use Natural Gas To Power Vehicles
North America is largely self-suffi cient in natural gas, and major gas utili ties are offering to sell it for vehicle use at the equiva lent of 70 cents a gallon. Burned in a car or truck, natural gas produces far lower levels of soot and the chemicals that cause smog and acid rain than gasoline does. (Methanol and ethanol, two other alternative fuels, are more expensive than gasoline and offer less of an environmental advantage over gasoline.) Thousands of gasoline stations sit astride pipes that carry natural gas to homes, factories and other businesses. Natural gas does not require new refineries. Cars would have to be built with different fuel tanks, or have the tanks added, but existing gasoline engines will run acceptably without major modifications, and with relatively modest changes, a gasoline engine can be converted to run well on natural gas.
In the San Francisco area, Pacific Gas and Electric says that of the seven million vehicles in its service territory, 500,000, which account for one-quarter of the area's fuel use, would be obvious candidates for an easy switch to natural gas. These are almost all fleet vehicles, from buses and delivery trucks to the vans of plumbers and electricians, that could or already do refuel at a central point.
Pacific Gas and Electric, with two other big California utilities and others in Texas, recently signed a deal with General Motors to produce 1,000 three-quarter-ton pickup trucks powered solely by natural gas. They are to be sold and serviced through regular G.M. dealers in 1991. But progress has been slow, even in California, with its severe air pollution problems. ''We face a public acceptance obstacle,'' said Norman L. Bryan, vice president of Pacific Gas and Electric. The public dislikes the idea of a gaseous fuel, he said, even though natural gas appears to have technical advantages over gasoline. For one thing, if it leaks, it dissipates rather than forming a puddle, he pointed out. Explosion is a possibility with any flammable substance, but the ignition temperature of natural gas is 400 degrees higher than gasoline's.
Natural gas is also hampered by a public perception, accurate 10 years ago when Government price regulations depressed drilling, that the supply is limited. This is a self-fulfilling perception, because fears about supply have held down demand for gas and therefore its price, removing an incentive for exploration. Experts point out that prospectors are drilling deeper and deeper, and the deeper the well, the more likely that what is found is natural gas. The size of the inventory in this continent is uncertain but seems likely to be substantial.
Natural gas in vehicles also requires bulky canisters, which cut down cargo space in cars. And some bridges and tunnels deny access to vehicles carrying bottled gas.
PROSPECTS: Natural gas will cease to be unusual in fleet vehicles. But it may be be many years before most drivers are interested in exploring this option.
 
6 Tax Imported Oil To Spur U.S. Drilling
American oil pro duction is declining 5 or 6 percent a year, because even now prices are too low to stimulate drilling, and drillers are not sure how long the current higher price will last. In many cases, even the current prices do not justify keeping open wells that produce only small amounts.
Since 1986, when Saudi Arabia entered a price war with other OPEC producers and the price of a barrel dropped below $10, production in this country has declined by 2.3 million barrels a day, or about a quarter.
If the Government taxed imports, it would raise the price that domestic producers could get for their oil, to the amount of the world price plus the tax. That would encourage drilling.
But two hurdles stand in the Government's way. Washington has signed a free trade agreement with Canada, a major source of crude oil, and is negotiating a similar pact with Mexico, another major oil supplier. In addition, this country does not want to damage Mexico's economy, which is already shaky.
If Canada and Mexico were excluded, it would be difficult to tax oil from Venezuela, with which Washington has cultivated strong ties, experts say. Venezuela is a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries but during the oil embargo of 1973-74 it produced extra oil to help the United States weather a difficult period, and is doing the same now.
If Venezuelan oil is exempted, what about oil from Saudi Arabia, which is also an ally of the United States? And if not Saudi oil, then who would be singled out? One expert suggested Iraq, Iran and Libya, from which imports are already effectively banned.
And the timing for such a tax is dreadful. Few lawmakers are willing to add to the burden of higher oil prices with an oil tax.
PROSPECTS: Nil.
 
7 Conserve Electricity
Nationwide, the Energy Depart ment says, utilities burn about 650,000 barrels of oil a day, accounting for about 6 percent of their fuel. But New York and New Eng land get about a third of their electricity from oil-powered generating plants.
If electricity demand falls, many utilities continue to use the same amount of coal, hydroelectric and nuclear power, and the cut in output comes from lowering their use of oil. Conversely, if demand rises, the increase is met by burning oil because the plants that use cheaper fuels are already in full use.
Of the 870,000 barrels of oil used each day in New England, 158,000 go to generate electricity, said Armond M. Cohen, senior attorney at the Conservation Law Foundation, a Boston group that has negotiated efficiency programs with utilities. Putting more insulation in home attics and walls, wrapping water heaters and pipes, installing low-flow showerheads and faucet aerators and putting in fluorescent lighting where appropriate can cut consumption by 15 to 20 percent in electrically heated houses, he said. These improvements can yield direct oil savings if the houses use oil for heat; if they use gas, they can save gas that would be available elsewhere as a substitute for oil. Many such changes could also be made in the commercial sector.
In their manufacturing processes, most factories use big electric motors and put brakes on them to adjust them to the proper speed, and they use big pumps and reduce the flow to the proper level by forcing the pump to strain against a valve. If these companies bought smaller motors or variable-speed motors, which consume less power when less work is needed, and they modernized their lighting, they could save 12 to 15 percent of their electric consumption, Mr. Cohen said.
In many cases, he said, it costs less to save a kilowatt-hour of electricity than to buy the oil to produce it.
But even if such conservation makes sense economically, there are barriers. ''It's rare to find a business that will spend to improve energy efficiency if it doesn't pay back in a year or two,'' Mr. Cohen said, although a utility will build a new generator to meet inflated demand, while projecting a payback of 15 or 20 years.
And ''most homeowners are so cash constrained that if they face a $2,000 or $3,000 investment that pays back in six months, they won't do it,'' he said.
PROSPECTS: Despite resistance, increasingly efficient electrical use is likely. Many states, driven by worries about acid rain and climatic change as well as the oil crisis, will establish regulations that reward electric companies for selling less power.
 
8 Give Tax Breaks To Drillers
In addition to the standard corporate income tax, oil drill ers in the United States are taxed on revenues, in the form of royalties, which they pay to landowners on all oil taken from the ground, and severance taxes, which are based on the amount produced. When times are bad, this encourages the abandonment of marginal wells, some experts say, because the Government is taking a portion of the revenues, which are already lower than expenses.
Robinson West, president of the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting firm, said the United States should follow the example of countries that tax profits; it would reap proportionally more in good years and would avoid depressing production in bad ones.
Mr. Eck of Amoco argues that the 1986 tax law penalizes projects with a heavy start-up investment and slow recovery of resources, like drilling for hard-to-get deposits. An investment tax credit or accelerated depreciation to reduce taxes on those projects and unconventional gas wells could stimulate production, he said.
But some drilling companies will report record profits this year, making it hard to argue that they deserve tax breaks.
PROSPECTS: The mood in Washington is to cut spending and raise taxes to close the budget deficit. Giving drillers more money is unlikely.
 
9 Breathe New Life Into Nuclear Power
Opponents of nu clear power have a long list of prerequi sites: solve the waste storage prob lem, ''prove'' nu clear power is safe, insulate customers from the effects of cost overruns, exhaust the potential for improved efficiency first.
Many utilities agree. They do not want to be stuck with radioactive wastes, they are afraid of cost overruns, and they would prefer not to build anything.
''Nuclear is a long-range solution,'' said Timothy Guzzle, chief executive officer of Teco Energy, the parent of the Tampa Electric Company.
PROSPECTS: For now, none.
 
10 Do Nothing; Wait and See
Drillers are find ing oil a lot faster than customers are using it. Proved re serves, or oil found and waiting to be pumped, rose by 50 percent in the 1980's. True, these reserves are not in North America, but in the long term, the supply of willing sellers seems large. Some, notably the Saudis, are determined not to let the price get too high, lest substitutes be found. The oil market will have occasional wild periods, as in 1973 and 1979, but the long-term average price is likely to be moderate.
Constructing an energy policy, winning public support and enforcing the rules is expensive, inconvenient and a little painful. And it must compete for attention with problems like a budget deficit, a shaky economy, an education crisis, homelessness, the environment and the drug problem.
PROSPECTS: For doing little, excellent.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about energy policy choices referred incorrectly to a comment on fuel economy by Thomas H. Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. He said cars that get 40 miles a gallon or better -not 50 or better - made up less than 3 percent of the market last year.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Mitterrand Says Iraqi Withdrawal Could Help End Mideast Disputes

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 24

 BODY:
President Francois Mitterrand of France said today that an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait could help settle other Middle East disputes, like the Arab-Israeli conflict, and bring about a regional disarmament accord for which diplomats said Iraq might then take credit.
His remarks, delivered on the opening day of the General Assembly's annual debate, appeared calculated to establish a bridge with the beleaguered Iraqi Government by telling President Saddam Hussein that he could still save face if he withdrew from Kuwait.
The Persian Gulf crisis is expected to dominate the political agenda of the 45th General Assembly session. Also addressing the Assembly today was the Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, whose country has a 750-mile border with Iraq and is rebuilding relations with Baghdad after an eight-year war. 
Mr. Velayati pledged that Iran would abide by the sanctions against Iraq adopted by the United Nations Security Council.
''It is the firm conviction of the Islamic republic of Iran that faithful commitment to and compliance with the relevant Security Council resolutions by all parties, particularly Iraq, is the only path to the establishment of peace and tranquillity in the area,'' he said. ''The Islamic Republic of Iran reaffirms its intention to comply with relevant Security Council resolutions in line with its obligations under the Charter.''
 
Iran Sees a Discrepancy
But Mr. Velayati criticized the Security Council for reacting so firmly to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait after failing to impose similar sanctions when Iraq attacked Iran 10 years ago.
Reports attributed to intelligence officials and to Middle Eastern oil industry sources have said that Iraq has discussed a deal with Iran in which Baghdad would provide 200,000 barrels of oil a day to Teheran in return for food and medicines. Iran has steadfastly denied the reports, and Mr. Velayati seemed to underscore those denials today.
Mr. Mitterrand was careful in his presentation to remain firm in opposing the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait. The French President, who has ordered ships, warplanes and about 4,000 troops to the gulf, called Iraq a ''warlike state.'' He said there could be ''no compromise'' with Baghdad as long as it rejected the Security Council's order to withdraw its forces and allow the Kuwaiti Government to resume power.
But Mr. Mitterrand seemed pessimistic about the prospects for an Iraqi withdrawal. ''Not one gesture, not one word from the President of Iraq has given us a glimpse, a hope of reconciliation,'' he said.
 
France's Warning to Iraq
He said France had told Iraq that it would side with any country in the region that became a victim of aggression.
His words suggested that France would join with the United States and other countries in defending Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations from any further Iraqi attack. The remark also implied that France would support Israel if Iraq tried to provoke an Arab-Israeli confrontation.
The idea of linking a resolution of the Kuwaiti crisis to a wider Middle East settlement is not new. Spokesmen for President Hussein have talked repeatedly of the need for a comprehensive settlement that would link the Kuwaiti issue to the settlement of disputes between Arab countries and Israel. Mr. Hussein has also called for a plebiscite in Kuwait.
But President Mitterrand appears to be the first Western leader to have publicly suggested that the Iraqi President could offset the humiliation of giving up Kuwait by claiming he is breaking the impasse in Middle East diplomacy.
 
Mitterrand Offers a Scenario
In a discourse that French officials said often departed from his prepared text, Mr. Mitterrand said that if Iraq would ''declare its determination to withdraw from Kuwait and free the hostages,'' then ''everything might be possible.''
Without explaining how it could come about, the French President said ''the international community'' could then guarantee the withdrawal of foreign forces from the gulf region, as well as ''the democratic expression of the Kuwaiti people's will.''
This would be followed by what Mr. Mitterrand called ''a third stage'' replacing ''confrontation with the dynamics of good neighborliness and security and peace for each country.'' He spoke of a direct dialogue, with an international conference eventually serving ''as a catalyst for a solution.''
The French President said the solution would involve a settlement of the Lebanese conflict and a resolution of the Palestinian issue. It would also mean that Israel was no longer ''living in constant insecurity,'' he said.
In what he called a fourth stage, Mr. Mitterrand said he could envisage a ''mutually agreed reduction of armaments'' in the Middle East. He said the cuts should cover an area extending ''from Iran to Morocco,'' implying disarmament by both Iraq and Israel.
 
No Promise to Hussein
The French President did not specifically say that Mr. Hussein could claim political credit if Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait led to a breakthrough in the search for a Middle East peace settlement. But diplomats said that such a tradeoff was implicit in his remarks.
In Washington, President Bush restated his opposition to linking an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait with any other issue, although he did not address President Mitterrand's proposal.
At a White House meeting with Arab-Americans, Mr. Bush said, ''Our objectives remain clear: Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait completely, immediately, and without condition.'' At another point, he said, ''We must also resist his attempt - Saddam Hussein's attempt - to link the Iraqi invasion with other conflicts.''
Mr. Mitterrand's address dominated the opening session of the Assembly's general debate, in which heads of government and foreign ministers outline their views on world problems.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 25, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 946 words

HEADLINE: Bush Rejects Delays in Deadline For Automatic Cuts in Spending

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Tightening the political screws a notch, the White House stressed today that President Bush would reject any measure extending the Oct. 1 deadline for across-the-board spending cuts.
Without a change in the budget law, or an agreement between Congress and the President to lower the Federal budget deficit, spending for most Government programs will automatically be reduced by more than 30 percent over the fiscal year. The process will begin on the first day of the new fiscal year, this Monday.
The immediate furloughs of thousands of Federal employees could result in flight cancellations and havoc at major airports, long lines at tax, Social Security and immigration offices and delays of trials in Federal courts. 
 
Not the Usual Game of Chicken
Games of political chicken are commonplace in Washington, with the President and lawmakers approaching an absolute deadline before one or the other swerves or a compromise is struck.
But the political oratory has reached such heights this time and the differences boil down to such fundamental principles that it will be more difficult than usual for either party to back down.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the veto threat was serious, and it was taken seriously by Congressional leaders of both parties, meeting separately today.
The automatic cuts, Mr. Fitzwater told reporters, ''are an important discipline.''
''They were put there by Congress to enforce decision-making,'' he said, ''and we won't agree they should be extended.''
Richard G. Darman, the budget director, took the same stance after a meeting with the Republican Congressional leadership, saying, ''If you get into the business of suspending and suspending and suspending, we will be at it for 114 years.''
Mr. Darman, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and John H. Sununu, the President's chief of staff, met again tonight with top Congressional leaders from both parties in the sixth meeting they have held in the last week on their differences over the budget.
The main division appears to be over President Bush's determination to lower the capital gains tax rate and the Democrats' insistence that any cut in that rate be accompanied by a higher income tax for the wealthy.
 
Debate Over Capital Gains
Mr. Bush maintains that a reduction in the capital gains rate is essential to stimulate a weakened economy. The Democrats counter that the benefits would go largely to the wealthy and that the price of deficit-reduction would thus be paid by people with modest incomes and even the poor.
Mr. Fitzwater and other Republicans emphasize that important differences also remain over spending limits and the procedures to enforce whatever agreement is reached. But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, has conceded that the tax issue is the main sticking point.
At the Republican leadership meeting today, according to people who were there, Mr. Brady wondered aloud whether room existed to ''split the difference.''
Mr. Darman reportedly replied, ''Split the difference? What difference?''
Some Congressional staff assistants took that exchange to indicate divisions in the White House team, but others said it was just idle talk.
 
Few Back Suggestions on Impasse
The suggestions made by Mr. Dole over the last few days to break the deadlock appear to have gained little support at the White House or among Republicans in the House of Representatives.
Mr. Dole has proposed that the issues of capital gains taxes and tax rates on the wealthy be subjected to a separate vote from that on other deficit-reduction measures. On Sunday, he hinted that he might favor some way of eliminating the part of the tax system that allows the wealthy to pay a lower rate on the last dollars they earn than the rate paid by taxpayers who are somewhat less affluent.
All sides agree that a condition of any budget compromise is that it have the support of a majority of lawmakers from both parties in each house of Congress.
''It's a very delicate process of coalition-building,'' said Mr. Darman, perhaps indicating that the White House could not back any idea that could not carry the votes of a majority of Republican Representatives.
Several Republicans today gave speeches on the House floor blaming the Democratic leadership for the impasse and vowing to oppose any tax increase.
 
Panels Work on Legislation
Committees in both houses are working on legislation that would extend until later next month the requirements of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law for automatic, across-the-board spending cuts.
No firm action on these bills is expected until late this week.
A measure scheduled to go before the House Rules Committee on Tuesday would extend the deadline for automatic spending cuts until Oct. 20, continue spending authority for Government agencies until that date and provide $2 billion requested by the President for military operations in the Persian Gulf.
If this measure gains the support of the Democratic Congressional leadership, it would likely pass, but probably by an insufficient margin to withstand a Presidential veto.
Democrats are of several minds about extending the deadline. Some fear the disruption that would occur if the indiscriminate spending reductions go into effect. Others worry that the President could pin the blame on Democrats for whatever damage or inconvenience voters suffer from the cuts.
One person who sat through the Democratic leadership meeting today said the prevailing view seemed to be that automatic spending cuts ''would cause havoc for Republicans too'' and that the Democrats should do nothing to stop them.

HEADLINE: Apartment Doubling-Up Hits the Working Class

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Willie Avery Jr. is the kind of hard-working, tax-paying citizen who forms the bedrock of any community. But he cannot afford his own New York City apartment, so he and his wife, Sonja, and their two small daughters live with relatives in a small house in Springfield Gardens, Queens: 10 people jammed into four bedrooms.
Doubling-up, once mainly the plight of the poorest of New York's poor, has become an affliction of the working class. Affordable housing has become so hard to find that the number of families forced to live doubled- and tripled-up has increased markedly in the last few years, housing experts say.
In housing projects alone, the number of two- and three-family households has doubled in seven years, according to housing officials, who estimate that at least 100,000 people live doubled-up in projects. Labor leaders say crowded housing is among the gravest concerns of workers. 
For these families, temporary stays with relatives and friends are often grueling ordeals that strain marriages and friendships. Adults have little privacy and children readily pass around illnesses and find it difficult to study for school.
At the Averys' temporary quarters, now populated by Mrs. Avery's mother, uncle, a brother-in-law, two sisters and one of their children, the line can be long for the only bathroom. The kitchen is used in shifts.
Their long-term prospect is worse. Like many others in their circumstances, the Averys' ordeal may be only a stop on the way to homelessness.
Mr. Avery worked for 28 years at the same job, distributing chemicals at an auto parts factory in Woodside, Queens. He was earning $30,000 a year when he had heart-bypass surgery in January. He has been out of work ever since, and has seen his weekly income of $600 shrink to a $105 disability check. His family was evicted from their apartment in Hollis in June because they could not pay the rent.
Now they cannot afford even the $360 a month Mrs. Avery's mother asks for the two small bedrooms in which the family has been living. She has ordered them out by the end of the month.
''I might have to go on welfare,'' said Mr. Avery, a wiry man with a dark beard and glasses who looks considerably younger than his 49 years. ''I don't want to, but I might have to.''
The number of families that became homeless increased sharply and unexpectedly in July and August, city officials said last week. The increase forced the city to begin moving families back into welfare hotels, breaking a promise two years ago to stop using the hotels by this past summer.
City officials attributed the increase to their recent success in providing permanent apartments for homeless families living in hotels and shelters. They speculated that families who had been living doubled-up may have decided to declare themselves homeless to qualify for the apartments.
Many housing experts agreed with that, but added that the economics of New York housing had contributed significantly to the increase in crowding and homelessness.
When asked how far up the economic ladder crowding went, Peter Marcuse, a professor of urban planing at Columbia University, said, ''I can tell you that it goes right through tenured college professors.'' He lives with a daughter and her foster child in his small Manhattan apartment.
The reasons for such crowding are clear. Rents on vacant apartments have increased more sharply in the last decade than many people's incomes. The city has begun an ambitious effort to produce new housing, but cannot begin to meet the demand.
 
No Trickle Down
Overcrowding is expanding even in New York's real-estate slump. Housing prices have fallen and some rents for luxury apartments have declined, but that has had no effect on housing for the less affluent.
''The real-estate market's woes do not mean that the affordable housing problem has been solved,'' said Eric H. Weinstock, director of the housing research project of the Community Training and Resource Center, a nonprofit agency. ''It really doesn't matter much to these people that a studio apartment that was selling for $120,000 has dropped to $90,000.''
The statistics show a big gap between families' incomes and housing costs. The median household income in New York in 1987 was $20,000 a year, according to the city's most recent housing survey. The median renter's income was $16,000 a year.
Most of those in such households -as well as those earning $25,000 or $30,000 - could not buy an apartment or house, even at lower prices. Many cannot afford to rent, either. ''And rental rates have not dropped significantly,'' Mr. Weinstock said.
 
'We Couldn't Afford It'
A family making $20,000 a year can afford a monthly rent of about $500, under conventional guidelines. But a vacant two-bedroom apartment in most neighborhoods - including many of the most impoverished and crime-ridden areas - rents for at least $600 to $700 a month, many experts say.
Sandy D. and her husband, Gary, together make $22,000 a year at their jobs at a Queens garment factory. After getting married last winter, they lived in a furnished studio in Forest Hills that rented for $650 a month.
''We couldn't afford it,'' Sandy said. ''We either had money for rent and no money for food, or money for food and no money for rent.''
After four months, they moved in with Gary's mother, who has a three-bedroom apartment in the East Tremont section of the Bronx. Ten to 12 people shared the apartment. $700 Is Too Much The couple eventually wound up in a city shelter in Brooklyn. Because Sandy is pregnant - she is expecting to give birth to twins in about a week -they were given a pleasant room of their own in a special section. ''We were not the only working couple there,'' Sandy recalled.
After two months in the shelter, Sandy and Gary moved in with her mother in Forest Hills. They can stay there for a while, but ultimately they want to move on. ''My mother has her own life,'' Sandy said. ''Plus I'm married; I have my own responsibilities. I want a place of my own.''
But she has no idea how she will afford one. If Sandy and Gary were to pay 30 percent of their gross income for rent - the conventional standard -they could afford $550 a month. A two-bedroom apartment almost anywhere in Queens costs at least $700 or $800 a month, said Sandy, who has looked at many apartments. ''It depresses me a lot,'' she said. Doubled-up families encompass a wide range of people. Some are young couples like Sandy and Gary, forced to seek shelter temporarily with parents. Others are single mothers, many of them still teen-agers, who raise their children in their own parents' apartments. Still others are immigrants, many recently arrived, sharing small quarters with their extended families.
''Overcrowding is probably the classic way of dealing with a housing shortage,'' said Mr. Marcuse of Columbia.
No one knows precisely how many families are living with friends or relatives in New York City. ''The standard measures are so restrictive that we don't have a firm estimate of the scope of the problem,'' said Bonnie Brower, executive director of the Association of Neighborhood and Housing Development, a coalition of community groups.
Many experts say they believe estimates by the city's Housing Authority provide the best measure of the problem. Those estimates come from school and utility records, staff reports and even the agency's own waiting list. Thousands of those applying for apartments list their current addresses as other apartments in the projects, where they are living with friends or relatives.
 
Largest Since World War II
In 1983, the Housing Authority estimated that 50,000 people were living doubled-up in city projects, the largest total since after World War II, when returning veterans married and, because of a housing shortage, moved in with family members.
Today, the total is twice what it was. About 20 percent of the 178,000 city project apartments contain more than one family, an arrangement that is against housing rules but almost never enforced. Most of the projects' authorized tenants - more than 70 percent of the households - work for a living.
The city's triennial housing report, which measures apartment crowding citywide, estimates the number of people a room, excluding kitchens and bathrooms. The most recent report showed that in 1987 the number of ''seriously crowded apartments,'' those with more than 1.5 people a room, increased to 42,000 from 29,000 in 1978. To be considered seriously crowded, a two-bedroom apartment would have to contain five or more people.
This growing population encompasses some of the people that city officials say are so difficult to count in census enumerations. The officials say many such families tend to move from place to place and fear talking to government representatives.
The Community Service Society, a nonprofit social-welfare organization, estimated in 1986 that 103,000 families living below the poverty level were doubled up. Tens of thousands of other families above poverty level are also crowded, said Victor Bach, the society's director of housing policy and research.
''I'm not sure it's acceptable by American standards of housing,'' Mr. Bach said. ''It's not a stable form of housing for many families.''
Jaime Estades, a social worker for District 65 of the United Auto Workers, surveyed the union's Hispanic members last year. Housing was cited as their most serious problem.
''We're talking about people who are working, who are members of the union,'' Mr. Estades said. ''They cannot even have an apartment of their own. The American dream does not exist for them.''
 
'Really Pretty Hopeless'
Some unions try to keep members informed about new apartments completed by the city under its $5.1 billion housing effort. But the apartments are scooped up quickly under a lottery system, and many are set aside for the homeless and for families earning $25,000 to $30,000 a year. The Housing Authority has a waiting list of 180,000.
''It's really pretty hopeless in New York City,'' said George Bailey, director of the members assistance program for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
Mr. Estades of the auto workers union said: ''They come here and say, 'Help me.' There is so much frustration in saying, 'We cannot do anything.' ''
''Living overcrowded drives the families crazy,'' he added. ''But what else can they do?''
Mr. Avery said he has begun looking for a place to live after he leaves his mother-in-law's house, but has found nothing under $700 a month.
''I don't know what I'm going to do,'' he said. ''I shouldn't have to go through this after working 28 years.''

HEADLINE: Khrushchev on Rosenbergs: Stoking Old Embers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Nearly four decades after Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were executed for conspiring to pass America's atomic bomb secrets to the Soviet Union, the case that has haunted scholars, historians and partisans of the left and the right has found a new witness: Nikita S. Khrushchev.
But the late Soviet leader's testimony - praise for the Rosenbergs in a newly disclosed memoir that seems to reaffirm the verdict of the court that condemned them in 1953 - is unlikely to settle a matter that has generated passionate books and an endless debate that swirls with intrigue and mirrors an age of nuclear fear and cold-war doubt.
From Stalin and from the longtime Soviet Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, the memoir says, Khrushchev learned that Julius and Ethel Rosenberg had ''provided very significant help in accelerating the production of our atomic bomb.''
''Let this be a worthy tribute to the memory of those people,'' the memoir says of the Rosenbergs. ''Let my words serve as an expression of gratitude to those who sacrificed their lives to a great cause of the Soviet state at a time when the U.S. was using its advantage over our state to blackmail our state and undermine its proletarian cause.'' 
The reaction yesterday was like much of the controversy that has engulfed the case for years: fervent and inconclusive.
''That is absolute nonsense,'' said Michael Meeropol, a son of the Rosenbergs, who with his brother, Robert, has written books, filed lawsuits and struggled for years to obtain secret Government documents in the case and clear their parents' names.
But Ronald Radosh, co-author with Joyce Milton of ''The Rosenberg File,'' a 1983 book that concluded that Julius Rosenberg was a spy and that Ethel Rosenberg was at least aware of his activities, called the Khrushchev memoir ''formidable evidence,'' and added, ''This comes as a vindication for our theory that espionage was going on.''
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman, who presided at the Rosenbergs' 1951 trial and passed the death sentences, declined to comment on the Khrushchev memoirs, saying he had made it a policy never to comment on cases.
The Khrushchev memoir, excerpted in this week's issue of Time magazine, is to be published next month by Little, Brown & Company, as the third and final volume of ''Khrushchev Remembers,'' subtitled ''The Glasnost Tapes.''
 
Dictated After Fall From Power
Between his fall from power in 1964 and his death in 1971, Khrushchev dictated hundreds of hours of reminiscences of his life and work in the inner circles of Soviet power. The tapes were the basis of two previous volumes, published in 1970 and 1974.
According to Little, Brown, Khrushchev's family withheld some of the tapes dealing with sensitive issues, fearing that he had gone too far, for example, in criticizing powerful living people. The tapes were smuggled to the West.
The memoir is the latest piece of circumstantial evidence in a case that J. Edgar Hoover called ''the crime of the century,'' and that the Columbia Law Review called ''the outstanding political trial of this generation.''
The Rosenbergs were accused of having received atomic secrets from Ethel Rosenberg's brother, David Greenglass, a machinist at the Los Alamos, N.M., atomic bomb plant, and of having passed them to Moscow.
Mr. Greenglass, the chief witness against them, was later sentenced to 15 years in prison. After appeals and public protests, the Rosenbergs were put to death on June 19, 1953.
Defenders of the Rosenbergs say they were victims of a Government conspiracy, that the evidence was coerced and manufactured, and that they were unfairly tried and executed in an atmosphere of cold-war hysteria. The Government contends that the evidence was convincing if circumstantial.
The Meeropols, who were children at the time of the execution and took the name of their adoptive parents, have spent 15 years struggling with the Government to obtain documents that they contend would prove that the Rosenbergs were framed.
In a telephone interview yesterday from Springfield, Mass., where he is a professor of economics at Western New England College, Michael Meeropol called the Khrushchev memoir ''absurd,'' and noted that the director of the nameless city where the Soviet Union developed its first atomic bomb denied last year any involvement by the Rosenbergs.
The director, Boris V. Brokhovich, told The New York Times in an interview that development of the bomb had been a matter of trial and error. ''You sat the Rosenbergs in the electric chair for nothing,'' he said. ''We got nothing from the Rosenbergs.''
Mr. Radosh, a professor of American history at Queensboro Community College, also said that, with the end of the cold war, the Soviet Union and its former East European satellites might release information vital to historians and scholars on cases like that of the Rosenbergs, but he said he believed that would only reaffirm the verdict.
''I think the Soviets want to own up to this in the post-cold-war world,'' he said. ''They want to get Stalinism behind them, and these Khrushchev memoirs are part of that process.''
