HEADLINE: End to Pakistan Aid Is Sought Over Nuclear Issue

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Asserting that Pakistan has ignored American demands to curtail its program to develop nuclear weapons, a leading member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee has urged President Bush to cut off all military and economic aid to Islamabad.
The urging that aid be cut off was made in a Sept. 19 letter to President Bush by Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs and an influential lawmaker on the issue of aid to Pakistan.
The letter comes as the White House is considering the issue of Pakistan's nuclear intentions and it signals a re-emergence of the policy debate over Islamabad's nuclear activities.
 
Certification Required
To continue its aid program to Pakistan, the Administration must certify that Pakistan does not possess a nuclear weapon and that American assistance to Pakistan will reduce the risk that Pakistan will acquire such a device. That decision, which is required by law, is usually made before the new fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. A senior Administration official declined to comment on the status of President Bush's decision, saying the decision involved ''extremely delicate'' foreign policy issues. 
On the one hand, advances in the Pakistani nuclear program are making it increasingly difficult for the White House to make such a certification. On the other hand, Bush Administration officials are pleased that Pakistan is contributing troops to the multinational forces defending Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Solarz, however, said in an interview that Mr. Bush should decide against certification because of continued advances in the Pakistani nuclear program.
''For over a decade there has been a growing temptation to look the other way,'' Mr. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat, said, noting Pakistan's past role in funneling aid to the Afghan rebels.
''We have now reached the point where continuing to certify would deprive us of what tattered shreds may be left of our global nonproliferation policy,'' Mr. Solarz said, adding that this was the first time he had publicly opposed certification.
 
Basis of Cutoff Request
In calling for an aid cutoff, Mr. Solarz cited news reports that Pakistan is continuing to enrich uranium and procure equipment for its nuclear program, as well as conversations he has had with Administration specialists about the Pakistani nuclear program. The United States provides about $500 million a year to Pakistan in military and economic aid.
Mr. Solarz's letter drew criticism from a senior Administration official, who declined to be identified. ''This is not a particularly good time to bash the Pakistanis,'' the official said, noting that Pakistan is contributing troops to the multinational force in the Persian Gulf region and has just undergone a change of government.
In addition, the official complained that Congress was taking a tougher stance toward Pakistan's nuclear activities than toward India, which exploded a nuclear device in 1974.
But at the same time the senior Administration official said continued progress by the Pakistanis on nuclear issues made the certification question ''a very difficult issue.'' Leonard S. Spector, an expert on nuclear proliferation issues for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said that Mr. Solarz's letter was significant because the lawmaker has been a major participant in the Washington policy debate over Pakistan and because the letter would send an alarming message to the Indians.
''You want to be in a position to take a firm stance on Iraq's nuclear future and impose tough restrictions when this crisis is over,'' Mr. Spector said.
In his letter to Mr. Bush, Mr. Solarz wrote, ''On the basis of a number of reports I've received from unclassified sources, I have the impression that Pakistan's commitments to respect the various markers we set last year have not been met.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Views Threat by Iraq As Strategy to Split Critics

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials said today that Saddam Hussein's threat Sunday to attack Israel and Saudi Arabian oilfields if trade sanctions ''strangled'' Iraq's economy appears to be part of Baghdad's continuing political strategy to split the international coalition opposing Iraq.
But they said that discounting the tone of comments as merely threatening bravado would be a repetition of a mistake the Administration made in July, before Iraq invaded Kuwait, when it underestimated the Iraqi President's willingness to take military action.
''It's a deliberate step in his plan to keep what he's got and drive our coalition apart,'' said one Pentagon official. ''At the same time, we're not sloughing this off. He has the capability to do these things.'' 
By invoking fears of an attack on Israel and projecting images of oilfields burning out of control to send oil prices soaring and plunging Western economies deeply into recession, the Iraqi leader was trying to make the costs of war sound so horrific as to discourage any attack against Baghdad, officials explained.
 
'A Daily Diatribe'
While the officials acknowledged the statements marked an escalation in Mr. Hussein's bellicose oratory, they took pains to note that the threats were conveyed within an established context of intimidating public displays and comments emanating from Baghdad. ''We get a daily diatribe from Saddam, and this is another one of them,'' said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater.
Iraq announced Sunday that Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz was canceling a visit to New York to attend the United Nations General Assembly because the United States would not permit his Iraqi airliner to land.
State Department officials said the Mr. Aziz could take a commercial flight to New York, but that no Iraqi government plane would be allowed to land while Baghdad held hostage the 1,000 Americans remaining in Iraq and occupied Kuwait.
President Bush today reiterated the Administration's position against any negotiations with Baghdad until Iraq abided by the United Nations sanctions, and withdrew its forces from Kuwait.
In doing so, Mr. Bush noted the lack of success that Arab leaders, including Jordan's King Hussein, have had in brokering a settlement.
''Whoever else has stepped up to the plate, they have struck out because of this man's insistence on remaining in Kuwait,'' Mr. Bush told a group of leaders from the Arab-American community at the White House.
 
Pressures on Jordan
Earlier in the day, Mr. Fitzwater's comments about King Hussein were even more pointed. When asked about the king's call for the removal of American troops from Saudi Arabia, Mr. Fitzwater said that the Jordanian monarch ''has some difficult pressures on him, but nevertheless, we are disappointed in the conduct of that country at this point.''
When pressed by the Arab-American group to explain the objective of American involvement in the Gulf, President Bush said it was to thwart hostile aggression: ''Iraq is no model of democracy, nor was Kuwait. That isn't the question here. The question is international law and respect for one's neighbor.''
For Government officials and Middle East scholars who have been trying to weigh Mr. Hussein's real intentions, his increasingly threatening comments in recent days recalled the days just before the invasion of Kuwait, when the Iraqi leader's ominous rhetoric was discounted in Washington as well as European and Arab capitals.
Although Iraqi forces are currently arrayed in a defensive posture along the Saudi border, military experts said an Iraqi rocket attack against Israel or Saudi oilfields would not require extensive preparation.
Administration officials said they were discouraged that Mr. Hussein has so far shown no sign of seeking a way out of the crisis. If anything, they said, his dismemberment of Kuwait, including a decision enacted today to replace the Kuwaiti currency with the Iraqi dinar, suggested a commitment to remain as an occupying power.
Today brought no change in the tone or substance of Mr. Hussein's warnings.
''Kuwait is Iraqi and we won't give it up even if we fight over it for a thousand years,'' Baghdad radio quoted Mr. Hussein as saying today.
 
Israeli Reaction
JERUSALEM, Sept. 24 (Special to The New York Times) - Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned today that Israel stood ready to ''repay'' any attack by Iraq.
Responding to the most bellicose statement yet from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Israeli officials sought to keep the low profile requested by the United States. But all used almost the same words, saying they took the threat seriously.
''We of course, are taking his threats seriously and preparing for them,'' Mr. Shamir told Israel radio this evening, ''to anticipate, prevent and, God forbid, if he'll really attack, to repay him.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
East Germans to Supply Equipment to Gulf Force

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Sept. 24

 BODY:
About half the military aid promised by West Germany for the buildup of forces in the Persian Gulf will be in the form of East German military equipment, the Government spokesman said today.
The spokesman, Hans Klein, said that of the $1 billion in military equipment pledged by Chancellor Helmut Kohl when he met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Sept. 15, $460 million would come from the East German Army, which will merge with the West German Army when the two countries unite on Oct. 3.
The military aid is part of a total package of about $2 billion that also includes economic aid to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. But West German officials have acknowledged that much of the money was pledged before Mr. Kohl and Mr. Baker met. 
Mr. Klein confirmed the plan to send military equipment after it was reported by Die Welt, a daily, and Der Spiegel magazine. The spokesman said that weapons were not part of the package, but that it might include protective equipment against nuclear, chemical and biological attacks. He said that some of the equipment being provided might be Soviet-made.
 
Trucks and Cranes
Die Welt reported Saturday that the Defense Ministry was considering sending East German trucks, radio equipment, electric generators, cranes, water transport vehicles and engineering equipment.
American diplomats said they were not surprised by the inclusion of East German equipment in the package, noting that the army was probably the best-equipped in the Warsaw Pact and that much of its equipment is new.
Der Spiegel said in a report published today that the Americans were irritated when they learned that they would be receiving East German equipment. But officials at the United States Embassy denied this.
The East German Army has been disintegrating since the move toward reunification began last winter, and Die Welt said that army officers were complaining that it had become increasingly difficult to guard the stores.
When Mr. Baker visited Mr. Kohl in Ludwigshafen on Sept. 15, the Chancellor said that the West German Government would contribute $2.06 billion toward the American-led effort to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Mr. Baker greeted the announcement and said the package was ''substantially'' larger than the aid that Bonn had discussed earlier.
The West Germans say that their Constitution bars them from taking part directly in military operations outside the NATO region, and they have not sent troops to the Gulf. But Mr. Kohl is known to be sensitive to any perception that the Germans, with their economic strength, are not helping defend Western interests.
Beyond military equipment, the package announced by Mr. Kohl included $840 million in aid to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey to help them overcome the losses incurred through the blockade against Iraq.
How much of the package constitutes new aid is in dispute.
A spokesman for the Ministry of International Cooperation said that of the $609 million promised to Egypt, for example, $147 million had been pledged before the Kohl-Baker meeting, and $337 million was aid that had been delayed until Egypt met certain conditions. Thus only $125 million of the $609 million was fresh money for the package. [In Washington, a State Department official said that Mr. Kohl had told Mr. Baker that some of the equipment pledged was coming from East Germany, but that it was new. [The official said that Mr. Baker apparently did not press Mr. Kohl on any issue other than whether all of the money for Egypt and other countries was actually being sent after Aug. 2, the day that Iraq invaded Kuwait. Mr. Kohl assured him that it was, the official added.] A West German Government minister acknowledged last week at a briefing that the $2.06 billion package included money that was allocated before the meeting.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Convoy Heads to Baghdad With Powdered Milk, but No Exemptions

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 24

 BODY:
A convoy of more than 40 tractor-trailers loaded with food set out from this capital at dusk today on a 570-mile journey across a desert road to Baghdad.
The convoy's sponsors were a group of Palestinian volunteer agencies based in Jordan, and their action in dispatching the food supplies was an opening shot in what is likely to be a protracted battle. At issue are the United Nations economic sanctions against Iraq, and how much food, and under what arrangements, will be permitted to pass through the blockade that the United Nations Security Council has imposed on Baghdad.
The organizers of the convoy said they had not sought exemption from the Security Council's sanctions committee for the convoy, as required under the terms of the sanctions, because their undertaking was a humanitarian one. The organizers said the cartons of powdered milk, sugar, rice, pasta and vegetables were to be unloaded sometime Tuesday evening and turned over to the Iraqi Labor Ministry in Baghdad. They said the food was intended for Iraqi children. 
 
Children Chant Slogans
Hundreds of children who gathered to see the tractor-trailers depart chanted slogans in support of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. ''With our souls and blood,'' the children shouted, ''we sacrifice ourselves to you, Saddam.''
On Sunday, apparently prompted by tightening food shortages, Mr. Hussein issued a warning to the United States and other nations with military forces deployed against Iraq that Baghdad would not allow its 16 million people to be ''strangled'' by the United Nations embargo. Mr. Hussein implied that Iraq might mount pre-emptive strikes against Israel and against oilfields in Saudi Arabia and other Arab states arrayed against Iraq.
Mr. Hussein's statement set the stage for what diplomats here and in Baghdad said today is likely to be a new, and, for the United States and its allies, increasingly awkward phase of the confrontation with Iraq.
Mr. Hussein has already indicated that he intends to use the specter of food shortages in Iraq to weaken and perhaps break the common front among nations that have condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The diplomats predicted that Baghdad would increasingly publicize scenes of Iraqi women and children, in particular, suffering from food shortages.
An official representing a United Nations relief agency in Amman put it bluntly. ''How long will the Americans be able to hold to the embargo when the television news begins to show shots of hungry children?'' he said.
The situation poses a dilemma for Jordan, which is caught between strong support for Iraq among its 3.5 million people and a desire not to alienate Western nations that are its main sources of aid. Senior officials on the Government's Higher Committee for Relief, set up to handle refugees from the invasion arriving in Jordan, said tonight that they had no knowledge of the food convoy heading for Iraq.
A senior Foreign Ministry official said that the Government had not approved the convoy. ''I didn't have any idea about this,'' he said.
 
Shipments Subject to Approval
When it voted 10 days ago to approve shipments of food through the embargo ''to relieve human suffering,'' the Security Council authorized its sanctions committee to review specific cases and approve shipments. The Council ruled that food should be provided ''through the United Nations in cooperation with the International Committee of the Red Cross or other appropriate humanitarian agencies and distributed by them or under their supervision in order to insure that they reach the intended beneficiaries.''
Officials of the United Nations committee in New York say that only one exemption has been granted - to India, the nation that pressed the issue hardest. The committee gave permission for an Indian ship, the Vishwa Siddhi, to carry 10,000 tons of food for Indian and other Asian residents of Kuwait.
Indian diplomats in Baghdad said today that their Ambassador, Kamal Bakhshi, was in Umm Qasr, a port in southern Iraq, awaiting the ship's arrival, which United Nations officials said is expected on Tuesday.
Jordan has said that it will abide by the United Nations sanctions. But the Palestinian convoy that left Amman today appeared not to meet the conditions set by the sanctions committee. Abu Mohammed, a spokesman for the General Union of Voluntary Societies, the Palestinian organization that chartered the tractor-trailers, said that distribution of the food would be left to the Iraqi authorities.
United Nations officials said that at least 60,000 Asians are in transit camps around Baghdad, and that conditions there may be worse than anything evacuees encountered when they began pouring into camps in the Jordanian desert last month.
Diplomats who have visited the Baghdad camps said that they are closely guarded by heavily armed Iraqi security forces, that food is extremely scarce, and that there are no organized sanitary arrangements.
United Nations officials here said that information about Asians in the Baghdad camps and about food shortages in Kuwait was extremely sketchy because nearly all United Nations staff members who are not Iraqis or Kuwaitis were evacuated shortly after the Iraqi invasion. But the officials said that Asians who arrived in Jordan over the weekend were markedly weaker than those who arrived only a week ago, and that their accounts of their stays in the Baghdad camps were grim.
''What we are seeing is just the tip of the iceberg,'' a United Nations official said. ''I'm afraid that if we don't get more supplies into Iraq, we may end up with some of these people dying before they even get here.''
 
Iran Says It Seized Food
CAIRO, Sept. 24 (Special to The New York Times) - The Iranian authorities said today they had seized 29 people accused of trying to smuggle food across a remote border region into Iraq, the first suggestion that Teheran is enforcing the international embargo imposed after Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait.
The Iranian press agency said two bands of smugglers trying to cross the frontier had been arrested with contraband food including rice, vegetable oil and sugar and had been handed over to a revolutionary court in the northwestern Kurdish-speaking city of Sanandaj. It gave no other details. Iran officially supports the international sanctions imposed on Iraq. But there have been suggestions, despite Iranian denials, that Teheran has agreed with Baghdad to provide food in exchange for oil.
The announcement coincides with a visit to Iran by the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, his first since the Islamic revolution of 1979. Syria is considered Iraq's archrival in Arab politics. The Syrian leader is said by diplomats to be pressing Iran for a tough stance against Baghdad, Teheran's foe in the eight-year gulf war.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Forum on Mideast Crisis Proposed

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Based on the so-called Helsinki process that helped ease East-West tensions over the last 15 years, Spain and Italy proposed today that a broad new organization be created to address security and development problems throughout the Mediterranean and the Middle East.
The initiative, which also has the backing of France and Portugal, was originally born of growing concern that economic problems and population pressures in North Africa would continue to stimulate large-scale emigration to the countries of southern Europe.
''But the gulf crisis has reminded us how, despite the end of the East-West confrontation, the North-South issue remains fundamental if we are to build a new international order,'' Italy's Foreign Minister, Gianni de Michelis, said. 
Underlining the model for their new organization, the plan was unveiled at a meeting in Palma de Mallorca, organized by the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. That conference gave birth to the 1975 Helsinki accords committing signatories to respect human rights and promote democracy.
 
Recalling 'Spirit of Helsinki'
''We must apply the spirit of Helsinki to the Mediterranean and the Middle East,'' Spain's Foreign Minister, Francisco Fernandez-Ordonez, told the meeting today. ''Events in the gulf have shown in a dramatic way the lack of a system for preventing and discussing crises in the area.''
So far, preparations for a Conference on Security and Cooperation in the Mediterranean have involved Spain, Italy, Portugal and France in Europe and Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, Libya and Mauritania in North Africa. But the plan is that it eventually embrace other nations in Europe and the Middle East as well as the United States and the Soviet Union.
Mr. De Michelis said that both Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization would be invited to take part. Recognizing the possibility of an Israeli boycott, he noted that the Helsinki process operated well despite the absence of one country, Albania.
Spanish officials have said the purpose of the conference is not to resolve specific disputes in the region, but rather to establish a broad code of conduct covering a variety of problems, from the inviolability of borders and democracy to immigration and economic development.

HEADLINE: Philadelphia's Financial Crisis Turns on Mayor

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Mayor W. Wilson Goode, a sharecropper's son and self-made man, took office in 1984 amid high hopes that he would put the city on a sound financial footing and help ease the city's racial tensions.
Instead he has led the city to brink of insolvency and has lost support among the city's largely white population and power structure. Elected state officials, Democrats and Republicans alike, say that he has lost so much credibility in Harrisburg, the state capital, that he is now the greatest obstacle in solving the city's deepening fiscal crisis.
Democrats who control the State House of Representatives say there has been a complete collapse of the political process in Philadelphia. And Republican leaders who control the State Senate say they are so outraged by the Democratic Mayor's handling of the city's finances that they will block any solution that does not include a temporary state takeover of the city's management and finances. 
 
City's Fate in Question
The 52-year-old Mayor has flatly ruled out that alternative, setting up a situation where the fate of city employees and services may depend on whether the Mayor or the legislators, who have apparently nothing to lose, will accept defeat first.
''Mayor Goode and his administration are kind of like the alcoholic who says, 'I'm O.K., I don't drink too much; just give me another drink,' '' said State Senator Robert C. Jubelirer, a Republican from Altoona, in western Pennsylvania, who is president pro tempore of the Senate. ''We're not going to throw more money at the Goode administration, or give them more taxing authority, until they admit they have a problem, admit they need help and say they are going to dry out.''
Senator Jubelirer's words only add to a chorus of criticism against the Mayor, who made history here by becoming the city's first black Mayor nearly seven years ago, riding in on a comfortable majority of votes. Back then, it was widely thought that if anyone could forge racial harmony and bring sense to city management and finances, it would be this deeply religious, hard-working man with a master's degree in business from the prestigious Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and a reputation for being fair to a fault.
Conservative in dress, speech and manner, he was widely seen as someone who could satisfy the board room without losing the people on the street. A few months after Mr. Goode took office, Walter F. Mondale interviewed him as a possible running mate in the 1984 Presidential election.
 
Fellow Democrat's Doubts
But now Mr. Goode's political star has fallen so low that even Gov. Robert P. Casey, a fellow Democrat, has publicly expressed doubts about the Goode administration. Although Mr. Goode says he has repeatedly briefed the Governor on the severity of the city's financial problems, Mr. Casey told reporters last week that the state would not help the city until the Goode administration provided ''a clear, accurate picture of the extent of the problem.''
Democratic legislative leaders say they will put together a proposed solution by Dec. 1, but not before the Nov. 6 statewide elections. This suggests they fear a backlash from voters elsewhere in the state if they do anything now that could be portrayed as a state rescue of the city. The Governor and nearly all legislators are up for re-election this year. Members of the City Council, which has in the past routinely imposed its own financial plans and ignored Mayor Goode's, are also testing campaign slogans for elections next year. Several are jockeying to succeed the Mayor, who is in his next-to-last year in office and is prohibited from seeking a third consecutive term.
The shifting deadline underscores Mayor Goode's credibility problem in Harrisburg, since he initially said Philadelphia could be insolvent as early as late October. Then last Friday, he announced a variety of accounting measures that he said would postpone insolvency until Dec. 1. ''After that we can't make payroll,'' he said.
Mayor Goode, sitting in his wood-paneled office in City Hall, seems insulated from the howls at his door. ''We have got to change this unproductive course, making groundless charges of mismanagement,'' he said, speaking with the dispassion of an academic in an interview last week. ''A distressed city declaration by the state won't solve the problem, a bankruptcy won't solve the problem, a municipal assistance corporation won't solve the problem. What we need is the taxing authority to solve our own problems.''
The taxing authority is needed because, unlike many other major cities, Philadelphia is not permitted to increase city taxes without approval of the State Legislature.
 
Politics, Race and Class
''I don't understand why state legislators won't help us out,'' he continued, ''not unless something else is involved: politics, race or class or all three.''
Just days earlier, Philadelphia, which has chronically failed to balance its books, was thrown into a financial crisis with the collapse of a deal to borrow $375 million in short-term notes. The money was desperately needed to cover cash outlays until winter taxes are collected.
The deal was doomed in June, when Moody's Investor Services downgraded the city's bond rating to Ba, which is reserved for speculative investments. Moody's and other credit agencies acted after reviewing the city's $2.1 billion budget for the fiscal year 1991, and determining that it was unrealistic. The Mayor later acknowledged that the budget would result in a $206 million deficit. All credit agencies now rate the city as one fast approaching a default.
The city and the state are usually at odds over budget issues, and the debate is always colored by Philadelphia's enduring reputation for corruption and mismanagement. That enrages most state legislators in this largely white, rural and conservative state.
One of the seeds for the current fiscal crisis was planted back in 1850, when the General Assembly tried to contain Philadelphia by preventing it from annexing any more territory. That decision stifled the city's growth and kept it from following its residents out to the suburbs, as Houston, Atlanta and other cities have done. Philadelphia has lost a half-million middle-class residents since 1950, leaving behind an increasingly poor, elderly, needy and black population totaling 1.5 million, preliminary 1990 census figures show.
In this environment, it is hard to determine whether City Hall's history has simply rubbed off on the Mayor and magnified his errors or whether the conventional wisdom is correct: that he is an incompetent manager with few political skills and no credibility outside the 39 percent of the city's population that is black.
 
Target of Ridicule
Agreeing with what several Goode supporters said in interviews, Dr. Sandra Featherman, director of the Center for Public Policy at Temple University, said: ''I don't think he was a bad Mayor; he tried hard to be a good Mayor. But he was weak, not vindictive enough - and you have to be vindictive to manage something as complex as this city, with its fractious City Council. He has been a target of ridicule for a long time.''
Philadelphians are used to the ridicule; some even wake up to it if their clock radios are tuned to KISS-AM. Every morning the soft-rock station does a brief satire titled, ''Bad Wilson: The Blunder Years.''
The division among Mayor Goode's supporters and detractors is largely along racial lines, as interviews with people on the street suggest. ''He's a black Mayor, and I don't want to give him any type of criticism,'' said J. Farmer, a black letter carrier. Several white residents gave the Mayor mainly negative reviews. ''I think he is a nice man, but he is not qualified to be Mayor,'' said J. Woodcock, a banker. ''This whole mess is totally attributable to Wilson Goode.''
Judgment of the Mayor may be overly harsh because expectations of him were very high when he was elected in 1983. ''Mayor Goode couldn't have been as good as he was portrayed then, just as it's impossible for him to be as bad as everybody says he is now,'' said Frederick L. Voight, executive director of the Committee of 70, a private nonpartisan agency dedicated to better government.
At first, Mr. Goode seemed to have something for everybody. He says he considered becoming a Baptist minister, but took up public service instead. In the 1960's, his community group built more low-income housing than the city's housing agency. He later obtained his master's degree in business administration and became chairman of the State Public Utility Commission.
In 1980, Mayor William J. Green made him the first black managing director, placing him in charge of the city's 10 operating divisions.
 
'He Doesn't Smile Much'
He viewed himself then as a ''technocrat,'' and displayed the charisma of one. As his 87-year old mother, Rozelar Goode, said in a recent interview: ''He doesn't smile much or have much to say. He took after his father.''
In 1983, Mr. Goode ran for Mayor and was elected with 97 percent of the black vote and 22.5 percent of the white vote, Dr. Featherman said.
Friend and foe alike say the decline in the Mayor's political fortunes began after 17 months in office, at 5:30 P.M. on May 13, 1985. It was on that night that he permitted a police helicopter to drop a bomb on a West Philadelphia house held by an armed radical group, Move, that had been the subject of complaints by many neighbors. The resulting explosion and fire killed six adult members of the group and their five children and burned 250 other homes.
Perhaps the worst thing he did in 1985 was to avoid accepting responsibility for the debacle until after a commission, appointed by him, reported its finding that he had been negligent, irresponsible and had ''abdicated his responsibilities as a leader.''
His actions during and after the bombing crippled his ability to govern, and the incident continues to provide an easy hook for anybody who wants to criticize his management skill without adding new specifics.
In 1987, Philadelphia voters had the choice between what a political analyst here said was the ''evil of two lessers'' - Mr. Goode and former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo. Mr. Goode narrowly won re-election, getting 97 percent of the black vote and 18 percent of the white vote.
The Mayor's second term has been dominated by insurmountable budget deficits and what he calls ''unproductive'' relations with almost all elected officials in the city and state.
Mr. Goode has no close friends or regular advisers, but his press secretary said William V. Donaldson would have a balanced view of the Mayor. ''He is a competent, journeyman mayor,'' said Mr. Donaldson, president of the Philadelphia Zoological Society, chairman of the Mayor's Advisory Committee on the Budget and Cincinnati's manager in the 1970's.
''What we have here is a case of failed good intentions,'' he said. ''When the Federal Government took away the money for social services, the city had to do a bunch of things that they neither had the fiscal nor intellectual ability to do. City government here is not made up of faculty of the Harvard Business School, you know. What happened is simple to explain. What to do about it is beyond me.''

HEADLINE: Debate Over Logging Means Trouble For Incumbent in Washington State

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLYMPIA, Wash.

 BODY:
A Congressional district that has the volcanoes of Mount Rainier and Mount St. Helens on one side and the Pacific Ocean on the other would seem a natural to embrace a politician whose family is well-known among outdoor enthusiasts here.
But Representative Jolene Unsoeld, the first-term Democrat from southwest Washington State, is in trouble, primarily because of the rancorous debate over what to do with all that scenery.
After winning a seat by 618 votes in the closest House race of 1988, Ms. Unsoeld has worked to save salmon runs from huge Japanese fishing nets and to protect ancient forests from timber companies that export the logs. Those are positions an Unsoeld (pronounced UN-sold) is expected to take in the Northwest: her husband, Willi Unsoeld, who died in an avalanche nearly 10 years ago, was an outspoken environmentalist and one of the first Americans to climb Mount Everest. 
But those positions, and Ms. Unsoeld's support for logging restrictions to protect the threatened northern spotted owl, do not always go over well in this part of Washington, where saving forests usually translates into lost jobs.
 
Catcalls From Loggers
Under Washington's open primary system, all candidates for Representative run in the same primary, and the top finisher from each party runs in the November election. Last Tuesday, Ms. Unsoeld received 52 percent of the total primary vote, Gomer Robert Williams, a conservative Republican, won 38 percent and two other candidates split the remainder.
Small, soft-spoken and bespectacled, Ms. Unsoeld has had a tough time among loggers, millworkers and others whose livelihood is dependent on the evergreen forests in this wet part of the country.
Trying to explain the news that timber jobs are disappearing because of overcutting, which she opposes, and environmental restrictions, which she supports, Ms. Unsoeld has at times been met with boos, catcalls and disparaging remarks about her sex and appearance.
 
A Strong Challenge
Her critics say she comes across too much like an urban environmentalist and a feminist in a district where chain saws are hung over the doorways and the spotted owl is sometimes spoken of sarcastically as a delicacy for dinner.
Several thousand people in the timber industry here are expected to be out of work in the next few years if the Forest Service, as expected, restricts the number of trees to be cut in an effort to save the rare owl.
The district is heavily Democratic, with a populist labor tradition dating from the days of the radical Industrial Workers of the World, the Wobblies. Its urban edges, at the Columbia River north of Portland, and in the state capital of Olympia, are fast-growing high-technology and government centers, with little connection to the tree-cutting economy. Mr. Williams, an accountant who has strong backing from fundamentalist Christians and the timber industry, is running a strong race. A former state Representative, Mr. Williams was the Republican challenger for governor two years ago. He has been attacking Ms. Unsoeld as too liberal, too environmentalist and too ineffective.
''It's the loggers who got her elected, and she hasn't done anything for them,'' he said. Mr. Williams says the owl could be saved even with continued high levels of logging in national forests.
Even some Unsoeld supporters have doubts on her environmental positions. ''What Jolene needs to do is make some real solid announcements about supporting working people,'' said a backer, Frank Chestnut, an official with the International Woodworkers of America, a timber workers union, in Aberdeen, a coastal logging town.
Mr. Chestnut said most loggers realize that no matter who is elected, the days of unrestricted tree cutting and shipping overseas - sometimes criticized here as ''rip and ship'' - are over, and that jobs in the woods will be lost. But he said the woodworkers want somebody to speak out on their behalf, to assure them that mortgages will not suddenly be threatened and that their families will not crumble from debt.
Ms. Unsoeld has asked for Federal money to retrain laid-off loggers and, in a move she says will help save 6,000 mill and logging jobs, has championed a ban on log exports recently signed by President Bush. She says that the timber crisis was caused by overcutting by private companies and the export boom. Last year one in four logs from the Northwest were sent overseas and never touched the hands of American millworkers.
''Our overcutting, our mismanagement of the forest, our export of raw logs, all are to blame for the situation we're in,'' she said in a recent interview. ''It's a difficult and complex situation. People criticize me because they are emotional, they feel threatened. I understand that.''
She would like to see more bite in American trade policy so that Japan buys less raw goods and more finished wood products like building material, furniture and siding. Tariffs as high as 30 percent keep many Northwest wood products out of Japan.
In recent weeks, as anxieties in the timber towns increase over the uncertainty about next year's logging level, Ms. Unsoeld has changed her message somewhat to emphasize her ties to logging as well as the environment.
During a House hearing in Olympia on timber, Ms. Unsoeld talked about the loggers in her family. ''My father and grandfather were timber men,'' she said. ''My father started out as a kid working a donkey engine on Larch Mountain. My brother is the third generation in this proud industry and today owns a wood treatment plant. My family has long been supported by timber dollars.''
Ms. Unsoeld may have come from timber stock, but her reputation was made, early on, in the mountains. She was the first woman to climb the north face of Mount Teton, in Wyoming. Robert Redford bought the rights to the life story of Mrs. Unsoeld's husband for a possible film. Their daughter, Nanda Devi, was named for a Himalayan peak. She died in 1976 while trying to climb the mountain with her father.
Ms. Unsoeld got into politics as a consumer advocate and campaign reformist and later was a state representative known for taking on industrial polluters and big companies. She won the primary here in 1988 after the long-time representative, Don Bonker, made an unsuccessful try at the Senate. She barely beat a political unknown, Bob Wight, in the general election.
Then, as now, she said it was important to tell voters the truth about how their area was changing. Those in this district who want to believe that jobs in the woods will always be plentiful might not like her message, but Ms. Unsoeld says she thinks they will share her vision, even if it is not always optimistic.
''Nobody who knows anything about the forest believes we can continue cutting as we have,'' Ms. Unsoeld said.

HEADLINE: All U.S. Hondas to Get Air Bags by Fall of '93

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The new president of the Honda Motor Company said today that starting in the fall of 1993 all Hondas sold in the United States would be equipped with air bags on both the driver's and front passenger's sides.
On his first visit to this country as head of his company, Nobuhiko Kawamoto, who was promoted in May, said Honda made the decision two months ago. Mr. Kawamoto was in the United States to address a meeting of Honda dealers and to attend a conference on motorcycles, with a trip to Detroit to meet automotive reporters. Honda's announcement raises the competitive stakes for American and foreign auto makers, who have increasingly been installing air bags to comply with the Federal law requiring passive restraints in addition to seat belts. Most auto makers at first installed ''automatic'' belts that did not require buckling for front-seat passengers. 
Air bags have become popular as evidence has accumulated that they are effective and that they do not inflate prematurely, a possibility that had concerned auto makers.
The Ford Motor Company, which already installs air bags on the driver side in about half its cars, said last January that it would have air bags for drivers and front-seat passengers by the mid-1990's. But Ford has been plagued by supplier problems that make its schedule uncertain.
 
Moves by American Makers
Daimler-Benz has driver-side air bags in all its cars and passenger-side air bags in more expensive Mercedes-Benz models.
Last month, the General Motors Corporation said it would install driver-side air bags on all its American-made cars starting in the fall of 1995 and some for front-seat passengers by 1992. Because of G.M.'s size and influence, its decision virtually assured that air bags would become a standard piece of safety equipment. The Chrysler Corporation was the first auto maker to commit itself to installing air bags, in 1988.
What may be most remarkable about Honda's announcement is how swiftly the auto maker will switch from mostly automatic belts to air bags. Honda now has air bags only in its Acura Legend luxury car and Acura NSX sports coupe, which account for 10 to 12 percent of the 700,000 cars it sells each year in this country.
Within 36 months Honda must accomplish the design and engineering on its remaining lineup - the Civic, Accord, and Acura Integra - to accommodate the air bag systems, which require advanced electronic sensors and propellants for inflation.

HEADLINE: White House Objects to Bills on Cleaner Fuel

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The White House has decided to oppose both the House and Senate versions of plans to make oil companies provide cleaner-burning gasoline. Those requirements are a centerpiece of proposed revisions to the Clean Air Act.
In a letter dated Friday, the White House, which had not expressed a public position beyond saying that any new requirements should be worth the cost, said, ''Both the House and Senate reformulated gas provisions are needlessly inflexible and present enormous implementation problems.''
Both houses had approved unusually specific legislation about what steps would be required, reflecting frustration over past laws that had failed to achieve the anticipated progress. 
The letter, addressed to Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, continued, ''Unless these provisions are changed, they will result in unnecessary increases in the price of gasoline to consumers and in potential supply disruptions, without producing commensurate environmental benefits.''
The letter was signed by the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, William K. Reilly, the Secretary of Energy, James D. Watkins, and the President's assistant for economic and domestic policy, Roger B. Porter.
 
Passage Further Complicated
The letter does not explicitly mention a veto, but it concludes that the signers ''look forward to working with you to produce a bill that the President can endorse.'' The letter would appear to further complicate passage of a new bill, which would be the first major amendment to the 20-year-old act since 1977. The bill has been before a conference committee all summer.
Air pollution experts say reformulated gasoline is a particularly important step to achieve progress quickly. William Sessa, a spokesman for the California Air Resources Board, said that requiring changes in automobile emissions would also help, but he said: ''Emission standards reduce emissions from cars yet to be built. Cleaner gasoline affects emissions from all cars on the roads.''
But the letter said: ''It is simply inappropriate and needlessly expensive to specify a formula for gasoline in the statute, because technology and markets move in ways that cannot be easily anticipated. If it is not possible to eliminate the formula from the bill, at a minimum the conference should include flexible language allowing fuels that provide equivalent benefits to be used in lieu of the mandated formula.''
The oil industry has raised similar concerns and has lobbied hard against the provisions.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who is a leading proponent of the gasoline provisions, called the White House's position ''unbelievable.'' Reducing pollution by changing gasoline is far cheaper than reducing it by other means, he said, and the White House's position is ''not good for the environment and it's not good for the economy.''
House staff members said the House version was not overly restrictive. At the urging of the oil industry, staff members said, the House had drafted a law that would allow oil companies to use either the House's recipe for gasoline or any equally clean gasoline.
The House and Senate took different approaches, but set specifications for the levels of certain kinds of hydrocarbon compounds in gasoline and the oxygen content. Oxygen is present in methanol, alcohol and other combustible liquids that can be added to gasoline, promoting fuller combustion. But it can also result in increased production of nitrogen oxides. And by some estimates, the additives required under the bill would be in very short supply and would have to be imported.
The Administration estimated that the reformulation provisions would cost the oil industry an average of at least $3 billion annually between 1992 and 1994 and raise gasoline prices by at least six to eight cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: How to Answer Iraq's Threats

 BODY:
The United States and its allies would make a terrible mistake to take all Saddam Hussein's rhetorical flourishes literally. But they would commit at least equal error in not taking the man and his record of fulfilling past threats seriously.
The Iraqi leader thus confronted the U.N. allies with a genuine dilemma on Sunday when he threatened to launch a pre-emptive strike against his adversaries if the U.N. economic embargo strangled his country. In some of his bloodiest language to date, Mr. Hussein said ''Iraq is in good shape and ready to start a war'' to ''strangle'' Arab states, the oilfields and Israel. 
It's easy enough to find lots of reasons not to respond at all to this oratory. Maybe it's just bravado. Or perhaps it's simply his retort to General Dugan, the former U.S. Air Force Chief of Staff, who was dismissed after saying his aircraft were ready to lay waste to Baghdad. Or maybe he's trotting out his terrorist thesaurus - filled with words like ''strangle,'' ''flood,'' turn ''into flames'' - to spook a U.N. coalition already shaky at any thought of war. No need to answer him on these accounts.
Perhaps, too, Mr. Hussein's tirade is a good sign, a sign that the U.N. embargo is already pinching his country hard. In that event, and in any event, the response then should be to keep squeezing and closing loopholes in the embargo, like air traffic.
Yet Mr. Bush and Israeli leaders were wise yesterday not to entirely discount that Saddam Hussein could be contemplating a first strike. It could be that he doesn't have the patience to try to outwait the embargo, or the confidence he could do so. It could be that the pressure is getting to him, and he's becoming less rational. Or maybe he's quite rational and believes war is inevitable, and that it would be far better for Iraq to strike the first blow.
For these reasons, the possibility of an Iraqi pre-emptive attack cannot simply be dismissed. But Washington's response ought not to be to launch the first strike itself. Few, if any, allies would now join such an effort. The whole crisis would be transformed into an Iraqi-American conflict. The coalition that President Bush labored so skillfully to forge these past seven weeks would be destroyed. And whatever the results of the attack, the full wrath of the Arab world eventually would fall on the United States alone.
The most adroit response for Washington would be to discuss the issue with its allies now - urgently and frankly. What are the costs and risks of leaving the initiative to Baghdad? Could substantial numbers of lives and oilfields be saved by hitting first? Would the political costs of pre-emption outweigh these savings? If U.S. forces received signals of an imminent Iraqi attack, would the allies back a unilateral American action? If not, what then?
Tackling these questions will be a nasty but necessary and prudent exercise. The U.N. coalition, so vital to prevailing over Iraq, could swiftly fall apart if it proves unable to come to terms with the issue of whether and when to use force.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 512 words

HEADLINE: Good Politics, Bad Economics

 BODY:
The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, is desperately seeking a way out of the impasse over capital gains taxes that plagues negotiations on deficit reduction. He now floats two ideas: One is to vote separately on a package to cut the deficit by $500 billion over five years and on a controversial package of revenue-losing measures, including a capital gains tax cut. The second is for Republicans to swallow higher income taxes on the rich in exchange for a lower tax on capital gains. 
These ideas are ingenious. But by improving the chances of success for President Bush's misguided campaign to lower the tax on capital gains, Mr. Dole would solve a political problem and create a severe economic one. What's needed is not ingenuity but a sense of national interest. Mr. Bush has to abandon his obsessive romance with a capital gains tax cut and let Congress complete the vital task of whacking the Federal deficit down to size.
Mr. Dole's first idea is to split the deficit votes into two stages. The first vote would be on proposals to cut the deficit. The second would be on proposals that would wind up increasing the deficit - a package of new spending and tax cuts, including lower capital gains taxes. This package would contain the means to pay for these new initiatives.
One danger is that the deficit reduction package would not receive final approval unless the second package also passed. That would make deficit reduction hostage to a capital gains tax cut.
There is another, more subtle danger. Along with capital gains, the second package would include plans to raise the standard deduction and the earned income tax credit, two changes that would insulate poor families from the brunt of deficit reduction. This package would also include provisions for child care and other useful increases in neglected social services. Thus legislators could reject the capital gains tax cut only by rejecting the needs of the poor.
Mr. Dole's second idea is to link the capital gains tax cut to higher income tax rates for the rich. That seems like a fair compromise. It would cure the problem of inequity, but by creating a bigger problem. The 1986 tax reform act equalized taxes on ordinary income and capital gains. This led investors to put their money in projects that would expand economic output, not minimize taxes. Mr. Bush's proposal threatens to unravel that magnificent accomplishment.
If the Republicans follow Mr. Dole's lead, the top rate on ordinary income would rise above 30 percent, while the rate on capital gains would fall to 15 percent. With that large a difference, armies of lawyers would be back in the business of creating appallingly wasteful tax shelters that allow investors to report their income as capital gains.
All Americans share Mr. Dole's frustration that the budget talks are deadlocked. Yet the summiteers have made significant progress on a wide range of issues. If Mr. Bush would get out of their way, they could begin fixing the nation's sordid fiscal stance without undermining either the tax code or the economy.

HEADLINE: Auto Fuel Efficiencies Lie Within Our Grasp

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Washington's Mood Worries Detroit'' (Business Day, Sept. 3) conveys the impression that stricter auto mileage standards could doom ''energy-consuming luxuries like air-conditioning and anti-lock brakes.'' An analysis of auto efficiency by Marc Ledbetter, policy analyst at the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy, and Marc Ross, a University of Michigan physicist, shows that Environmental Protection Agency-rated fleet average fuel efficiencies of 40.1 miles a gallon could be reached by the year 2000, using technical options, each costing no more than $1.13 a gallon, at an average conserved gasoline cost of 52 cents a gallon (Business Day, Aug. 1). 
Average automobile efficiencies similar to those proposed in Senator Richard H. Bryan's bill (40 miles per gallon) are feasible and cost effective. Policies to promote them (including fleet average efficiency standards, combined with revenue-neutral gas-guzzler taxes and gas-sipper rebates on new cars) are needed without delay. These policies will save consumers money and reduce the environmental consequences of automobile use without raising gasoline taxes.
 
JONATHAN G. KOOMEY
 Berkeley, Calif., Sept. 13, 1990
The writer is a research fellow, energy and resources group, University of California.

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Up-and-Down Town

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
New York is dying again, as it was in 1974 when I moved there from Washington. Then, as now, many people were saying good riddance. ''Drop Dead'' was The Daily News's famous headline summation of President Ford's advice to the city.
Fed-up New Yorkers were getting out, as always. After living there a while I was struck, on trips to the suburbs, by the vast population of former New Yorkers out there who had decamped because of previous deaths of the city. All over New Jersey, Westchester County and Long Island, old-timers who had lived in the city during the Depression or the war years or the fat 50's talked lovingly about its bygone glories. 
Still speaking the city's distinctive accents, they were quick to reminisce about its lost splendors. ''But I'd never live there now,'' they often added, and gave you an unpersuasive account of the quiet pleasures of suburban life.
They often seemed amazed to hear I had deliberately chosen to live in New York. So awful now. I should have been there in the old days . . .
I had several reasons for going in 1974. One was a hick's suspicion that though small-town roots and mud-between-the-toes rusticity might be wonderful to boast about, no American could claim he had lived life to the hilt until he had experienced New York.
I stayed 11 years, which may be longer than average for an adopted New Yorker. Settlers seem to exhaust the city's joys too quickly, maybe from overindulgence when they first arrive, and then start to miss the more pastoral pleasures remembered in quieter places. E. B. White, for example, though often thought of as the quintessential New Yorker, lived most of his adult life in Maine.
The dying New York of 1974 was the victim of a long siege of very bad government. Not just city government either, but state government in Albany and Federal Government in Washington, both of which were blind to the fact that cities are absolutely vital to a nation's health and, so, utterly uninterested in trying to make them flourish.
Nelson Rockefeller's revenue-sharing plan, later savaged by Reagan know-nothings, was a grudging Federal acknowledgment that, yes, maybe Washington ought to be interested in shoring up local governments, but the money it distributed was small when measured against the enormity of the American city's problems.
These problems were epitomized in New York, so when the Nixon recession of the early 1970's arrived, New York again began dying.
If you're not rich, the times when New York is dying may be the best times to move in. This was my experience in 1974. With Manhattan real estate on the rocks, there was a vast choice of apartments for rent or sale at what later seemed giveaway prices. And real estate is decisive in determining whether life in New York is to be wonderful, tolerable or wretched.
For paupers, a welfare hotel is better than the streets while a private apartment is a place where maybe you can start reassembling your life. In ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' Tom Wolfe expresses the millionaire's real-estate agony to perfection when he observes that after you are accustomed to living in a $3 million apartment, living in a $1 million apartment is simply impossible.
For Manhattan's well-to-do, discovering that you're not well-to-do enough to stay in a skyrocketing real-estate market - ah, friend, that is crushing evidence that you are not well-to-do at all and might as well go away. This was the awful truth delivered to me by the real-estate orgies of the 1980's when it seemed the good times could never end and New York could never die again.
Priced out, I lit out for suburbs, but suburbs far, far away. I did not want to become another of those old New Yorkers out in Jersey, in Westchester, on Long Island telling visitors that New York was just a ruined replica of the city I knew in the good old days.
You who plan to leave New York, hark! I will now tell you of suburbs: They are safer, quieter, cleaner, superior in many ways to New York. Also: in suburbs it is hard to find people who will excite, infuriate, exhilarate, amaze, stupefy, astound and provoke you, or make you re-examine everything you ever believed.
Also: It's hard to find a good play, a good restaurant, a good opera and a good protest demonstration. When everybody has fled to the suburbs and there are no more cities for suburbanites to refresh themselves in, it will be said of America, ''A restful place to visit, but I wouldn't want to live there.''

HEADLINE: Inflation Isn't Our Biggest Problem

BYLINE: By Roger C. Altman; Roger C. Altman, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury from 1977 to 1980, is vice-chairman of the Blackstone Group Inc.

 BODY:
The world's finance ministers, meeting in Washington this week, have reportedly urged tighter monetary policies to combat the inflation they expect from the recent doubling of oil prices. While that may make sense for the strong economies in Europe and Japan, it is wrong for the U.S., which is now almost certainly in a recession.
For the U.S., accepting the finance ministers' prescriptions would mean following the same course that proved so disastrous after the 1973 and 1979 oil price rises. Those actions - in essence, a tight money policy combined with a moderately loose fiscal policy - led directly to the severe recessions of 1974-75 and 1981-82. 
This time the results could be en n rsrse.evev b bororhaha w wheheededntnta a receioion with b budt t deficit as high as 5 percent of gross national product. A bad slump, along the lines of those of 1974-1975 and 1981-1982, could balloon the deficit into the $300 to $400 billion range. The U.S. has never had to finance amounts like these. Further, with Germany struggling to pay for unification and Japan's financial markets weakening, we no longer can count on huge inflows of foreign capital to finance our deficits, as we did in the 80's. And corporate debt is dangerously high. Currently, American corporations devote approximately 50 percent of their earnings - a historic high - to meeting interest payments. Thus, a recession could send bankruptcy rates soaring over the next year, with big job losses.
Finally, the Government lacks the traditional, Keynesian tools to fight a recession. Previously, Washington would try to revive a slowing economy with lower taxes and higher spending. Today's large deficits rule this out. Financial markets would panic if it were tried.
In short, we cannot afford to let this recession deepen. If nothing else, we should at least try to avoid the mistakes of the Carter years.
After the Iran oil embargo of 1979, the Carter Administration followed a status quo economic policy. With the economy sluggish, no effort was made to tighten fiscal policy.
Into this vacuum stepped the Federal Reserve, slamming on the monetary brakes to reduce demand and, ostensibly, to suppress oil-driven inflation. The result, however, was to severely deepen the recessionary influences that already had been set in motion. The key point is this. In today's weak economy, we can't cure the inflation of an oil shock by tightening money. That would just squeeze demand, guaranteeing a longer recession. Better to accept some temporary inflation from the oil shock than slam on the brakes and throw the economy into a dive.
The only way to stimulate the current economy is to lower interest rates sharply. But the Fed has no rationale for loosening the money supply until Congress comes up with a credible plan for cutting the budget deficit.
Before the Iraqi invasion, the Administration and Congress were on the verge of an agreement on cuts totaling $50 billion in 1991 and $500 billion over five years. A deal along these lines remains imperative. With that in place, the Fed could ease monetary policy substantially. With budget policy less stimulative, the money supply could grow and short-term rates decline without undue pressure on inflation. Undoubtedly, the Fed is not eager to repeat its 1979 overreaction.
If we reversed fiscal and monetary policy, the confidence of financial markets would soar and interest rates would fall dramatically. The Fed Chairman, Alan Greenspan, has predicted that a credible budget deal could lead to rate reductions of two full percentage points. This stimulus would easily offset the fiscal drag of a tighter budget.
Many in Washington prefer the status quo on economic policy. There is relief that the political focus is temporarily on the Middle East, not on pocket book issues at home. But, this is whistling past the graveyard.
Since the invasion of Kuwait, the economy has dropped like a stone. Consumers and businesses, recalling the earlier oil shocks, are retrenching, cutting back purchases in anticipation of a steeper downturn. Retail sales have run into a wall.
This economic fallout from the two earlier oil shocks drove Presidents Ford and Carter from office, and many Congressmen with them. Mr. Bush's war-driven approval ratings notwithstanding, the same thing can happen again.

HEADLINE: Koreans See a Gain From Boycott: Unity

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Members of New York City's Korean-American community say the long, bitter boycott of two Korean-owned stores has produced one unforseen benefit: It has mobilized their community and spurred it to integrate itself into the city's political life.
''The boycott has motivated the community to realize we have to really follow and be part of the city's politics to show the city that it has to recognize us as a political power,'' said Jay Sung Lee, founder and president of Korean-Americans for Social Concerns.
His group consists of Koreans born in the United States and those who call themselves the ''one point five'' (1.5) generation: born in Korea but educated in this country. It was one of several groups that rallied thousands of Koreans outside City Hall last week, a turning point for a community that believed it was time to speak up.
 
Dinkins Found Ineffective
The rally, called to promote racial harmony, was peaceful, but the crowed booed during remarks by Mayor David N. Dinkins, who people in the crowd said they believed had been ineffective in breaking the boycott in Brooklyn. And in case the Mayor failed to get the message, young Koreans weaved through the crowd, handing out voter registration forms. 
While their community has too few eligible voters, many Korean-Americans said they felt that the rising generation of young adults born or educated here were developing the savvy to exercise power in the political system through such devices as the building of coalitions.
''The first generation was concerned with economic stability,'' said 31-year-old Mr. Lee, who left Korea when he was 17 to attend college in New York. ''It's past time now, and we have to look for political power. We are looking at the year 2000 to how and where Korean-Americans can stand in this society.''
Several days later Mayor Dinkins purchased about $10 worth of fruits and vegetables at the boycotted stores in a show of support. When he appeared Sunday at the Ninth Annual Korean-American Harvest and Folklore Festival Day in Queens, he was greeted warmly and serenaded by a group of Korean children.
''Last week in City Hall a lot of Koreans said boo,'' said Heung Ram Park, 25, a student at Queens College. ''Today they welcome him because a lot has happened.''
The decision to mount last week's rally was greeted with hesitation at first, said several advocates who helped organize the event. There was trepidation that the rally's purpose of forging peaceful links to black and other racial and ethnic communities would be misunderstood, they said, especially if they criticized the Mayor.
But the tense standoff each day between the boycotters and the owners of the Family Red Apple store and the Church Avenue Fruits and Vegetables store in the Flatbush section had pushed many Koreans to the limit.
The boycott began in January after a Haitian-American customer said she had been assaulted by an employee of Family Red Apple. The store owners said the customer had refused to pay for groceries. When a crowd intervened on the customer's behalf, the employee sought refuge across the street at Church Avenue Fruits and Vegetables.
Korean-Americans were incensed that the city had opposed a judge's restraining order that would have placed the demonstrators 50 feet from the boycotted stores.
The tension grew over the weekend when 19 gasoline bombs were discovered on the roof of the Family Red Apple store, The police yesterday had made no arrests in the case.
Estimates of the city's Korean population vary widely, from the New York City Planning Department's figure of 40,000 to the 250,000 cited by several Korean trade and civic associations. The community is relatively new to this country, dating back two decades, and it is composed heavily of young adults and the middle-aged, whose participation in politics is hampered because they often are not registered to vote, have limited fluency in English and lack familiarity with American ways.
Still, Korean groups have participated in the give-and-take of the city's political scene by endorsing Jesse Jackson in the 1988 Presidential election and raising money and distributing literature during the last mayoral campaign. They have even elected a Korean woman to a seat on the board of Community School District 25 in Flushing, Queens, where many Koreans live.
 
A Force to Reckon With
Korean-Americans do not appear to be wedded as a group to either of the major political parties. ''They're not necessarily all Democrats,'' said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, a Democrat who represents sections of western Queens where many Koreans live. ''They're pretty evenly split between the Republicans and the Democrats.''
Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, in an interview three days after the Korean rally, said: ''I don't think you can count out any constituency as a political force in this town. There seems to be a rising political consciousness in relation to electoral politics in the Korean community.''
The strife in Brooklyn has helped heighten that awareness and unify a community that had been too caught up with looking out for the narrower interests of various business associations.
''The many organizations were like separate islands,'' said Hanyoung Lee, 55, who was elected to the Flushing school board last year. ''But now we have a common issue where we work together.''
Pulling together is an expected result of conflicts involving small ethnic businesses, especially in an ethnically diverse city like New York, said Pyong Min, an assistant professor of sociology at Queens College who has researched how such businesses foster ethnic solidarity.
 
Only the Beginning
Mr. Min said that past boycotts against Korean businesses had strengthened the community's sense of solidarity but that the intensity and duration of the current conflict had had an even greater unifying effect.
''This is the beginning,'' he said of the recent City Hall rally. ''They learned they can do it, and in the future they will stand upon that collective mobilization more often.''
The boycott had already spurred Mr. Min and several other Koreans to form the Korean-American Civil Rights Committee of the Korean Association of New York. The group intends to advocate Korean interests, not just in matters relating to businesses and the current boycott, but also discrimination and voter registration. He added that the group planned to lobby at state and city levels.
Before they can have a real impact on the city's political scene and begin electing their own candidates, Korean-Americans will have to broaden the issues that concern them, said Sung Soo Kim, a self-styled ombudsman for Korean business owners and founder of the Korean-American Small Business Service Center of New York.
''We have to educate our people to be aware that politics is daily life,'' Mr. Kim said. ''Concentrating exclusively on the issues that Korean-Americans have is not enough.''
 
Rise of Younger Generation
A number of Korean candidates are said to be waiting in the wings to run for a seat on the expanded City Council after redistricting. But the candidates who may have the best shot could come not from the older leadership but from the ranks of their children.
The younger generation speaks of building coalitions and addressing issues that concern the city's minority communities, and they do so with a native's understanding of how the city's agencies and officials work.
''We are prepared and willing to work with other progressive and liberal groups to make city politics better, more just and fair to everybody,'' Mr. Lee said. ''The Korean-American community of New York is becoming larger and more active, and we deserve more attention and fair representation.''
