HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
New Group to Direct Flow of Crisis Aid

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
President Bush announced today the formation of a steering group of countries to coordinate international economic aid to nations hard hit by oil price increases and other results of the Persian Gulf crisis.
Establishment of the council, the Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group, helps resolve what had been a growing dispute over control of the money.
Washington had been eager to keep as much control as possible, while Japan, Germany, Saudi Arabia and other creditor nations, who have altogether pledged $20 billion in the effort, had sought to have international organizations coordinate the effort.
The President made the announcement in a welcoming speech to delegates from more than 150 countries at the 45th annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which have sweeping responsibilities in the global economic system. #2 Americans to Head Committee Both organizations have endorsed plans to speed billions of dollars to help the countries most seriously affected by the Iraqi invasion through faster disbursement of loans and other measures. That assistance is separate from direct commitments of money from one country to another, which will be coordinated by the new group. 
Although the new steering committee is multinational, both its chairman and deputy chairman will be Americans. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady will head the organization. His deputy is to be an official to be named by the State Department.
The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are also providing major financial support for newly emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and soon may even play a role in restructuring the Soviet economy.
 
Continued Aid for Egypt
As the President was addressing the delegates, one element of the Administration's effort to help hard-hit countries lost ground when the House Appropriations Committee set aside a proposal to forgive Egypt's $6.7 billion military debt, after lawmakers said the plan would die on the House floor.
To buy time for legislators and the Administration to work out a compromise, the committee adopted a temporary waiver that allows Egypt to continue receiving American military aid. Without the waiver, aid would have been cut off because Egypt is a year behind in repaying its military debt.
The President spoke to the bank-fund meeting after seeing President Turgut Ozal of Turkey at the White House. Their talks were dominated by the global response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and Turkey's strategic role in the buildup against Iraq.
 
Aid and Trade for Turkey
The Turkish leader vowed to continue honoring the United Nations trade embargo against Iraq and received assurances of both aid and trade to soften the economic effects.
While there are no immediate plans to send emergency military aid to Turkey, officials familiar with American arms sales said Ankara would probably receive surplus F-4 fighter planes and M-60 tanks from the European inventories of the United States and other NATO countries next year.
Turkey is one of the nations that is to get assistance not only from the bank and the fund but from the individual country donors who have joined the new gulf coordination group.
In his address, the President made reference to ''special invitees'' from the Soviet Union whose ''presence here reminds us all of how events of the past year are producing a new partnership of nations.''
 
A Soviet Application
The two organizations had invited Moscow to take part in an annual meeting for the first time, as a prelude to possible full membership.
Viktor Gerashchenko, chairman of Gosbank, or the State Bank of the Soviet Union, led a 15-person Soviet delegation to the meeting. Members of the group told reporters to expect a Soviet membership application soon.
The World Bank makes long-term loans, largely for projects like dams, irrigation works, harbors, ports and so on. The I.M.F. makes shorter-term loans to help members cover short-term cash shortages. Both organizations impose conditions of economic policy on their assistance.
 
Head of World Bank Speaks
Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the World Bank, and Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, also spoke of the long shadow cast by the gulf crisis on the world economy.
''The crisis in the Middle East has reminded us all that peace is fragile and that economies are always vulnerable,'' Mr. Camdessus said in his opening remarks.
Mr. Conable warned that the crisis could have a ''serious effect'' on the poor. He noted that more than a billion people, half of them in South Asia, still live on less than a dollar a day.
 
Criticism in House
As the World Bank and the I.M.F. met, members of two House subcommittees blamed the Bush Administration for failing to warn thousands of Americans to leave Iraq and Kuwait before they were taken hostage.
Elizabeth M. Tamposi, Assistant Secretary of State for Consular Affairs, said her office did not do more to warn Americans before the invasion because few people anticipated the attack.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, blamed President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for lapses of judgment.
''Certainly, the chances of a loss of life, the dangers, were real enough that some warning could be given, flights averted, people asked to make plans for their own personal safety,'' Mr. Torricelli said. ''The victimization of Americans in Kuwait really began with the failure of judgment in the United States State Department.''
Representative Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, the ranking Republican on the International Operations Subcommittee, expressed bewilderment that the State Department did not update travel advisories already in affect for months warning against terrorism in the Middle East to advise travelers that the Iraqi buildup on the Kuwaiti border might endanger their lives.

GRAPHIC: Photos: President Bush with President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, right, after they met yesterday at the White House. HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Man in the News;
The Exiled Emir: Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 25

 BODY:
One of the first tasks assigned to Iraqi troops when they invaded Kuwait in the early hours of Aug. 2 was to capture or kill Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah, the Emir of Kuwait. Alerted early in the morning about the invasion, the Emir fled in a car to Saudi Arabia, minutes before the first Iraqis soldiers entered the grounds of Dasman Palace.
The Iraqis wanted to consolidate their seizure of Kuwait by capturing and probably killing the estimated 1,200 Sabahs who form the vast clan whose name has been associated with the existence of a Kuwaiti entity since the 18th century.
But many members of the family were vacationing abroad at the time and most of the senior Sabahs in Kuwait, including the Crown Prince, Sheik Saad al-Abdallah al-Salem al-Sabah, slipped away to safety in Saudi Arabia, where they now live in the summer resort town of Taif.
 
In All Major Posts
As Emir since 1978, Sheik Jaber, who is scheduled to meet with President Bush on Saturday, has reigned at the head of this powerful clan, with his brothers, cousins and other relatives controlling all major aspects of government, including security, oil, the economy, information and defense. 
Until his flight to Saudi Arabia, the Emir steered his country through difficult years that included the Iranian revolution in 1979, the Iraq-Iran war from 1980 to 1988 and the spectacular rise and fall of oil revenues in that period.
He refused to yield to Iranian threats, backed by hijackings of Kuwaiti planes and an attempt on his life by pro-Iranian militants, maintaining his financial and moral support of Iraq in its war against Iran. Playing Americans against Russians, Kuwait put its oil tankers under the flag of the two superpowers to discourage Iranian attacks.
Once the war was over, however, the Emir shut the money tap to Iraq. He gambled, wrongly as it turned out, that Kuwait's skillful diplomacy of playing enemies against each other would save his country from Iraqi demands for money and access to the Persian Gulf through Kuwait.
 
Quiet and Aloof
Although most Kuwaitis do not regard their Emir as a brilliant or even exceptional ruler, they do not hold him responsible for any major errors in judgment throughout his rule, and few think he could have done things differently to prevent the invasion by Iraq.
Asked what they thought of him as a person or what they knew about his life, numerous Kuwaitis seemed to have little to say beyond that fact that he had grown quite aloof since becoming Emir.
The 64-year-old Emir received little formal education, being pulled out of school by his father while in fifth grade to be trained in the ways of governing. He continued his formal education with private tutors and is not known to have received any university degrees.
By all accounts he is a quiet man who says little in private meetings, even those with heads of state. A senior American official who met with him in Kuwait for more than two hours in 1987 to discuss security questions surrounding the Iraq-Iran war commented that Sheik Jaber ''hardly said two words the whole time,'' leaving much of the talking to others there.
Associates say he is a practicing Muslim and a hard worker who when in Kuwait rose with the sun to be driven to his seaside office complex on the Persian Gulf shore by 8:30 every morning.
 
Father of More Than 70
Although he stuck firmly by the Koranic law allowing Muslim men to have as many as four wives, he has pushed the edict to its most liberal intepretations, marrying scores of women - perhaps as many as 40 -while divorcing others to keep the number of wives always at four.
He is said to have fathered well over 70 children. His personal wealth, managed by Khalid Abu al-Saud, a Palestinian investment banker, ranks him as one of the world's billionaires, bankers say.
Signs of his aloofness deepened after he was named Crown Prince in 1966 and then Emir in 1978.
He has gradually left day-to-day affairs of state to other senior members of the Sabah family, including Crown Prince Saad, who is Prime Minister, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah, the Emir's brother, who is Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, and Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, a distant cousin, who has served brilliantly as Oil and Finance Minister, moving quickly to control Kuwait's funds abroad after the invasion.
Many older Kuwaitis give their Emir high marks for his early performence as Finance Minister in 1963 and eventually as Prime Minister from 1965.
 
On-the-Job Training
He started his on-the-job training in 1949 as Governor of the vulnerable oil province of Al Ahmadi, where he became particularly mindful of security operations. Most refineries and oil sites in the province have now been mined by Iraqi troops.
The Emir takes credit for adopting, when Finance Minister in the 1960's, a Fund for Future Generations by setting aside part of the country's oil earnings every year for investments abroad. The fund has grown into a huge portfolio of foreign investments estimated today to be worth well over $100 billion, virtually all of it outside Kuwait and away from Iraqi control.
This money, an enormous amount for a country with a native Kuwaiti population of no more than 600,000 people, now constitutes the war chest that largely sustains the Kuwaiti government-in-exile headed by the Emir, who lives in Taif.
Leading Kuwaiti political figures and business people say that while they continue to revere their Emir as the only possible ruler of a liberated Kuwait, he must move quickly after the liberation to reduce the influence of the Sabahs in government, which gained alarmingly in the last decade.
''Sheik Jaber did a splendid job in privatizing the economy and organizing the structure of government in the 60's and 70's,'' said Abdallah Youssef al-Ghanem, a promiment Kuawiti businessman. ''But after liberation the Kuwait we want back must be a democratic country where there is a much clearer sharing of power.''
 
No Free Parliament
After much debate and consultations last year with pro-democracy advocates who agitated for an unconditional return of the Parliament that the Emir abolished in 1986, the family council headed by the Emir refused to allow a free parliament to be elected or to lift press censorship.
Instead, the Emir offered a weak alternative in the form of a National Assembly in which 25 of 75 members were Government-appointed. Most opposition figures boycotted the election to the National Assembly, which opened its sessions in July.
In defending the Emir's decision, supporters say it was impossible for a tiny country like Kuwait, wedged between huge autocratic nations like Iraq, Iran and Saudi Arabia, to carry on with a democratic experience that might provoke those neighbors. ''No ship sailing in the sea of international politics can seclude itself,'' the Emir declared after closing Parliament.
At the moment, the priority for most Kuwaitis is to rally around the Emir until their country is freed from Iraqi control. ''Then we will have something to say about the way the country should be run,'' said Ahmad al-Khatib, a former member of Parliament and a pro-democracy advocate who was in London when the invasion took place.
 
The Emir Before Hussein
Given a choice between their Emir and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, most Kuwaitis have no hesitation in choosing.
''I am not a member of the ruling family, but I can tell you I don't want to go back if the Emir does not go back,'' said Siham Youssef, a Kuwaiti who is working in the Free Kuwait movement in London.
''Even those who disagreed with him have been allowed to do so without having their assets confiscated, being sent to jail or executed,'' she added. ''Can Iraq say the same about the way it treats its citizens?''

HEADLINE: Stakes High in Contest For Alabama Governor

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 25

 BODY:
Senator Howell Heflin put his hands in his pockets, leaned his ample belly into the lectern and gave Lee County Democrats what they came for: a dose of old-time Democratic religion.
Senator Heflin was laying into the Republicans in all their many varieties, including what he calls the ''Grey Poupon element of the Republican Party'' - the ''Gucci-clothed, Mercedes-driving, Jacuzzi-soaking, Perrier-drinking, Aspen-skiing Republicans,'' to be exact.
Mr. Heflin is up for re-election this year but is considered to be so far ahead of his Republican opponent, Bill Cabaniss, that Democrats snicker about it. Most of this partisan fervor is being directed to another state race: the governorship.
Four years ago, after an extraordinarily bitter and divisive primary to choose a successor to George C. Wallace, Democrats lost control of the governor's office here for the first time since 1874. 
They want it back. They hope that Paul Hubbert, a top official with the Alabama Education Association, the state teachers' organization, who won the Democratic nomination last summer in a runoff after a five-way primary, can get it.
 
Determined to Keep Power
For their part, Republicans are determined to prove that Gov. Guy Hunt, a fundamentalist Primitive Baptist preacher and former county probate judge, is no fluke. Control of the governorship can do wonders for Republicans trying to develop a vigorous two-party state.
There is a shortage of independent polls in Alabama at the moment, which has only fed speculation on where the race stands. Democrats insist their polling shows the race to be close and winnable, while Republicans contend they have a comfortable lead.
 
Democrat Has Edge in Money
Recent campaign finance reports showed Mr. Hubbert with an edge in contributions, and his organizational base with teachers, the party apparatus and black political groups is considered formidable. Still, Mr. Hunt, whose rural roots make him decidedly not a ''Grey Poupon Republican,'' has the advantages of incumbency and a certain folksy appeal, many Alabamians say.
''People out there don't have any reason to vote against Hunt,'' said Ken Lamb, communications director for the Alabama Republican Party.
William Barnard, professor of history at the University of Alabama, said he believed Democrats tended to underestimate Mr. Hunt. ''There's a lot of people who see him as a decent man,'' said Mr. Barnard. ''And in some circles, simply not to have the state embarrassed over the past three years is an achievement.''
Mr. Hubbert, who like Mr. Hunt has rural roots, is trying to sell voters on the need for a New South governor, for better leadership on education and economic development to help Alabama catch up with states like Georgia.
At the Lee County Democratic Club dinner in Auburn on Saturday night, Mr. Hubbert gave a quiet, reflective speech.
He talked about picking up the paper that week, reading that Atlanta had been chosen as the site of the 1996 Olympics, and realizing the difference that leadership had made in the fates of Atlanta and Birmingham 30 years ago.
 
Leadership Issue Pressed
''While Birmingham was worried about whether they had enough firehose,'' Mr. Hubbert said, ''Atlanta was negotiating with Delta Airlines.''
Later, in an interview, the Democratic candidate argued, ''We have not had a Lamar Alexander or a Bob Graham or a Bill Clinton, the New South kind of governor who has been able to market this state the way they've been able to market theirs,'' he said, referring to two past and governors of Tennessee and Florida and the current Governor of Arkansas.
Republicans argue that in fact Alabama does have a successful New South governor who happens to be a Republican. Governor Hunt argues in his television spots that things are ''just fine'' in Alabama.
A series of regional commercials hails the plants and projects Mr. Hunt has brought to the state; critics assert the state still has far to go on jobs, per capita income, and a number of other indicators.
 
Criticism of Challenger
There are a number of subplots here. Republicans are trying to cast Mr. Hubbert as a special-interest candidate because of his ties to organized labor and the teachers' organization. ''It's just a question of whether the people of Alabama are prepared to turn the state over to A.E.A., and I believe they're not,'' said Mr. Lamb of the Alabama Republican Party.
Republicans are quick to note that Mr. Hubbert has drawn heavily from teachers in his fund-raising.
Another recent subplot came to light in The Birmingham Post-Herald, which reported that Hunt campaign officials had called in Alabama business leaders and told them not to engage in the time-honored custom of hedging their bets with contributions to both candidates.
''It's having a reverse effect with some business folks,'' said Mr. Hubbert. ''They don't like to be threatened.''
All of the maneuvering attests the high political stakes here. For example, Billy Joe Camp, a longtime Wallace aide and the Democratic nominee for Secretary of State, said: ''You've got a lot of boards and commissions in Alabama. With an eight-year span of appointments, there will be a lot of Republicans in office throughout the state for a long time to come.''
Democrats are beginning to feel the heat; an eight-year fluke would be no fluke at all. So at the Lee County Democratic Club dinner Saturday night, there was lots of talk of unity, of Democrats ''coming home'' and ending their ''backsliding'' ways.
 
THE 1990A CAMPAIGN
 
Alabama Governor: The Record vs. Calls for Change
Scripts and photographs of television commercials from the governor's race.
 
GUY HUNT - Republican
 
BACKGROUND: Governor Hunt is touting his record on economic development and arguing that Alabama is doing, as his commerical puts it, ''just fine.'' The Hunt campaign is also trying to present Mr. Hubbert, a top official with the Alabama Education Association, as a candidate of special interests.
 
SCRIPT: ''For four years he's governed. And under Guy Hunt's leadership, Alabama is doing just fine. The environment is safer. The economy is growing. The drug dealers are finding it tougher to survive. And increasingly, citizens are joining Governor Hunt in the fight to return control of our schools to the people of Alabama. Guy Hunt's working hard for us. And it's paid off. This November re-elect Guy Hunt for governor.''
 
PRODUCER: Ed Blakely, Smith & Harroff Inc., Alexandria, Va.

HEADLINE: Bill to Raise Cars' Fuel Efficiency Dies With Senate Vote on Debate

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The Senate failed by three votes to cut off debate today on a bill that would require car makers to improve fuel efficiency significantly. The vote in effect kills the measure in this session of Congress.
It was the first legislative test of a measure intended to reduce American dependence on foreign oil since the start of the Persian Gulf crisis.
The auto industry and the Bush Administration lobbied heavily against the bill, saying it would do little to clean up the environment and would exact a major financial toll on car makers. 
In a vote of 57 to 42, the Senate rejected a petition that the bill be brought to a vote. Sixty votes were needed to cut off debate. #40 Miles to the Gallon The legislation would require that new cars sold in this country attain a level of fuel use averaging about 40 miles to the gallon by the year 2001. Current law generally requires that auto makers sell cars that get an average of 27.5 miles to the gallon.
Although the plan took on added interest because of the Middle East conflict, it was considered an effort to curb air pollution when it was introduced last year.
The bill's chief sponsor, Senator Richard H. Bryan, said the Senate's action was ''a small and shortsighted victory against our struggle for a real energy conservation policy.'' Although Senate leaders said they did not plan to take up the matter again this year, Mr. Bryan vowed to introduce a similar bill when Congress returns in January.
''Clearly the auto industry mounted a massive campaign against it,'' said Mr. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat. ''They need to ask themselves: What is their answer to every parent in America whose son or daughter is in the Middle East because of our oil dependence? What are they proposing to make us less vulnerable on foreign oil and vulnerable to the potential instability in the Middle East?''
Environmental groups were less restrained in expressing their disappointment. ''Today the gas guzzler won and they're popping the champagne corks in Saddam Hussein's palace,'' said Daniel F. Becker, who heads the Sierra Club's energy and global warming program.
 
'Horrendously Expensive'
But the leading opponent of the bill, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said its passage would place a ''horrendously expensive'' burden on auto makers. He said manufacturers would have no choice but to build smaller cars, which would lead to increased traffic deaths.
''The automobile industry is under a considerable amount of stress these days,'' he said. ''You can't just wave a wand and impose massive costs on a major part of the economy without weighing the implications very carefully.'' He disputed Mr. Bryan's contention that the bill was a step toward developing a national energy plan and called the plan ''a piecemeal strategy.''
The bill's backers said the auto makers could meet the new fuel-use standards by altering the design of the engine combustion system to stress fuel efficiency over power or by reducing the size of the vehicles. But manufacturers argued that the proposed new standards were unrealistic and that the technology needed to meet the requirements could not be developed quickly enough to comply with the law.
Even if the bill had not been stopped in the Senate, its prospects were not strong. In the House, it probably would have had difficulty getting past the Energy and Commerce Committee, headed by Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who is a staunch backer of the auto industry.
 
Administration Opposed It
And Administration officials lobbied vigorously against the bill, threatening a Presidential veto.
''We do not believe that recent events in Kuwait should cause us to rush ahead with ill-considered policies,'' Samuel K. Skinner, the Secretary of Transportation, and James D. Watkins, the Secretary of Energy, asserted in a recent letter to the Senator majority leader, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine. They said their overriding concern was that highway safety would be compromised.
The heavy lobbying campaign appeared to pay off. In the first test of the proposal last month, the Senate voted 68 to 28 to limit debate - 11 votes more than today.
Besides raising the fuel-use standards, the bill would double penalties for repeated violations of the standards; provide a fuel economy credit for makers of small passenger cars that are equipped with airbags, and require reports to Congress on the accuracy of tests of vehicle fuel economy.

HEADLINE: Swift and Wide Impact Is Expected If Negotiations on U.S. Budget Fail

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
From the control towers overlooking the nation's airports to the guard towers overlooking its prisons, thousands of Federal workers could be laid off on Monday if the Government cannot quickly resolve its budget crisis.
The Federal Aviation Administration and the Bureau of Prisons are just two of the agencies planning to furlough employees unless negotiations between Congress and the Bush Administration produce an agreement on spending, taxes and the deficit by the beginning of the fiscal year on Monday.
Although sweeping automatic spending cuts have been imposed before, they have never been as deep as those that might take effect next week. Congressional negotiators have been meeting with White House officials for weeks and talks continued late tonight, but if these efforts fail, the automatic cuts would be felt immediately across the country.
 
Stakes if Talks Fail
For example, air travelers would face delays and cancellations that would escalate day by day as thousands of airline flights were canceled because of a shortage of air traffic controllers. Within weeks, fresh meat could become scarce in supermarkets, the accuracy of weather forecasts might deteriorate and lines would probably grow longer and longer at offices where citizens go for such routine tasks as obtaining a new Social Security number. 
But as dozens of agencies draw up detailed plans for this possible havoc, few Government officials claim to know today exactly what to expect.
The Federal Aviation Administration, for example, has agreed with airlines to phase in disruptions to flight schedules over the first few days, avoiding instantaneous gridlock on Monday morning, but the airlines still call the plan unworkable.
The National Weather Service, which at one point envisioned immediately canceling nighttime weather reports and thereby grounding all flights at night, is now forecasting no disruptions to its programs for the next two weeks. That could be managed by paying workers with about $1 million left over from this year's budget. But the White House's Office of Management and Budget has not yet approved this fiscal maneuver.
 
Impact of Layoffs
Some Government programs are exempt from cuts. They include Social Security benefit payments, pay for the uniformed military, medical assistance and Congressional salaries. Even so, the layoffs of Federal workers would be widely felt.
The National Park Service is drawing up plans to cushion the effects in the field by cutting heavily at headquarters, but the cuts would ruin some vacations, said George Berklacy, assistant to the director. Yellowstone, like many other wilderness parks, would close campsites and visitor centers, and the Government would miss collecting fees from visitors to the park. The Statue of Liberty, like many other monuments, would be closed on Mondays and Tuesdays and would accept only half the usual 20,000 visitors on other days, at a financial loss to the private companies that operate ferries and other services there.
If the emergency measures were to last an entire year, something nobody expects, Government agencies would be seriously crippled. According to the Office of Management and Budget, over the course of the year F.B.I. investigations of organized crime groups would be cut 20 percent, there would be 27,400 fewer inspections of mines by occupational safety experts and the Internal Revenue Service would fail to collect $8.5 billion in taxes.
 
Effects on New York
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, said today that a yearlong cut of this sort would be ''a disaster'' for New York City. ''We would lose a tremendous amount of Federal aid in areas in which the city can least afford it: mass transit, education, housing and other social services,'' Mr. Schumer said. He estimated the cost to the city of the budget cuts over the course of a year at more than $715 million. The entire Federal budget would be cut by $85.4 billion, with only a few agencies spared.
But officials say they believe that an immediate outcry over the initial disruptions would force politicians to enact a budget that distributes the nation's fiscal burdens more rationally.
Automatic spending cuts have been imposed three times before under the Federal deficit-reduction law, at the start of the fiscal years 1986, 1988 and 1990, but the 1988 order was rescinded and in the other two instances the cuts were small and of short duration. The 1990 cuts, for example, in the end amounted to only about 1.5 percent, a far cry from the current situation.
 
Budget Cuts of 32%
As the Oct. 1 deadline approaches, Federal agencies are planning for furloughs on the assumption that they must cut their annual budgets by 32 percent, beginning immediately.
At most agencies, cuts of that magnitude cannot be achieved without laying off workers. Rather than dismissing much of the work force, agencies are directing employees to take a few days off without pay in each pay period.
At the aviation agency, for example, furloughs would affect every employee for two and a half days in each 10-day pay period. With one-fourth fewer controllers at work each day, the agency says it must cancel up to 3,000 flights daily to ensure safety in the skies.
At the busiest times of day, under the plan devised by the F.A.A., airlines would have to cancel about one-third of all flights landing and taking off from major airports.
For example, at New York's La Guardia Airport, on a weekday at 4 P.M., only 24 of the 43 scheduled landings could occur. At the peak departure time, which is 7 A.M., only 24 flights could take off when 40 normally leave.
After the plan was presented to airlines last week, Robert Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association, dashed off a letter to F.A.A. Administrator James B. Busey calling it ''totally unacceptable,'' ''basically unworkable,'' and ''a scheduling impossibility.'' Among other changes, the airlines asked the agency to control takeoffs but to leave landings unrestricted, simplifying their scheduling problems.
This week, the situation grew even more confused, as the National Weather Service told airlines that it planned to close weather stations from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. Without the weather forecasts, no planes could land or take off during the night, rendering the F.A.A.'s elaborate schedules meaningless.
Reed Boatright, a spokesman for the weather service, said today that its own officials ''didn't get the word'' about a change in plans that would delay any such disruption to weather services. But he admitted that the agency had not yet won approval from the White House to exempt itself temporarily from the budget cuts.
At the Food Safety and Inspection Service, the branch of the Agriculture Department that inspects meat products during processing, managers have drawn up contingency plans for furloughing about 7,500 inspectors for four days on Oct. 9.The whole industry, with an estimated 7,000 plants employing upward of 300,000 workers, would be shut down simultaneously if the furloughs occurred.
 
Cutbacks at Prisons
Out of the public eye, Federal prisons across the nation are also bracing for a one-third reduction in normal staffing. Each penitentiary is drawing up its own plans, which vary depending on whether the prison keeps inmates under maximum security.
''Just because the staff is working only two-thirds time doesn't mean you can serve only two meals a day,'' said Steven B. Schwalb, deputy director of the Northeast regional office of the Federal Bureau of Prisons. ''An education department might have to be closed to have the education staff go do rudimentary parts of the food service.''
The biggest problem facing prison managers, several officials said, is balancing the need for security against the need for supervised recreation. Almost all prison employees are trained to stand guard duty, but using them that way will cut into other services for inmates. As inmates' routines are disrupted, Mr. Schwalb said, ''the tension level among them is going to rise.''
''It's a scary situation,'' said Michael Grotefend, president of the prison employees union, who works at the Federal prison in Oxford, Wis.
''This is another new experience I wish I had never experienced,'' said Mr. Grotefend. ''But we are going to make it through. I just hope nobody gets hurt. That would be too heavy a price to pay for this silly game.''

HEADLINE: The Politics of Anti-Politics

 BODY:
In Massachusetts last week, Republican and Democratic voters rejected established politicians in favor of mavericks who had never held elective office. In Oklahoma, voters repudiated familiar faces and imposed a 12-year limit on the tenure of state legislators.
The September primary election results were fragmentary but the message seems unmistakable: Americans are frustrated and dismayed by the unresponsiveness of their elected leaders. Though that message has been registered at the state and local level, Congress and the White House would be foolish not to listen. 
There's no shortage of explanations for voter discontent, starting with economic fears. Both Massachusetts and Oklahoma are suffering recessions. Cynicism runs a close second. Polls show that at least two-thirds of Americans think government is usually wasteful and that politicians quickly lose touch with their constituents.
The daily headlines from Washington certainly can't help incumbents at any level of government: endless partisan wrangling over the budget deficit . . . the monumental savings and loan scandal that could not have occurred without the complicity of both the executive and legislative branches . . . a Congress that cannot bring itself to clean up a system based on buying and selling influence. Of course, the voters may also be angry with themselves. After all, they enthusiastically endorsed eight years of Reaganism. But if the public wanted less from government 10 years ago, it seems to want more now. Nearly every survey suggests widespread and well-articulated concern about a range of issues: industrial decline, stagnant standard of living, better schools, safer streets, cleaner air.
But people perceive politicians as living in cocoons, inside the beltway or the state house or city halls. The result, as former Vice President Walter Mondale once put it, is a politics of irrelevance and avoidance, yielding few new ideas and no real evidence of political will.
Do the politicians themselves offer any defense? Yes: they blame the voters. If Americans do not believe in the politicians they elect, Michael Oreskes noted in a recent article in The Times, the politicians are terrified of the people who elected them. He quotes Ed Jenkins, Democrat of Georgia: ''We are simply afraid to make any difficult decisions. We're afraid we'll make someone mad at us.''
Yet what voters seem to resent most is inertia. What they seem to want most is ingenuity and courage. For nervous incumbents, some risk-taking might be in order. It might win them respect, and perhaps even re-election.

HEADLINE: Divorce Case Quandary: Is Fame Property?

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
It sounds like something out of an opera plot. In Act I, a mezzo-soprano on the cusp of celebrity marries an aspiring bass-baritone she meets in music school. In Act II, she becomes an internationally renowned star; he acts as her photographer, adviser, voice teacher and companion on the Bois de Boulogne.
But in Act III, which takes place many years and two children later, their marriage comes apart. And as for the final scene, it remains to be written. The libretto now rests with the courts, which must answer whether or not a performer's enhanced celebrity status is ''marital property,'' and therefore must be quantified and divided when a marriage is dissolved. 
The setting for the drama is State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The principal players are Frederica von Stade, the opera star; her husband of 17 years, Peter Elkus; two lawyers, Raoul Lionel Felder and Alfred Ferrer 3d, and Justice Walter M. Schackman, who yesterday handed down the first of what will likely be several decisions in an evolving area of the law.
In his decision, handed down a day after the couple's divorce, Justice Schackman rejected Mr. Elkus's claim that having aided Ms. von Stade in her rise to stardom, he was entitled under New York's equitable distribution law to a chunk of her star value.
The ruling comes in the latest, and perhaps the most glamorous, in a series of cases in which New York courts have wrestled with precisely what contributions during marriage are compensible at the time of divorce.
Mr. Felder, who is representing Ms. von Stade, hailed the decision. ''For the first time a court has drawn the line in the sand. There is a limit to what is possible under equitable distribution,'' he said. ''And that limit is drawn when one seeks to obtain a portion of someone's God-given talent or recognition. Who knows what a career is worth? And where do you stop? How about the shoeshine man and the plumber?''
 
An Economic Partnership
Mr. Ferrer said he planned to appeal the decision, which, he said, favored spouses of doctors and lawyers over spouses of artists and other ''nonprofessionals.''
''A marriage is an economic partnership, regardless of what business activities each of the spouses engages in,'' he said.
All documents in the case are under seal. In the opinion, the 45-year-old Ms. von Stade is referred to only as ''F. Elkus,'' though Justice Schackman notes that she has become ''quite well known over the last few years'' and has performed on two recent occasions for President Bush. Neither she nor Mr. Elkus, 50, was available for comment. But according to the decision, Mr. Elkus had hoped to introduce expert testimony as to the value of Ms. von Stade's career at trial. Conversely, Ms. von Stade disputed what Justice Schackman referred to as ''the nature and value'' of her former husband's ''alleged contributions.''
Five years ago, in the landmark case of O'Brien v. O'Brien, New York's highest court ruled that a wife who had deferred her own career to send her husband to medical school effectively owned part of his medical licence. Since then, trial courts have found that degrees in law, accounting, and other academic disciplines, as well as teaching certificates, are also marital assets.
 
Acting as Property
In two others cases, it has extended that principle to celebrity status. Mr. Ferrar cited one of them, a 1988 divorce case involving the actress Marisa Berenson and A. Richard Golub, the lawyer. In it, the court held that the increased value of Ms. Berenson's acting and modeling career were in fact marital property, even though no license or degree was involved.
''The courts should treat all matrimonial litigants equally,'' the court stated. ''The noncelebrity spouse should be entitled to a share of the celebrity spouse's fame - limited, of course by the degree to which that fame is attributable to the noncelebrity spouse.''
Justice Schackman disputed the applicability of the O'Brien case, in which a husband sued to end his nine-and-a-half year marriage three months after receiving a medical degree paid for largely through the sacrifices of his wife. He noted that Ms. von Stade and Mr. Elkus had been married longer, and that Mr. Elkus had remained working in music, his chosen field.
He further noted that Mr. Elkus had enjoyed ''a substantial life style'' from Ms. von Stade's earnings and stood to benefit from the sale of their house, worth close to $1 million and other assets accumulated during the marriage. Having ''reaped the rewards of his association'' with Ms. Von Stade, Justice Schackman wrote, Mr. Elkus ''can hardly be equated with the discarded spouse in O'Brien.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frederica von Stade, whose divorce case poses the question of whether a performer's celebrity status is ''marital property.'' (Steve J. Sherman)

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Papal Document on Education Hailed For Support of Academic Freedom

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
Pope John Paul II issued a long-awaited document on Roman Catholic higher education yesterday, and many Catholic educators promptly expressed satisfaction and relief at the degree to which the Pope recognized the legitimacy of autonomy and academic freedom for their institutions.
The Apostolic Constitution on Catholic Universities, issued in the Vatican, strongly enjoined Catholic colleges and universities to maintain their religious character and fidelity to Catholic teachings.
But the document did not adopt some of the more stringent provisions of earlier drafts, which had appeared to inject the Vatican authorities and local bishops directly into university affairs.
''This is a totally different, much more positive and progressive document than the drafts produced in 1985 and 1988,'' said the Rev. J. Donald Monan, president of Boston College. ''The document itself and the process by which it was written are major reasons for satisfaction.'' 
 
Academic Freedom Stressed
At a major consultation with Vatican officials in April 1989, Catholic educators warned that assigning responsibility for upholding their institutions' Catholic identity to the church authorities outside university ranks could violate academic freedom and possibly jeopardize government financing.
Several educators involved in that meeting called it a turning point.
''We made the point that universities, to be universities, had to have the proper kind of autonomy and academic freedom,'' said the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, president of Fordham University in New York. ''It also came through loud and clear that universities all around the world were concerned about not having universal prescriptons from Rome.''
About one in seven private universities and colleges in the United States are affected by the papal document; 230 of the 1,620 such institutions in this country are Catholic. That is by far the largest number of Catholic institutions of higher education in a single country. The next highest is the Philippines, with 20, according to the Vatican, which says there are 935 Catholic institutions of higher education throughout the world.
 
A Brief Set of Guidelines
Despite the Vatican's apprehension about theologians who question Catholic teachings or student groups who advocate homosexual or abortion rights, the Apostolic Constitution issued yesterday includes only a brief set of guidelines, called general norms, and permits them to be tailored to local conditions by national bishops' conferences and university officials.
Sister Janet Fitzgerald, president of Molloy College in Rockville Centre, L.I., who attended the April 1989 gathering at the Vatican, said much of the wording emerged directly from that session.
But the document still contains several potentially explosive strictures. It called on Catholic institutions of higher education and especially Catholic theologians on their faculties to adhere to church doctrine, but left unresolved how such requirements were to be interpreted or enforced.
The papal document also contains a requirement, not present in any earlier version, that the majority of teachers at all Catholic institutions of higher education be Catholic. Although it is widely thought that a majority of faculty members at most Catholic colleges and universities are Catholic, many schools do not request any religious identification in hiring.
 
'Statistical Standard' Questioned
Several Catholic educators said the requirement would have to be adjusted to American practices.
The general norm reflected a valid concern ''that recruitment of personnel is critical to the character of an institution,'' Father O'Hare said, ''but trying to assure that through a statistical standard, at least in the United States, is not effective.''
Like several other university presidents, he said non-Catholic faculty members often made a greater contribution to maintaining their schools' Catholic character than did some Catholic faculty members.
In Rome, Archbishop Pio Laghi said yesterday that a Catholic majority might be a goal, but was clearly impossible for Catholic schools like Sophia University in Tokyo, for example, because of the small number of Catholics in a particular population.
The Archbishop, a former papal Ambassador to the United States who is now head of the Vatican's Congregation for Catholic Education, presented the Apostolic Constitution at a news conference yesterday.
 
Governance by Lay Trustees
Some Catholic universities have been founded or directly governed by the papacy, by national bodies of bishops or by individual dioceses. But many, particularly in the United States, were founded by religious orders and operated independently of local bishops, although usually with their approval.
In recent years many Catholic schools have transferred governance to lay boards of trustees. While retaining theology departments, religious guidance for those seeking it and varying degrees of interest in Catholic culture, many schools have dropped strict obligations on students or faculty to study Catholicism or to participate in religious exercises.
Catholic educators have acknowledged that these steps, sometimes taken so that the schools can qualify for state funds, have shown a tension between keeping a distinct religious identity for their schools and joining the mainstream of American higher education.
Much of the papal document urges Catholic universities and colleges to overcome the fragmentation of knowledge by academic specialties, to inject ethical reflection into professional training and to foster exchange between religious and scientific scholarship.
 
Needs of 'Emerging Nations'
The Pope also called on these schools to examine ''contemporary problems in areas such as the dignity of human life, the promotion of justice for all, the quality of personal and family life, the protection of nature, the search for peace and political stability, a more just sharing of the world's resources and a new economic and political order that will better serve the human community.''
Catholic universities should especially strive to make education accessible to the poor and to minorities, the Pope said, and to direct attention to the needs of ''the emerging nations.''
The document should be put ''in the context of America's wider debate about the role of the university in general,'' said the Rev. Charles Hagan, a staff member dealing with higher education for the American bishops' conference.
''The document comes down on the side of the university as an instrument for dialogue with the culture and for raising questions about meaning,'' Father Hagan said, ''not just as a place for learning practical skills.'' In that view, he added, ''theology is a key discipline.''
 
Intervention Seen as Limited
Although the papal document calls on local bishops to insure that Catholic universities and colleges act in accord with their religious identity, the educators interviewed by telephone yesterday agreed that intervention by the church authorities would remain limited because of the tenure rights of professors or other established patterns of academic freedom.
''There still are some ambiguities that will have to be worked out,'' Father Monan said. But he added that the document does not authorize the Vatican or a local bishop to remove a Catholic theologian who challenged official church teaching in the way the Rev. Charles E. Currran was banned from teaching theology at Catholic University last year.
The Rev. James W. Sauve, who worked on the document for several years at the Vatican's Congregation for Catholic Education, agreed. Father Sauve, now vice president of the Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities, noted that the Vatican acted against Father Curran on the basis of another document governing theology departments, like Catholic University's, that offer special Vatican-accredited degrees.
''The effort bore fruit,'' said the Rev. Edward Malloy, president of the University of Notre Dame, who was deeply involved in the discussions between educators and the Vatican. ''It is a reminder that when the church develops a good process of consulation, the final result is far superior.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Rev. Edward Malloy, President of University of Notre Dame: ''The effort bore fruit. O'Hare, President of Fordham University: ''We made the point that universities, to be universities, had to have the proper kind of autonomy and academic freedom.'' (G. Steve Jordan)

PUB-DATE: September 26, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 3; Living Desk

LENGTH: 1513 words

HEADLINE: In the New Home Ec, Choices for Life

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
EVERY day more than 3 million teen-agers take their seats in home economics classes across the United States. Many of their classrooms, unchanged since the 1950's, look like shabby sanctuaries of June and Ward Cleaver's home. Rows of battered sewing machines and files of well-used clothing patterns seem ready to train yet another generation of resourceful homebodies. The trim kitchenettes seem to promise an unchanging tide of well-balanced, matter-of-fact meals.
But between the McCall's and Simplicity patterns on the wall in the sewing classroom of Intermediate School 318 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn was a poster picturing a crashed car and the words ''Crack: Is It Worth the Trip?'' Across the hall, in the cooking classroom, there were no familiar posters picturing the ''four food groups.'' Instead, there was a sign that said, ''Being Healthy Is Building a Positive Self-Concept.''
What the New Math was to the 60's, the New Home Ec is to the 90's. Around the country, the courses are called ''Human Environmental Science,'' ''Family Life Management,'' and other serious-sounding euphemisms. But they share common cause. 
''We are seeking to empower families to function effectively and maintain meaningful lives in a very confusing world,'' said Dr. Beverly J. Crabtree, Dean of the College of Family and Consumer Sciences at Iowa State University.
Just as the New Math didn't exactly teach the multiplication tables, the New Home Ec doesn't necessarily teach tidy blind-stitching or perfect egg poaching. ''I teach students how to decide if they want an egg, is an egg the best choice for their family's nutrition, the best use of their family's resources, the best use of their own time,'' said Alma Ortiz of Intermediate School 318. ''The actual cooking is a way of getting students involved in making their own decision.''
''Decisions, decisions, decisions,'' said Jehova Delgada, a 13-year-old student. ''When do we cook?''
''After you've decided what to cook,'' Ms. Ortiz said, ''and you can explain to me why you want to cook it.''
The theoretical approach to home economics began replacing the time-honored practical approach in a handful of states about three years ago. Already, it has been blamed for everything from the increase of food-borne illnesses to the demise of the family dinner. But like the theoreticians who tried to prepare a generation of math students for computer-age thinking, home economists believe they are responding to a nation of decentralized families.
''Two out of three meals are eaten away from home; everybody works,'' said Jewell Deene Ellis, director of Home Economics Education for the Kentucky Department of Education. ''At the basic level, we teach students how to manage consumer information and make their best decisions. At the advanced levels, we try to train professionals for work in family eating environments away from home, in child care and in geriatric care.''
Accommodating a shift from the home to the marketplace is nothing new to home economists. In 1917, when the Smith-Hughs Act established vocational education in American public schools, the traditional ''domestic arts'' of textile- and garment-making had largely moved out of homes into factories.
''The theme of woman's kingdom slowly slipping away from her, of men appropriating woman's work and removing it to the industrial world outside the home, was a recurring one,'' wrote Laura Shapiro in ''Perfection Salad,'' (Farrar Straus & Giroux, 1986), a social history of home economics at the turn of the century. In response, schools offered domestic arts courses that focused fiercely on what remained: cooking.
And lest the field suffer another loss to the industrial sector, its practitioners relinquished the moniker and the attitude of ''domestic arts'' and fortified themselves with the more scientific ''home economics.'' Their approach has endured for most of the century, from when cooking was still done over wood-burning stoves to the introduction of the microwave oven.
Like so many good little wives, home economists responded to the needs of society as staunchly as if those needs were the man of the house. During the Depression they preached canning, preserving and cooking on a budget. During the 1950's, they became the handmaidens of convenience.
''Hands-on work was practical at one point in history,'' said Karl Weddel, executive director of the American Home Economics Association, based in Alexandria, Va. ''Learning how to purchase and employ convenience products is more practical for the modern world.''
Consumer orientation assures a professional niche for the home economist, something that is increasingly important. ''For the past 15 years, I've asked my students how many planned to use their skills outside the home and every year more and more raise their hands,'' said Dr. Crabtree of Iowa State. ''Few have the luxury of staying home.''
In response, and in accord with society, the field became ''a group of specializations over the past three decades,'' Mr. Weddle said. In recent interviews, several dozen home economists were quick to identify themselves by specialty. One was an ''apparel manager,'' another a ''family resource manager,'' a third was a ''nutrition and dietary manager.'' Others specialized in housing, geriatric care, childcare and ''family wellness management.''
''Science'' and ''economics'' have now gone the way of ''arts.'' Domestic life now requires ''management.'' ''Look at the pressures facing American families and tell me proper management won't help,'' Dr. Crabtree said. ''There are two working parents, teen-age pregnancy, single parenting, drugs, homelessness and an aging population with nobody to care for it. Our mission hasn't changed; the world changed.''
And home cooking has become a luxury. The hand that feeds today's world is increasingly a fast, cheap, commercial one. The family meal, the historic underpinning of home economics, has left home. And graduate-level ''family life managers'' have responded by designing a secondary school curriculum that uses cooking (and sewing) as merely a metier for teaching students the decision-making and information-processing skills mandated by the changing world.
But for the secondary school students who reported to the courses two weeks ago, the allure is as unchanged as the look of the classrooms.
''When are we going to start cooking?'' asked Cynthia Rosaria, a 13-year-old student in the Food and Nutrition class at Intermediate School 318. After the 20-member class has learned sanitation, kitchen safety, tool identification and measurements, replied her teacher, Ms. Ortiz.
Pacing between the classroom's six kitchenettes and the card tables where her students are scribbling notes, she primed students for a world that might have shocked homemakers of yore. ''If you have cuts or sores on your hands, you are going to wear clear plastic gloves when handling food like bread dough,'' she said. ''Why?'' ''Germs,'' answered Jehova Delgado. ''Bacteria and viruses,'' said the teacher. ''And when you start cooking next week, you are going to leave these kitchens cleaner than a hospital. Why?'' ''Pests and rodents,'' chorused the students. ''That's right. And Mom's not home and the maid died. So you are going to clean up here and at home. Get it?''
As in most secondary-school classes nowadays, Ms. Ortiz's class is nearly an even mixture of young men and women. The American Home Economics Association estimates that 20 percent of public-school students study home economics and, while the programs have become elective, rather that required, in most states over the last two decades, the percentage has remained unchanged. According to Mr. Weddel, at least two states, New York and Virginia, have reinstated the requirement for home economics study in the last two years.
''They saw that they'd lost a critical component of secondary education,'' he said. And it wasn't simply the preparation of workers for family care at large that was lost.
''It was the surrogate parent,'' Ms. Ortiz said. ''What do you think I do all day?''
Waving toward a flow chart of the decision-making process, she addresses her class: ''You identify the problem. You examine your choices. You make a choice. You act on your choice. Get it? You have a choice!''
Jehova Delgado, who said that he planned to be a lawyer but had enrolled in the class because he wanted to learn to make hamburgers, looked surprised. So did Cynthia Rosaria, who plans a career in science, but wants to be able to ''cook nice meals on the weekends.''
''Next week you are going to make muffins,'' Ms. Ortiz told them. ''I am going to give you three choices and you are going to decide. Do you want cranberry, blueberry or corn? You have a choice. Just like when you go to a party and your friend wants you to smoke crack, right?
''You have a choice.'' And then she leaned toward her students and softly sounded a timeless parental refrain: ''If somebody had told me that, it would have saved me a lot of grief.''
